fields.content: Biotechnology is the application of genetic engineering where DNA and genetic materials are manipulated for some purpose. The DNA created from this application of engineering comes from various organisms  and is termed recombinant DNA. An example of this would be manipulating bacterial DNA to get it to produce insulin needed for diabetes patients.
fields.title: Biotechnology Overview

fields.content: The common method used to manipulate DNA is through special bacterial DNA called plasmids. Plasmids are small circular pieces of DNA that bacteria have in them floating around. Their use consists of pulling these plasmids out of the bacteria cells, inserting desired genes into them, and then reinserting them into the bacteria so that they may replicate and become recombinant DNA. Furthermore, once the modified bacteria cell reproduces, more and more cells will have the capabilities of the original engineered bacteria cell.The key part of the creation of recombinant DNA is how exactly the DNA is inserted. Special enzymes called restriction enzymes are used to cut the plasmid to open it up. Restriction enzymes are very specialized and are only able to cut at specialized nucleotide sequences. These specialized sequences are called restriction sites. When a cut is made at a restriction site, two possible openings are created. One opening is called a sticky end and only occurs if the cut occurs ina staggered way. The other opening is called a blunt end; this cut occurs straight through. ***Note- only sticky ends can fit with other sticky ends; the same goes for blunt ends. For sticky ends, it really depends on the orientation of the cut to see if two fragments will fit.  Finally, DNA ligase is used to seal the fragments together.
fields.title: Bacteria: The Key to Manipulating Dna

fields.content: There are several procedures used in biotechnology labs to harness the power of DNA cloning and recombination. The following includes important procedures or terms that are frequently used in genetic engineering:genomic library: many times a large database of DNA is kept for reference and frequent use. A genomic library holds hundreds of plasmids, each one recombined with some inserted DNA from restriction enzymes. complimentary DNA: this is DNA produced from mRNA through the use of reverse transcriptase, and enzyme that turns mRNA into DNAcDNA library: a genomic library of cDNA****Procedures...nucleic acid hybridization: this is used to help find a gene of interest within a genomic library. Here, a nucleic acid probe, that has the complimentary sequences to the desired DNA segment, is radioactively labeled, so that it will glow. The cell under inspection will then be treated with heat to break open the cell and denature the DNA. Then, the probe can search and hybridize to the correct complimentary DNA fragment and glow. Thus the desired gene is found. Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR): a common way to amplify DNA, meaning the quantity of a desired piece of DNA is created. This is a quick way to produce massive quantities of DNA. The gene of interest is added to a soluton of primers, heat-resistant DNA polymerase, and four nucleotides. The solution is then heated to open up the DNA, then cooled so the primers can H-bond to the complimentary code. Finally, the polymerase is added and it builds the complimentary sequence and attaches them to the 3' end of the primers. This short procedure is repeated many many times to amplify the DNA.gel electrophoresis: a lab procedure that separates nucleic acids, DNA fragments, and proteins according to their size and charge. Remember, size is inversely proportional to distance traveled, so shorter fragments go farther in the gel. The whole apparatus used is based on an electric current driven through the gel. Since the DNA is negatively charged because of their phosphate groups, they move away from the negative side and toward the positive side.Southern blotting: a technique that combines gel electrophoresis and nucleic acid hybridization where fragments travel in gell and hen are transferred to another testing area, usually nitrocellulose paper where the desired gene is found through bonding with a complimentary strand that radioactively glows.

fields.content: We can start to apply what we learned in calculus so far to real life situations through optimization. We look for maximum or minimum values for a function that satisfies a constrain that has to be true no matter what. In a lot of these problems, there is a pattern on how to solve them. These steps are seen belowIdentify the constraint and the value to be optimizedRearrange the constraint equation to solve for one of the variablesPlug this into the equation that needs to be optimizedDifferentiate this equation and set it equal to 0Solve for the values that make it equal to 0Choose the value that is the maximum or minimum that we are looking forSolve for the other variablesex.) A gardener has 300 feet of fencing to enclose three equal sized rectangular garden plots. What dimensions x and y will maximize the total area?The constraint equation is and the optimization equation is .We can rearrange the constraint equation to solve for yPlug y into the optimization equation to get Differentiate this to get and set it equal to 0 to get So Plugging this into , we get which means Therefore our optimal dimensions are and

fields.content:
We call a point at a critical point of a function if exists and if

1.

OR

2. does not exist

Finding Critical Points

Ex.) Find all the critical points on the function
  • To find the critical points we have to first find the derivative of <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(x)}"/>
  • This comes out to be <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}"/>
  • This can be rewritten as <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=(3x-3)(2x+4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=(3x-3)(2x+4)}"/>
  • Critical points occur when <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/> so we set <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)}"/> equal to 0 which gives us <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=(3x-3)(2x+4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=(3x-3)(2x+4)}"/>
  • This means there are critical points at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x= 1}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=&space;1}"/> and at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/>
  • Critical points also occur where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)}"/> does not exist, but there are no points on the function <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}"/> where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)}"/> does not exist

fields.title: Critical Points

fields.content:
Increasing and Decreasing Functions

  • If for every x on some interval, is increasing on that interval
  • If for every x on some interval, is decreasing on that interval
  • If for every x on some interval, is constant on that interval

This is all demonstrated by the example function below

Maximums and Minimums

Extrema: What we call maximum and minimum points of a function

Relative (Local) Maximums and Minimums

  • There is a relative (local) maximum at a point if for all x-values around
  • There is a relative (local) minimum at a point if for all x-values around

The First Derivative Test

If a point at is a critical point of ,

is a relative minimum

  • If to the right of and to the left of , then the point at is a relative maximum

is a relative maximum

  • If is the same sign on both sides of , then the point at is neither a relative minimum or relative maximum

is neither a relative minimum or relative maximum

Absolute (Global) Maximums and Minimums

  • There is an absolute (global) maximum at a point if for all x-values between the closed interval
  • There is an absolute (global) minimum at a point if for all x-values between the closed interval

Finding Maximums and Minimums

To find relative maximums and minimums of a function ,

  2. Set the derivative function equal to zero
  3. Solve for the x-values that makes this equation hold true (find the critical points where )

*In the above graph, the local maximums and minimums occur when the tangent line to the graph is perfectly horizontal (slope = 0) which is why we try to find where the derivative equals 0)*

To find absolute maximums and minimums of a function over a closed interval ,
  1. Find the derivative function

  3. Solve for the x-values within the interval that makes this equation hold true (find the critical points where within the interval )
  4. Solve for at these points and then solve for at and
  5. If there are any points on that are defined, but for which does not exist, solve for at these points too
  6. The largest value of from all of these points is the absolute maximum; The smallest value of from all of these points is the absolute minimum

ex.) Find the absolute extrema and relative extrema for the function over the interval .

  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f{}'(x)=2x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f{}'(x)=2x}"/>

Concavity

Concave Down

fields.title: Graphs

fields.content:
We can start to apply what we learned in calculus so far to real life situations through optimization. We look for maximum or minimum values for a function that satisfies a constrain that has to be true no matter what. In a lot of these problems, there is a pattern on how to solve them. These steps are seen below

  1. Identify the constraint and the value to be optimized
  2. Rearrange the constraint equation to solve for one of the variables
  3. Plug this into the equation that needs to be optimized
  4. Differentiate this equation and set it equal to 0
  5. Solve for the values that make it equal to 0
  6. Choose the value that is the maximum or minimum that we are looking for
  7. Solve for the other variables

ex.) A gardener has 300 feet of fencing to enclose three equal sized rectangular garden plots. What dimensions x and y will maximize the total area?

  • The constraint equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/> and the optimization equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total\, \, Area = xy}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;=&space;xy}"/>.
  • We can rearrange the constraint equation to solve for y
  • Plug y into the optimization equation to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total \, \, Area=x\left (75-\frac{x}{2} \right )=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area=x\left&space;(75-\frac{x}{2}&space;\right&space;)=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}"/>
  • Differentiate this to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left (Total \, \, Area \right ){}'(x)=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\left&space;(Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;\right&space;){}'(x)=75-x}"/> and set it equal to 0 to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=75-x}"/>
  • So <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/>
  • Plugging this into <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/>, we get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2(75)+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2(75)+4y=300}"/> which means <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>
  • Therefore our optimal dimensions are <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>

We call a point at a critical point of a function if exists and if

Finding Critical Points

Ex.) Find all the critical points on the function
  • To find the critical points we have to first find the derivative of <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(x)}"/>
  • This comes out to be <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}"/>
  • This can be rewritten as <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=(3x-3)(2x+4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=(3x-3)(2x+4)}"/>
  • Critical points occur when <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/> so we set <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)}"/> equal to 0 which gives us <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=(3x-3)(2x+4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=(3x-3)(2x+4)}"/>
  • This means there are critical points at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x= 1}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=&space;1}"/> and at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/>

  • Therefore the only critical points occur at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x= 1}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=&space;1}"/> and at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/>

  • Critical points occur when <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/>, but there are no points here where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/>. Therefore the only critical points occur where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)}"/> does not exist

fields.title: Critical Points

fields.content:
Increasing and Decreasing Functions

  • If for every x on some interval, is increasing on that interval
  • If for every x on some interval, is decreasing on that interval
  • If for every x on some interval, is constant on that interval

This is all demonstrated by the example function below

Maximums and Minimums

Extrema: What we call maximum and minimum points of a function

Relative (Local) Maximums and Minimums

  • There is a relative (local) maximum at a point if for all x-values around
  • There is a relative (local) minimum at a point if for all x-values around

The First Derivative Test

If a point at is a critical point of ,

  • If <img align="absmiddle" alt="{f}'(x)> 0" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{f}'(x)>&space;0"/> to the right of <img align="absmiddle" alt="x=c" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?x=c"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{f}'(x)< 0" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{f}'(x)<&space;0"/> to the left of <img align="absmiddle" alt="x=c" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?x=c"/>, then the point at <img align="absmiddle" alt="x=c" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?x=c"/> is a relative minimum

is a relative minimum

  • If to the right of and to the left of , then the point at is a relative maximum

is a relative maximum

  • If is the same sign on both sides of , then the point at is neither a relative minimum or relative maximum

is neither a relative minimum or relative maximum

Absolute (Global) Maximums and Minimums

  • There is an absolute (global) maximum at a point if for all x-values between the closed interval
  • There is an absolute (global) minimum at a point if for all x-values between the closed interval

Finding Maximums and Minimums

To find relative maximums and minimums of a function ,

  1. Find the derivative function
  2. Set the derivative function equal to zero
  3. Solve for the x-values that makes this equation hold true (find the critical points where )

*In the above graph, the local maximums and minimums occur when the tangent line to the graph is perfectly horizontal (slope = 0) which is why we try to find where the derivative equals 0)*

To find absolute maximums and minimums of a function over a closed interval ,
  1. Find the derivative function
  2. Set the derivative function equal to zero
  3. Solve for the x-values within the interval that makes this equation hold true (find the critical points where within the interval )
  4. Solve for at these points and then solve for at and
  5. If there are any points on that are defined, but for which does not exist, solve for at these points too
  6. The largest value of from all of these points is the absolute maximum; The smallest value of from all of these points is the absolute minimum

ex.) Find the absolute extrema and relative extrema for the function over the interval .

  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f{}'(x)=2x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f{}'(x)=2x}"/>
  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x=0}"/> so there is a critical point at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=0}"/>
  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(0)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(0)=0}"/>, <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(-2)=4}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(-2)=4}"/>, and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(3)=9}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(3)=9}"/>
  • Therefore there is a relative and absolute minimum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=0}"/> and an absolute maximum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=3}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=3}"/>. There is not a relate maximum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/> since it is just an endpoint

Concavity

Concave Up

  • A curve is concave up if the curve at a point is above the tangent line to the point
  • A curve is concave down if \(f''(x)<0\)

Concave Down

Points of Inflection

If a point at is a critical point of such that ,

fields.title: Graphs

fields.content:
We can start to apply what we learned in calculus so far to real life situations through optimization. We look for maximum or minimum values for a function that satisfies a constrain that has to be true no matter what. In a lot of these problems, there is a pattern on how to solve them. These steps are seen below

  1. Identify the constraint and the value to be optimized
  2. Rearrange the constraint equation to solve for one of the variables
  3. Plug this into the equation that needs to be optimized
  4. Differentiate this equation and set it equal to 0
  5. Solve for the values that make it equal to 0
  6. Choose the value that is the maximum or minimum that we are looking for
  7. Solve for the other variables

ex.) A gardener has 300 feet of fencing to enclose three equal sized rectangular garden plots. What dimensions x and y will maximize the total area?

  • The constraint equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/> and the optimization equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total\, \, Area = xy}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;=&space;xy}"/>.
  • We can rearrange the constraint equation to solve for y
  • Plug y into the optimization equation to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total \, \, Area=x\left (75-\frac{x}{2} \right )=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area=x\left&space;(75-\frac{x}{2}&space;\right&space;)=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}"/>
  • Differentiate this to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left (Total \, \, Area \right ){}'(x)=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\left&space;(Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;\right&space;){}'(x)=75-x}"/> and set it equal to 0 to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=75-x}"/>
  • So <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/>
  • Plugging this into <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/>, we get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2(75)+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2(75)+4y=300}"/> which means <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>
  • Therefore our optimal dimensions are <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>

  • This means there are critical points at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x= 1}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=&space;1}"/> and at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/>

fields.title: Graphs

fields.content:
We can start to apply what we learned in calculus so far to real life situations through optimization. We look for maximum or minimum values for a function that satisfies a constrain that has to be true no matter what. In a lot of these problems, there is a pattern on how to solve them. These steps are seen below

  1. Identify the constraint and the value to be optimized
  2. Rearrange the constraint equation to solve for one of the variables
  3. Plug this into the equation that needs to be optimized
  4. Differentiate this equation and set it equal to 0
  5. Solve for the values that make it equal to 0
  6. Choose the value that is the maximum or minimum that we are looking for
  7. Solve for the other variables

ex.) A gardener has 300 feet of fencing to enclose three equal sized rectangular garden plots. What dimensions x and y will maximize the total area?

  • The constraint equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/> and the optimization equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total\, \, Area = xy}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;=&space;xy}"/>.
  • We can rearrange the constraint equation to solve for y
  • Plug y into the optimization equation to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total \, \, Area=x\left (75-\frac{x}{2} \right )=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area=x\left&space;(75-\frac{x}{2}&space;\right&space;)=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}"/>
  • Differentiate this to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left (Total \, \, Area \right ){}'(x)=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\left&space;(Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;\right&space;){}'(x)=75-x}"/> and set it equal to 0 to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=75-x}"/>
  • So <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/>
  • Plugging this into <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/>, we get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2(75)+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2(75)+4y=300}"/> which means <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>
  • Therefore our optimal dimensions are <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>

We call a point at a critical point of a function if exists and if

OR

Finding Critical Points

Ex.) Find all the critical points on the function
  • To find the critical points we have to first find the derivative of <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(x)}"/>
  • This comes out to be <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}"/>
  • This can be rewritten as <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=(3x-3)(2x+4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=(3x-3)(2x+4)}"/>
  • Critical points occur when <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/> so we set <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)}"/> equal to 0 which gives us <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=(3x-3)(2x+4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=(3x-3)(2x+4)}"/>
  • This means there are critical points at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x= 1}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=&space;1}"/> and at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/>
  • Critical points also occur where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)}"/> does not exist, but there are no points on the function <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}"/> where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)}"/> does not exist
  • Therefore the only critical points occur at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x= 1}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=&space;1}"/> and at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/>
Ex.) Find all the critical points on the function
  • To find the critical points we have to first find the derivative of <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(x)}"/>
  • This comes out to be <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=\frac{1}{(x-4)^{1/2}}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=\frac{1}{(x-4)^{1/2}}}"/>
  • Critical points occur when <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/>, but there are no points here where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/>. Therefore the only critical points occur where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)}"/> does not exist
  • This means that the only critical point occurs at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=4}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=4}"/> because the denominator of <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(4)}"/> equal 0 which makes <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(4)}"/> not exist
fields.title: Critical Points

fields.content:
Increasing and Decreasing Functions

  • If for every x on some interval, is increasing on that interval
  • If for every x on some interval, is decreasing on that interval
  • If for every x on some interval, is constant on that interval

This is all demonstrated by the example function below

Maximums and Minimums

Extrema: What we call maximum and minimum points of a function

Relative (Local) Maximums and Minimums

  • There is a relative (local) maximum at a point if for all x-values around
  • There is a relative (local) minimum at a point if for all x-values around

The First Derivative Test

If a point at is a critical point of ,

  • If <img align="absmiddle" alt="{f}'(x)> 0" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{f}'(x)>&space;0"/> to the right of <img align="absmiddle" alt="x=c" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?x=c"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{f}'(x)< 0" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{f}'(x)<&space;0"/> to the left of <img align="absmiddle" alt="x=c" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?x=c"/>, then the point at <img align="absmiddle" alt="x=c" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?x=c"/> is a relative minimum

is a relative minimum

  • If to the right of and to the left of , then the point at is a relative maximum

is a relative maximum

  • If is the same sign on both sides of , then the point at is neither a relative minimum or relative maximum

is neither a relative minimum or relative maximum

Absolute (Global) Maximums and Minimums

  • There is an absolute (global) maximum at a point if for all x-values between the closed interval
  • There is an absolute (global) minimum at a point if for all x-values between the closed interval

Finding Maximums and Minimums

To find relative maximums and minimums of a function ,

  1. Find the derivative function
  2. Set the derivative function equal to zero
  3. Solve for the x-values that makes this equation hold true (find the critical points where )

*In the above graph, the local maximums and minimums occur when the tangent line to the graph is perfectly horizontal (slope = 0) which is why we try to find where the derivative equals 0)*

To find absolute maximums and minimums of a function over a closed interval ,
  1. Find the derivative function
  2. Set the derivative function equal to zero
  3. Solve for the x-values within the interval that makes this equation hold true (find the critical points where within the interval )
  4. Solve for at these points and then solve for at and
  5. If there are any points on that are defined, but for which does not exist, solve for at these points too
  6. The largest value of from all of these points is the absolute maximum; The smallest value of from all of these points is the absolute minimum

ex.) Find the absolute extrema and relative extrema for the function over the interval .

  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f{}'(x)=2x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f{}'(x)=2x}"/>
  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x=0}"/> so there is a critical point at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=0}"/>
  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(0)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(0)=0}"/>, <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(-2)=4}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(-2)=4}"/>, and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(3)=9}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(3)=9}"/>
  • Therefore there is a relative and absolute minimum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=0}"/> and an absolute maximum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=3}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=3}"/>. There is not a relate maximum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/> since it is just an endpoint

Concavity

Concave Up

  • A curve is concave up if the curve at a point is above the tangent line to the point
  • A curve is concave down if \(f''(x)<0\)

Concave Down

  • A curve is concave down if the curve at a point is below the tangent line to the point

Points of Inflection

Point of Inflection: A point where the curve changes from concave down to concave up or from concave up to concave down

The Second Derivative Test

If a point at is a critical point of such that ,

  • If , then the point at can be a relative maximum, relative minimum, or neither
fields.title: Graphs

fields.content:
We can start to apply what we learned in calculus so far to real life situations through optimization. We look for maximum or minimum values for a function that satisfies a constrain that has to be true no matter what. In a lot of these problems, there is a pattern on how to solve them. These steps are seen below

  1. Identify the constraint and the value to be optimized
  2. Rearrange the constraint equation to solve for one of the variables
  3. Plug this into the equation that needs to be optimized
  4. Differentiate this equation and set it equal to 0
  5. Solve for the values that make it equal to 0
  6. Choose the value that is the maximum or minimum that we are looking for
  7. Solve for the other variables

ex.) A gardener has 300 feet of fencing to enclose three equal sized rectangular garden plots. What dimensions x and y will maximize the total area?

  • The constraint equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/> and the optimization equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total\, \, Area = xy}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;=&space;xy}"/>.
  • We can rearrange the constraint equation to solve for y
  • Plug y into the optimization equation to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total \, \, Area=x\left (75-\frac{x}{2} \right )=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area=x\left&space;(75-\frac{x}{2}&space;\right&space;)=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}"/>
  • Differentiate this to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left (Total \, \, Area \right ){}'(x)=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\left&space;(Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;\right&space;){}'(x)=75-x}"/> and set it equal to 0 to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=75-x}"/>
  • So <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/>
  • Plugging this into <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/>, we get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2(75)+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2(75)+4y=300}"/> which means <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>
  • Therefore our optimal dimensions are <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>

Finding Critical Points

Ex.) Find all the critical points on the function
  • To find the critical points we have to first find the derivative of <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(x)}"/>
  • This comes out to be <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}"/>
  • This can be rewritten as <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=(3x-3)(2x+4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=(3x-3)(2x+4)}"/>
  • Critical points occur when <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/> so we set <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)}"/> equal to 0 which gives us <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=(3x-3)(2x+4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=(3x-3)(2x+4)}"/>
  • This means there are critical points at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x= 1}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=&space;1}"/> and at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/>

Increasing and Decreasing Functions

  • If for every x on some interval, is increasing on that interval

This is all demonstrated by the example function below

Maximums and Minimums

Extrema: What we call maximum and minimum points of a function

Relative (Local) Maximums and Minimums

  • There is a relative (local) maximum at a point if for all x-values around
  • There is a relative (local) minimum at a point if for all x-values around

The First Derivative Test

If a point at is a critical point of ,

is a relative minimum

  • If to the right of and to the left of , then the point at is a relative maximum

is a relative maximum

  • If is the same sign on both sides of , then the point at is neither a relative minimum or relative maximum

is neither a relative minimum or relative maximum

Absolute (Global) Maximums and Minimums

  • There is an absolute (global) maximum at a point if for all x-values between the closed interval
  • There is an absolute (global) minimum at a point if for all x-values between the closed interval

Finding Maximums and Minimums

To find relative maximums and minimums of a function ,

  3. Solve for the x-values that makes this equation hold true (find the critical points where )

*In the above graph, the local maximums and minimums occur when the tangent line to the graph is perfectly horizontal (slope = 0) which is why we try to find where the derivative equals 0)*

To find absolute maximums and minimums of a function over a closed interval ,
  1. Find the derivative function
  2. Set the derivative function equal to zero
  3. Solve for the x-values within the interval that makes this equation hold true (find the critical points where within the interval )
  4. Solve for at these points and then solve for at and
  5. If there are any points on that are defined, but for which does not exist, solve for at these points too
  6. The largest value of from all of these points is the absolute maximum; The smallest value of from all of these points is the absolute minimum

ex.) Find the absolute extrema and relative extrema for the function over the interval .

  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f{}'(x)=2x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f{}'(x)=2x}"/>

  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(0)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(0)=0}"/>, <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(-2)=4}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(-2)=4}"/>, and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(3)=9}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(3)=9}"/>
  • Therefore there is a relative and absolute minimum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=0}"/> and an absolute maximum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=3}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=3}"/>. There is not a relate maximum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/> since it is just an endpoint

Concavity

Concave Up

Concave Down

fields.title: Graphs

fields.content:
We can start to apply what we learned in calculus so far to real life situations through optimization. We look for maximum or minimum values for a function that satisfies a constrain that has to be true no matter what. In a lot of these problems, there is a pattern on how to solve them. These steps are seen below

  1. Identify the constraint and the value to be optimized
  2. Rearrange the constraint equation to solve for one of the variables
  3. Plug this into the equation that needs to be optimized
  4. Differentiate this equation and set it equal to 0
  5. Solve for the values that make it equal to 0
  6. Choose the value that is the maximum or minimum that we are looking for
  7. Solve for the other variables

ex.) A gardener has 300 feet of fencing to enclose three equal sized rectangular garden plots. What dimensions x and y will maximize the total area?

  • The constraint equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/> and the optimization equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total\, \, Area = xy}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;=&space;xy}"/>.
  • We can rearrange the constraint equation to solve for y
  • Plug y into the optimization equation to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total \, \, Area=x\left (75-\frac{x}{2} \right )=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area=x\left&space;(75-\frac{x}{2}&space;\right&space;)=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}"/>
  • Differentiate this to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left (Total \, \, Area \right ){}'(x)=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\left&space;(Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;\right&space;){}'(x)=75-x}"/> and set it equal to 0 to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=75-x}"/>
  • So <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/>
  • Plugging this into <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/>, we get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2(75)+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2(75)+4y=300}"/> which means <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>
  • Therefore our optimal dimensions are <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>

  • Differentiate this to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left (Total \, \, Area \right ){}'(x)=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\left&space;(Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;\right&space;){}'(x)=75-x}"/> and set it equal to 0 to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=75-x}"/>

We call a point at a critical point of a function if exists and if

Finding Critical Points

Ex.) Find all the critical points on the function
  • To find the critical points we have to first find the derivative of <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(x)}"/>
  • This comes out to be <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}"/>
  • This can be rewritten as <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=(3x-3)(2x+4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=(3x-3)(2x+4)}"/>
  • Critical points occur when <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/> so we set <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)}"/> equal to 0 which gives us <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=(3x-3)(2x+4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=(3x-3)(2x+4)}"/>
  • This means there are critical points at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x= 1}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=&space;1}"/> and at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/>
  • Critical points also occur where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)}"/> does not exist, but there are no points on the function <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}"/> where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)}"/> does not exist
  • Therefore the only critical points occur at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x= 1}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=&space;1}"/> and at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/>

  • Critical points occur when <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/>, but there are no points here where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/>. Maximums and Minimums

is a relative minimum

is a relative maximum

Absolute (Global) Maximums and Minimums

To find absolute maximums and minimums of a function over a closed interval ,

ex.) Find the absolute extrema and relative extrema for the function over the interval .

  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f{}'(x)=2x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f{}'(x)=2x}"/>

There is not a relate maximum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/> since it is just an endpoint

Concavity

Concave Up

Concave Down

fields.title: Graphs

fields.content:
We can start to apply what we learned in calculus so far to real life situations through optimization. We look for maximum or minimum values for a function that satisfies a constrain that has to be true no matter what. In a lot of these problems, there is a pattern on how to solve them. These steps are seen below

  1. Identify the constraint and the value to be optimized
  2. Rearrange the constraint equation to solve for one of the variables
  3. Plug this into the equation that needs to be optimized
  4. Differentiate this equation and set it equal to 0
  5. Solve for the values that make it equal to 0
  6. Choose the value that is the maximum or minimum that we are looking for
  7. Solve for the other variables

ex.) A gardener has 300 feet of fencing to enclose three equal sized rectangular garden plots. What dimensions x and y will maximize the total area?

  • The constraint equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/> and the optimization equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total\, \, Area = xy}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;=&space;xy}"/>.
  • We can rearrange the constraint equation to solve for y
  • Plug y into the optimization equation to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total \, \, Area=x\left (75-\frac{x}{2} \right )=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area=x\left&space;(75-\frac{x}{2}&space;\right&space;)=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}"/>
  • Differentiate this to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left (Total \, \, Area \right ){}'(x)=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\left&space;(Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;\right&space;){}'(x)=75-x}"/> and set it equal to 0 to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=75-x}"/>
  • So <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/>
  • Plugging this into <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/>, we get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2(75)+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2(75)+4y=300}"/> which means <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>
  • Therefore our optimal dimensions are <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>

  • The constraint equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/> and the optimization equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total\, \, Area = xy}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;=&space;xy}"/>.
  • We can rearrange the constraint equation to solve for y
  • Plug y into the optimization equation to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total \, \, Area=x\left (75-\frac{x}{2} \right )=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area=x\left&space;(75-\frac{x}{2}&space;\right&space;)=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}"/>
  • Differentiate this to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left (Total \, \, Area \right ){}'(x)=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\left&space;(Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;\right&space;){}'(x)=75-x}"/> and set it equal to 0 to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=75-x}"/>
  • So <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/>
  • Plugging this into <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/>, we get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2(75)+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2(75)+4y=300}"/> which means <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>
  • Therefore our optimal dimensions are <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>

fields.content:
We call a point at a critical point of a function if exists and if

1.

OR

2. does not exist

Finding Critical Points

Ex.) Find all the critical points on the function
  • To find the critical points we have to first find the derivative of <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(x)}"/>
  • This comes out to be <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}"/>
  • This can be rewritten as <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=(3x-3)(2x+4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=(3x-3)(2x+4)}"/>
  • Critical points occur when <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/> so we set <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)}"/> equal to 0 which gives us <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=(3x-3)(2x+4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=(3x-3)(2x+4)}"/>
  • This means there are critical points at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x= 1}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=&space;1}"/> and at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/>
  • Critical points also occur where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)}"/> does not exist, but there are no points on the function <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=6x^{2}+6x-12}"/> where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)}"/> does not exist
  • Therefore the only critical points occur at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x= 1}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=&space;1}"/> and at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/>
Ex.) Find all the critical points on the function
  • To find the critical points we have to first find the derivative of <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(x)}"/>
  • This comes out to be <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=\frac{1}{(x-4)^{1/2}}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=\frac{1}{(x-4)^{1/2}}}"/>
  • Critical points occur when <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/>, but there are no points here where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/>. Therefore the only critical points occur where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)}"/> does not exist
  • This means that the only critical point occurs at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=4}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=4}"/> because the denominator of <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(4)}"/> equal 0 which makes <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(4)}"/> not exist
fields.title: Critical Points

fields.content:
Increasing and Decreasing Functions

  • If for every x on some interval, is increasing on that interval
  • If for every x on some interval, is decreasing on that interval
  • If for every x on some interval, is constant on that interval

This is all demonstrated by the example function below

Maximums and Minimums

Extrema: What we call maximum and minimum points of a function

Relative (Local) Maximums and Minimums

  • There is a relative (local) maximum at a point if for all x-values around
  • There is a relative (local) minimum at a point if for all x-values around

The First Derivative Test

If a point at is a critical point of ,

  • If <img align="absmiddle" alt="{f}'(x)> 0" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{f}'(x)>&space;0"/> to the right of <img align="absmiddle" alt="x=c" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?x=c"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{f}'(x)< 0" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{f}'(x)<&space;0"/> to the left of <img align="absmiddle" alt="x=c" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?x=c"/>, then the point at <img align="absmiddle" alt="x=c" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?x=c"/> is a relative minimum

is a relative minimum

  • If to the right of and to the left of , then the point at is a relative maximum

is a relative maximum

  • If is the same sign on both sides of , then the point at is neither a relative minimum or relative maximum

is neither a relative minimum or relative maximum

Absolute (Global) Maximums and Minimums

  • There is an absolute (global) maximum at a point if for all x-values between the closed interval
  • There is an absolute (global) minimum at a point if for all x-values between the closed interval

Finding Maximums and Minimums

To find relative maximums and minimums of a function ,

  1. Find the derivative function
  2. Set the derivative function equal to zero
  3. Solve for the x-values that makes this equation hold true (find the critical points where )

*In the above graph, the local maximums and minimums occur when the tangent line to the graph is perfectly horizontal (slope = 0) which is why we try to find where the derivative equals 0)*

To find absolute maximums and minimums of a function over a closed interval ,
  1. Find the derivative function
  2. Set the derivative function equal to zero
  3. Solve for the x-values within the interval that makes this equation hold true (find the critical points where within the interval )
  4. Solve for at these points and then solve for at and
  5. If there are any points on that are defined, but for which does not exist, solve for at these points too
  6. The largest value of from all of these points is the absolute maximum; The smallest value of from all of these points is the absolute minimum

ex.) Find the absolute extrema and relative extrema for the function over the interval .

  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f{}'(x)=2x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f{}'(x)=2x}"/>
  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x=0}"/> so there is a critical point at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=0}"/>
  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(0)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(0)=0}"/>, <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(-2)=4}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(-2)=4}"/>, and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(3)=9}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(3)=9}"/>
  • Therefore there is a relative and absolute minimum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=0}"/> and an absolute maximum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=3}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=3}"/>. There is not a relate maximum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/> since it is just an endpoint

Concavity

Concave Up

  • A curve is concave up if the curve at a point is above the tangent line to the point
  • A curve is concave down if \(f''(x)<0\)

Concave Down

  • A curve is concave down if the curve at a point is below the tangent line to the point
  • A curve is concave down if

Points of Inflection

Point of Inflection: A point where the curve changes from concave down to concave up or from concave up to concave down

  • A point is a point of inflection if <img align="absmiddle" alt="f{}'{}'(c)=0" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?f{}'{}'(c)=0"/>

The Second Derivative Test

If a point at is a critical point of such that ,
  • If , then the point at is a relative maximum
  • If , then the point at is a relative minimum
  • If , then the point at can be a relative maximum, relative minimum, or neither
fields.title: Graphs

fields.content:
We can start to apply what we learned in calculus so far to real life situations through optimization. We look for maximum or minimum values for a function that satisfies a constrain that has to be true no matter what. In a lot of these problems, there is a pattern on how to solve them. These steps are seen below

  1. Identify the constraint and the value to be optimized
  2. Rearrange the constraint equation to solve for one of the variables
  3. Plug this into the equation that needs to be optimized
  4. Differentiate this equation and set it equal to 0
  5. Solve for the values that make it equal to 0
  6. Choose the value that is the maximum or minimum that we are looking for
  7. Solve for the other variables

ex.) A gardener has 300 feet of fencing to enclose three equal sized rectangular garden plots. What dimensions x and y will maximize the total area?

  • The constraint equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/> and the optimization equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total\, \, Area = xy}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;=&space;xy}"/>.
  • We can rearrange the constraint equation to solve for y
  • Plug y into the optimization equation to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total \, \, Area=x\left (75-\frac{x}{2} \right )=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area=x\left&space;(75-\frac{x}{2}&space;\right&space;)=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}"/>
  • Differentiate this to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left (Total \, \, Area \right ){}'(x)=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\left&space;(Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;\right&space;){}'(x)=75-x}"/> and set it equal to 0 to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=75-x}"/>
  • So <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/>
  • Plugging this into <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/>, we get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2(75)+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2(75)+4y=300}"/> which means <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>
  • Therefore our optimal dimensions are <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>

  • Therefore the only critical points occur at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x= 1}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=&space;1}"/> and at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/>
Ex.) Find all the critical points on the function
  • To find the critical points we have to first find the derivative of <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(x)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(x)}"/>
  • This comes out to be <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=\frac{1}{(x-4)^{1/2}}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=\frac{1}{(x-4)^{1/2}}}"/>
  • Critical points occur when <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/>, but there are no points here where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)=0}"/>. Therefore the only critical points occur where <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(c)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(c)}"/> does not exist
  • This means that the only critical point occurs at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=4}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=4}"/> because the denominator of <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(4)}"/> equal 0 which makes <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(4)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(4)}"/> not exist
fields.title: Finding Critical Points

This is all demonstrated by the example function below
fields.title: Increasing and Decreasing Functions

fields.content:
Extrema: What we call maximum and minimum points of a function

Relative (Local) Maximums and Minimums

  • There is a relative (local) maximum at a point if for all x-values around
  • There is a relative (local) minimum at a point if for all x-values around

The First Derivative Test

If a point at is a critical point of ,

  • If <img align="absmiddle" alt="{f}'(x)> 0" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{f}'(x)>&space;0"/> to the right of <img align="absmiddle" alt="x=c" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?x=c"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{f}'(x)< 0" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{f}'(x)<&space;0"/> to the left of <img align="absmiddle" alt="x=c" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?x=c"/>, then the point at <img align="absmiddle" alt="x=c" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?x=c"/> is a relative minimum

is a relative minimum

  • If to the right of and to the left of , then the point at is a relative maximum

is a relative maximum

  • If is the same sign on both sides of , then the point at is neither a relative minimum or relative maximum

is neither a relative minimum or relative maximum

Absolute (Global) Maximums and Minimums

  • There is an absolute (global) maximum at a point if for all x-values between the closed interval
  • There is an absolute (global) minimum at a point if for all x-values between the closed interval

Finding Maximums and Minimums

To find relative maximums and minimums of a function ,

  1. Find the derivative function
  2. Set the derivative function equal to zero
  3. Solve for the x-values that makes this equation hold true (find the critical points where )

*In the above graph, the local maximums and minimums occur when the tangent line to the graph is perfectly horizontal (slope = 0) which is why we try to find where the derivative equals 0)*

To find absolute maximums and minimums of a functionover a closed interval,
  1. Find the derivative function
  2. Set the derivative function equal to zero
  3. Solve for the x-values within the interval that makes this equation hold true (find the critical points where within the interval )
  4. Solve for at these points and then solve for at and
  5. If there are any points on that are defined, but for which does not exist, solve for at these points too
  6. The largest value of from all of these points is the absolute maximum; The smallest value of from all of these points is the absolute minimum

ex.) Find the absolute extrema and relative extrema for the function over the interval .

  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f{}'(x)=2x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f{}'(x)=2x}"/>
  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x=0}"/> so there is a critical point at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=0}"/>
  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(0)=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(0)=0}"/>, <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(-2)=4}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(-2)=4}"/>, and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(3)=9}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(3)=9}"/>
  • Therefore there is a relative and absolute minimum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=0}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=0}"/> and an absolute maximum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=3}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=3}"/>. There is not a relate maximum at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=-2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=-2}"/> since it is just an endpoint
fields.title: Maximums and Minimums

fields.content:
Concave Up

  • A curve is concave up if the curve at a point is above the tangent line to the point
  • A curve is concave down if \(f''(x)<0\)

Concave Down

  • A curve is concave down if the curve at a point is below the tangent line to the point
  • A curve is concave down if

Points of Inflection

Point of Inflection: A point where the curve changes from concave down to concave up or from concave up to concave down

  • A point is a point of inflection if <img align="absmiddle" alt="f{}'{}'(c)=0" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?f{}'{}'(c)=0"/>

The Second Derivative Test

If a point atis a critical point ofsuch that,
  • If , then the point at is a relative maximum
  • If , then the point at is a relative minimum
  • If , then the point at can be a relative maximum, relative minimum, or neither
fields.title: Concavity

fields.content:
We can start to apply what we learned in calculus so far to real life situations through optimization. We look for maximum or minimum values for a function that satisfies a constrain that has to be true no matter what. In a lot of these problems, there is a pattern on how to solve them. These steps are seen below

  1. Identify the constraint and the value to be optimized
  2. Rearrange the constraint equation to solve for one of the variables
  3. Plug this into the equation that needs to be optimized
  4. Differentiate this equation and set it equal to 0
  5. Solve for the values that make it equal to 0
  6. Choose the value that is the maximum or minimum that we are looking for
  7. Solve for the other variables

ex.) A gardener has 300 feet of fencing to enclose three equal sized rectangular garden plots. What dimensions x and y will maximize the total area?

  • The constraint equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/> and the optimization equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total\, \, Area = xy}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;=&space;xy}"/>.
  • We can rearrange the constraint equation to solve for y
  • Plug y into the optimization equation to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total \, \, Area=x\left (75-\frac{x}{2} \right )=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area=x\left&space;(75-\frac{x}{2}&space;\right&space;)=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}"/>
  • Differentiate this to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left (Total \, \, Area \right ){}'(x)=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\left&space;(Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;\right&space;){}'(x)=75-x}"/> and set it equal to 0 to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=75-x}"/>
  • So <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/>
  • Plugging this into <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/>, we get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2(75)+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2(75)+4y=300}"/> which means <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>
  • Therefore our optimal dimensions are <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>
fields.title: Optimization

fields.content: Biotechnology is the application of genetic engineering where DNA and genetic materials are manipulated for some purpose. The DNA created from this application of engineering comes from various organisms and is termed recombinant DNA. An example of this would be manipulating bacterial DNA to get it to produce insulin needed for diabetes patients.
fields.title: Biotechnology Overview

fields.content: The common method used to manipulate DNA is through special bacterial DNA called plasmids. Plasmids are small circular pieces of DNA that bacteria have in them floating around. Their use consists of pulling these plasmids out of the bacteria cells, inserting desired genes into them, and then reinserting them into the bacteria so that they may replicate and become recombinant DNA. Furthermore, once the modified bacteria cell reproduces, more and more cells will have the capabilities of the original engineered bacteria cell.The key part of the creation of recombinant DNA is how exactly the DNA is inserted. Special enzymes called restriction enzymes are used to cut the plasmid to open it up. Restriction enzymes are very specialized and are only able to cut at specialized nucleotide sequences. These specialized sequences are called restriction sites. When a cut is made at a restriction site, two possible openings are created. One opening is called a sticky end and only occurs if the cut occurs ina staggered way. The other opening is called a blunt end; this cut occurs straight through. ***Note- only sticky ends can fit with other sticky ends; the same goes for blunt ends. For sticky ends, it really depends on the orientation of the cut to see if two fragments will fit. Finally, DNA ligase is used to seal the fragments together.
fields.title: Bacteria: The Key to Manipulating Dna

fields.content:
There are several procedures used in biotechnology labs to harness the power of DNA cloning and recombination. The following includes important procedures or terms that are frequently used in genetic engineering:

  • genomic library: many times a large database of DNA is kept for reference and frequent use. A genomic library holds hundreds of plasmids, each one recombined with some inserted DNA from restriction enzymes.
  • complimentary DNA: this is DNA produced from mRNA through the use of reverse transcriptase, and enzyme that turns mRNA into DNA
  • cDNA library: a genomic library of cDNA
****Procedures...
  • nucleic acid hybridization: this is used to help find a gene of interest within a genomic library. Here, a nucleic acid probe, that has the complimentary sequences to the desired DNA segment, is radioactively labeled, so that it will glow. The cell under inspection will then be treated with heat to break open the cell and denature the DNA. Then, the probe can search and hybridize to the correct complimentary DNA fragment and glow. Thus the desired gene is found.
  • Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR): a common way to amplify DNA, meaning the quantity of a desired piece of DNA is created. This is a quick way to produce massive quantities of DNA. The gene of interest is added to a soluton of primers, heat-resistant DNA polymerase, and four nucleotides. The solution is then heated to open up the DNA, then cooled so the primers can H-bond to the complimentary code. Finally, the polymerase is added and it builds the complimentary sequence and attaches them to the 3' end of the primers. This short procedure is repeated many many times to amplify the DNA.
  • gel electrophoresis: a lab procedure that separates nucleic acids, DNA fragments, and proteins according to their size and charge. Remember, size is inversely proportional to distance traveled, so shorter fragments go farther in the gel. The whole apparatus used is based on an electric current driven through the gel. Since the DNA is negatively charged because of their phosphate groups, they move away from the negative side and toward the positive side.
  • Southern blotting: a technique that combines gel electrophoresis and nucleic acid hybridization where fragments travel in gell and hen are transferred to another testing area, usually nitrocellulose paper where the desired gene is found through bonding with a complimentary strand that radioactively glows.
fields.title: Application of Genetic Engineering

fields.content: Biotechnology is the application of genetic engineering where DNA and genetic materials are manipulated for some purpose. The DNA created from this application of engineering comes from various organisms and is termed recombinant DNA. An example of this would be manipulating bacterial DNA to get it to produce insulin needed for diabetes patients.

fields.title: Application of Genetic Engineering

fields.content:
Overall cell communication is made up of several signal transduction pathways. A signal transduction pathway is defined as the process of turning a signal on cell's surface or within the cell into a cellular response. There are essentially three stages in communication through a pathway:

  • reception - involves the binding or reception of a signal on or inside a cell
  • transduction - series of steps that convert the signal into readable information for the cell structures working at the destination of the signal.
  • response - the cell structures acting after the transduced signal is read.
Lastly, there are two types of cell signaling: long distance and local. Long distance signalling includes the nervous system and hormones; both of these examples spread a signal large distances from the signals origin. Local regulators include the neurotransmitters released at neural synapses and cystolic communication through plasmodesmata and gap junctions. Now, lets go in depth inside each of the steps within cell communication...
fields.title: Cell Communication Overview

fields.content:
Reception usually beings with a ligand, or a signalling molecule, binding to a receptor protein; sometimes this causes a change in the shape of the receptor protein inducing transduction.
