*The function is actually <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(x)=\sqrt{x}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(x)=\sqrt{x}}"/> which has a derivative function as <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(x)=\frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(x)=\frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}}}"/> through the Power Rule. Plugging in <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x= 4.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=&space;4.5}"/>, the actual derivative comes out to <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(4.5)=\frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{\sqrt{4.5}}=.2357}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(4.5)=\frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{\sqrt{4.5}}=.2357}"/>, which is really close to our approximated answer <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(4.5)\simeq .24}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(4.5)\simeq&space;.24}"/>*
fields.title: Approximating Derivatives

fields.content:
To see how to implicitly differentiate, we will outline the steps and try to differentiate the example function
  • Differentiate both sides with respect to x
  • Solve for <img align="absmiddle" alt="\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?\frac{\mathrm{d}&space;y}{\mathrm{d}&space;x}"/>
fields.title: Steps

fields.content:
The periodic table is a organizational tool that is used to sort all known elements. An element is a pure substance made up only one type of atom. This is different from a compound, which is made up of atoms of different elements chemically bonded to one another uniformly.Each column in the periodic table (vertical) is called a group; horizontal rows are called periods.On the perodic table, each element has its own little box. Within that space, three important things are displayed. At the top lies the elements atomic number. The atomic number describes how many protons an atom has in its nucleus, Additionally, since atoms have no electrical charge, they have the same number of electrons as protons. Thus the atomic number can also state the number of electrons in an atom. Next, in the middle of the box is the element's symbol. This is the way chemists can universally identify an element. Finally, at the bottom of the box we find the elements molar mass. Molar mass is the combination of protons and neutrons that create the nucleus of the atom. This mass is in grams and constitutes a whole mole of atoms of said element; a mole is a measurement method that is used universally of 6.023 x molecules.The number of protons determines the element of an atom, but not all atoms of an element have the same mass number. An isotope is an atom with the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons. For example, Oxygen usually has an molar mass of 16 (O-16) but some atoms only have 12 neutrons, and thus are called oxygen-12 isotope. Although many isotopes may exist for an element, the molar mass will reflect the most common isotope of an element.

Atomic Structure and Electron Clouds

Each atom is made up of a nucleus, formed through proton and neutron combinations, and an electron cloud which surrounds the nucleus. It's called a cloud because the electrons move around the nucleus randomly, but stay within a certain area. Often times, the whole cloud will be made up of several shells, subshells, and orbitals. I will explain below.

- Electron's Quantum Numbers:

  1. Shells (n) - this is called the principal quantum number. It states how far an electron is from the nucleus and how mch energy it contains. Stability is inversely proportional to distance, while energy is directly proportional. The numbers here will increase from 1 onward. Generally, the period number will tell you the number of shells. For example, if n=2 then the electron cloud has two shells.
  2. Subshells (l) -this is callled the angular momentum quantum number. It determines the shape of an individual electron cloud, or orbital. Subshells begin from 0 and incriment upwards. Remember, that "l=n-1 This means that if n=2, there would be two subshells: l=0 and l=1. Furthermore, each subshell has a name:
    1. s-cloud occurs when l=0; this contains one orbital, with two maximum in each orbital, totaling 2.
    2. p-cloud occurs when l=1; this contains three orbitals, with two maximum in each orbital, totaling 6
    3. d-cloud occurs when l=2; this contains five orbital, with two maximum in each orbital, totaling 10
    4. f-cloud occurs when l=3; this contains seven orbital, with two maximum in each orbital, totaling 14
  3. Orbitals ()- this is the magnetic quantum number. It states the orbitals orientation within the cloud. Here, all you need to know is that = -l through +l
  4. Spin () - an electron can have a positive spin or a negative spin. This value is either +1/2 or -1/2
fields.title: The Chemist's Main Guide: The Periodic Table

fields.content:
Electrons are highly mobile within the electron cloud. Their movement affects many of the properties that an element has. There are three principles that are important to remember, especially for the AP exam:

  1. Aufbau Principle - electrons will fill lower energy shells, subshells, and orbitals first
  2. Pauli's exclusion principle - each electron will have its own unique set of quatum numbers; no two can have the same
  3. Hund's rule - electrons will always try to fill an empty orbital before it pairs up with another in an orbital.
These rules are not only important to know in general, but also when you are writing electron orbital diagrams and writing out electrong configurations for elements (i.e. which consequently is Nitrogen).
fields.title: Three Rules on Electron Interactions

fields.content:
Knowing these trends are super important...but actually, learn them and love them. They will show up on both sections of the exam. These trends are all explained by a few common atomic mechanisms, which i have listed below. Remember, electrons are negatively charged and protons in the nucleus are postively charged. Therefore, since opposites attract in chemistry, electrons are attracted and held in the cloud by the nucleus' charge. And subsequently, electrons repell eachother.

  • <strong>Electron Sheilding</strong> - this is an interaction where the electrons in the valence shell (outermost) are less attracted to the nucleus because they are simultaneously repelled by electrons in lower shells and blocked from the nucleus' charge
  • Affective nuclear charge - electrons are more attracted the closer they are to the nucleus; the more protons in the nucleus, the stronger the attractive force
  • Stability is what atoms will naturally trend toward, thus full electron shells are more stable then partially filled ones. Atoms will exchange electrons in order to complete their respective shells.
    • Side note- elements vary in their magnetism. When electron levels are filled completely, an element will be diamengentic and have no charge. In other words, their electrons are all paired in their orbitals. When some orbitals are left unfilled, elements have some magnetic charge (it varies by how many orbitals are unparied or empty) and are called paramagnetic.
-Atomic Radius: the distance from the center of the nucleus to the outer edge of the electron cloudAtomic radius increases down a group. The explanation is simple; with each step down the group, a whole new shell of electrons is added to the cloud. However, atomic radius decreases across a period from left to right. This is because as we move left to right in a period, an atom gains a proton. This increase the nuclear attractive force; the number of electron shells doesnt change though. This means, as we move across a period, the nucleus attracts the cloud closer and closer to it, decreasing the radius.Atomic radius varies by ions as well. Negative ions are called anions; they gain electrons to become negative. Anions are bigger thena their atom counterparts because the gain of electrons increase electron-electron repulsion, causing the valence electrons to move farther from the nucleus.Postive ions are called cations; they lose electrons to become positive. Cations are smaller than their respective atoms because when they lose electrons, either (1) they lose an electon cloud or (2) their electron-electron repulsion between the the valence electrons and the inner electron clouds is reduced. Both of these result in the valence electron cloud moving closer to the nucleus.-Electron Affinity: this is basically the opposite of Ionization Energy. Its defined as the energy turnover when an electron is added to an atom as opposed to taken away.There's a no real change down a group for electron affinity. As for across a period, it increases because affective nuclear charge increase as you go across a period, so that is more energy to overcome.-Electronegativity: the attractive force of an atoms nucleus on nearby electronsThis decreases down a group, simply due to the fact that there is more electron-electron repulsion and electron sheilding that blocks affective nuclear charge. Electronegativity increases across a period because the number of protons in the nucleus increases as well.-Ionization energy: the amount of energy needed to remove an electron from an atom.This property varies by how many valence electrons there are. Moving down a group, ionization energy increases due to the fact that as the valence electron moves farther away from the nucleus (since they grow), there is less affective nuclear charge acting on them. Thus it takes less energy to pull one away.Moving left to right across a period, ionization energy increases. This again has to do with affective nuclear charge. As the number of protons increases across a period, there is more affective nuclear charge as the nucleus attracts the electrons more. Therefore, its harder to pull electrons off.Finally (thank god, because this lesson is dragging...am i right?), since ionization energy depends on the valence electrons present, it will increase little by little untill a whole shell is taken off. The ionization energy jumps through the roof once a new shell is reached and we try to disrupt the stability of the complete shell. Remember, atoms like stability, taking stability away takes alot of energy.
fields.title: Periodic Trends!!!

fields.content:
Since atoms are made of clouds of electrons, most IMFs and bonding occurs due to interactions of electrons which are called electrostatic forces. These forces are basically the positively charged nucleus of one atom being attracted to the negatively charged electrons of another atom.There are two different types of main bonds:

  1. Covalent Bonding - this involves two atoms sharing electrons; however, how they share these electrons causes variablity within bonding. The electrons shared are counted as a part of both bonding atoms valence shells. Covalent bonds usually occur between nonmetals.
  2. Ionic Bonding - this consists of one atom completely giving up its electrons to another; this results in one atom becoming a cation and the other becoming an anion. Since these types of bonds occur mainly between nonmetals and metals, the metals become cations and the nonmetals in anions.
fields.title: Types of Bonds

fields.content:
When two atoms bond covalently, there can be an array of bond sizes, strenths, and lengths. First off there are three types of bondings possible: single, double, and triple. Single bonds are made up of a sigma bond, a type of bond overlapping orbital. Double and Triple bonds include both sigma bonds and pi bonds. The distinction between sigma and pi bonds is structural in its 3D shape, but this is outside the scope of this course. A Double bond is made up of one sigma and one pi bond; a triple bond is made up of one sigma and two pi bonds.

The bond order is a term that tells what level of bond exists somewhere in a molecule. Single bonds have a bond order of 1; double has an order of 2, and so on. Now, bond strength is inversely proportional to size. Therefore, a stronger triple bond would be much shorter than a single bond.
fields.title: Bond Order, Strength, and Length

fields.content:
Inter molecular forces (IMFs) are different from bonds. Bonds are very strong links that are created through chemical interactions; IMFs are attractive forces that occur naturally between molecules/atoms. There are several types of IMFs. Here they are, listed in order of increasing strength:

  • London Dispersion/Van Der Waals Forces - these are the weaksest IMFs. they can occur between any molecules, but generally occur between nonpolar molecules (neutral). These forces are created through random motion of electrons within the interacting molecules to produce a charge creating a weak attractive force.
  • Dipole-Dipole interactions - ***Remember when i said that in covalent bonding the sharing of electrons doesnt have to necessarily share them equally? Well, if I didn't, now I am. In covalent bonding, two atoms CAN share electrons equally, but the degree of sharing actually comes down to the respective electronegativity of each atom. Atoms with stronger electronegativity will pull electrons closer towards themselves, causing an uneven sharing of electrons. This uneven sharing is called a dipole moment. Thus two dipole moments interacting causes a dipole-dipole interaction (#duh). These interactions occur mostly between polar molecules.
    • Dipoles are actually the forces that cause a mechanism called Polarity. Polarity is where there is an uneven distribution of charge created in one molecule. A prime example is a water molecule. The highly electronegative O atom pulls the shared electrons closer to itself. This gives it a slightly negative charge, while the H atoms have slightly positive charges. Thus, the molecule is polar because it contains multiple charges.
  • Hydrogen Bonds (H Bonds) - hydrogen bonds are a stronger form of dipole dipole interactions. They consist of an H bonded to either an Nitrogen, Oxygen, or Fluorine atom. The logic here is that since N, O and F have such high electronegativities and H has a low one, the bond is extremely polar. This causes even stronger interactions with other polar molecules.
  • Ion-Dipole Interactions - the name says it all here. An ion and polar molecule interacting is stronger than dipole-dipole because the charge of the ion creates a stronger attractive force to the dipole.
  • Network Covalent Bonds - these are interactions between covalent bonds causing them to arrange themselves into a lattic structure. This allows lots of smaller bonds to act as one huge interactive molecule. One last thing, the lattice structure limits the motion of electrons, which makes the whole interaction stronger and a poor conductor of electricity.
fields.title: Intermolecular Forces

fields.content:
This is an important concept for both sections of the exam. Since here I don't have enough tools to create all the individual diagrams, I will give descriptions of each shape and examples of these molecules. Its up to you to learn and read up on Lewis Dot diagrams and these 3D diagrams, as well as how to draw them. All of this follows the VSPER model.

Molecular Geometries show us how a molecule looks after it comes together. The fact that electrons repel each other complicates these basic shapes. We're almost done with this lesson, so lets finish strong with a look at each shape...

  • Linear - this is where the central atom only has 2 electron pairs, and only 2 potential atoms bonded to it. An example would be CO2
  • Trigonal Planar - the central atom has 3 electron pairs, and three potential atoms bonded to it. An example is BCl3
    • if this has 1 lone pair (a set of unparied electrons), then it becomes a bent shape. Example: SO2.
  • Tetrahedral - the central atom has 4 electron pairs, an a maximum of 4 atoms bonded to it. Example: SiH4
    • if there is 1 lone pair, then its called trigonal pyramidal. Example: NH3
    • if there are 2 lone pairs, then its called bent again. Example: H2O
  • Trigonal Bipyramidal - 5 electron pairs on the central atom. Example: PCl5
    • seesaw: one lone pair with trigonal bipyramidal. Example: SF4
    • T-shaped: two lone pairs. Example: ICl3
    • linear: three lone pairs. Example: PF2
  • Octahedral - 6 electron pairs on the central atom. Example: SF6
    • square pyramidal: one lone pair. Example: BrF5
    • square planar: two one pairs. Example: XeCl4
fields.title: Molecular Geometry

fields.content:
This is a silly little last thing, but nonetheless important. Hybrization is a notation that describes the electron clouds mixing when a complex molecule is formed. It's just something to remember along with molecular geometry, and it's pretty easy.

  • Linear - sp (1 s cloud and 1 p cloud)
  • Trigonal Planar -
  • Tetrahedral -
  • Trigonal Bipyramidal -
  • Octahedral -
 Well....Thats All folks!!! (i miss the loony toons :/ )
fields.title: Hybridization

fields.content:
Measuring the concentration of a solution is one of the most important prerequisites to doing problems in this unit. There are three main concentrations:

  1. Mole Fraction - This is the fraction of moles of some element or molecule. This is used primarily with vapor pressure, which i will explain later.
    1. Formula -
  2. Molality - this is the concentration of a solution with respect to how much moles of solute by the mass of the solvent. This is heavily used with colligative property calculations.
    1. Formula -
  3. Molarity - this expresses solution concentration based on the volume of solvent rather than the mass. This is its main difference from molality.
    1. Formula -
fields.title: Important Measurement Methods

fields.content: One rule affects how things dissociate, which means to break into ions or monomers/ions. This is called "like dissolves like Due to the many intermoleular forces at work, solutes with similar polarity as their solvents will dissociate in them. Like polarities are dissociable. The same goes for nonpolar solutes in nonpolar solvents.Another thing that affects dissociation and more so solubility is van't Hoff factor (i). This tells us how many ions a solute molecule will break up into. Solutes that cant be dissociated are given a factor of 1, and the property increases up the scale depending on the number of ions it breaks up into.
fields.title: Dissociation and Properties That Affect It

fields.content:
There are four main colligative properties, or properties that vary by the number of solute particless in the solvent.

  1. Boiling Point Elevation - this is where boiling point increases with solute presence and concentration.
    1. Formula - (where the change in temperature equals the van't Hoff factor times the Boiling point elevation constant (k) times the molality (m)
  2. Freezing Point Depression- basically the opposite of number 1 above...
    1. Formula - (where the change in temperature equals the van't Hoff factor times the Freezing point depression constant (k) times the molality (m)
  3. Decrease of Vapor Pressure - involves the speed at which molecules hit and exert pressure on the walls of a container.
    1. Formula - (where vapor pressure equals the mole fraction (X) times the Vapor Pressure of the Solvent
  4. Osmotic pressure - The pressure that must be exerted to prevent the movement of a pure solvent into a solution across a membrane.
    1. Formula - (where osmotic pressure in atm is equal to moles of solute times the gas constant (R) times temperature in Kelvin over the volume of the solution in liters times the van't Hoff Factor; can also be turned into M which is Molarity of the solution)
***This one isnt a true colligative property but it should still be known about: Density.

Density = ; its affected by solute presence.
fields.title: Colligative Properties

fields.content: Most things dont dissociate completely in solution, but to a degree. In comes solubility product or , which describes to what degree a solute or an ion dissociate. Most of the time with problems involving have to do with a salt. The expression for solubility product is This means the is the product of each consituent ion with its own charge and ratio in molecule. For example:If we work with the equation then... = -Common Ion Effect: where the solubility of an ion (from a solute) is decreased by the presence of that same ion in solution already. Lets try a example problem...If the of NaCl is 1.6 x then,1.6 x = 1.6 x = (a)(a)1.6 x = a = [Na+]= [Cl-] = 1.3 x However, if we add some sort of salt with a common ion to NaCl, then the solubility of some ions decreases. When two salts with a common ion are mixed, the one with the smaller precipitates first. Heres what I mean...If we put 0.1 M Cl- in the solution, the solubility of Na decreases dramatically.1.6 x = 1.6 x = M Once again....Thats all folks!!!
fields.title: Solubility and Equilibrium

fields.content:
Significant Figures (sig-figs) are basically rounding rules for chemistry. They tell us to what degree of specificity we ought to report data. There are several sig fig rules. Firstly, lets cover what a sig-fig actually is...

  • Nonzero digits and zeros sandwiched between nonzero digits are significant
  • Zeros that are at the end of a number and to the right of a decimal are considered significant
  • Zeros that are at the end of a number are not significant if the number is greater than one, unless there is a decimal after them.
  • All other zeros are NOT significant
Sig-fig rules still apply to mathematical operations like adding, subtracting, multiplying and dividing.-Addition and Subtraction: the answer should be rounded to the decimal place as the number with the least decimal places in the calculations.ex) 0.003 + 0.2 = 0.2-Muliplication and Division: the answer should have the same number of sig-figs as the number with the least number of sig figs in the calculation.ex) 1200 x 234 = 280800 = 280000
fields.title: Significant Figures

fields.content: This topic requires in depth knowledge of conversions between measurements. They will be your links between what yore given in a problem and how to get the unit of the answer. The most universal conversion is a mole, or Avagadro's number.So.... 1 mole = moleculesThe biggest conversion with moles in chemistry is between moles and grams:# of moles =
fields.title: Useful Conversions

fields.content:
1. Percent composition: this is the percent by mass that one element makes up in a compound
    1. To calculate, deduce the molar mass of the compound, then divide by this molar mass to get the number of moles
    2. then divide the number of moles of the compound by the number of moles of the desired element in that compound
    3. finally, find the mass of the moles of this desired element and divide it by the total mass of the original compound and muliply that by 100
  2. Empirical Formulas: the simplest chemical formula of a compound
    1. Generally, you will be given either the mass of each element in the compound or the moles of each. Let's say we are given the mass...
    2. divide by the molar mass to determine moles of each substance
    3. once you have moles, divide each number of moles by the smallest number of moles present among the elements
    4. At this point, you should have some numbers close to whole numbers and one number that is one. These are the proportions of each element in the empirical formula. If the number is like 1.5 or something not close to a whole number, either you did something wrong or you need to multiply all the numbers by a common coefficient to get them all whole.
  3. Balancing Chemical Equations: simply put, the number of molecules for each element on the reactants side needs to equal that of the products side (due to the conservation of mass)
    1. You could to trial and error, but if it is a multiple choice test, start from the middle of the choices and work your way through them until one of the selections just clicks.
  4. Limiting Reactant problems: these are the baddest of the bunch. In chemical equations, usually one reactant runs out before the other when producing products. This reactant is justly called the limiting reactant.
    1. There are a couple things you need to take care of before you solve this type of problem. The biggest two things are balancing the chemical equation and converting the reactants to moles
    2. From here, use your molar ratios from your balanced equation to see which reactant would yeild how many moles of the product under question. Whichever reactant yeilds less...it limits the whole equation and thus is the limiting reactant
***A final note about all of these types of questions. Remember to double check what exactly you are solving for, its easy to get lost in these problems!!!
fields.title: The Most Common Problems With Stoichiometry

fields.content: Aggregate demand is basically the general willingness of the population to buy goods and services produced in a country. If people in a country tend to be conservative with their money and like to save, that country has a low aggregate demand. Likewise, if people in a country like to spend most of their incomes, that country has a high aggregate demand.
fields.title: Definition

fields.content: The aggregate demand curve (AD) is inversely proportional to the general price level (PL). When prices are low, people are willing to spend their money, and thus output, real GDP, is high. When prices are high, people aren't willing to spend as much, and thus real GDP is low. It's honestly just common sense. There are other reasons for why there's an inverse relationship, but I haven't seen it covered on any exams.As you can see on the graph to the left, if the general price level drops from PL1 to PL2, real GDP (output) increases from Y1 to Y2 because more people are inclined to spend at that lower price level. This curve is meant to illustrate the tendencies of people as consumers. Never will you actually see an economy "move along" the AD curve as pictured in the graph. An economy's state will always be at the intersection point of the AD curve, and another curve, which you will learn next chapter. Just understand why the AD curve is inversely proportional to price levels.
fields.title: Ad Curve

fields.content: If you know the equation for GDP, you know the components of aggregate demand. In case yove forgotten, the components are: consumer spending (C), business investment (I), government spending (G), and net exports (X-M). You must know this.
fields.title: Gdp

fields.content:
This is the most important part of the chapter. It's pretty simple too. Scenario: a country has a certain level of aggregate demand. If that country's level of aggregate demand increases, the AD curve will shift to the right. This should make sense: if a country's level of aggregate demand increases, people are willing to spendmoreat every price level, hence the shifting of the curve to the right. The converse is true also. If aggregate demand decreased, the AD curve would shift to the left.This graph depicts exactly how the AD curve shifts to the right. The output of an economy would increase from Y1 to Y2 if it had a fixed general price level PL1 and the AD curve shifted to the right. This is consistent with with the paragraph above.So, what exactlydoesincreases aggregate demand? Easy: any increase in the components of aggregate demand will increase aggregate demand itself, and thus shift the AD curve to the right. Once again, the converse of this is true as well. I will give many examples of change in aggregate demand below. It is necessary that you understand all of them.

Consumer Spending

  • Scenario: The government increases personal income taxes.
    • If personal income taxes increase, people will have less money to spend. Therefore, consumer spending will decrease, thus decreasing aggregate demand and shifting the AD curve to the left.
  • Scenario: The government increases transfer payments to welfare beneficiaries.
    • An increase in transfer payments to welfare beneficiaries would increase the amount of money they have to spend. Therefore, consumer spending would increase, thus increasing aggregate demand and shifting the AD curve to the right.
  • Scenario: The marginal propensity to save decreases.
      • *This one may require some explanation. The tendencies for people to spend and save when income changes are called the marginal propensity to consume (MPC) and the marginal propensity to save (MPS), respectively.
      • Together, they form the equation: MPC + MPS = 1. It should make sense that an increase in one will lead to the decrease in the other.
    • Here's the answer: If the marginal propensity to save decreases, then the marginal propensity to consume will increase. This means that consumers will tend to spend more money. Therefore, consumer spending will increase, thus increasing aggregate demand and shifting the AD curve to the right.
  • Scenario: The country is experiencing high unemployment.
    • If there is high unemployment, people will be fearful of losing their jobs. Thus, they will start to save more money in case they do end up being let go (so they have money to fall back on). Therefore, consumer spending will decrease, thus decreasing aggregate demand and shifting the AD curve to the left.
  • Scenario: The country is experiencing high inflation.
    • If there is high inflation, people will try to spend their money now so it won't lose value later. Therefore, consumer spending will increase, thus increasing aggregate demand and shifting the AD curve to the right.

Business Investment

  • Scenario: Real interest rates rise.
      • *Most businesses get the money to invest through loans. It should make sense then that business investment will be high when real interest rates are low and vice-versa. This relationship is depicted by the investment-demand curve to the left. There is an inverse relationship between business investment and real interest rates (real i), just as we said.
      • The "economic reason" for this is profitability. Businesses lose potential profits when they must pay back high interest loans, which is why high real interest rates cause lower business investment
    • Answer: If real interest rates rise, then business investment will decrease due to lower profitability of loans. Therefore, aggregate demand decrease, shifting the AD curve to the left.
Note: Consumers take out loans as well. Therefore, you could say that consumption would decrease as well as business investment. However, the main focus with real interest rates is business investment.

Government Spending

  • Scenario: The government passes a bill that will create interstate highways.
    • The government will have to fund the creation of interstate highways. Therefore, government spending will increase, thus increasing aggregate demand and shifting the AD curve to the right.
  • Scenario: The government decreases spending by $10 million.
    • Honestly, most government spending questions will be obvious like this one. The exam will tell you the scenario, and you should say: Because government spending decreases, aggregate demand decreases as well, shifting the AD curve to the left. However, the question will have many other parts relating to other chapters. This piece of the problem should be the easy part.

Net Exports

These scenarios should be very easy to pick out, since they'll have to do with other countries.
  • Scenario: The U.S. government places a tariff on foreign goods
    • Because the tariff will tax imported goods, American citizens will stop purchasing, eventually decreasing the amount of imports into the country. This will increase net exports, thus increasing aggregate demand and shifting the AD curve to the right.

Summary

By now, you should have an idea of how components of aggregate demand will be changed and how this will affect aggregate demand. The answers I gave are common to the scenarios presented, but by no means are they guaranteed to be true. The AP exam will usually phrase questions in such a way that you will know what they're looking for.For example, the exam may ask: "How could a country experiencing high inflation have an increase in aggregate demand?" With this question, you know the answer I gave above is applicable because the end result answered the actual question. Yoll never get one of the scenarios above without a direction for the answer.***My answers are pretty much exactly how you should phrase them when answering problems on the AP exam (and also just thinking about the problems in general). It may seem repetitive to write all of that for a question, but it's what I'd do if I were you.
fields.title: Shifting the Ad Curve

fields.content: Aggregate supply is basically the general willingness of business to produce goods and services in a country. If there are many businesses willing to produce goods and services, then a country's level of aggregate supply is high. If there are few businesses willing to produce goods and services, then a country's aggregate supply is low.
fields.title: Definition

fields.content: The aggregate supply curve (AS) is upward sloping . When the general price level is low, businesses aren't as willing to produce goods and services because their profits would be low., As a result, output, real GDP, is low.When prices are high, businesses are more willing to produce goods and services because they have higher profit margins. As a result, real GDP is high.Just like aggregate demand, aggregate supply should seem easy to understand. As you can see on the graph to the left, if the general price level increases from PL1 to PL2, real GDP (output) increases from Y1 to Y2 because businesses are more inclined to produce at a higher price level in order to make big profit.This curve is meant to illustrate the tendencies of businesses as producers. Never will you actually see an economy "move along" the AS curve as pictured in the graph. An economy's state will always be at the intersection point of the AS curve, and the AD curve. Yoll learn more about this in the next chapter.
fields.title: As Curve

fields.content:
This is the most important part of the chapter. It's way shorter than the aggregate demand chapter's section. The only thing that will shift the AS curve is a change in the per unit cost of production of goods. Anything that changes this and only this, will shift the AS curve.A decrease in the per unit cost of production will shift the AS curve to the right like in the graph to the left. If the per unit cost of production decreases, businesses will have higher profit margins. Therefore, they will be more willing to producemoregoods and services at every price level. This marks an increase in aggregate supply and a shift in the AS curve to the right.If the per unit cost of production increases, businesses will have lower profit margins, and will thus be less willing to produce goods and services at every price level, decreasing aggregate supply and shifting the AS curve to the left.I'll give some examples below. Make sure you understand them instead of trying to memorize all the scenarios.
  • Scenario: The government increases excise taxes on tobacco.
      • *Excise taxes are taxes on specific commodities, such as tobacco. They are applied to the producers of such goods. Yes, producers can pass the tax down and increase sale prices, but often producers still end up paying for it through a cut in their profit margins. Therefore, increasing excise taxes increases the per unit cost of production of such goods.
    • An increase in excise taxes would increase the per unit cost of production. This would decrease aggregate supply and shift the AS curve to the left.
  • Scenario: The government increases subsidies for businesses across the country.
      • *Subsidies are forms of grant money offered from the government to businesses producing certain commodities. They're essentially the opposite of excise taxes because they can increase businesses' profit margins by decreasing their expenses. Therefore, increasing subsidies decreases the per unit cost of production of such goods.
    • An increase in subsidies would decrease the per unit cost of production. This would increase aggregate supply and shift the AS curve to the right.
  • Scenario: The price of oil decreases.
      • *Businesses use oil to run factories, provide transportation, etc. If the price of oil dropped, businesses' expenses would decrease. Therefore, decreasing oil prices decreases the per unit cost of production.
    • A decrease in the price of oil would decrease the per unit cost of production. This would increase aggregate supply and shift the AS curve to the right.
  • Scenario: New technology increases the productivity of factory machines.
    • If advances in technology increases the productivity of factory machines, the per unit cost of production will decrease. This would increase aggregate supply and shift the AS curve to the right.
      • **I hope that some of you picked up on this. Technology is a factor of production. Better technology increases the quality of factors of production, which will result in long term economic growth. So, new technology can have two different effects.
  • Scenario: The federal minimum wage is increased.
      • *An expense all businesses have is wages to their employees. If the federal minimum wage is increased, businesses across the country would have larger expenses. Therefore, increasing the federal minimum wage would increase the per unit cost of production.
    • If the government increases the federal minimum wage, the per unit cost of production would increase. This would decrease aggregate supply and shift the AS curve to the left.
  • *Challenge* Scenario: A 1000 square foot oil field is discovered in Texas.

Supply Shocks

Supply shocks are events that cause large increases in resource costs, such as oil. These price increases raise the per unit cost of production; therefore, supply shocks decrease aggregate supply, which shifts the AS curve to the left.

Summary

By now, you should have an idea of aggregate supply can be changed and how it will shift the AS curve. The answers I gave are common to the scenarios presented, but by no means are they guaranteed to be true. The AP exam will usually phrase questions in such a way that you will know what they're looking for.For example, the exam may ask: "How could increasing the federal minimum wage decrease aggregate supply?" With this question, you know the answer I gave above is applicable because the end result answered the actual question. Yoll never get one of the scenarios above without a direction for the answer.***My answers are pretty much exactly how you should phrase them when answering problems on the AP exam (and also just thinking about the problems in general). It may seem repetitive to write all of that for a question, but it's what I'd do if I were you.
fields.title: Shifting the as Curve

fields.content:
In the broad sense, money is anything that is widely accepted as payment for goods and services. Usually, money takes the form of print (e.g. dollars) or coins. There are three functions of money:

Medium of Exchange

Money is used to buy and sell goods and services. Before money was used as currency, people used to have to barter by trading goods and services (e.g. one goat for three lambs). Money has made the process of obtaining goods and services much easier by being a medium of exchange.

Unit of Account

Money can be used to evaluate the worth of goods and services. For example, one might say that a tennis racket is worth $30. Using money as a means to appraise goods and services is essential to its use as a medium of exchange.

Store of Value

People keep money in banks or on hand as a means to store their wealth. It's better and more convenient to hold your fortune in money instead of buying $100,000 worth of laptops with it because money's value is retained over time (unlike laptops), and because money is liquid, or immediately available as a medium of exchange. Like the ones above, this is just kind of common sense.
fields.title: Money

fields.content:
Money is not always just dollar bills and coins. It can take several forms. The following forms of money are ordered in descending liquidity, or immediate availability to use. I'm going to be honest; these aren't extremely important to know, but here they are anyway:

M0

M0 is physical currency, such as bills and coins. This is the most liquid form of money because it's universally accepted as immediate payment for goods and services.

M1

M1 includes all of M0, along with demand deposits (checking accounts).

M2

M2 includes all of M1, along with money market funds, savings accounts, and small time deposits.

M3

M3 includes all of M2, along with large time deposits.
fields.title: Types of Money

fields.content: Biotechnology is the application of genetic engineering where DNA and genetic materials are manipulated for some purpose. The DNA created from this application of engineering comes from various organisms and is termed recombinant DNA. An example of this would be manipulating bacterial DNA to get it to produce insulin needed for diabetes patients.
fields.title: Biotechnology Overview

fields.content: The common method used to manipulate DNA is through special bacterial DNA called plasmids. Plasmids are small circular pieces of DNA that bacteria have in them floating around. Their use consists of pulling these plasmids out of the bacteria cells, inserting desired genes into them, and then reinserting them into the bacteria so that they may replicate and become recombinant DNA. Furthermore, once the modified bacteria cell reproduces, more and more cells will have the capabilities of the original engineered bacteria cell.The key part of the creation of recombinant DNA is how exactly the DNA is inserted. Special enzymes called restriction enzymes are used to cut the plasmid to open it up. Restriction enzymes are very specialized and are only able to cut at specialized nucleotide sequences. These specialized sequences are called restriction sites. When a cut is made at a restriction site, two possible openings are created. One opening is called a sticky end and only occurs if the cut occurs ina staggered way. The other opening is called a blunt end; this cut occurs straight through. ***Note- only sticky ends can fit with other sticky ends; the same goes for blunt ends. For sticky ends, it really depends on the orientation of the cut to see if two fragments will fit. Finally, DNA ligase is used to seal the fragments together.
fields.title: Bacteria: The Key to Manipulating Dna

fields.content:
There are several procedures used in biotechnology labs to harness the power of DNA cloning and recombination. The following includes important procedures or terms that are frequently used in genetic engineering:

  • genomic library: many times a large database of DNA is kept for reference and frequent use. A genomic library holds hundreds of plasmids, each one recombined with some inserted DNA from restriction enzymes.
  • complimentary DNA: this is DNA produced from mRNA through the use of reverse transcriptase, and enzyme that turns mRNA into DNA
  • cDNA library: a genomic library of cDNA
****Procedures...
  • nucleic acid hybridization: this is used to help find a gene of interest within a genomic library. Here, a nucleic acid probe, that has the complimentary sequences to the desired DNA segment, is radioactively labeled, so that it will glow. The cell under inspection will then be treated with heat to break open the cell and denature the DNA. Then, the probe can search and hybridize to the correct complimentary DNA fragment and glow. Thus the desired gene is found.
  • Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR): a common way to amplify DNA, meaning the quantity of a desired piece of DNA is created. This is a quick way to produce massive quantities of DNA. The gene of interest is added to a soluton of primers, heat-resistant DNA polymerase, and four nucleotides. The solution is then heated to open up the DNA, then cooled so the primers can H-bond to the complimentary code. Finally, the polymerase is added and it builds the complimentary sequence and attaches them to the 3' end of the primers. This short procedure is repeated many many times to amplify the DNA.
  • gel electrophoresis: a lab procedure that separates nucleic acids, DNA fragments, and proteins according to their size and charge. Remember, size is inversely proportional to distance traveled, so shorter fragments go farther in the gel. The whole apparatus used is based on an electric current driven through the gel. Since the DNA is negatively charged because of their phosphate groups, they move away from the negative side and toward the positive side.
  • Southern blotting: a technique that combines gel electrophoresis and nucleic acid hybridization where fragments travel in gell and hen are transferred to another testing area, usually nitrocellulose paper where the desired gene is found through bonding with a complimentary strand that radioactively glows.
fields.title: Application of Genetic Engineering

fields.content: Biotechnology is the application of genetic engineering where DNA and genetic materials are manipulated for some purpose. The DNA created from this application of engineering comes from various organisms and is termed recombinant DNA. An example of this would be manipulating bacterial DNA to get it to produce insulin needed for diabetes patients.

fields.content:
Overall cell communication is made up of several signal transduction pathways. A signal transduction pathway is defined as the process of turning a signal on cell's surface or within the cell into a cellular response. There are essentially three stages in communication through a pathway:

  • reception - involves the binding or reception of a signal on or inside a cell
  • transduction - series of steps that convert the signal into readable information for the cell structures working at the destination of the signal.
  • response - the cell structures acting after the transduced signal is read.
Lastly, there are two types of cell signaling: long distance and local. Long distance signalling includes the nervous system and hormones; both of these examples spread a signal large distances from the signals origin. Local regulators include the neurotransmitters released at neural synapses and cystolic communication through plasmodesmata and gap junctions. Now, lets go in depth inside each of the steps within cell communication...
fields.title: Cell Communication Overview

fields.content:
Reception usually beings with a ligand, or a signalling molecule, binding to a receptor protein; sometimes this causes a change in the shape of the receptor protein inducing transduction. There are some special types of receptors that need to be known in depth for the AP. The first three work with the plasma membrane while the last one is intracellular.

  1. G-protein linked receptors: when a ligand binds to this receptor, a G-protein will be activated. This occurs through the replacement of a GDP molecule attached to the G-protein with a GTP molecule. The G-protein then goes on to turn on another membrane bound enzyme, which triggers the transduction. After activating another enzyme, the G-protein is deactivated; all of this happens within thr cystol. This type of reception is used by several neurotransmitters and hormones and occurs in development and sensory reception.
  2. Receptor tyrosine kinases: these can trigger many different pathways instead of just one. Once a ligand binds to two receptors, they form a dimer. The tyrosine kinase (bottom) tail of rach receptor on the cytoplasmic side becomes phosphorylated after reception. These phosphorylated tyrosines now serve as a binding dock for an array of relay proteins. Once these relay proteins activate, they can trigger multiple pathways.
  3. Ligand-gated ion channels: this receptor changes shape when a ligand binds to it. The ligand either opens or closes a "gate" within the receptor protein that regulates the flow of a certain ion. Usually, the activation or decativation of such a receptor will change the ion concentration within the cell, and in turn cause a cellular response. Neurotransmitters in the synapse function like this.
  4. Hydrophobic messengers:some ligands that are hydrophobic cross through the cell membrane and bind ot receptor swithin the cytoplasm or even the nucleus. Steroid hormones sometimes act like this to influence the production of proteins by acting as a transcription factor within the nucleus.
fields.title: Reception

fields.content: Signal transduction pathways often allow a small signal to be amplified through relaying of the signal to produce a bigger cellular response. Relay proteins become very important in transduction as they transfer signals between receptors and the proteins that cause a response. Protein kinases are enzymes that often act in phosphorylating proteins by stripping phosphates from ATP. Thus, the activated protein is enabled to continue to communication. Protein phosphatases are enzymes that work against kinases. They dephosphorylate and "turn off" certain proteins after they have done their job. Second messengers are water-soluble molecules that relay a signal from a first messenger further along the pathway. Examples include cAMP (cyclic AMP) and calcium ions (when G-protein receptors or kinases are used).
fields.title: Transduction

fields.content: These transduction pathways can result in an array of responses including activation of transcription factor (manipulate the expression of certain genes), activation of cytoplasmic enzymes, open or closure of protein channels, etc. Another important thing to not about these signal transduction pathways is how much they can amplify a resoonse from a signal cascade incolving hundreds of kinases and relay proteins to produce one or multiple responses.
fields.title: Response

fields.content: Apoptosis is signaled cell death. Lysosomes and break down organelles and everything is packaged into vesicles.These vesicles are then phagocytically swallowed by scavenger cells. Regardless of the reason for apoptosis, this process is one of the best examples of a signal transduction pathway. Ligands are released in response to damaged DNA, diseased cells, and cancerous cells too.
fields.title: Apoptosis

fields.content: There are a couple types of respiration. There is fermentation - the breakdown of sugars without the use of oxygen to release energy. Aerobic respiration involves the breakdown of some organic material using oxygen to release energy. Finally, there is anaerobic respiration, which is like fermentation only sugar is not the organic material used. The common theme here is that respiration is a catabolic process, one in which things are broken down and energy is released. The way in which energy is released within these processes is through redox reactions. These reactions consist of the transfer of electrons between molecules. The molecule that receives the electrons is called the oxidizing agent, while the molecule that loses an electron is called a reducing agent. In most of these processes, oxygen is the main oxidizing agent due to its large electronegativity. ***When these electrons are transferred, they incrementally lose potential energy. It is this potential energy that is used in respiration.The first form of respiration we will explore is aerobic respiration. There are three steps in this process: glycolysis, the citric acid cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation.
fields.title: Review: Catabolic Reactions and Redox Reactions

fields.content: Glycolysis is a process which takes place in the cystol and doesn't require oxygen. The whole process consists of breaking down glucose down into two pyruvate acid molecules. Specifically, two ATP molecules are split into two G3P molecules, a common organic intermediate. Then the G3Ps are converted into pyruvate, yeilding 2 NADH and 4 ATPs by substrate-level phsophorylation (enzymes transfer phosphate groups to ADP from a substrate). Thus glycolysis yields 2 net NADH and 2 net ATP.On a side note, glycolysis is a very primitive energy harvesting process that is common to aerobic respiration and fermentation. Thus it can be said to be an evolutionary link between eukaryotes and prokaryotes, who did it before oxygen was widely available in the atmosphere.
fields.title: Glycolysis

fields.content: The pyruvate molecules produced in glycolysis are moved into a mitochondria where they are modified through several steps into a compound called Acetyl CoA. This interm transformation involves the reduction of NAD+ into NADH. Acetyl CoA is the starting compound of the citric acid cycle. It is added to oxaloacetate to form citrate, which is then decomposed back to oxaloacetate. This is what makes up one turn of the cycle. Each glucose molecule fuels two turns of the cycle, with each turn of the cycle producing three NADH and FADH2 (like NADH), one ATP, and one CO2 which exits the cycle.
fields.title: Citric Acid Cycle

fields.content: There are two parts to oxidative phosphorylation:- The Electron Transport ChainThe cristae of mitochondria (inner structural folds) have many little electron transport chains embedded within them. The chain is comprised of proteins that facilitate the reduction and oxidation of the electron carriers of respiration (NADH and FADH2). A these proteins reduce and oxidize these electron carriers in assembly line fashion. The potential energy harnessed the proteins is used to pump hydrogen ions into the intermembrane space. This pumping of hydrogen ions sets up the second step of oxidative phosphorylation.- ChemiosmosisThe pumping of hydrogen ions creates a concentration gradient of hydrogen ions which naturally flows from the intermembrane space to the mitochondral matrix. At the end of the electron transport chain, there lies the most important protein in the chain: ATP synthase. As the concentration gradient builds up, the hydrogen ions are forced from the intermembrane space to the mitochondrial matrix. The only place for the hydrogen ions to travel with the gradient is through ATP Synthase. This protein is built with a rotor mechanism, so that as hydrogen ions travel with the proton gradient, the rotor turns and catalyzes the phosphorylation of ADP. Generally, 32 to 33 ATP molecules are created through this process.***In total, one glucose molecule yields about 36-38 ATP molecules. However, it should be noted that cellular respiration only functions with 40 percent efficiency, and the rest is released as heat.
fields.title: Oxidative Phosphorylation

fields.content: Many organisms create ATP energy without using oxygen; they're electron transport chains (ETC) don't use oxygen as their final electron acceptor. These organisms use anaerobic respiration. Organisms with no ETC or that generate ATP without oxygen undergo fermentation. There are two main types of fermentation. Humans sometimes undergo lactic acid fermentation in which pyruvate is reduced to lactate and NAD+ is recycled constantly from NADH; this only happens when oxygen supplies are low. Alcohol fermentation occurs with other organisms where pyruvate is converted to acetaldehyde and carbon dioxide is released. Overall, fermentation is much less efficient than aerobic respiration.
fields.title: Fermentation and Anaerobic Respiration

fields.content: Like most mechanisms, respiration is controlled through negative feedback to maintain metabolic efficiency. When the organism has adequate levels of ATP, the ATP molecules inhibit enzyme phosphofructokinase in glycolysis to slow down the whole system. This enzyme is also inhibited by citrate from the citric acid cycle. This inhibition works to synchronize all three processes in cellular respiration and increase efficiency.
fields.title: Respiration and Feedback Mechanisms

fields.content:
The cell membrane is selectively permeable and a fluid mosaic. All these two words are saying is that cell membranes only let certain things in and out of the cell and that the membrane is constantly moving and fluid. A cell membrane maintains its selective permeability through its makeup and embedded transport structures.Cell membranes are usually made up a phospholipid bilayer. Hydrophilic heads face the outsides of the membrane and the hydrophobic tails make up the middle of the membrane. To give you a visual, the heads would be the cookie part of an oreo while the tails would be the white stuffing. However, this bilayer is filled with scattered proteins that serve various functions.The cell membrane is held together by hydrophobic interactions as the lipid bilayer is in constant motion. The phsopholipid layers move about each other; it looks like they are vibrating if viewed through a microscope. The proteins in the layer are attached to cytoskeleton structures. Now lets look a little more closely at these proteins. Note that their function varies by the type of cell that the membrane belongs to...- Membrane Proteins:

  • Integral proteins: extend through the membrane with two hydrophobic ends
  • Peripheral proteins: attached to one of the surface of the membrane, often to an integral protein.
Often times, these proteins will have modified carbohydrates attached to them that function in cell-cell recognition. These are usually glycoproteins or glycolipids.
fields.title: Cell Membrane Structure

fields.content: A cell membrane can naturally allow hydrophobic molecules through itself, but hydrophilic molecules have a harder time. This is due to the fact that the middle of the bilayer is made up of hydrophobic fatty acids. Thus, its simple for nonpolar molecules to move across the membrane.Transport proteins help polar molecules travel across the membrane. Channel proteins are often specific for a specific molecule, like water or sodium ions. Carrier proteins bind and transport molecules and then release them.
fields.title: Membrane Permeability

fields.content:
Passive transport or diffusion is the movement of something from an area of high concentration to an area of location of low concentration, or along the concentration gradient. No energy is used when a cell uses passive transport.Osmosis is a type of passive transport, specifically regarding the movement of water. Water moves down its own concentration gradient, and this depends heavily of the solute concentration of where water is moving. This is due to the fact that a solute will bind to water, reducing the quantity of molecules able to move across a membrane.Water potential is the measure of a sample of water to move from one are to another. The water potential of only water is 0. Water potential slowly gets more negative as solute is added, since less water is able to move. Also, remember water always moves from a less negative to a more negative water potential area.Three types of water environments are important to know for the AP test:

  • isotonic - there are equal solute concentrations on either side of a membrane, thus tehre will be no net movement of water
  • hypotonic - the solute concentration inside a cell is greater than outside, thus water will move into the cell and cause swelling or even lysis (bursting) of the cell.
  • hypertonic - the solute concentration outside a cell is greater than inside, thus water will move out the cell and cause shriveling of the cell.
fields.title: Passive Transport

fields.content: This consists of polar molecules moving though a membrane with the help of transport proteins but without the use of energy. Water does this with protein channels called aquaporins, which speed up diffusion. Ion channels or gated channels function in this manner as well. Many of these proteins will change shape when a required molecule attaches to it, and this shape change moves this molecule across.
fields.title: Facilitated Diffusion

fields.content:
Active transport is the movement of molecules across a membrane using energy. This involves movement of molecules from an area of low concentration to an area of high concentration, against the concentration gradient.- Specific Types of Active Transport:

  • sodium-potassium pump - exchanges sodium and potassium ions across human and other animal cell membranes creating a high concentration of potassium and a low concentration of sodium within the cell; used heavily in the nervous system
  • voltage gated channels - protein channels that open only when there is an electrochemical gradient created across a membrane; they are opened to reduce the magnitude of the gradient and restore equilibrium
  • cotransport - active transport is indirectly driven by a pump that moves two substance against its gradient simultaneously
  • exocytosis - release of large molecules by fusion of vesicles with the cell membrane
  • endocytosis - the intake of a large molecule by pinching off of the cell membrane
    • phagocytosis - endocytosis done with a food particle
    • pinocytosis - done with liquid molecules
fields.title: Active Transport

fields.content: DNA, or deoxyribonucleic acid, is the most common genetic material used in eukaryotes. It has a twisted double helix structure with side chains made up of phosphate-sugars and the two chains connected in the middle by nucleic bases. There are two classes of bases. Purines are one type and the bases that are most common are adenine and guanine. Pyrimidines are the other type of base; the main bases are cytosine and thymine. ***Note- when pairing bases, adenine ALWAYS has to go with thymine and guanine ALWAYS has to go with cytosine. They wont pair in any other fashion in DNA.
fields.title: Dna Overview

fields.content: Replicating DNA is basically the way DNA copy's itself before the cell enters mitosis. It is a fast and accurate process that involves many different enzymes and proteins. Replication begins a special points called origins of replication. These points are where a special enzyme called helicase unwinds the double helix forming an elliptical DNA "bubble The two ends of this bubble are called replication forks. Downstream past both replication forks, enzymes called topoisomerases keep the DNA from twisting or breaking during replication. A couple more terms need to be known before we jump into the active coping process. In DNA, each nucleotide is attached to its own phosphate group at its 5' carbon and connects to the adjacent nucleotide at the 3' carbon. Finally, in DNA replication there is a leading strand and a lagging stand. I will clear this up below as to what these two terms actually mean.The actual process of copying DNA begins with the placement of a RNA primer by the enzyme primase. This primer is critical to starting the new strand and later will be replaced by actual DNA code. DNA polymerase III is the main enzyme that copies the DNA onto a new strand. *** Polymerase only replicates DNA in the 5' to 3' direction. Usually what will happen is that the primer will be placed in the center of the strands; in the bubble, each strand runs antiparallel, so the top strand will go 5' to 3' from left to right while the bottom will go 5' to 3' right to left.The leading strand will be a continuous strand that is copied in the 5' to 3' direction from the primer to the replication fork. The lagging strand will sit behind the leading strand and will be built from several shorter segment of DNA called Okazaki fragments. They are formed in the 5' to 3' direction from the replication fork back to the primer in the center of the bubble strand. Each okazaki fragment requires a primer to start it. The leading and lagging strand are bound after DNA polymerase I replaces the primers with DNA ligase seals the fragments together.Errors in replication are prevented by proofreading done by DNA polymerase and other enzymes. Damaged DNA is cut out by nuclease (another enzyme) and the fix is made by polymerase and ligase. Yep, thats about it...wait. One more thing. TELOMERES!!!As DNA is replicated, it also is slowly degraded and shortened because polymerase cannot attach more DNA to the 5' end of the strands. Telomeres solve this problem. They are multiple repetions of some short nucelotide sequence. Telomerase is the enzyme that lengthens telomeres after polymerase creates them.
fields.title: Replicating Dna

fields.content: Transcription is the process of transferring genetic code from DNA to RNA. This will serve as a template for the creation of proteins later in translation. RNA is different from DNA- it uses ribose as its sugar, it is single stranded, and thymine is replaced by a different base called Uracil. Transcription happens in both prokaryotes and eukaryotes; the difference lies between them in that prokaryotes can transcribe DNA instantaneously while in eukaryotes the RNA that is created must travel outside the nucleus after being produced.The type of RNA created from transcription is called messenger RNA or mRNA. Transcription starts at a special DNA sequence called the promoter. RNA polymerase binds to the promoter and starts the whole show. At the other end of the process, a squence of nucleotides called the terminator signals RNA polymerase to stop. There are a couple other structures that make sure RNA transcription occurs at the right place. Transcription factors exist in eukaryotes that bind to the promoter and attract the polymerase to it. The polymerase unwinds the helix at the promoterand joins the complimentary nucleotides to the 3'end of the mRNA strand. Once the polymerase hits the terminator, it releases the DNA and the helix structure reforms.
fields.title: Transcription: Dna to Rna

fields.content: Two things are added to mRNA to prevent degredation of code after the strand travels outside of the nucleus. A poly-A tail is added to the 3' end while a string of guanine nucleotides are added to the 5' end; its called a 5' cap. Additionally, these two additions may help with the strands attachment to ribosomes.
fields.title: Mrna Modification

fields.content: DNA is more complex in eukaryotes. One of its special qualities are its long and numerous non coding section called introns. The stretches of code that are actually expressed and synthesized into proteins are called exons. RNA splicing is the process of cutting out the introns out of a strand of pre-mRNA and joining the remaining exons. Spliceosomes are special protein complex that carry out this splicing.
fields.title: Splicing Rna

fields.content: Translation occurs when mRNA meets tRNA, or transfer RNA. Side note- tRNA is synthesized in the nucleus and moves to the cytoplasm where it is repeatedly used. tRNA carries required amino acids to ribosomes as a ribosome attaches to and reads a strand of mRNA. This whole process is centered around the reading of codons. Codons are units of three nucleotides that are grouped together and read, almost like a letter. There can be multiple codons for one amino acid; its up to the tRNA to recognize the right one.Ribosomes are where the actual reading of codons occurs. There are two subunits of a ribosome that come together to be the facility of translation. These subunits come together when they attach to a mRNA stand. There are three spots that the top unit of a ribosome contains; the bottom unit holds and moves the mRNA while the top reads (kind of). The P-site holds the tRNA holding the growing amino acid chain; the A-site holds the tRNA carrying the next amino acid; the E-site is where the tRNA is released. When the tRNA molecules shift from right to left, the growing amino acid chain is moved to the tRNA in the P-site.The construction of the polypeptide occurs when a start codon is read; it stops when a stop codon (UAA/UGA/UAG) is read.
fields.title: Translation: Mrna to Proteins

fields.content:
Questions about these occurs fairly often on the multiple choice. A mutation is a change in genetic information; it involves either large very significant changes or small unnoticeable ones. There are several types of mutations one should be familiar with...

  • base-pair substitutions: one nucleotide and its compliment are substituted for another pair.
  • missense: a mutation that occurs causing an incorrect amino action do be added
  • point mutations: change that affects only one pair of nucleotides
  • nonsense: point mutations cause a amino acid codon to become a stop codon, stopping polypeptide creation.
  • frameshift: mutations that involve the deletion or addition of a nucleotide pair that do not occur in groups of threes
The danger of these mutations depends on where they happen in a codon and how they affect the proteins overall stucture.
fields.title: Mutations

fields.content: I don't think they will ask you very much if anything at all, but its good to know this concept just in case. The proteins an organism produces comes from the reading of genetic code. Many organisms adjust to changes in their environment; this may cause a need for different proteins. These organisms are able to shift the reading of genetic code to synthesize new proteins due to operons. Operons are like on and off switches for patches of exons and access to them is regulated by the same principles as feedback control. Operons have a promoter and an operator, a gate which is opened and closed in response to environmental changes. The operator is opened and closed by a repressor, the molecule being responded to. Downstream from the repressor lies the genes needed to produce different proteins. And...that's all folks. Now go numb your mind with tv, because that my friend was a lot of reading. :)
fields.title: Operons

fields.content:
There are several types of ecology. Organismal ecology focuses on how the organisms in an ecosystem interact and their specific behavioral and physiological characteristics. Population ecology looks at the size of different populations of organisms in an ecosystem and the affects of this size. Community ecology examines how different organism interact with each other and act as a community within a ecosystem; this type of ecology is the most prominent of the group. Ecosystem ecology studies how chemical cycling and energy flow affect the functioning of ecosystems.Ecosystems are made up of both biotic (living) and abiotic (nonliving) entities. The interaction of biotic characters alters gene pools and affects entire ecosystems. Abiotic factors are equally important. There are four staple abiotic elements.

  1. Temperature is essential because it heavily influences metabolism of organisms. Most organisms function in a small range of temperatures
  2. Water varies by habitat and the abundance of it reflects the organisms and their distribution within an ecosystem
  3. Light/Light energy is the engine driving a majority of ecosystems. The availability of light determines the size and complexity of an ecosystem due to its affects on primary producers (aka plants).
  4. Soil also affect the plant life in an ecosystem and lays the groundwork for the structure of an ecosystem.
Climate is another big element of an ecosystem. An ecosystem's climate is the weather conditions within the area. This determines the light availability, water availability, and temperature of the ecosystem. Fun fact: the tropics are receive the most light energy and the least variability of solar radiation, allowing them to be the most diverse of the world.
fields.title: Ecology Overview

fields.content:
A population is a group of organisms that are the same species occupying the same area in an ecosystem. The individuals in an ecosystem are in frequent contact with each other; they interbreed and share resources regularly. There are two main factors in population ecology that influence all else in population ecology. One is density, or the individuals in a given measure of area. The second is dispersion, which is the spacing of the organisms within an area. Lets look at each in a little more detail...Population density is measured through sampling an area of an ecosystem for individuals of a certain species to get an idea of how many are there total. Now a population's density and size are affected by a couple things. They grow larger through birth and immigration of individuals into the population; they decrease through death of individuals and emigration of individuals out of the ecosystem.The dispersion of a population can come in many forms. A clumping pattern of individuals shows a high level of social interaction between individuals. Uniform distribution indicates competition among individuals and high interaction as well. Random spacing shows a lack of interaction between individuals.-Population Growth Rate ModelsPopulation ecology often times looks at how a population size increases or decreases and how this effects the ecosystem as a whole. Sometimes there may be a math grid-in problem on the AP exam that focuses on these types of growth models. The formula will be given on the formula sheet. The critical variables to be familiar with are...

  • b = per capita birth rate
  • d = per capita death rate
  • N = population size
  • r = rate of population growth
There are two types of growth models: exponential and logistic. The exponential growth model is seen in normally in newer, growing populations that are regrowing from a disaster or filling an empty niche (purpose in an ecosystem). When graphed, it produces a J-shaped curve. In this model, the larger the population grows, the faster the growth rate becomes. A logistic growth model is seem much more often in nature. This is where a population grows exponentially to a point and then growth slows to almost a zero slope. The point at which the growth rate peters off is called the carrying capacity (K), which represents the maximum population size an ecosystem can support. Many times, if a population following the logistic model exceeds the carrying capacity, then limited resources and death rates will naturally restore the population size to carrying capacity or cause the population to die out (due to some extraneous factor). This model produces a S-shaped curve when graphed.-Life History traits and types of organismsThe organisms which inhabit an ecosystem come in different lifestyles, and their lifestyles affect the growth model the population takes on. Life history is a term used to describe how a species reproduces and takes care of its young. Note- each ecosystem's situation is different and natural system will favor a life history based on it's own population densities and other abiotic factors. The first main type of life history is k-selection. Here, traits that increase competitive ability to find resources is favored. K-selection occurs in ecosystems in which population densities are high. Usually, organisms that reproduce less frequently and take more care of their offspring follow k-selection. An example would be humans.R-selection is the second type of life history; it favors maximum reproductive potential with respect to time and quantity. R-selection is prevalent in ecosystem with low density populations. Organisms that trive in r-seletion usually reproduce quickly and have several offspring; they engage in little to no child rearing. An example would be fruit flies.-Population Regulation:Population densities are regulated through two things: density dependent and density independent factors. Density dependent factors are things that affect growth rates of a population proportionally as population density increases. Examples include food and resource supplies, disease, predation, or even accumulation of wastes. Density independent factors are factors that affect growth rates with no correlation to population density. Examples here include weather, climate, or even natural disasters.-Miscellaneous Population Dynamics Info:Population dynamics is the study of the factors that affect populations and the variations that result. Much of this field, for the purpose of this course, focuses on predator-prey cycles and population stability. Predator-prey cycles are the growth and decline of populations of predators and prey in line with each other. Population stability is reaching the carrying capacity and maintaining it; this is basically where there is zero population growth. This can be attained through high birth and death rates or low birth and death rates.
fields.title: Population Ecology

fields.content:
Community ecology is the most important and involved of the ecological topics covered on the test. A community is made up of several different species populations that interact in various with each other and the ecosystem as a whole.

-Community interactions:

Interspecific interactions between different species is very common in a community, and is classified by whether they aid, hurt, or have no visible effect on the organisms involved. One of the most common interactions is interspecific competition between species for a shared, limited resource; this often impacts population size, growth, survival and reproductive success. When competition occurs, the competitive exclusion principle states that the weaker, less efficient competitor will die out.

Each species has its own ecological niche, in other words its role in the environment and usage of resources. An organism's fundamental niche is the complete role it CAN play in the ecosystem; its realized niche is the actual role it ends up playing after all other community members are accounted for. When two species share the same niche, they often cannot coexist due to resource limitation. The competitive exclusion principle takes effect and one species dies out. Another possible scenario involves resources partitioning. This is where the competing species will slightly change their niche to coexist.

Other important interactions include predation, herbivory, and symbiosis.

Predation is basically what you think it is... one organism eating another (prey). Often times, predators and prey adapt to each other in unison, with the predator adjusting after the prey does. Prey often use mechanisms to protect themselves like cryptic coloration, where a non threatening species mimics the coloration of a threatening species to ward off predators. Herbivory is like predation, only this time the organism eats plants. Symbiosis is a relationship between two different species in direct contact with each other. There are three types of symbiosis. Parasitism is where a parasite feeds off a host; its a pretty one way relationship where one benefits and one is hurt. Mutualism is a relationship that benefits both organisms involved. Finally, commensialism is where only one seems to be benefiting from the relationship.

-Community Structure:

A community's diversity is based upon the abundance of different species present in the community and the sheer quantity of individuals within each of the populations. The size of a ecosystem and species diversity are driven by the primary producers of the ecosystem...but we will get into that in a bit.

The tropic structure in a community shows each class of organism, from primary producers to upper level predators. Tropic structures can be represented by food chains, which show the energy transfer between levels, or food webs, which show the specific feeding relationships between prevalent organisms.
