Predation is basically what you think it is... one organism eating another (prey). Often times, predators and prey adapt to each other in unison, with the predator adjusting after the prey does. Prey often use mechanisms to protect themselves like cryptic coloration, where a non threatening species mimics the coloration of a threatening species to ward off predators. Herbivory is like predation, only this time the organism eats plants. Symbiosis is a relationship between two different species in direct contact with each other. There are three types of symbiosis. Parasitism is where a parasite feeds off a host; its a pretty one way relationship where one benefits and one is hurt. Mutualism is a relationship that benefits both organisms involved. Finally, commensialism is where only one seems to be benefiting from the relationship.

-Community Structure:

A community's diversity is based upon the abundance of different species present in the community and the sheer quantity of individuals within each of the populations. The size of a ecosystem and species diversity are driven by the primary producers of the ecosystem...but we will get into that in a bit.

The tropic structure in a community shows each class of organism, from primary producers to upper level predators. Tropic structures can be represented by food chains, which show the energy transfer between levels, or food webs, which show the specific feeding relationships between prevalent organisms.

As each tropic level feeds off the next, energy is lost in the process. ***The energetic hypothesis states that approximately 10% of energy is able to travel up a tropic pyramid (from each level to the next) toward predators. Essentially its more efficient to eat primary producers since no energy has been lost yet. When we eat meats, some energy has already been lost due to the metabolic functions of the animal we just consumed.

Certain species are very important to a community's structure; they can alter the way an ecosystem functions. The dominant species have the highest number of individuals and the largest biomass within the community. They often influence the distribution and suvival of other species, because of their dominant resource usage. An invasive species is like a pioneer within a growing ecosystem. They can fill and grow in an array of empty niches due to a lak of predators. Finally, a keystone species is a species which has a huge impact on the cmmunity and how it functions. They link to multiple tropic levels and keep a balance within the community.
fields.title: Community Ecology

fields.content: Disturbances within an ecosystem can be both good and bad. Although things like storms, droughts, human destruction threaten the existing species and the stability of an ecosystem, they can increase diversity and produce chances for newer species to fill open niches.Ecological succession is essentially the rebirth of an ecosystem after it dies. These transitions usually follow a major disturbance where the ecosystem is severly damaged or completely destroyed. There are two types of succession. Primary succession involves the soil, the basic growing environment of the primary producers, being destroyed. It's a complete turnover. Secondary succession is where the soil remains intact. In both forms, early colonizing organisms facilitate the improvement and habitability of the ecosystem so that they may grow once more.If you think this lesson is long...imagine how long it took me to write it LOL....:'D..... but lets continue.
fields.title: Distrubances and Ecological Succession

fields.content: Ecosystems are powered by solar energy; this energy is converted into usable chemical energy by autotrophs, primarily plants. All other herbivores and carnivores feed of this base amount of chemical energy that plants produce from photosynthesis. Energy is eventually lost from the ecosystem as heat. Thus, energy really functions as a cycle within ecosystems.This energy cycling shows us a couple of things. Firstly, conservation of energy occurs as energy moves through an ecosystem; it flows and converts between forms, but its never lost. Secondly, mass is conserved in ecosystems through chemical cycling and net input/output of the ecosystem as a whole.Tropic levels become important when it comes to understanding energy transfer. Primary producers are autotrophs that synthesize organic compounds using sunlight. Herbivores are primary consumers; secondary consumers are carnivores. Now, the size of an ecosytem is based upon the primary production of that ecosystem, which is the amount of solar energy that is able to be converted by the primary producers. This is because the rest of the trophic levels feed off the primary producers for energy.Lastly, when energy is transffered between tropic levels, the actual energy that makes it to the next level rages from 5-20 perccent. This is called tropic efficiency.
fields.title: Energy Transfer and Ecosystems

fields.content: There is a lot more ideas and notable thinkers who contributed to evolutionary theory over time, but here i will just cover a few of them. In the 1700's, a scientist named Linnaeus created a binomial system for organizing organisms by their genus and species. He also created a heirarchy of groups to organize his binomial system further; essentially, Linnaeus founded taxonomy, or the study of classifying organisms into groups. He laid the basis for our classification or organisms today.Before Darwin came out with the currently accepted view of evolution, a man named Lamarck hypothesized that evolution occurs according to two rules. One, the use/disuse of body parts leads to their subsequent strength or weakness. Second, he stated that offspring can inherit traits that parents have acquired over time. This idea of acquired traits was later proved wrong by Darwin, but both of Lamarck's ideas were accepted as fact for quite some time.Darwins theory of evolution, the currently accepted one, revolves around two ideas: adaptations and natural selection. An adaptation is a change, either physical or behavioral, in an organism that helps it stay alive and pass on its genes through reproduction in a given environment. Natural selection is takes this idea of adaptations a step further. It states that the environment will change naturally and, in the process, some traits of organisms will be selected for. What does that even mean?!?!?! Well, it means that certain traits, like fur color or thickness will be more beneficial in the selecting environment. Thus, organisms possessing these traits will be able to produce more offspring than those without them.
fields.title: A Brief History of Evolutionary Theory

fields.content: Darwin's theory consists of two main ideas. The first is descent with modification. He stated that this modification resulted in all the differences between organisms today. Furthermore, he argued that this linked all organisms to some very distant ancestor; the only reason organisms differentiated was due to environmental selection.The second was natural selection. There are three key points that need to bee remembered about this concept. One, natural selection is a macroevolutionary principle, meaning it functions only on populations. Two, natural selection only acts on the gene pool available, it doesn't create new adaptations...it just chooses the best one from the variations available. Finally, natural selection is completely environmentally based.
fields.title: More About Darwin!

fields.content:
There are several different proofs for the theory of evolution:

  1. Fossil Records: this keeps track of the differences between present and past organisms. These fossils have been examined in terms of anatomy and molecular makeup and have been used to link orgamisms together on a evolutionary level
  2. Homology: similarity of organisms based on common descent over time. The main sources of similarity are homologous structure and vestigial organs. Homologous structures are those that have the same structural elements, but can have different functions. Vestigal organs are structures that have slowly lost their purpose in an organism, but still link the organism to other animals that still display the organ. An example would be the the human appendix.
  3. Comparative embryology or Molecular genetic makeup: these provide a molecular and early developmental view of organisms and the similarities that lie between when compared
  4. Bio-geography: the influence of continental drift on the geographic species distribution. This helps in linking an organism of a specific environment to others that may have lived in similar ones before it.
fields.title: Proof of Evolution

fields.content: Evolution is heavily based on sexual reproduction due to the genetic variability that it provides. Both genetic variation and natural mutation create this variation within sexual reproduction. Genetic variations create the majority of different phenotypes that the environment can naturally select from. Mutations act a little differently. These changes in DNA sequences occur rarely, but when they do they're almost always harmful. Finally, its important to remember that steps in meiosis, like crossing over and independent assortment, add more variation that contributes to slow changes over time.Now, these mechanisms may be a prerequisite to the change within evolution, but several things can regulate these changes and the rate at which they occur. The first on the list is natural selection. Natural selection allows organisms with allele frequencies for more favorable traits to flourish, while those with the less favorable ones have less reproductive and survival "fitness Second, we have genetic drift. This is a condition that only occurs in small populations, where chance causes massive and random changes in allele frequencies. Genetic drift is known as bottleneck effect when a catastrophe reduces the population to a level that did not reflect the previous allele frequencies; flounder effect is genetic drift among a small migratory population. Finally, gene flow, or the movement of alleles between populations, can change allele frequencies as well.
fields.title: Population Evolution

fields.content:
Natural selection is the only evolutionary mechanism that consistently causes adaptive evolution and increase the population of organisms with the highest relative fitness in a certain environment. It's important to remember that natural selection acts on the whole organism and all its phenotypes, not just one or any genotypes.There are three types of selection:

  • Directional selection is where one allele may be favored, most frequently during environmental change.
  • Disruptive selection favors the alleles at opposite ends of the phenotypic range, thus usually the heterozygotes suffer
  • Stabilizing selection favors the intermediate phenotypes and selects against the extremes
Although natural selection may act against some alleles, genetic variation is maintained through ecological factors and balancing selection, where frequencies of two or more phenotypes of a population can be maintained. Often times, frequency-dependent selection results as a phenotype becomes too common and the environment/ecosystem changes in response.
fields.title: Natural Selection: A Closer Look

fields.content:
Speciation is the creation of new species from common ancestors; it increases biological diversity while maintaining unity between them. Speciation can occur through many different situations...A species is defined by the biological species concept, which states that a species is a group of populations that can interbreed naturally and produce viable (healthy) and fertile offspring, but cannot successfully mate with other species. The main mechanism causing speciation is reproductive isolation. This means that two populations are separated by some kind of barrier for a necessary period of time, in which they differentiate to the point of not being able to interbreed. There are two main types of barriers:

  • Prezygotic barriers: these act before a zygote is even conceived, often preventing mating or successful fertilization if gametes do meet. Examples include geographic isolation, mechanical isolation (it doesn't fit...if you catch my drift), behavioral isolation (mating practices are incompatible), etc.
  • Postzygotic barriers: these act after conception; they stop the offspring, usually called a hybrid, from producing offspring by making it infertile or not viable.
However, there are other ways to define species, like based on physical characteristics (morphological species concept), habitat/ecological niche (ecological species concept), or evolutionary linkage (phylogenic species concept). Furthermore, geographic separation is the primary cause of speciation, but it can happen without this separation. Allopatric speciation consists of a geographic barriers causing a gene flow interruption between two populations. Sympatric speciation is more complicated. It involves no geographic barriers, only reproductive ones. Usually sympatric speciation does not occur with animals, rather with plants or organisms that engage in polyploidy. When it happens in animals, it involves primarily different resource usage within an area.Well...that too was a large lesson, but thats AP Bio i guess. I hope yore having some fun and this website is helping.
fields.title: Speciation

fields.content:
Some common terms are needed to be learned to follow the explanations in this unit. Get ready for some reading, because there's a lot of them...

  • gene- genetic material on a chromosome that holds the code for creating and building a trait or protein.
  • allele- one type of many different genes for a trait. For example, there is a gene for hair color and there are alleles for both black and brown hair.
  • homologous chromosomes- pair of chromosomes that contain the same genetic information and are basically copies of each other. During sexual reproduction, each parent gives one chromosome in the pair. When looked at under a microscope and slide, it looks like a "X"
  • recessive and dominant genes- when parents give their offspring alleles, they may not contribute the same allele. When alleles are different, some alleles are expressed over others. Thus, they are termed dominant; alleles that are covered up are referred to as recessive.
  • genotype- written down representations of a persons actual alleles for a genetic trait. Usually, each allele contributed is represented by a letter. Each genotype only has 2 alleles. A dominant allele is written as a capital letter (B); a recessive one is written as a lower case letter (b). There are three genotypic conditions. Homozygous dominant refers to having two dominant alleles (BB); homozygous recessive is the same thing only with recessive alleles (bb); heterozygous refers to having one dominant and one recessive allele (Bb).
  • phenotype- the actual expression of a trait. Examples include the color of your hair, eyes and skin.
fields.title: Genetics and Heredity Overview

fields.content:
A monk named Gregor Mendel studied the inheritance of traits, such as pea color, in pea plants and was able to develop two laws that gave the randomness of genetic inheritance some order...

  1. Law of independent assortment- a law which states that the migration of each sister chromatid during meiosis doesnt affect the movement of any other chromosomes. Hence, genes are affected by generally only one set of alleles
  2. Law of segregation- each gamete contains only one copy of a chromosome, thus each copy of a allele separates to a different gamete
fields.title: Mendelian Laws of Genetics

fields.content: There are generally two types of crosses that you will have to work with in this course: monohybrid and dyhibrid crosses. Crossing means taking two parents genotypes and mixing them as if they had mated. Punnet squares are the most common chart representation of a cross of genotypes. It shows possible genotypes of the offspring. A monohybrid cross is a cross involving only one set of alleles per parent in the cross. An example of this would be like BB x Bb (a homozygous dominant person's alleles are mixed with a heterozygous genotype). A dihybrid cross involves two sets of alleles per parent contributing to a genotype. An example would be AaBB x aaBb. A monohybrid cross would only have four squares; a dihybrid would have 16.
fields.title: Genetic Crossing

fields.content: There are multiple ways genes are inherited by an offspring. The type of inheritance that has already been covered is called complete dominance. This is where one allele covers the other and the dominant phenotype always shows if a dominalant allele is present. Incomplete dominance is where one allele doesn't completely cover another, but when two alleles come together in the heterozygous condition, blending of traits occurs. For instance, if a flower is red in the homozygous dominant condition but white color in a homozygous recessive, incomplete dominance would render the heterozygous flower pink. Codominance is where the heterozygous will express both the recessive and dominant alleles. In the slower example, codominance would create a flower with some red and some white petals.In some cases, there are multiple genes for a trait. This most commonly occurs with blood type. Each different blood type (A, AB, B, and O) has its own genotype. There are two varieties of the dominant alleles (IA, IB) that are equally strong, and the homozygous recessive condition creates type O blood (ii).We're almost done! Hang in there. So... a couple more inheritance patterns. Epistasis is when one gene affects another completely separate gene, like dependent inheritance. Pleiotropy is when one gene affects several phenotypic traits. Polygenic inheritance is the opposite, it's where multiple genes affect a single trait. An example of this is height!Sex-linked inheritance is when a trait is inherited from a sex chromosome. Some of these genes may be X-linked or Y-linked. Note that a female has two X chromosomes, and a male's sex genotype is XY.
fields.title: Inheritance

fields.content: Gene linkage refers to genes that are very close together on the same chromosome and are almost always inherited together as a result. These genes don't follow the law of segregation because of their proximity to each other on a chromosome. During crossing over in meiosis I, if two genes have a crossover rate about 50%, it generally points to gene linkage.
fields.title: Gene Linkage

fields.content: This is a technique used to figure out an unknown genotype by crossing that genotype with a homozygous recessive genotype, and then analyzing the offspring to deduce the unknown genotype.
fields.title: Test Crossing

fields.content: These are really simple math problems found on the Grid-in portion of the AP exam. Hardy-Wineburg is a theoretical system that allows us to calculate the allelic frequencies and genotypic frequencies within a population. One allele is represented as "p" and the other as "q The genotypes are represented as follows: homozygous dominant is p^2 (p squared), homozygous recessive is q^2 (q-squared), and heterozygous is pq. These are the main formula for figuring out these problems.What the first formula is saying is that the homozygous dominant, heterozygous, and homozygous recessive percentages of individuals in a population will always equal to 100 percent or 1. The second formula says that the allelic frequencies of each allele for a gene will always add up to 100 percent or 1.Damn, that was a looooonnnnggg lesson. Go take a break kiddo! Unless yore cramming for this exam...then i sadly must urge you to go the next lesson.
fields.title: Hardy-Wineburg Equilibrium

fields.content: Meiosis I begins with prophase I. This is where the differences are really set up. The nucleus disappears here and the chromatin condenses into chromosomes. Here's where it gets weird. After the chromosomes are fully formed, homologous chromosomes are paired up in a process called synapsis. So, basically when these pairs line up in metaphase I along a metaphase plate, you can see two pairs of sister chromosomes. These units of paired chromosomes are called tetrads. A special process occurs during synapsis called crossing over. This is where adjacent chromosomes within the tetrad will exchange genetic material at a place called chiasmata.After crossing over occurs, the rest of the steps in meiosis I are really the same. The tetrads line up in metaphase I and are separated into two different daughter cells in anaphase. ***Note that because the tetrads separate instead of actual chromosomes, the number of chromosomes is cut in half in meiosis I. The two daughter cells will eventually be haploid after meiosis I. In meiosis II, the chromosome number will be maintained.Meiosis' ultimate purpose is to create sex cells for sexual reproduction. There lie many mechanisms within meiosis to create much needed genetic variation within gametes.
fields.title: Meiosis I

fields.content:
The sexual reproduction that meiosis sets up, results in cells with variable genetic material. This variability is called genetic recombination. Three events are the source for recombination:

  • Crossing over: the exchange of genetic material between adjacent chromosomes in a tetrad furing synapsis create genetic material totally unique from either parent cell.
  • Independent Assortment: the orientation of the tetrads during metaphase I and the separation of each chromosome during anaphase I is random. This randomness means that each gamete doesn't receive the identical set of chromosomes each time duing metaphase and anaphase I.
  • Random joining of assortment: although a female contributes probably only one egg, it is completely random which of the male's sperm cells ends up fertilizing the egg. This adds more variability into the process of sexual reproduction.
fields.title: Genetic Variation

fields.content: A pathway is the steps taken for a process to occur and turn a reactant into a product. As we will soon discuss, enzymes play a role in a majority of these steps by enhancing their spontaneity. There are two types of pathways: anabolic and catabolic. An anabolic pathway involves the build up of smaller molecules into bigger ones through the use of energy; catabolic pathways are the opposite, the involve the breakdown of complex molecules and the release of energy in the process.-Spontaneity of reactions:The equation above is called Gibbs Free Energy Equation. It sums up everything one needs to knwo about energy and if a reaction will proceed on its own or not. The G stands for "free energy"; the H for "enthalpy" (the difference in energy bewtween the reactants and products) ; the T for temperature; the S for entropy (disorder within a system), For the AP, you might need to know how to just plug in numbers for the grid-in section, but not much more than that.With this equation, one must note, a negative delta-G shows a reactions can proceed on its own, while a positive shows it cannot proceed without energy input.
fields.title: Metabolic Pathways

fields.content: The difference between these two types of reactions is crucial information for the free response section. Exergonic reactions release energy and often occur spontaneously; endergonic reactions require energy input and absorb said energy. Thus exergonic has a negative gibbs free energy quantity, while endergonic has a positive gibbs free energy.
fields.title: Exergonic vs Endergonic Reactions

fields.content: ATP, or adenosine triphosphate, is the most commonly used fuel source for harnessing metabolic energy in organisms. The molecule consists of an adenine nitrogenous base, a ribose sugar, and three phosphates. The phosphate section is where ATP gets its functionality. These phosphates are attached by very unstable, high energy bonds. When broken, these bonds release energy that can be used for metabolic work. The breaking of ATP is called dephosphorylation, while the formation is called phosphorylation. Finally, ATP is ususally regenerated through cellular respiration.
fields.title: Atp: The Metabolic Fuel

fields.content: Most of the free energy our body makes available wouldn't be present without the work of enzymes. Enzymes are molecules that speed up, or catalyze, a reaction by reducing the energy input required for the reaction to proceed. This energy input is known as the activation energy. Without enzymes in our bodies, we wouldn't be able to function because the activation energy for most of our bodily processes would not be met.Enzymes lower activation energy in a couple of ways. Almost all enzymes work with one or multiple specific molecules/reactants called substrates. An enzyme will usually join to a substrate to form a enzyme-substrate complex. A substrate usually fits into the active site of an enzyme when it forms this complex. Often times, this active site will have certain side chain/R-groups to facilitate a reaction of the substrate or will put the substrates in such close proximity to each other, the likelihood that the substrates react will increase.Thus, an enzyme will increase the rate of a reaction using its active site. IF one increases the substrate concentration, the reaction rate will level off with respect to time, since the enzymes will become saturated. At this point, only adding more enzyme will affect the reaction rate.
fields.title: Enzymes

fields.content: There remains only a couple things left to talk about with enzymes.Enzyme inhibitors are molecules that disrupt the ability of the enzyme to catalyze a reaction. Inhibitors can be competitive or noncompetitive. Competitive inhibitors actively compete with the substrate to get into the active site and are similar enough to the substrate to fit. Noncompetitive inhibitors do not inhibit from the active site, but rather attach to the enzyme at another location and change the shape of the enzyme and active site, ruining its catabolic abilities.Enzymes frequently work within pathways to produce intermediate and final products. In organisms, feedback regulation controls to what extent certain product are produced for efficiency's sake. ***This is a huge topic on the AP. Feedback refers to a pathway regulating the continuation itself through production of temporary enzyme inhibitors. Negative feedback is when a pathway will slow itself down; Positive feedback involves a pathway speeding itself up and continuing itself. For example, a four step process may produce a end product that inhibits the second step's enzyme from functioning correctly.Finally, location...the function of an enzyme will greatly affect its location withing an organism. This compliments enzymes extreme specificity of substrates for enzymes will proportionally be used where their function is needed.
fields.title: Inhibitors, Feedback, Location...Oh My

fields.content: Eukaryotic cells have DNA within their nuclei. The unit of replication for DNA is a chromosome, which is just tightly coiled DNA to prevent breakages while replicating. In somatic, or body cells, this genetic material comes in copied pairs and thus these cells can be called diploid. Haploid cells are those that contain only one copy of the total number of chromosomes; usually reproductive cells like eggs and sperm (LOL) will be haploid. In humans, diploid cells have 46 chromosomes (two sets of 23) and haploid cells have 23 chromosomes.
fields.title: Genetic Material Within Eukaryotic Cells

fields.content: Cell division is always begins with preceded by copying of the DNA and then coiling of the DNA into chromosomes. Each chromosome has a copy called a sister chromatid. The two sister chromatids are attached initially in the middle by cohesion proteins most closely at the centromere. During Mitosis, the chromosome pairs line up in the middle of the parent cell and then are pulled apart from the centromere by mitotic spindles which arise from a small organelle called centrioles. Once these have been pulled to two opposite ends of the cell, nucleuses begin reforming around the two new sets of chromosomes. Then the cytoplasm divides in a process called cytokinesis. Thus, two new daughter cells are born!
fields.title: An Overview of Cell Division

fields.content: There are several phases of the cell cycle. The two big sections of the cell cycle are mitosis and interphase. A cell spends about 90% of its time in interphase; this is where the cell grows and readies itself for cell division. Interphase is broken into three sub-phases: G1 phase, S phase, G2 phase. The G1 and G2 phases involve growth of the cell in preparation for cell division, while S phase consists of the cell copying DNA and synthesizing chromosomes. Normal development of an eukaryotic cell and ekaryotic organisms depend on a normal, steady progression through these phases and correctly timed mitosis.
fields.title: Cell Cycle Phases

fields.content: The progression of the cell cycle is dependent on a series of cell signals and passing through checkpoints. Chemical signals from cyclically functioning molecules help the cell cycle progress through its three main checkpoints in G1, G2, and M phase (Mitosis phase). *** If a cell never receives a signal to proceed at G1 phase, it exits the cell cycle and enters G0 phase where it does not divide. This frequently happens with mature cardiac muscle cells and nervous cells.
fields.title: Controlling the Cell Cycle

fields.content: There are some very distinct differences between cells that progress normally through the cell cycle and cancer cells which exit and multiply rapidly in no regular cycle. Two characteristics of normal cells include density dependent inhibition and anchorage dependence. Density dependent inhibition consists of the binding of surface proteins on adjacent proteins which sends signals inhibiting further cell division. If there's no space to divide, normal cells will stop dividing. Anchorage dependence is the characteristic of having to be attached to some sort of extracellular matrix or some other layer of tissue. Cancer cells don't exhibit these two characteristics and don't rely on growth factors (chemicals that trigger growth within cells) to divide. They don't follow normal cell cycle checkpoint control and may divide indefinitely. If a cell transforms into a cancer cell, the immune system may destroy it, but if it proliferates it may become a tumor. The key to unlocking the cure to cancer is heavily dependent on making the cell cycle and its control system insanely precise even with age.
fields.title: Cancer Cells vs Normal Cells

fields.content: Carbohydrates are basically sugars. Their function is to be burned or stored as fuel; however, some carbs can be used for structural purposes. The carbohydrate monomer is called a monosaccharide. These have the general chemical formula of (CH2O)n (n signifies how many times you multiply that bases formula). Monosaccharides are linked through dehydration synthesis to form Polysaccharides. They are linked by glycosidic linkages. Note that the function of monosaccharides is to act as quick fuel, whereas polysaccharides act as storage or structural molecules. Starch (plants) and Glycogen (animals) are two storage carbohydrates most common in organisms. Common structural carbohydrates include cellulose, which is used in the cell wall of many plans and other organisms, and chitin, which is utilized by insets and some fungi as an exterior shell.
fields.title: Carbohydrates

fields.content:
Lipids are also used for stored fuel, but play a huge part in making up cell membranes and provide a basis for horomones. Note- lipids cannot be considered macromolecules because there is no definite monomers of them. There are three types of lipids: phospholipids, steroids, and fats.

***The linkage most common in lipids is called an ester linkage

Phospholipids are made of a glycerol molecule linked to two fatty acids and a phosphate group. Phospholipids are interesting because they have a hydrophilic and hydrophobic side, whereas usually all lipids are nonpolar. Hydrophillic means attracted to water; hydrophobic means repelled by water. As a result, phospholipids have a hydrophilic head, and a hydrophobic tail. This dual nature allows them to make up a majority of cell membranes.

Steroids are lipids connected with carbon rings and with several functional groups attached. Their ring shape will always distinguish them. Steroids provide the base for almost all hormones (long distance chemical messengers). Cholesterol is a common steroid in animals.

Fats are the last class of lipid. They consist of three fatty acids attached to a glycerol molecule. Triglycerides are synonymous with Fats. They can be made up of either unsaturated or saturated fatty acids. Unsaturated fatty acids have a double or triple bond, while saturated fatty acids only have single bonds.
fields.title: Lipids

fields.content:
Proteins have a wide range of functions in organisms. They include enzymatic functions, transport, movement, cell signal reception, defense and structure. The monomer of a protein is an amino acid. Amino acids are linked together to form a peptide bond. When this is done multiple times, a polypeptide results. Multiple polypeptides joined together yields a protein. There are four levels of protein structure, since they are so complex.- Protein Structure:

  • Primary: genetically coded amino acid sequence
  • Secondary: polypeptide backbone is folded and coiled; hydrogen bonds are present here and determine the shape of the secondary structure.
  • Tertiary: amino acids can have side chains called R-groups. There side chains interact and determine the tertiary structure of the protein. Depending on the side chain, interactions involve hydrophobic interactions, hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, and covalent bonds.
  • Quaternary- when multiple polypeptides come together, this structure is formed
fields.title: Proteins

fields.content: Nucleic acids are the macromolecules that carry genetic code. They consist of a phosphate group linked to a nitrogenous base. There are two types of bases: Pyrimidines and Purines. Adenine and Guanine are Pyrimidines; Cytosine and Thymine are Purines. That is all you need to know right now, the rest is covered in the DNA section about nucleic acids.
fields.title: Nucleic Acids

fields.content: An autotroph is a organism that produces its own energy, and often undergo photosynthesis. For the purposes of conceptualization, lets look at a plant to examine chloroplast structure, since its the most common autotroph. In a plant, photosynthesis occurs in the mesophyll layer of a leaf. Within the cells of the leaf, there lies a double membraned organelle called a chloroplast. This is where the whole show happens.Within the inner membrane of the chloroplast, a fluid called stroma surrounds a system of membranous sacs called thykaloids. These two structures are the main location for the conversion of light energy into chemical energy. We'll get more involved into how they matter in a bit.
fields.title: Chloroplast Structure

fields.content: The overall formula for photosynthesis is: In this equation, water is split and the electrons harnessed are used to fuel the photosynthetic process, while the oxygens and hydrogens are paired with the carbon dioxide to form glucose (look C.B. Van Neal's bacteria experiment for further details). This equation represents two cycles in one. Solar energy is converted into chemical energy within light reactions. Dark reactions or The Calvin Cycle involve carbon dioxide is mixed with pre-existing organic compounds by carbon fixation. Like many other cases in the world of biology, each of these cycles fuels the other.
fields.title: Photosynthesis Overview

fields.content: Light exists in both wave and photon form. These forms of light are absorbed by pigments of chlorophyll within the chloroplasts. There are three types of pigments most commonly found in plants. Chlorophyll a absorbs violet-blue and red light the best; it is the main pigment of most plants. Chlorophyll b is a accessory pigment, meaning it supports main pigments by broadening the light spectra to help absorb maximum light. Finally, there are carotenoids which are used for photo-protection, essential keeping the chloroplast from absorbing too much light.***There are several types of graphs that depict light absorption by pigment types. Two graphs that frequently show up on the AP are the action spectra and the absorption spectra. An action spectra shows rates of photosynthesis for a pigment under different wavelengths of light. An absorption spectra shows how much light is absorbed for a given pigment at different wavelengths.
fields.title: Photosynthetic Pigments and Chlorophyll

fields.content: Light reactions occur in Photosystems within the thykaloid membrane within chloroplasts. These are multicellular stuctures that contain light harvesting complexes and a reaction center complex. Light harvesting complexes trap solar energy and pass it throughout the photosystem until it reaches the reaction center complex. At this point the two specially joint chlorophyll a molecules within the reaction center will trap the excited electrons that have moved around from each light harvesting complex. These electrons will then be passed to the primary electron acceptor of the photosystem.Before we move on, its important to note that there are two types of photosystems. Photosystem II (PSII) comes first chronologically and its chlorophyll a dimer is called P680; Photosystem I (PSI) comes second and its chlorophyll a dimer is called P700.So lets continue...Once an excited electron is trapped by the primary electron acceptor the reaction center undergoes a redox reaction in which the first chlorophyll a is oxidized, losing its electrons. It's electrons are replenished through the splitting of a water molecule to form hydrogen ions and oxygen gas. The hydrogen ions later become very important. Up to this point, the excited electrons have only moved around. But after the first photosystem (PSII), the electrons enter an electron transport chain in which some the potential energy from the electrons is released by transport proteins. This energy is used to create a proton gradient that powers the synthesis of ATP, much in the same fashion as ATP synthesis in chemiosmosis.Now, these electrons haven't lost all their energy, so they are moved to PSI. PSI utilizes the energy remaining in these partially excited electrons and traps energy in the same way as PSII. The only real difference is that P700 acts as the chlorophyll dimer. After a lot of bouncing around, the electrons move into another ETC where they are used in another redox reaction. Here, NADP+ is reduced to NADPH. Both NADPH and ATP become reactants for the second part of photosynthesis- The Calvin Cycle.
fields.title: Light Reactions

fields.content: In photosynthesis, chemiosmosis is very similar to chemiosmosis in respiration. Both have ETC's built into membranes. In Photosynthesis, the ETC lies in the thykaloid membrane. The proton gradient flows from the stroma into the thykaloid membrane and then diffuses back into the stroma, where ATP is phosphorylated from ADP + P. The ETC here is the initial structure that pumps the hydrogen ions into the thykaloid membrane. This ATP is then used in the Calvin Cycle.
fields.title: Chemiosmosis in Photosynthesis

fields.content:
The Calvin Cycle is very similar to the Citric Acid Cycle. It turns thrice to fixate three molecules of CO2 into one sugar intermediate called G3P. G3P is then transformed into usable, more complex types of sugar like glucose. There are three phases of this:

  1. Carbon fixation- carbon dioxide is added to a five carbon sugar called RuBP forming a unstable six carbon intermdiate. This six carbon molecule almost immediately spits into 2 molecules of 3-phosphoglycerate
  2. Reduction - Each molecule of 3-phosphoglycerate is phosphorylated into another intermediate compound which is reduced by NADPH to create one G3P molecule.
  3. Regeneration of CO2 - this is done to create an acceptor of RuBP at the beggining of the cycle. The rearrangement that happens here requires three ATP.
In total the cycle requires 9 ATP and 6 NADPH to synthesize one G3P. Remember, the products of the Calvin Cycle (NADH+ and ADP + P) are used to fuel the light reaction.
fields.title: The Calvin Cycle

fields.content:
There are a few hallmark differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells:

  • prokaryotic cells have no nucleus or membrane bound organelles; eukaryotic cells do
  • prokaryotic cells have a region of clustered DNA that is unbounded, called the "nucleoid;" eukaryotic cells carry their DNA in the nucleus
  • Prokaryotic cells are usually bateria or archeabacteria, while eukaryotic cells can be animal, plant, or protist
  • Prokaryotic cells are much older, smaller and less complex than eukaryotic cells. It is said that eukaryotic cells have evolved from prokaryotes
Although very different, the two types of cells are similar in that they both have plasma membranes and are filled with a medium called cystol. Prokarytic cells are pretty simple so lets delve into the complexities of eukaryotes.
fields.title: Prokaryotic vs Eukaryotic Cells

fields.content: Eukaryotic cells may contain an array of different organelles which carry out very specific cell functions. Not all cells will have all these organelles, but cell function will determine the structures within the cell. So here we go, there's quite a few of them...- Membranes: enclose the cell and several other organelles to create localized environments for the organelles to function and carry out their chemical reactions. This includes the cell membrane which is made up of a phospholipid bilayer- Nucleus: it holds the cells hereditary information in the form of DNA. Its surrounded by a double membraned nuclear envelope to protect the DNA. This envelope is perforated by small holes called nuclear pores to allow movement of mRNA and ribosomes in and out of the nucleus. The center of the nucleus contains a nucleolus, a thick structure responsible for the creation of ribosomal RNA and the construction of ribosomal subunits.- Ribosomes: made of protein and ribosomal subunits. Their main function is to read genetic information and build needed proteins according to the code sent from the nucleus***The following organelles are in the endomembrane system, the system responsible for most of the cell's chemical activities.- Endoplasmic Reticulum (ER): There are two types of ER, the rough ER and the smooth ER. The main strutureal difference is that the rough ER has bounded ribsomes on its surface while the smooth ER doesn't. The two organelles surround the nucleus and have very different functions. The smooth ER contains enzymes that help synthesize steroid and phospholipids, metabolize carbs, detoxif drugs and poison, and release calcium ions during muscle contraction. The rough ER modifies many proteins that will be secreted from the cell, like glycoproteins. IT also builds membranes for the cell, which are added to the cell membrane or other organelles through transport vesicles (little circular compartments built from the produced membrane).-Golgi Apparatus: made up of flattened sacs and vesicles that produce and modify glycoproteins and other secretory molecules from the cell. The Golgi apparatus also tags these products for different locations, basically functioning as the shipping and tagging center of the cell.- Lysomes: small vesicles containing hydrolytic enzymes bounded by a membrane. They're found primarily in animal cells and are used for breaking down or digesting foreign invaders or macromolecules like food. Also can be important in autophagy, programmed cell death.- Vacuoles: larger membrane bound compartments used for various functions, like holding food (food vacuole), pumping excess water out of the cell (contractile vacuoles), or simply storing water (central vacuoles in plants).***The endomembrane system ends here.- Mitochondria: carries out cellular respiration in cells without chloroplasts. Its main function is to produce ATP for the cells usage using oxidative phosphorylation. It has lots of folds in its membrane to increase its surface area.- Chloroplasts: captures solar energy and utilizes it to make ATP through photosynthesis. Usually found in plants and protists. Both the mitochondria and chloroplasts will be covered more in depth in the cell respiration and photosynthesis chapters.- Cytoskeleton: funtions in mechanical support and motility of a cell. It has three main components: microtubules, microfilaments, and intermediate filaments. Microtubules support the cell's membrane and serve as tracks for motile organelles with the help of motor proteins. Cillia and Flagella on most protists are made out of microtublues. Microfilaments are larger and thicker than microtubules, and provide more solid structural support for the cell and many of its organelles. They are key in the structure of willi and muscle fibers. Intermediate filaments are in between microtubules and microfilaments in terms of size and thickness, and help maintain cell shape.- Cell Wall: composed of microfibrils and cellulose and found in plant cells and many bacteria cells. Its main function is to support the cell it encloses, which is very important in plants bring able to support their own wight without a skeletal system.- Intercellular Junctions: these are found only in multicellular organisms and serve the function of connecting the cystol in cells for communication purposes. In plants, they are known as plasmodesmata. In animal cells, there are three types: tight junctions (hold adjacent cells together), desmosomes (support intermediate filaments to mesh cells into sheetlike structures), and gap junctions (important in cell communications, just like plasmodesmata). These are important in inter cell communication in terms of triggering reactions in a general cellular area.
fields.title: Cell Organelles

fields.content: It's important to remember that a cells function will determine the type and quantity of each organelle it has. For example, a muscle cell will have more mitochondria and less ER since it needs ATP to power its contractions and secretes very few proteins. This will be very important on the AP.
fields.title: Not All Cells Are Created the Same

fields.content: Water is made up of 2 hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom; the oxygen (O) and hydrogen (H) molecules are a special type of covalent bond called a hydrogen bond. Hydrogen bonds are formed between only H molecules and either O, Fluorine (F), or Nitrogen (N). The large disparity between the electronegativities (the ability to attract electrons) between H and O, F, and N (note- H has a very low electronegativity and O, F, and N have large ones). The hydrogen bonds result in an uneven sharing of electrons, with a net negative dipole created near the oxygen and a net positive created near the hydrogen. This uneven sharing causes attractive intermolecular forces to function between water molecules and facilitates water's unique nature.
fields.title: The Polarity of Water

fields.content:
There are four essential properties of water that are integrated into many biological processes:

  • Cohesiveness - the ability of water molecules to attract to other water molecules due to collective polarity.
    • This also relates to adhesion, the ability of water molecules to polarize and attract to other molecules, and high surface tension.
  • Temperature Moderation - the nature of dipole dipole interactions created by Water's H bonds causes it to have very high specific heat. Specific heat is the amount of heat energy gained or lost when a gram of a substances changes its temperature by 1 degree Celsius. With a high specific heat, water is able to take in and release large amounts of energy without having its' internal temperature change.
    • Water Specific heat = 4.184 J/(g * degree Celcius)
    • This specific heat allows water to have a high heat of vaporization and engage in evaporative cooling (cooling of the surface of water when the molecules with the highest energy leave the liquid state)
  • Ice Insulation of Water - H bonding causes water to form a lattice structure while freezing; this lattice structure integrates space/holes into the molecular structure resulting in ice being less dense than water. In nature, it's usually the other way around. Therefore, bodies of water can still support life forms even when the surface freezes, since the lower levels of water remain liquid and habitable
  • Universal Solvent - is a polar covalent solvent due to the dipole's created by H bonding. This means it can help dissolve ionic, polar, and nonpolar compounds (to a certain degree). This makes water a staple biological solvent, since it's able to dissociate many types of solutes and facilitate different reactions and processes
fields.title: Water's Special Properties

fields.content:
Molecules dissociate, or break apart, in varying degrees, and water is no exception. Water dissociates into hydrogen ions (H3O+) and hydroxide ions (OH-). The dissociation concentrations of water determine the pH of solutions, with normal concentrations being 10^-7 M. Note- water is in a situation of dynamic equilibrium, where water molecules constantly dissociate and reform as shown below:

2 H2O ---> H3O+ + OH-

When water interacts with acids and bases in nature, different pH's result depending on the strength of the acid/base. For the purposes of this course, however, you will not have to calculate pH's or know pH range interactions. Buffers are the only essential topic.

A buffer system is a compound that minimizes volatility in hydrogen and hydroxide concentrations. It usually consists of a acid or base, and it's conjugate sitting in equilibrium. These systems are important in nature to control spikes in pH. For example, if human blood leaves it's usual range of pH for a couple minute, one could die. A common buffer system is bicarbonate and its conjugate- carbonic acid (H2CO3 ---> HCO3- + H+)
fields.title: Water Dissociation and Acids and Bases

Relative (Local) Maximums and Minimums

The First Derivative Test

Absolute (Global) Maximums and Minimums

  • There is an absolute (global) maximum at a point if for all x-values between the closed interval
  • There is an absolute (global) minimum at a point if for all x-values between the closed interval

Finding Maximums and Minimums

To find relative maximums and minimums of a function ,

To find absolute maximums and minimums of a functionover a closed interval,

Concave Up

  • A curve is concave up if the curve at a point is above the tangent line to the point
  • A curve is concave down if \(f''(x)<0\)

Concave Down

  • A curve is concave down if the curve at a point is below the tangent line to the point
  • A curve is concave down if

Points of Inflection

Point of Inflection: A point where the curve changes from concave down to concave up or from concave up to concave down

  • A point is a point of inflection if <img align="absmiddle" alt="f{}'{}'(c)=0" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?f{}'{}'(c)=0"/>

The Second Derivative Test

If a point atis a critical point ofsuch that,
  • If , then the point at is a relative maximum
  • If , then the point at is a relative minimum
  • If , then the point at can be a relative maximum, relative minimum, or neither
fields.title: Concavity

fields.content:
We can start to apply what we learned in calculus so far to real life situations through optimization. We look for maximum or minimum values for a function that satisfies a constrain that has to be true no matter what. In a lot of these problems, there is a pattern on how to solve them. These steps are seen below

  1. Identify the constraint and the value to be optimized
  2. Rearrange the constraint equation to solve for one of the variables
  3. Plug this into the equation that needs to be optimized
  4. Differentiate this equation and set it equal to 0
  5. Solve for the values that make it equal to 0
  6. Choose the value that is the maximum or minimum that we are looking for
  7. Solve for the other variables

ex.) A gardener has 300 feet of fencing to enclose three equal sized rectangular garden plots. What dimensions x and y will maximize the total area?

  • The constraint equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/> and the optimization equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total\, \, Area = xy}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;=&space;xy}"/>.
  • We can rearrange the constraint equation to solve for y
  • Plug y into the optimization equation to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total \, \, Area=x\left (75-\frac{x}{2} \right )=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area=x\left&space;(75-\frac{x}{2}&space;\right&space;)=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}"/>
  • Differentiate this to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left (Total \, \, Area \right ){}'(x)=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\left&space;(Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;\right&space;){}'(x)=75-x}"/> and set it equal to 0 to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=75-x}"/>
  • So <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/>
  • Plugging this into <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/>, we get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2(75)+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2(75)+4y=300}"/> which means <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>
  • Therefore our optimal dimensions are <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>

fields.content:
Say we want to find the derivative of a function at a point, point P. If another point, point Q, lies on the same function, the secant line between the two does not look like the tangent line to point P unless points P and Q are very close. This is seen with the graphs below.

As we can see, when P and Q become very close as h approaches 0, the secant and tangent lines look identical. This means that the average rate of change becomes the instantaneous rate of change (the derivative). So when we take the limit of the average rate of change as h approaches 0, we can find the derivative at the point.

  • This can be seen with the equation

This is the definition of the derivative!

fields.content:
When we are taking the derivative of a function that has a function within it, we use the Chain Rule. It states that to find the derivative of a composite function, we find the derivative of the outside function first, then multiply it by the derivative of the inside function as seen below.

If we substitute u for g(x), this can be rewritten as

Another variation for the Chain Rule can be written as

Ex.) Find the derivative of .

We can substitute this to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left ( u\right )^{5}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&amp;space;\left&amp;space;(&amp;space;u\right&amp;space;)^{5}}"/>.
  • The derivative of <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left ( u\right )^{5}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\left&space;(&space;u\right&space;)^{5}}"/> is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 5\left ( u\right )^{4}\cdot \frac{\mathrm{d} u}{\mathrm{d} x}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;5\left&space;(&space;u\right&space;)^{4}\cdot&space;\frac{\mathrm{d}&space;u}{\mathrm{d}&space;x}}"/>.
  • Since <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} u=\left (x^{3} +4x-3 \right )}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;u=\left&space;(x^{3}&space;+4x-3&space;\right&space;)}"/>, <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \frac{\mathrm{d} u}{\mathrm{d} x}=\left (3x^{2} +4 \right )}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\frac{\mathrm{d}&space;u}{\mathrm{d}&space;x}=\left&space;(3x^{2}&space;+4&space;\right&space;)}"/>.
  • Plugging these into <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 5\left ( u\right )^{4}\cdot \frac{\mathrm{d} u}{\mathrm{d} x}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;5\left&space;(&space;u\right&space;)^{4}\cdot&space;\frac{\mathrm{d}&space;u}{\mathrm{d}&space;x}}"/>, we get our final answer as
