Also can be important in autophagy, programmed cell death.- Vacuoles: larger membrane bound compartments used for various functions, like holding food (food vacuole), pumping excess water out of the cell (contractile vacuoles), or simply storing water (central vacuoles in plants).***The endomembrane system ends here.- Mitochondria: carries out cellular respiration in cells without chloroplasts. Its main function is to produce ATP for the cells usage using oxidative phosphorylation. It has lots of folds in its membrane to increase its surface area.- Chloroplasts: captures solar energy and utilizes it to make ATP through photosynthesis. Usually found in plants and protists. Both the mitochondria and chloroplasts will be covered more in depth in the cell respiration and photosynthesis chapters.- Cytoskeleton: funtions in mechanical support and motility of a cell. It has three main components: microtubules, microfilaments, and intermediate filaments. Microtubules support the cell's membrane and serve as tracks for motile organelles with the help of motor proteins. Cillia and Flagella on most protists are made out of microtublues. Microfilaments are larger and thicker than microtubules, and provide more solid structural support for the cell and many of its organelles. They are key in the structure of willi and muscle fibers. Intermediate filaments are in between microtubules and microfilaments in terms of size and thickness, and help maintain cell shape.- Cell Wall: composed of microfibrils and cellulose and found in plant cells and many bacteria cells. Its main function is to support the cell it encloses, which is very important in plants bring able to support their own wight without a skeletal system.- Intercellular Junctions: these are found only in multicellular organisms and serve the function of connecting the cystol in cells for communication purposes. In plants, they are known as plasmodesmata. In animal cells, there are three types: tight junctions (hold adjacent cells together), desmosomes (support intermediate filaments to mesh cells into sheetlike structures), and gap junctions (important in cell communications, just like plasmodesmata). These are important in inter cell communication in terms of triggering reactions in a general cellular area.
fields.title: Cell Organelles

fields.content: It's important to remember that a cells function will determine the type and quantity of each organelle it has. For example, a muscle cell will have more mitochondria and less ER since it needs ATP to power its contractions and secretes very few proteins. This will be very important on the AP.
fields.title: Not All Cells Are Created the Same

fields.content: Water is made up of 2 hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom; the oxygen (O) and hydrogen (H) molecules are a special type of covalent bond called a hydrogen bond. Hydrogen bonds are formed between only H molecules and either O, Fluorine (F), or Nitrogen (N). The large disparity between the electronegativities (the ability to attract electrons) between H and O, F, and N (note- H has a very low electronegativity and O, F, and N have large ones). The hydrogen bonds result in an uneven sharing of electrons, with a net negative dipole created near the oxygen and a net positive created near the hydrogen. This uneven sharing causes attractive intermolecular forces to function between water molecules and facilitates water's unique nature.
fields.title: The Polarity of Water

fields.content:
There are four essential properties of water that are integrated into many biological processes:

  • Cohesiveness - the ability of water molecules to attract to other water molecules due to collective polarity.
    • This also relates to adhesion, the ability of water molecules to polarize and attract to other molecules, and high surface tension.
  • Temperature Moderation - the nature of dipole dipole interactions created by Water's H bonds causes it to have very high specific heat. Specific heat is the amount of heat energy gained or lost when a gram of a substances changes its temperature by 1 degree Celsius. With a high specific heat, water is able to take in and release large amounts of energy without having its' internal temperature change.
    • Water Specific heat = 4.184 J/(g * degree Celcius)
    • This specific heat allows water to have a high heat of vaporization and engage in evaporative cooling (cooling of the surface of water when the molecules with the highest energy leave the liquid state)
  • Ice Insulation of Water - H bonding causes water to form a lattice structure while freezing; this lattice structure integrates space/holes into the molecular structure resulting in ice being less dense than water. In nature, it's usually the other way around. Therefore, bodies of water can still support life forms even when the surface freezes, since the lower levels of water remain liquid and habitable
  • Universal Solvent - is a polar covalent solvent due to the dipole's created by H bonding. This means it can help dissolve ionic, polar, and nonpolar compounds (to a certain degree). This makes water a staple biological solvent, since it's able to dissociate many types of solutes and facilitate different reactions and processes
fields.title: Water's Special Properties

fields.content:
Molecules dissociate, or break apart, in varying degrees, and water is no exception. Water dissociates into hydrogen ions (H3O+) and hydroxide ions (OH-). The dissociation concentrations of water determine the pH of solutions, with normal concentrations being 10^-7 M. Note- water is in a situation of dynamic equilibrium, where water molecules constantly dissociate and reform as shown below:

2 H2O ---> H3O+ + OH-

When water interacts with acids and bases in nature, different pH's result depending on the strength of the acid/base. For the purposes of this course, however, you will not have to calculate pH's or know pH range interactions. Buffers are the only essential topic.

A buffer system is a compound that minimizes volatility in hydrogen and hydroxide concentrations. It usually consists of a acid or base, and it's conjugate sitting in equilibrium. These systems are important in nature to control spikes in pH. For example, if human blood leaves it's usual range of pH for a couple minute, one could die. A common buffer system is bicarbonate and its conjugate- carbonic acid (H2CO3 ---> HCO3- + H+)
fields.title: Water Dissociation and Acids and Bases

fields.title: Concavity

fields.content:
We can start to apply what we learned in calculus so far to real life situations through optimization. We look for maximum or minimum values for a function that satisfies a constrain that has to be true no matter what. In a lot of these problems, there is a pattern on how to solve them. These steps are seen below

  1. Identify the constraint and the value to be optimized
  2. Rearrange the constraint equation to solve for one of the variables
  3. Plug this into the equation that needs to be optimized
  4. Differentiate this equation and set it equal to 0
  5. Solve for the values that make it equal to 0
  6. Choose the value that is the maximum or minimum that we are looking for
  7. Solve for the other variables

ex.) A gardener has 300 feet of fencing to enclose three equal sized rectangular garden plots. What dimensions x and y will maximize the total area?

  • The constraint equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/> and the optimization equation is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total\, \, Area = xy}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;=&space;xy}"/>.
  • We can rearrange the constraint equation to solve for y
  • Plug y into the optimization equation to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} Total \, \, Area=x\left (75-\frac{x}{2} \right )=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area=x\left&space;(75-\frac{x}{2}&space;\right&space;)=75x-\frac{x^{2}}{2}}"/>
  • Differentiate this to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left (Total \, \, Area \right ){}'(x)=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\left&space;(Total&space;\,&space;\,&space;Area&space;\right&space;){}'(x)=75-x}"/> and set it equal to 0 to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0=75-x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0=75-x}"/>
  • So <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/>
  • Plugging this into <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2x+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2x+4y=300}"/>, we get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 2(75)+4y=300}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;2(75)+4y=300}"/> which means <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>
  • Therefore our optimal dimensions are <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=75}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=75}"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} y=37.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;y=37.5}"/>

fields.content:
Say we want to find the derivative of a function at a point, point P. If another point, point Q, lies on the same function, the secant line between the two does not look like the tangent line to point P unless points P and Q are very close. This is seen with the graphs below.

As we can see, when P and Q become very close as h approaches 0, the secant and tangent lines look identical. This means that the average rate of change becomes the instantaneous rate of change (the derivative). So when we take the limit of the average rate of change as h approaches 0, we can find the derivative at the point.

Ex.) Find the derivative of .

  • We take our <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} u}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&amp;space;u}"/> as <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left (x^{3} +4x-3 \right )}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&amp;space;\left&amp;space;(x^{3}&amp;space;+4x-3&amp;space;\right&amp;space;)}"/>. We can substitute this to get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left ( u\right )^{5}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&amp;space;\left&amp;space;(&amp;space;u\right&amp;space;)^{5}}"/>.
  • The derivative of <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \left ( u\right )^{5}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\left&space;(&space;u\right&space;)^{5}}"/> is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 5\left ( u\right )^{4}\cdot \frac{\mathrm{d} u}{\mathrm{d} x}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;5\left&space;(&space;u\right&space;)^{4}\cdot&space;\frac{\mathrm{d}&space;u}{\mathrm{d}&space;x}}"/>.
  • Since <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} u=\left (x^{3} +4x-3 \right )}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;u=\left&space;(x^{3}&space;+4x-3&space;\right&space;)}"/>, <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \frac{\mathrm{d} u}{\mathrm{d} x}=\left (3x^{2} +4 \right )}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\frac{\mathrm{d}&space;u}{\mathrm{d}&space;x}=\left&space;(3x^{2}&space;+4&space;\right&space;)}"/>.
  • Plugging these into <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 5\left ( u\right )^{4}\cdot \frac{\mathrm{d} u}{\mathrm{d} x}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;5\left&space;(&space;u\right&space;)^{4}\cdot&space;\frac{\mathrm{d}&space;u}{\mathrm{d}&space;x}}"/>, we get our final answer as

When we need to take the derivative of the product of two functions, we use the Product Rule. This is seen below.

fields.content:
If a function is differentiable (has a derivative) at , then is continuous at .

  • This stems from the definition of the derivative with <img align="absmiddle" alt="{f}'(c)" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{f}'(c)"/> as

  • This means that there cannot be a hole, jump, vertical asymptote, vertical tangent, corner, or cusp at

Say we have a table of values for a function or just a function in general and we need to find the approximate derivative of the function at a point. To do this, we can use the values around the point to approximate the slope of the function (derivative) at that point. This is seen in the equation below

Ex.) Find the approximate derivative at using the table plotting values of below.

f(x)011.411.7322.242.452.652.83
  • To find the derivative at <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x= 4.5}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=&space;4.5}"/>, we will use h as .5 and x as 4.5
  • Plugging these into the equation above, we get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(4.5)\simeq \frac{f(4.5+.5)-f(4.5-.5)}{2(.5)}\simeq \frac{f(5)-f(4)}{1}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(4.5)\simeq&space;\frac{f(4.5+.5)-f(4.5-.5)}{2(.5)}\simeq&space;\frac{f(5)-f(4)}{1}}"/>
  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(4)=2}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(4)=2}"/> and <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} f(5)=2.24}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;f(5)=2.24}"/> from the table above, so plugging these in, we get <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} {f}'(4.5)\simeq \frac{2.24-2}{1}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;{f}'(4.5)\simeq&space;\frac{2.24-2}{1}}"/>

fields.title: Approximating Derivatives

fields.content:
To see how to implicitly differentiate, we will outline the steps and try to differentiate the example function '
  • Differentiate both sides with respect to x
  • Solve for <img align="absmiddle" alt="\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{d} x}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?\frac{\mathrm{d}&space;y}{\mathrm{d}&space;x}"/>
fields.title: Steps

fields.content:
The periodic table is a organizational tool that is used to sort all known elements. An element is a pure substance made up only one type of atom. This is different from a compound, which is made up of atoms of different elements chemically bonded to one another uniformly.Each column in the periodic table (vertical) is called a group; horizontal rows are called periods.On the perodic table, each element has its own little box. Within that space, three important things are displayed. At the top lies the elements atomic number. The atomic number describes how many protons an atom has in its nucleus, Additionally, since atoms have no electrical charge, they have the same number of electrons as protons. Thus the atomic number can also state the number of electrons in an atom. Next, in the middle of the box is the element's symbol. This is the way chemists can universally identify an element. Finally, at the bottom of the box we find the elements molar mass. Molar mass is the combination of protons and neutrons that create the nucleus of the atom. This mass is in grams and constitutes a whole mole of atoms of said element; a mole is a measurement method that is used universally of 6.023 x molecules.The number of protons determines the element of an atom, but not all atoms of an element have the same mass number. An isotope is an atom with the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons. For example, Oxygen usually has an molar mass of 16 (O-16) but some atoms only have 12 neutrons, and thus are called oxygen-12 isotope. Although many isotopes may exist for an element, the molar mass will reflect the most common isotope of an element.

Atomic Structure and Electron Clouds

Each atom is made up of a nucleus, formed through proton and neutron combinations, and an electron cloud which surrounds the nucleus. It's called a cloud because the electrons move around the nucleus randomly, but stay within a certain area. Often times, the whole cloud will be made up of several shells, subshells, and orbitals. I will explain below.

- Electron's Quantum Numbers:

  1. Shells (n) - this is called the principal quantum number. It states how far an electron is from the nucleus and how mch energy it contains. Stability is inversely proportional to distance, while energy is directly proportional. The numbers here will increase from 1 onward. Generally, the period number will tell you the number of shells. For example, if n=2 then the electron cloud has two shells.
  2. Subshells (l) -this is callled the angular momentum quantum number. It determines the shape of an individual electron cloud, or orbital. Subshells begin from 0 and incriment upwards. Remember, that "l=n-1 This means that if n=2, there would be two subshells: l=0 and l=1. Furthermore, each subshell has a name:
    1. s-cloud occurs when l=0; this contains one orbital, with two maximum in each orbital, totaling 2.
    2. p-cloud occurs when l=1; this contains three orbitals, with two maximum in each orbital, totaling 6
    3. d-cloud occurs when l=2; this contains five orbital, with two maximum in each orbital, totaling 10
    4. f-cloud occurs when l=3; this contains seven orbital, with two maximum in each orbital, totaling 14
  3. Orbitals ()- this is the magnetic quantum number. It states the orbitals orientation within the cloud. Here, all you need to know is that = -l through +l
  4. Spin () - an electron can have a positive spin or a negative spin. This value is either +1/2 or -1/2
fields.title: The Chemist's Main Guide: The Periodic Table

fields.content:
Electrons are highly mobile within the electron cloud. Their movement affects many of the properties that an element has. There are three principles that are important to remember, especially for the AP exam:

  1. Aufbau Principle - electrons will fill lower energy shells, subshells, and orbitals first
  2. Pauli's exclusion principle - each electron will have its own unique set of quatum numbers; no two can have the same
  3. Hund's rule - electrons will always try to fill an empty orbital before it pairs up with another in an orbital.
These rules are not only important to know in general, but also when you are writing electron orbital diagrams and writing out electrong configurations for elements (i.e. which consequently is Nitrogen).
fields.title: Three Rules on Electron Interactions

fields.content:
Knowing these trends are super important...but actually, learn them and love them. They will show up on both sections of the exam. These trends are all explained by a few common atomic mechanisms, which i have listed below. Remember, electrons are negatively charged and protons in the nucleus are postively charged. Therefore, since opposites attract in chemistry, electrons are attracted and held in the cloud by the nucleus' charge. And subsequently, electrons repell eachother.

  • <strong>Electron Sheilding</strong> - this is an interaction where the electrons in the valence shell (outermost) are less attracted to the nucleus because they are simultaneously repelled by electrons in lower shells and blocked from the nucleus' charge
  • Affective nuclear charge - electrons are more attracted the closer they are to the nucleus; the more protons in the nucleus, the stronger the attractive force
  • Stability is what atoms will naturally trend toward, thus full electron shells are more stable then partially filled ones. Atoms will exchange electrons in order to complete their respective shells.
    • Side note- elements vary in their magnetism. When electron levels are filled completely, an element will be diamengentic and have no charge. In other words, their electrons are all paired in their orbitals. When some orbitals are left unfilled, elements have some magnetic charge (it varies by how many orbitals are unparied or empty) and are called paramagnetic.
-Atomic Radius: the distance from the center of the nucleus to the outer edge of the electron cloudAtomic radius increases down a group. The explanation is simple; with each step down the group, a whole new shell of electrons is added to the cloud. However, atomic radius decreases across a period from left to right. This is because as we move left to right in a period, an atom gains a proton. This increase the nuclear attractive force; the number of electron shells doesnt change though. This means, as we move across a period, the nucleus attracts the cloud closer and closer to it, decreasing the radius.Atomic radius varies by ions as well. Negative ions are called anions; they gain electrons to become negative. Anions are bigger thena their atom counterparts because the gain of electrons increase electron-electron repulsion, causing the valence electrons to move farther from the nucleus.Postive ions are called cations; they lose electrons to become positive. Cations are smaller than their respective atoms because when they lose electrons, either (1) they lose an electon cloud or (2) their electron-electron repulsion between the the valence electrons and the inner electron clouds is reduced. Both of these result in the valence electron cloud moving closer to the nucleus.-Electron Affinity: this is basically the opposite of Ionization Energy. Its defined as the energy turnover when an electron is added to an atom as opposed to taken away.There's a no real change down a group for electron affinity. As for across a period, it increases because affective nuclear charge increase as you go across a period, so that is more energy to overcome.-Electronegativity: the attractive force of an atoms nucleus on nearby electronsThis decreases down a group, simply due to the fact that there is more electron-electron repulsion and electron sheilding that blocks affective nuclear charge. Electronegativity increases across a period because the number of protons in the nucleus increases as well.-Ionization energy: the amount of energy needed to remove an electron from an atom.This property varies by how many valence electrons there are. Moving down a group, ionization energy increases due to the fact that as the valence electron moves farther away from the nucleus (since they grow), there is less affective nuclear charge acting on them. Thus it takes less energy to pull one away.Moving left to right across a period, ionization energy increases. This again has to do with affective nuclear charge. As the number of protons increases across a period, there is more affective nuclear charge as the nucleus attracts the electrons more. Therefore, its harder to pull electrons off.Finally (thank god, because this lesson is dragging...am i right?), since ionization energy depends on the valence electrons present, it will increase little by little untill a whole shell is taken off. The ionization energy jumps through the roof once a new shell is reached and we try to disrupt the stability of the complete shell. Remember, atoms like stability, taking stability away takes alot of energy.
fields.title: Periodic Trends!!!

fields.content:
Since atoms are made of clouds of electrons, most IMFs and bonding occurs due to interactions of electrons which are called electrostatic forces. These forces are basically the positively charged nucleus of one atom being attracted to the negatively charged electrons of another atom.There are two different types of main bonds:

  1. Covalent Bonding - this involves two atoms sharing electrons; however, how they share these electrons causes variablity within bonding. The electrons shared are counted as a part of both bonding atoms valence shells. Covalent bonds usually occur between nonmetals.
  2. Ionic Bonding - this consists of one atom completely giving up its electrons to another; this results in one atom becoming a cation and the other becoming an anion. Since these types of bonds occur mainly between nonmetals and metals, the metals become cations and the nonmetals in anions.
fields.title: Types of Bonds

fields.content:
When two atoms bond covalently, there can be an array of bond sizes, strenths, and lengths. First off there are three types of bondings possible: single, double, and triple. Single bonds are made up of a sigma bond, a type of bond overlapping orbital. Double and Triple bonds include both sigma bonds and pi bonds. The distinction between sigma and pi bonds is structural in its 3D shape, but this is outside the scope of this course. A Double bond is made up of one sigma and one pi bond; a triple bond is made up of one sigma and two pi bonds.

The bond order is a term that tells what level of bond exists somewhere in a molecule. Single bonds have a bond order of 1; double has an order of 2, and so on. Now, bond strength is inversely proportional to size. Therefore, a stronger triple bond would be much shorter than a single bond.
fields.title: Bond Order, Strength, and Length

fields.content:
Inter molecular forces (IMFs) are different from bonds. Bonds are very strong links that are created through chemical interactions; IMFs are attractive forces that occur naturally between molecules/atoms. There are several types of IMFs. Here they are, listed in order of increasing strength:

  • London Dispersion/Van Der Waals Forces - these are the weaksest IMFs. they can occur between any molecules, but generally occur between nonpolar molecules (neutral). These forces are created through random motion of electrons within the interacting molecules to produce a charge creating a weak attractive force.
  • Dipole-Dipole interactions - ***Remember when i said that in covalent bonding the sharing of electrons doesnt have to necessarily share them equally? Well, if I didn't, now I am. In covalent bonding, two atoms CAN share electrons equally, but the degree of sharing actually comes down to the respective electronegativity of each atom. Atoms with stronger electronegativity will pull electrons closer towards themselves, causing an uneven sharing of electrons. This uneven sharing is called a dipole moment. Thus two dipole moments interacting causes a dipole-dipole interaction (#duh). These interactions occur mostly between polar molecules.
    • Dipoles are actually the forces that cause a mechanism called Polarity. Polarity is where there is an uneven distribution of charge created in one molecule. A prime example is a water molecule. The highly electronegative O atom pulls the shared electrons closer to itself. This gives it a slightly negative charge, while the H atoms have slightly positive charges. Thus, the molecule is polar because it contains multiple charges.
  • Hydrogen Bonds (H Bonds) - hydrogen bonds are a stronger form of dipole dipole interactions. They consist of an H bonded to either an Nitrogen, Oxygen, or Fluorine atom. The logic here is that since N, O and F have such high electronegativities and H has a low one, the bond is extremely polar. This causes even stronger interactions with other polar molecules.
  • Ion-Dipole Interactions - the name says it all here. An ion and polar molecule interacting is stronger than dipole-dipole because the charge of the ion creates a stronger attractive force to the dipole.
  • Network Covalent Bonds - these are interactions between covalent bonds causing them to arrange themselves into a lattic structure. This allows lots of smaller bonds to act as one huge interactive molecule. One last thing, the lattice structure limits the motion of electrons, which makes the whole interaction stronger and a poor conductor of electricity.
fields.title: Intermolecular Forces

fields.content:
This is an important concept for both sections of the exam. Since here I don't have enough tools to create all the individual diagrams, I will give descriptions of each shape and examples of these molecules. Its up to you to learn and read up on Lewis Dot diagrams and these 3D diagrams, as well as how to draw them. All of this follows the VSPER model.

Molecular Geometries show us how a molecule looks after it comes together. The fact that electrons repel each other complicates these basic shapes. We're almost done with this lesson, so lets finish strong with a look at each shape...

  • Linear - this is where the central atom only has 2 electron pairs, and only 2 potential atoms bonded to it. An example would be CO2
  • Trigonal Planar - the central atom has 3 electron pairs, and three potential atoms bonded to it. An example is BCl3
    • if this has 1 lone pair (a set of unparied electrons), then it becomes a bent shape. Example: SO2.
  • Tetrahedral - the central atom has 4 electron pairs, an a maximum of 4 atoms bonded to it. Example: SiH4
    • if there is 1 lone pair, then its called trigonal pyramidal. Example: NH3
    • if there are 2 lone pairs, then its called bent again. Example: H2O
  • Trigonal Bipyramidal - 5 electron pairs on the central atom. Example: PCl5
    • seesaw: one lone pair with trigonal bipyramidal. Example: SF4
    • T-shaped: two lone pairs. Example: ICl3
    • linear: three lone pairs. Example: PF2
  • Octahedral - 6 electron pairs on the central atom. Example: SF6
    • square pyramidal: one lone pair. Example: BrF5
    • square planar: two one pairs. Example: XeCl4
fields.title: Molecular Geometry

fields.content:
This is a silly little last thing, but nonetheless important. Hybrization is a notation that describes the electron clouds mixing when a complex molecule is formed. It's just something to remember along with molecular geometry, and it's pretty easy.

  • Linear - sp (1 s cloud and 1 p cloud)
  • Trigonal Planar -
  • Tetrahedral -
  • Trigonal Bipyramidal -
  • Octahedral -
 Well....Thats All folks!!! (i miss the loony toons :/ )
fields.title: Hybridization

fields.content:
Measuring the concentration of a solution is one of the most important prerequisites to doing problems in this unit. There are three main concentrations:

  1. Mole Fraction - This is the fraction of moles of some element or molecule. This is used primarily with vapor pressure, which i will explain later.
    1. Formula -
  2. Molality - this is the concentration of a solution with respect to how much moles of solute by the mass of the solvent. This is heavily used with colligative property calculations.
    1. Formula -
  3. Molarity - this expresses solution concentration based on the volume of solvent rather than the mass. This is its main difference from molality.
    1. Formula -
fields.title: Important Measurement Methods

fields.content: One rule affects how things dissociate, which means to break into ions or monomers/ions. This is called "like dissolves like Due to the many intermoleular forces at work, solutes with similar polarity as their solvents will dissociate in them. Like polarities are dissociable. The same goes for nonpolar solutes in nonpolar solvents.Another thing that affects dissociation and more so solubility is van't Hoff factor (i). This tells us how many ions a solute molecule will break up into. Solutes that cant be dissociated are given a factor of 1, and the property increases up the scale depending on the number of ions it breaks up into.
fields.title: Dissociation and Properties That Affect It

fields.content:
There are four main colligative properties, or properties that vary by the number of solute particless in the solvent.

  1. Boiling Point Elevation - this is where boiling point increases with solute presence and concentration.
    1. Formula - (where the change in temperature equals the van't Hoff factor times the Boiling point elevation constant (k) times the molality (m)
  2. Freezing Point Depression- basically the opposite of number 1 above...
    1. Formula - (where the change in temperature equals the van't Hoff factor times the Freezing point depression constant (k) times the molality (m)
  3. Decrease of Vapor Pressure - involves the speed at which molecules hit and exert pressure on the walls of a container.
    1. Formula - (where vapor pressure equals the mole fraction (X) times the Vapor Pressure of the Solvent
  4. Osmotic pressure - The pressure that must be exerted to prevent the movement of a pure solvent into a solution across a membrane.
    1. Formula - (where osmotic pressure in atm is equal to moles of solute times the gas constant (R) times temperature in Kelvin over the volume of the solution in liters times the van't Hoff Factor; can also be turned into M which is Molarity of the solution)
***This one isnt a true colligative property but it should still be known about: Density.

Density = ; its affected by solute presence.
fields.title: Colligative Properties

fields.content: Most things dont dissociate completely in solution, but to a degree. In comes solubility product or , which describes to what degree a solute or an ion dissociate. Most of the time with problems involving have to do with a salt. The expression for solubility product is This means the is the product of each consituent ion with its own charge and ratio in molecule. For example:If we work with the equation then... = -Common Ion Effect: where the solubility of an ion (from a solute) is decreased by the presence of that same ion in solution already. Lets try a example problem...If the of NaCl is 1.6 x then,1.6 x = 1.6 x = (a)(a)1.6 x = a = [Na+]= [Cl-] = 1.3 x However, if we add some sort of salt with a common ion to NaCl, then the solubility of some ions decreases. When two salts with a common ion are mixed, the one with the smaller precipitates first. Heres what I mean...If we put 0.1 M Cl- in the solution, the solubility of Na decreases dramatically.1.6 x = 1.6 x = M Once again....Thats all folks!!!
fields.title: Solubility and Equilibrium

fields.content:
Significant Figures (sig-figs) are basically rounding rules for chemistry. They tell us to what degree of specificity we ought to report data. There are several sig fig rules. Firstly, lets cover what a sig-fig actually is...

  • Nonzero digits and zeros sandwiched between nonzero digits are significant
  • Zeros that are at the end of a number and to the right of a decimal are considered significant
  • Zeros that are at the end of a number are not significant if the number is greater than one, unless there is a decimal after them.
  • All other zeros are NOT significant
Sig-fig rules still apply to mathematical operations like adding, subtracting, multiplying and dividing.-Addition and Subtraction: the answer should be rounded to the decimal place as the number with the least decimal places in the calculations.ex) 0.003 + 0.2 = 0.2-Muliplication and Division: the answer should have the same number of sig-figs as the number with the least number of sig figs in the calculation.ex) 1200 x 234 = 280800 = 280000
fields.title: Significant Figures

fields.content: This topic requires in depth knowledge of conversions between measurements. They will be your links between what yore given in a problem and how to get the unit of the answer. The most universal conversion is a mole, or Avagadro's number.So.... 1 mole = moleculesThe biggest conversion with moles in chemistry is between moles and grams:# of moles =
fields.title: Useful Conversions

fields.content:
1. Percent composition: this is the percent by mass that one element makes up in a compound
    1. To calculate, deduce the molar mass of the compound, then divide by this molar mass to get the number of moles
    2. then divide the number of moles of the compound by the number of moles of the desired element in that compound
    3. finally, find the mass of the moles of this desired element and divide it by the total mass of the original compound and muliply that by 100
  2. Empirical Formulas: the simplest chemical formula of a compound
    1. Generally, you will be given either the mass of each element in the compound or the moles of each. Let's say we are given the mass...
    2. divide by the molar mass to determine moles of each substance
    3. once you have moles, divide each number of moles by the smallest number of moles present among the elements
    4. At this point, you should have some numbers close to whole numbers and one number that is one. These are the proportions of each element in the empirical formula. If the number is like 1.5 or something not close to a whole number, either you did something wrong or you need to multiply all the numbers by a common coefficient to get them all whole.
  3. Balancing Chemical Equations: simply put, the number of molecules for each element on the reactants side needs to equal that of the products side (due to the conservation of mass)
    1. You could to trial and error, but if it is a multiple choice test, start from the middle of the choices and work your way through them until one of the selections just clicks.
  4. Limiting Reactant problems: these are the baddest of the bunch. In chemical equations, usually one reactant runs out before the other when producing products. This reactant is justly called the limiting reactant.
    1. There are a couple things you need to take care of before you solve this type of problem. The biggest two things are balancing the chemical equation and converting the reactants to moles
    2. From here, use your molar ratios from your balanced equation to see which reactant would yeild how many moles of the product under question. Whichever reactant yeilds less...it limits the whole equation and thus is the limiting reactant
***A final note about all of these types of questions. Remember to double check what exactly you are solving for, its easy to get lost in these problems!!!
fields.title: The Most Common Problems With Stoichiometry

fields.content: Aggregate demand is basically the general willingness of the population to buy goods and services produced in a country. If people in a country tend to be conservative with their money and like to save, that country has a low aggregate demand. Likewise, if people in a country like to spend most of their incomes, that country has a high aggregate demand.
fields.title: Definition

fields.content: The aggregate demand curve (AD) is inversely proportional to the general price level (PL). When prices are low, people are willing to spend their money, and thus output, real GDP, is high. When prices are high, people aren't willing to spend as much, and thus real GDP is low. It's honestly just common sense. There are other reasons for why there's an inverse relationship, but I haven't seen it covered on any exams.As you can see on the graph to the left, if the general price level drops from PL1 to PL2, real GDP (output) increases from Y1 to Y2 because more people are inclined to spend at that lower price level. This curve is meant to illustrate the tendencies of people as consumers. Never will you actually see an economy "move along" the AD curve as pictured in the graph. An economy's state will always be at the intersection point of the AD curve, and another curve, which you will learn next chapter. Just understand why the AD curve is inversely proportional to price levels.
fields.title: Ad Curve

fields.content: If you know the equation for GDP, you know the components of aggregate demand. In case yove forgotten, the components are: consumer spending (C), business investment (I), government spending (G), and net exports (X-M). You must know this.
fields.title: Gdp

fields.content:
This is the most important part of the chapter. It's pretty simple too. Scenario: a country has a certain level of aggregate demand. If that country's level of aggregate demand increases, the AD curve will shift to the right. This should make sense: if a country's level of aggregate demand increases, people are willing to spend "more at every price level, hence the shifting of the curve to the right. The converse is true also. If aggregate demand decreased, the AD curve would shift to the left.This graph depicts exactly how the AD curve shifts to the right. The output of an economy would increase from Y1 to Y2 if it had a fixed general price level PL1 and the AD curve shifted to the right. This is consistent with with the paragraph above.So, what exactly 'does increases aggregate demand? Easy: any increase in the components of aggregate demand will increase aggregate demand itself, and thus shift the AD curve to the right. Once again, the converse of this is true as well. I will give many examples of change in aggregate demand below. It is necessary that you understand all of them.

Consumer Spending

  • Scenario: The government increases personal income taxes.
    • If personal income taxes increase, people will have less money to spend. Therefore, consumer spending will decrease, thus decreasing aggregate demand and shifting the AD curve to the left.
  • Scenario: The government increases transfer payments to welfare beneficiaries.
    • An increase in transfer payments to welfare beneficiaries would increase the amount of money they have to spend. Therefore, consumer spending would increase, thus increasing aggregate demand and shifting the AD curve to the right.
  • Scenario: The marginal propensity to save decreases.
      • *This one may require some explanation. The tendencies for people to spend and save when income changes are called the marginal propensity to consume (MPC) and the marginal propensity to save (MPS), respectively.
      • Together, they form the equation: MPC + MPS = 1. It should make sense that an increase in one will lead to the decrease in the other.
    • Here's the answer: If the marginal propensity to save decreases, then the marginal propensity to consume will increase. This means that consumers will tend to spend more money. Therefore, consumer spending will increase, thus increasing aggregate demand and shifting the AD curve to the right.
  • Scenario: The country is experiencing high unemployment.
    • If there is high unemployment, people will be fearful of losing their jobs. Thus, they will start to save more money in case they do end up being let go (so they have money to fall back on). Therefore, consumer spending will decrease, thus decreasing aggregate demand and shifting the AD curve to the left.
  • Scenario: The country is experiencing high inflation.
    • If there is high inflation, people will try to spend their money now so it won't lose value later. Therefore, consumer spending will increase, thus increasing aggregate demand and shifting the AD curve to the right.

Business Investment

  • Scenario: Real interest rates rise.
      • *Most businesses get the money to invest through loans. It should make sense then that business investment will be high when real interest rates are low and vice-versa. This relationship is depicted by the investment-demand curve to the left. There is an inverse relationship between business investment and real interest rates (real i), just as we said.
      • The "economic reason" for this is profitability. Businesses lose potential profits when they must pay back high interest loans, which is why high real interest rates cause lower business investment
    • Answer: If real interest rates rise, then business investment will decrease due to lower profitability of loans. Therefore, aggregate demand decrease, shifting the AD curve to the left.
Note: Consumers take out loans as well. Therefore, you could say that consumption would decrease as well as business investment. However, the main focus with real interest rates is business investment.

Government Spending

  • Scenario: The government passes a bill that will create interstate highways.
    • The government will have to fund the creation of interstate highways. Therefore, government spending will increase, thus increasing aggregate demand and shifting the AD curve to the right.
  • Scenario: The government decreases spending by $10 million.
    • Honestly, most government spending questions will be obvious like this one. The exam will tell you the scenario, and you should say: Because government spending decreases, aggregate demand decreases as well, shifting the AD curve to the left. However, the question will have many other parts relating to other chapters. This piece of the problem should be the easy part.

Net Exports

These scenarios should be very easy to pick out, since they'll have to do with other countries
  • Scenario: The U.S. government places a tariff on foreign goods
    • Because the tariff will tax imported goods, American citizens will stop purchasing, eventually decreasing the amount of imports into the country. This will increase net exports, thus increasing aggregate demand and shifting the AD curve to the right.

Summary

By now, you should have an idea of how components of aggregate demand will be changed and how this will affect aggregate demand. The answers I gave are common to the scenarios presented, but by no means are they guaranteed to be true. The AP exam will usually phrase questions in such a way that you will know what they're looking for.For example, the exam may ask: "How could a country experiencing high inflation have an increase in aggregate demand?" With this question, you know the answer I gave above is applicable because the end result answered the actual question. You'll never get one of the scenarios above without a direction for the answer.***My answers are pretty much exactly how you should phrase them when answering problems on the AP exam (and also just thinking about the problems in general). It may seem repetitive to write all of that for a question, but it's what I'd do if I were you.'.
fields.title: Shifting the Ad Curve

fields.content: Aggregate supply is basically the general willingness of business to produce goods and services in a country. If there are many businesses willing to produce goods and services, then a country's level of aggregate supply is high. If there are few businesses willing to produce goods and services, then a country's aggregate supply is low.
fields.title: Definition

fields.content: The aggregate supply curve (AS) is upward sloping . When the general price level is low, businesses aren't as willing to produce goods and services because their profits would be low., As a result, output, real GDP, is low.When prices are high, businesses are more willing to produce goods and services because they have higher profit margins. As a result, real GDP is high.Just like aggregate demand, aggregate supply should seem easy to understand. As you can see on the graph to the left, if the general price level increases from PL1 to PL2, real GDP (output) increases from Y1 to Y2 because businesses are more inclined to produce at a higher price level in order to make big profit.This curve is meant to illustrate the tendencies of businesses as producers. Never will you actually see an economy "move along" the AS curve as pictured in the graph. An economy's state will always be at the intersection point of the AS curve, and the AD curve. You'll learn more about this in the next chapter.
fields.title: As Curve

fields.content:
This is the most important part of the chapter. It's way shorter than the aggregate demand chapter's section. The only thing that will shift the AS curve is a change in the per unit cost of production of goods. Anything that changes this and only this, will shift the AS curve.A decrease in the per unit cost of production will shift the AS curve to the right like in the graph to the left. If the per unit cost of production decreases, businesses will have higher profit margins. Therefore, they will be more willing to produce "more goods and services at every price level. This marks an increase in aggregate supply and a shift in the AS curve to the right.If the per unit cost of production increases, businesses will have lower profit margins, and will thus be less willing to produce goods and services at every price level, decreasing aggregate supply and shifting the AS curve to the left.I'll give some examples below. Make sure you understand them instead of trying to memorize all the scenarios
  • Scenario: The government increases excise taxes on tobacco.
      • *Excise taxes are taxes on specific commodities, such as tobacco. They are applied to the producers of such goods. Yes, producers can pass the tax down and increase sale prices, but often producers still end up paying for it through a cut in their profit margins. Therefore, increasing excise taxes increases the per unit cost of production of such goods.
    • An increase in excise taxes would increase the per unit cost of production. This would decrease aggregate supply and shift the AS curve to the left.
  • Scenario: The government increases subsidies for businesses across the country.
      • *Subsidies are forms of grant money offered from the government to businesses producing certain commodities. They're essentially the opposite of excise taxes because they can increase businesses' profit margins by decreasing their expenses. Therefore, increasing subsidies decreases the per unit cost of production of such goods.
    • An increase in subsidies would decrease the per unit cost of production. This would increase aggregate supply and shift the AS curve to the right.
  • Scenario: The price of oil decreases.
      • *Businesses use oil to run factories, provide transportation, etc. If the price of oil dropped, businesses' expenses would decrease. Therefore, decreasing oil prices decreases the per unit cost of production.
    • A decrease in the price of oil would decrease the per unit cost of production. This would increase aggregate supply and shift the AS curve to the right.
  • Scenario: New technology increases the productivity of factory machines.
    • If advances in technology increases the productivity of factory machines, the per unit cost of production will decrease. This would increase aggregate supply and shift the AS curve to the right.
      • **I hope that some of you picked up on this. Technology is a factor of production. Better technology increases the quality of factors of production, which will result in long term economic growth. So, new technology can have two different effects.
  • Scenario: The federal minimum wage is increased.
      • *An expense all businesses have is wages to their employees. If the federal minimum wage is increased, businesses across the country would have larger expenses. Therefore, increasing the federal minimum wage would increase the per unit cost of production.
    • If the government increases the federal minimum wage, the per unit cost of production would increase. This would decrease aggregate supply and shift the AS curve to the left.
  • *Challenge* Scenario: A 1000 square foot oil field is discovered in Texas.

Supply Shocks

Supply shocks are events that cause large increases in resource costs, such as oil. These price increases raise the per unit cost of production; therefore, supply shocks decrease aggregate supply, which shifts the AS curve to the left.

Summary

By now, you should have an idea of aggregate supply can be changed and how it will shift the AS curve. The answers I gave are common to the scenarios presented, but by no means are they guaranteed to be true. The AP exam will usually phrase questions in such a way that you will know what they're looking for.For example, the exam may ask: "How could increasing the federal minimum wage decrease aggregate supply?" With this question, you know the answer I gave above is applicable because the end result answered the actual question. You'll never get one of the scenarios above without a direction for the answer.***My answers are pretty much exactly how you should phrase them when answering problems on the AP exam (and also just thinking about the problems in general). It may seem repetitive to write all of that for a question, but it's what I'd do if I were you.'.
fields.title: Shifting the as Curve

fields.content:
In the broad sense, money is anything that is widely accepted as payment for goods and services. Usually, money takes the form of print (e.g. dollars) or coins. There are three functions of money:

Medium of Exchange

Money is used to buy and sell goods and services. Before money was used as currency, people used to have to barter by trading goods and services (e.g. one goat for three lambs). Money has made the process of obtaining goods and services much easier by being a medium of exchange.

Unit of Account

Money can be used to evaluate the worth of goods and services. For example, one might say that a tennis racket is worth $30. Using money as a means to appraise goods and services is essential to its use as a medium of exchange.

Store of Value

People keep money in banks or on hand as a means to store their wealth. It's better and more convenient to hold your fortune in money instead of buying $100,000 worth of laptops with it because money's value is retained over time (unlike laptops), and because money is liquid, or immediately available as a medium of exchange. Like the ones above, this is just kind of common sense.
fields.title: Money

fields.content:
Money is not always just dollar bills and coins. It can take several forms. The following forms of money are ordered in descending liquidity, or immediate availability to use. I'm going to be honest; these aren't extremely important to know, but here they are anyway:

M0

M0 is physical currency, such as bills and coins. This is the most liquid form of money because it's universally accepted as immediate payment for goods and services

M1

M1 includes all of M0, along with demand deposits (checking accounts).

M2

M2 includes all of M1, along with money market funds, savings accounts, and small time deposits.

M3

M3 includes all of M2, along with large time deposits.
fields.title: Types of Money

fields.content: The money supply represents the total amount of money in circulation, including mainly cash and checking accounts. It's synonymous with the curve known as the supply of money (Sm) on the money market graph.The Sm curve is completely controlled by actions of the Federal Reserve. It will only shift left or right when the Federal Reserve implements a monetary policy, which you will learn about next chapter.In general, just understand that anything that increases the amount of money in circulation will shift the supply of money curve to the right, increasing the supply of money. Likewise, anything that decreases the amount of money in circulation will shift the supply of money curve to the left, decreasing the supply of money.
fields.title: Money Supply

fields.content:
The demand of money curve (Dm) represents how much a nation's people in general wish to hold their wealth as money. The Dm curve is inversely related to nominal interest rates. At higher nominal interest rates, people will want to invest in bonds and time deposits in order to make money, so the demand for money in liquid form - such as cash and demand deposits - is lower. The converse holds true as well.There are two types of demand of money. (Don't worry too much about the demand of money. The supply of money is much more important.)"

Transaction Demand

We hold money because its convenient to use to purchase goods and services. The transaction demand just represents in general how much money a nation's people hold at any given time in order to buy goods and services

Asset Demand

As you know, people keep money as an asset to store their wealth. At any given time, a nation's people in general will have a certain demand of money to keep as an asset.
fields.title: Demand of Money

fields.content:
The money market graph combines the Sm curve and the Dm curve. The equilibrium point (the intersection point) of this graph determines the quantity of money (AKA the money supply) and the 'nominal interest rate (not the real interest rate). Since the Sm curve 'is the money supply controlled by the Federal Reserve, there's no need to draw a dotted line to show the supply of money, as that would just be redundant.Even though we are referring to the nominal interest rate, for the sake of this course, when the nominal interest rate increases/decreases, so will the real interest rate. I'd hope this makes sense. If the inflation rate is constant, then by the equation:real rate = nominal rate - inflation rateIf the nominal interest rate goes up, so will the real rate.

Shifting the Dm Curve

The Dm curve is dependent on the nominal GDP. If the nominal GDP increases, the Dm curve will shift to the right. If the nominal GDP decreases, the Dm curve will shift to the left. Nominal GDP can change if either the real GDP changes or if inflation changes.If inflation rate increases, price levels are higher, 'which means that people will have to carry more money to buy goods and services.If the real GDP increases, people will have more wealth, which means the asset demand for money will increase because they'll need to store that increased wealth in money.Either way, you must make the determination if nominal GDP increases; that is the trigger for a shift in Dm.Ex: If aggregate demand increases, what will happen to the nominal interest rate?Answer: Using the AD-AS graph, shifting the AD curve to the right will yield higher price levels and higher real GDP. Thus, nominal GDP must increase as well. Therefore, the Dm curve will shift to the right, increasing the nominal interest rate.If you can understand what will increase/decrease the nominal GDP, yore in good shape. However, I need to remind you to stay in the question. Instead of asking you about nominal interest rates, the question above might have asked about the effect on unemployment instead. Don't whip out the money market graph unless you have to. Questions about the Dm curve are rare on the AP exam

Shifting the Sm Curve

The supply of money curve is completely controlled by the Federal Reserve (the Fed) and its monetary policies. Anything the Federal Reserve does to increase the amount of money in circulation will increase the money supply, shifting the Sm curve to the right.Any money held by the Federal Reserve is not considered to be in circulation or part of the money supply. Therefore, if the Fed was to acquire money from banks, the money supply would decrease, and the Sm curve would shift to the left.Likewise, if the Federal Reserve gave money to banks, more money would be in circulation, so the money supply would increase, and the Sm curve would shift to the right.The Federal Reserve gives/takes money away from banks in order to control the money supply, which is how the Federal Reserve changes interest rates. Yoll learn all the ways the Fed can give/take money from banks in the next chapter, but I'll give one example anyway:
Bonds
The Federal Reserve (Fed) can buy and sell bonds to banks. Bonds are basically like loans but they pay interest to the owners . If the Federal Reserve 'buys bonds from banks, the Federal Reserve will 'give the banks money for the bonds. Therefore, the money supply will increase, shifting the Sm curve to the right, which will decrease nominal interest rates. At a constant general price level, this will also decrease real interest rates. The decrease in real interest rates will increase business investment due to high profitability of loans. This increase in business investment will increase aggregate demand, shifting the AD curve to the right and increasing both real GDP and price levels.See how many chain reactions this had? This is why it's important to understand every chapter of economics. However, if you truly do comprehend the actual concepts, you won't have to memorize what does what. It'll just make sense. If the above did not come naturally to you, you should consider reviewing the previous chapters of this course.
fields.title: Money Market Graph

fields.content:
When someone puts money into a checkable/demand deposit account (checking or savings accounts), banks loan out some of those funds in order to make money off of the interest rate. Banks are not allowed to loan all of the demand deposits, however.The required reserve ratio (RRR) is the minimum percentage (as a decimal) of demand deposits banks must keep in reserves. For example, if the required reserve ration is 0.1, then banks must keep 10% of demand deposits in their reserves (called "required reserves"). This also means that banks are allowed to loan out the other 90% of demand deposits.Ex: The required reserve ratio is 0.2. A businessman deposits $20,000 into a bank. How much money can the bank loan out?Answer: To find the required reserve, just multiply the RR by the deposit amount: (0.2)($20,000) = $4,000. The amount the bank must keep as required reserves is $4,000. Therefore, the 'excess reserves, or the amount the bank currently holds that does not need to be kept, is $20,000 - $4,000 = $16,000. Thus, the bank can loan out $16,000.

Tip: You won't have a calculator on the AP exam, so you'll have to do these calculations by hand. An easy way to multiply decimals is to make them into fractions and then multiply them.

0.2 = 2/10

∴(0.2)($20,000) = (2/10)($20,000) = (2)($2,000) = $4,000

*Once you convert 0.2 to 2/10, you can cancel the 10 in the denominator with a 0 in the numerator to get (2)($2000)
fields.title: Reserve Requirement

fields.content: Banks can create money by loaning out their excess reserves. The person who deposits physical money into a bank is entitled to withdraw that amount at any time. Now, the bank can loan out some of that physical money to another person. This essentially "creates" money through borrowing on credit.Ex: The reserve requirement is 0.1. "Person" starts out with $1000. He deposits it all into Bank 1, which puts away $100 (10%) of that into required reserves. Now, the bank is left with $900 in excess reserves. Bank 1 decides to loan all of it out to Person B, who uses it to pay for the services of Person C, a carpenter.Person C deposits all of the $900 he receives from person B into Bank 2, which puts away $90 (10%) of that into required reserves. Now, Bank 2 is left with $810 in excess reserves. Bank 2 decides to loan all of it out to Person D, who uses it to pay for the services of Person E.Person E deposits all $810 into Bank 3, which puts away $81 (10%) of that into required reserves. Now, Bank 3 is left with $729 in excess reserves, which it decides to hold on to for the time being.Now, let's add up all the money... "Person" is entitled to his demand deposit of $1,000. Person C is entitled to his demand deposit of $900. Person E is entitled to his demand deposit of $810. Lastly, Bank 3 physically holds $729 in excess reserves. Required reserves must be held by the banks, and are therefore not considered to be in circulation.Adding these together yields $3,439, which is $2,439 more than we started out with at $1,000. As you can see, the process of loaning out money on credit increases the total amount of money in circulation, thus increasing the money supply. The graphic above is a basic illustration of the process of the creation of money.
fields.title: Making Money

fields.content:
When a question involves banking and money, the AP exam usually asks test takers to find:
  • The maximum total change in demand deposits in the banking system
  • The maximum total change in the money supply
They are very similar, but there is a slight difference between the two. In the example above, the total change in demand deposits in the banking system was $3,439 because originally, Banks 1, 2, and 3 all held $0, but after the deposit from "Person" and the creation of money by Banks 1 and 2, the sum of the demand deposits and excess reserves was $3,439.However, the increase in the 'money supply was only $2,439 because even though the total amount of money at the end was $3,439, the $1,000 that "Person" deposited into Bank 1 was originally already a part of the money supply.

Money Multiplier

The money multiplier (MM) is the tool used to find the maximum total changes in demand deposits and the money supply.$latex MM=\\frac{1}{RRR}&fg=007fff$Once again, you should convert the RRR to a fraction, and then calculate the MM.Ex: What is the money multiplier if the required reserve ratio is 0.2?Answer: RRR = 2/10 = 1/5

∴ MM = 1/(1/5) = 5

Solving the Problem

Once you have the money multiplier, calculating the maximum total changes in demand deposits and the money supply is easy.For any type of transfer of money into a bank, whether it be the purchase of a bond or a deposit, the maximum total change in demand deposits in the banking system is $latex (Amount)(MM)&fg=007fff$The maximum total change in the money supply depends on whether or not the money transferred into the bank was already a part of the money supply.
  • If the funds were already a part of the money supply, then the maximum total change in the money supply equals the maximum total change in demand deposits minus the original amount.
  • If the funds were not originally a part of the money supply, then the maximum total change in the money supply equals the maximum total change in demand deposits.
Ex: If the required reserve ratio is 0.5 and the Federal Reserve purchases $4,000 worth of bonds from a bank, what will be the maximum possible change in demand deposits in the banking system? What will be the maximum possible change in the money supply?Answer: RRR = 0.5 = 5/10 = 1/2

MM = 1/RRR = 1/(1/2) = 2

Maximum possible change in demand deposits in the banking system = ($4,000)(MM) = ($4,000)(2) = $8,000

Maximum possible change in the money supply: The $4,000 wasn't originally a part of the money supply. Therefore, the maximum increase in the money supply is the same as the maximum increase in the demand deposits in the banking system, which equals $8,000.

Ex: Assume that the required reserve ratio is 20% and banks hold no excess reserves. A person deposits $300 of cash into his checking account. Calculate:
    1. The immediate change in demand deposits in the banking system
    2. The immediate change in the money supply
    3. The maximum possible change in demand deposits in the banking system
    4. The maximum possible change in the money supply
Answer:
    1. The immediate change in demand deposits in the banking system is just $300. Money isn't created immediately; it takes time to be created through the process of loaning out funds. Pay attention to whether or not the question is talking about the immediate effect on something or the maximum effect on something.
    2. Since the $300 existed as cash before the person deposited it into a bank account, it was already a part of the money supply. since no money is created instantly, the immediate change in the money supply is zero.
    3. Since we're now talking about the maximum possible change in demand deposits, we can use the equation given above.RRR = 20% = 0.2 = 2/10 = 1/5MM = 1/RRR = 1/(1/5) = 5Maximum possible change in demand deposits in the banking system = ($300)(MM) = ($300)(5) = $1,500
    4. Since the $300 was already a part of the money supply to begin with, the maximum possible change in the money supply is $1,500 - $300 = $1,200

Exception

A deposit into a bank will only actually increase the money supply/demand deposits by the maximum possible amount if banks keep no excess reserves. If banks 'do keep excess reserves, then they won't loan out as much funds, which results in less money creation. This is a concept that has appeared on multiple choice questions before.
fields.title: Maximum Increase

fields.content:
AssetsLiabilities
Required Reserves: $20,000Demand Deposits: $100,000
Excess Reserves: $30,000
Loans: $50,000
You might come across tables such as the one to the left in free response questions. Demand deposits are the money people have put into the bank. Required reserves are obviously the amount that the bank is required to keep in order to back the demand deposits. Excess reserves are any leftover funds that were not loaned out. The sum of the monetary amount on the left side should always equal the sum of the monetary amount on the right side. Questions like the examples above are often asked with the balance sheet of a bank.Ex: Use the balance sheet of a bank provided above to answer the following questions.
    1. What is the required reserve ratio?
    2. Someone withdraws $10,000 from the bank
      1. By how much will the bank's reserves decrease?
      2. How much will the bank have to keep in required reserves now?
      3. What is the immediate impact on the money supply?
    3. Assume that the withdraw in part (b) did not take place. The bank buys $20,000 worth of bonds from the Federal Reserve.
      1. What is the immediate change in the demand deposits in that bank?
      2. What is the immediate impact on the money supply?
      3. What will happen to nominal interest rates?
Answer:
    1. RRR = (required reserves)/(demand deposits) = ($20,000)/($100,000) = 0.2 = 20%
      1. This is such an easy question that it seems confusing. The bank's reserves will decrease by the amount the person took out, $10,000
      2. Since someone withdrew $10,000, the demand deposits will decrease by that amount. Thus, the demand deposits will sum to $90,000. Multiplying this by the RRR will yield the required reserves: ($90,000)(0.2) = $18,000
      3. The bank has not loaned any money in this short time span, so no money has been created. The person transferred the $10,000 from the bank to cash in his pocket, both of which are part of the money supply. Therefore, the money supply won't change. All the person did was change the composition of part of the money supply from demand deposits to cash.
    3. Go through the steps... The bank buys bonds, so the bank gives money to the Federal Reserve.
      1. The demand deposits on a bank's balance sheet only have to do with deposits/withdraws made by people. Thus, the demand deposits won't change. The bank will use its excess reserves to pay for the bonds, and the new balance sheet will look like:
        AssetsLiabilities
        Required Reserves: $20,000Demand Deposits: $100,000
        Excess Reserves: $10,000
        Loans: $50,000
        Bonds: $20,000
      2. Since the bank is giving money to the Federal Reserve, money is being put out of circulation, so the money supply would decrease by $20,000 (remember, this is the immediate impact; also, money can only be created by transferring money to banks, so you wouldn't use the money multiplier in this situation anyway)
      3. If the money supply decreases, then the Sm curve will shift to the left. This will result in higher nominal interest rates.
If that last part got you, it's more than understandable. I do not believe that the AP exam would have such an intricate problem on the free response. However, hopefully you understand it. To sum it up, you need to determine if the deposit/funds was a part of the money supply (or the banking system) in order to find the actual maximum possible increase in either. If yore getting the problems right, then you shouldn't worry about it.
fields.title: Balance Sheets

fields.content: The United States has a market economy, which basically means that citizens privately own the majority of businesses and property. This is unlike a command, or planned, economy, in which the government centrally controls all economic decision making. Adam Smith was the most well known early proponent of market economies, saying that these types of economies were more productive because people would work in their own self-interest to make a profit. Even if they weren't business owners, people working in a market economy would try to maximize their utility, an economist's way of measuring overall pleasure or satisfaction, by making choices that would most benefit them, and as a result, benefit the economy.
fields.title: The United States' Economy

fields.content: The most fundamental economic problem is that you can't have it all. Humans have almost unlimited wants, but there are only a limited supply of resources to satisfy them. This idea represents scarcity: something is scarce when it is desirable but limited in quantity. Businesses face scarcity all the time.A business fully allocates all of its scarce resources to producing two goods: corn and wheat. If the business decides to produce more corn, it would have to reduce the amount of wheat it produces as well in order to free up more resources to be used for corn. The choice to make more corn had a cost: less wheat. This is called an opportunity cost, a term economists use to describe a trade-off. The opportunity cost is what you must give up to make a choice. For example, if you spend money on a new laptop, the opportunity cost could be the textbooks that you were supposed to buy with that money. It is the same idea with production in businesses and countries.
fields.title: The Fundamental Economic Problem

fields.content:
This is a very important section to understand. The amount of production a country can have is based on the quantity and quality of its resources. These resources are known as factors of production:

Land

Land includes all natural resources, such as oil, lumber, and the ground itself to be built on.

Labor

Labor includes not only the size of the workforce, but the knowledge and skill set of the workers themselves

Capital

Capital includes machinery, equipment, and factory (tools and things that make other goods). Capital also includes technology.

Entrepreneurship

Entrepreneurs are the people that incorporate the other factors of production in their own business.
fields.title: Factors of Production

fields.content: One of the nuances of the PPC specifically shown above is how capital and final goods relate to the future. Capital goods are factors of production. The more factors of production a country has, the more it can produce overall (so the farther the curve goes out). A country that is producing more capital goods than final goods will have a more economic growth in the future than a country that decides to produce mostly final goods. I will extensively connect the dots of economic growth and factors of production throughout this course.
fields.title: Capital vs. Final Goods

fields.content: Unfortunately, PPCs don't always have straight curves; in fact, the AP will most likely only use PPCs with straight curves for questions that involve calculations because the opportunity costs in these graphs are "constant. Most PPCs bow out as a result of the Law of Increasing Opportunity Costs. All the law says is that the more any certain good is produced, the more opportunity cost it will take to increase the production of that good.For example, at point a, if you trace the curve a little to the right, you might see that yore increasing the amount of final goods without losing too many capital goods. However, at point d, there are already much more final goods than at point a. As a result, if you trace the curve a little to the right, you'll see a drastic drop in the amount of capital goods. That drop is your opportunity cost.
fields.title: Increasing Opportunity Costs

fields.content: A country with an absolute advantage in the production of a good or service can produce that good or service at a cheaper per unit cost than any other country or entity. This is represented in PPCs by basically being the country that can produce more of a good than the country it's being compared to can. Of the two countries, Country X has an absolute advantage in the production of oranges. Coincidentally, Country X also has an absolute advantage in the production of bananas.
fields.title: Absolute Advantage

fields.content:
A country with a comparative advantage in the production of a good or service can produce that good or service at a lower 'opportunity cost than any other country or entity. For example, if Country X went from producing 0 bananas to producing 15 bananas, the opportunity cost would be 20 oranges. So, the relative opportunity cost of one banana is ', which equals 4/3 oranges per banana. The opportunity cost of one banana in Country Y is ', which equals 3/2 oranges per banana. Let's compare the two:
[table width="400"]Country,oranges per banana,oranges per banana (decimal)Country X,4/3,1.333Country Y,3/2,1.5[/table]
So, the opportunity cost of a banana is lower for Country X than for Country Y. This means that Country X has less to lose if it decided to produce a lot of bananas. This is called a comparative advantage. Country X has a comparative advantage in the production of bananas. Conversely, we would be able to say the Country Y has a comparative advantage in oranges. For the AP exam, know that if one country has a comparative advantage in the production of a good, the other country has a comparative advantage in the production of the other good. This is always be true unless you calculate each country's opportunity costs to be the exact same, in which case no one has a comparative advantageNotice how that even though Country X has an absolute advantage in the production of oranges, Country Y has a comparative advantage in the production of oranges. This is because comparative advantages are found by comparing the the two goods inside a country, while absolute advantages are found by comparing a good between two countries. If you still don't understand "why they're different, that's okay; just make sure you know "that they're different and how to find each.
fields.title: Comparative Advantage

fields.content:
Specialization is basically focusing on the production of one good instead of trying to produce many other goods. Economists all agree that countries benefit when they specialize because they are able to increase their consumption possibilities.Specialization is based on comparative advantage. A country that has a comparative advantage in the production of a good should specialize in producing that good. Country X should specialize in producing bananas, and Country Y should specialize in producing oranges. Do not try to use the idea of absolute advantage when considering specialization. Yes, Country X may be better at producing both oranges and bananas than Country Y, but Country X is better at producing bananas than it is at producing oranges, which is why it should only produce bananas.

Tariffs

Tariffs are basically taxes on imported goods into the country. They generate additional revenue for the domestic government but are generally used more for the purpose of enticing citizens to by goods domestically. This impedes the processes of trade and specialization and is therefore looked down upon by economists.'.
fields.title: Specialization

fields.content: As you can imagine, this model incorporates both the aggregate demand curve and the aggregate supply curve. This is a graph that you need to know and be able to use. The intersection point of these two curves (point a) represents the state of a corresponding nation's economy. This state is called the economy's equilibrium. At equilibrium, this economy's price level and real GDP are PL1 and Y1, respectively.Everything on this graph should be labeled the way it is. The title (AD-AS), the axis titles (Price Level and real GDP), labels on each curve (AD and AS), the equilibrium point (a), and labels of the price level and real GDP at equilibrium (PL1 and Y1).
fields.title: Intro

fields.content:
It is essential to be able to shift the AD and AS curves and interpret the results. The good thing is that yove already done half of this in the previous two chapters. Interpreting the results has to do with three factors: the price level, output/real GDP, and unemployment. You can easily see the answers to all three by actually shifting a curve on a graph.
