I think an example is the best way to show you thisScenario: How would an increase in government expenditures affect the economy?Answer: An increase in government expenditures would increase aggregate demand, shifting the AD curve to the right.

Once you shift the curve, make sure you label the graph correctly, just like to the left. Now, look at the second equilibrium point. Yoll see that price level increased from PL1 to PL2 and that real GDP increased from Y1 to Y2. The issue of unemployment is related to real GDP. From here on out, an <em>increase in</em> <em>real GDP</em> will be synonymous with a <em>decrease</em> in unemployment. This should make sense, as businesses need to hire more employees when they produce more goods and services.

Full answer: An increase in government expenditures would increase aggregate demand, shifting the AD curve to the right. This would result in an increase in both real GDP and price level, while lowering unemployment.Let's try another one.Scenario: How would an increase in excise taxes affect the economy?Answer: An increase in excise taxes would increase the per unit cost of production. Therefore, aggregate supply would decrease, shifting the AS curve to the left. This would result in a decrease in real GDP, while increasing price level and unemployment.
fields.title: Shifting Curves

fields.content: When doing these problems, don't try to memorize which shift increases what. Just find out if aggregate demand/supply increases or decreases, shift the curve accordingly, and then interpret the graph. If you do all of that, you won't need to memorize that a shift of the AS curve to the right increases real GDP and decreases price level and unemployment. Yoll be able to figure that out in a couple seconds. This is why I'm not going through every possible scenario.
fields.title: Rant

fields.content: If you remember a couple chapters ago, I drew a dashed curve inside the PPC and called it the production when the economy is at full employment, or NAIRU. An economy at NAIRU is producing goods and services at its optimal level. Every economy strives to reach this point. The AD-AS graph actually has one more curve on it that represents NAIRU. The curve is called long-run aggregate supply (LRAS). It is a vertical line simply because it represents a nation's optimal real GDP output level, Y"fe.The goal of an economy is to get it to full employment. An economy is at NAIRU when the equilibrium point is on the LRAS curve.When the equilibrium point is to the left of the LRAS curve, as depicted in the graph to the left, the nation's real GDP output (Y1) is "less than the output the nation would have if it was at full employment (Y'fe). This means that the nation is in a recession.When the equilibrium point is to the right of the LRAS curve, the nation's real GDP output is "more than the output the nation would have if it was at full employment. This means that the nation is facing an inflationary situation.Obviously, if the equilibrium point is on the LRAS curve, the nation is at full employment. Sometimes, the College Board will refer to full employment as "long-run equilibrium They both mean the same thing.(By the way, since LRAS is the long-run aggregate supply curve, the AS you've been seeing is technically the "short-run aggregate supply" curve, but as long as you specify LRAS as long-run, you won't have to worry about calling AS short-run.).
fields.title: Lras

fields.content:
Clearly, yore going to have to shift some curves to move the equilibrium point. It should make sense that if the equilibrium point is to the left of LRAS, you need to move either the AD or the AS curve to the right. Likewise, if the equilibrium point is to the right of LRAS, you need to move either the AD or the AS curve to the left.I'm going to go through an AP exam similar problem to show you how easy it is
  1. Assume that Germany's economy is currently in a recession.
    1. Draw a correctly labeled graph of aggregate demand and aggregate supply and show each of the following:
      1. The long-run equilibrium output, Yf
      2. The current equilibrium output Y1
      3. The current equilibrium price levels, PL1
    2. What is a supply side policy Germany's government can use to get its economy back to full employment?
    3. Depict your answer to part (b) on the graph, labeling the new output and price levels, Y2 and PL2, respectively.
    4. What would be the policy's effect on Germany's real GDP and unemployment rate?
Answer: (1.)(a) A recessionary situation is one in which the equilibrium point is to the left of LRAS because the equilibrium output is 'less than output at full employment. Check.(b) Yoll learn more about policies later, but I'm pretty sure you could have guessed it's something to do with the government. Either way, you know it has to do with the AS curve. In order to get to full employment, the AS curve would need to shift to the right. There are plenty of options you could choose:
  • Increasing subsidies
  • Lowering excise taxes
  • Decrease minimum wage
Any of the above would lower the per unit cost of production. Thus, aggregate supply would be increased, shifting the AS curve to the right. Note: all you had to do is write down an applicable policy. Since the question did not ask for an explanation, you don't have to!(c)" All you have to do is just draw an AS curve shifting to the right and label everything properly. Yes, yore right: the new AS curve "might not intersect exactly on the LRAS in real life. It's asking for a possible fix, and it is possible, so just do it.(d) This is easy: just look at what you labeled on the graph! The policy would increse Germany's real GDP, while lowering its price levels.AP free-response questions are just as easy as the problem above!.
fields.title: Getting Back to Full Employment

fields.content: Yove already know how to shift the LRAS curve. How did you shift the PPC? You changed either the quantity or quality of factors of production. The LRAS represents the same thing as the PPC (or at least that dashed line we drew that means that a nation is at NAIRU). The LRAS will shift to the right when factors of production increase and to the left when factors of production decreaseThe graphs beside this paragraph both illustrate a nation's economy at the same time.Scenario: Explain what could happen if a large amount of the nation's workforce retires.Answer: The quality and population of a nation's workforce are factors of production. Since the nation's workforce is decreasing, the nation's factors of production are decreasing as well. This means that both LRAS and the PPC shift to the left.**Do you remember long-run economic growth?Economic growth ties in with the PPC and LRAS as well. A decrease in the nation's factors of production signifies reduced economic growth as well. In fact, all three of these things mean the exact same thing! They all represent a nation's output when it is at full employment/NAIRU. I hope this is all starting to make sense.
fields.title: Shifting the Lras Curve

fields.content:
Anything that changes the per unit cost of production will change aggregate supply. Anything that changes the quantity or quality of factors of production will change long-run aggregate supply. Sometimes, changes in factors of production can also change aggregate supply. I'll list some examples:
  • The United States loses half of its imports of oil due to an embargo against it.
    • This decreases the amount of oil businesses can use, thus it decreases long-run aggregate supply.
    • Because oil is now scarce, its price is driven up quickly. This increases the per unit cost of production, decreasing short-run aggregate supply as well.
      • *Drastic decreases in natural resources such as oil are called supply shocks.
  • Advances in technology create more efficient factory machines.
    • Increases in technology also mean increases in factors of production. Thus, long-run aggregate supply would increase.
    • Higher productivity means that the per unit cost of production is lowered. Thus, short-run aggregate supply would increase as well.
These are just a few examples. Don't get caught up in memorizing them. Just remember what changes AS and what changes LRAS, and you should be able to figure it out.
fields.title: Overlap Between as and Lras

fields.content: I've spoken before about how inflation and unemployment are inversely related. High inflation corresponds with low unemployment, and vice-versa. There is a graph that illustrates this relationship, called the Phillips curve.A nation's economy can represent any point on the curve. The initial point on the curve is not important. What you need to understand is how the point's location can change.
fields.title: Trade-Offs

fields.content: Let's just say that a nation's economy is experiencing an inflationary situation and is on the Phillips curve at point (a) above. You implement a demand side policy to get the economy back to full employment. Let's just say you raise personal income taxes. Now, consumers have less money to spend, so consumption decreases, also decreasing aggregate demand. Thus, the AD curve shifts to left and gets the economy back to full employment. From the graph, you can tell that both output and price levels drop. Since output drops, unemployment increases (remember, less output means less workers needed to produce). Since price levels drop, inflation essentially decreases as well.Illustrating these results on the Phillips curve is easy. Unemployment increases and inflation decreases. Thus, the economy just moves along the Philips curve to the right.If the country was in a recession, and we increased aggregate demand to combat this, unemployment would decrease, and inflation would increase. This would correlate with the economy moving along the Phillips curve to the left. Try going through all the steps!.
fields.title: Aggregate Demand

fields.content: Let's just say that a nation's economy is experiencing a recession. You implement a supply side policy to get the economy back to full employment. Let's just say you increase business subsidies. Therefore, the per unit cost of production decreases, increasing aggregate supply and shifting AS to the right back to NAIRU. From the graph, you can tell that price levels decrease, but real GDP increases. As a result, both inflation and unemployment decrease.Finding a new point on the same Phillips curve is impossible because both unemployment and inflation decrease. The solution is to shift the Phillips curve in order to satisfy the change in unemployment and inflation. As you can see, this is only possible by shifting the Phillips curve to the left.If the country was experiencing high inflation, and we decreased aggregate supply to combat this, both inflation and unemployment would increase. This would correlate with a shift of the Phillips curve to the right.. Try going through all the steps!.
fields.title: Aggregate Supply

fields.content: Don't try to over analyze or memorize this, but you should've picked up that changing aggregate demand will move a nation's economy along the Phillips curve, while changing aggregate supply will shift the Phillips curve itself. Once again, you don't need to memorize this; common sense will lead you in the right direction.
fields.title: Short Summary

fields.content: There is one more long-run curve to know, the long-run Phillips curve (LRPC). The LRPC ties in with LRAS, the PPC, economic growth, and NAIRU. In fact, the long-run Phillips curve actually is NAIRU, the optimal unemployment level that doesn't cause high inflation. As you can see, it is a vertical line, just like the LRAS, at a certain unemployment level. This unemployment level is NAIRU, or full employment. Just as we wanted the economy to lie on the LRAS in the AD-AS graph, we want the economy to be a point on the LRPC.If an economy is a point to the right of this line, like in the graph to the left, it has higher unemployment than at NAIRU, so it is in a recession.If an economy is a point to the left of this line, it has higher inflation than at NAIRU, so it is experiencing high inflation.If an economy is a point on this line, it is at NAIRU/full employment.The long-run Phillips curve implies that there is no trade-off between inflation and unemployment "in the long-run, when an economy is at full employment.Once again, it is a goal to get an economy to be a point on this line, just as it is a goal to get an economy to rest on the LRAS line. They're both the same exact goals. I'll try to connect them together better in the last section.
fields.title: Long-Run Phillips Curve

fields.content: The LRPC represents almost the same exact thing as the LRAS curve, right? It only makes sense that whatever shifts the LRAS will also shift the LRPC. This is correct. An increase factors of production will spark economic growth. This is illustrated by the shift of the LRAS to the right (the economy can produce 'more at full employment). The real GDP at full employment increases as a result of this shift. Thus, unemployment must decrease (remember that we said that increases in output also mean decreases in unemployment). So to speak, unemployment 'at full employment decreases. This just means that NAIRU, the lowest rate of unemployment that doesn't cause high inflation, can be even lower without causing high inflation. This is illustrated by a shift of the LRPC to the left.
fields.title: Shifting the Lrpc

fields.content:
I think this will all make more sense if you see an example that incorporates almost every major concept yove learned
  1. Assume that France's economy is in a recession.
    1. Draw and correctly label the following graphs' depiction of the situation.
      1. AD-AS Graph
      2. Phillips Curve
    2. The real interest rate falls
      1. What will happen to aggregate demand?
      2. Show the impact of this on both graphs drawn in part (a)
    3. What is the potential impact of part (b) on the economic growth rate?
    4. Illustrate your answer to part (c) on the following:
      1. The AD-AS graph in part (a)
      2. The Phillips Curve in part (a)
      3. The nation's PPC
     
Answers:(a) In a recession, a nation's economy's output is less than it would have at full employment. This correlates with having higher unemployment than NAIRU. These two graphs are what you should draw.***Note: don't write (NAIRU) on the Phillips curve. I just put that there to help you understand the LRPC.(b) (i) If the real interest rate falls, the profitability of loans businesses take out will increase. Therefore, business investment will increase, thus increasing aggregate demand.(ii) An increase in aggregate demand will shift the AD curve to the right. This will result in higher price levels and real GDP, which correlates with more inflation and lower unemployment. This is illustrated on the Phillips curve by moving along the curve to the left. The economy is now at full employment.(c) (*If you remember, increases in business investment are synonymous with increases in factors of production) The increase in business investment will increase the nation's factors of production. This will induce economic growth, so the economic growth rate will increase.(d) The increase in economic growth will:

(i) Shift the LRAS curve to the right

(ii) Shift the LRPC to the left

(iii) Shift the PPC to the right
fields.title: Example

fields.content: I sure hope it's all coming together. The PPC, LRAS, and LRPC are all connected to each other. Increased business investment will increase factors of production, which induces economic growth (this means the same thing as increasing economic growth rate). This increase in long-run economic growth just means that a nation "can produce more at full employment/NAIRU, hence the shift of the LRAS and PPC to the right. Furthermore, in order to actually 'be able to produce more goods and services at full employment, more people must be employed. This means that the unemployment rate when the nation's economy is at full employment/NAIRU must be smaller, hence the shift in the LRPC to the left.
fields.title: Connections

fields.content:
Just to remind you, fiscal policies can affect aggregate demand by changing any one of the components of aggregate demand, but they'll usually affect consumption or government spending"

Personal Income Taxes

When the government raises personal income taxes, people are left with less expendable income. Therefore, consumer spending/consumption decreases, which decreases aggregate demand. This shifts the AD curve to the left, yielding lower price levels and lower output/real GDP. Remember that this is synonymous with lower inflation and higher unemployment.A decrease in personal income taxes will do the complete opposite of the above.

Government Spending

Sometimes the AP exam will just say that the government increases spending on something. Well, that means that government spending increases, which increases aggregate demand as well. This shifts the AD curve to the right, yielding higher price levels and higher output. This also means that there is lower unemployment and higher inflation.Decreases in spending will do the opposite of above.
Multipliers
You know how money was created through the banking system due to loans? Well, when the government changes personal income taxes or changes its spending, the total amount of change in aggregate demand is actually a lot more than the initial amount the government used for the same reason. If someone received $5, they might spend $4 for a good or service. The person receiving those $4 might spend $3 of it on a good or service. The person receiving those $3 might spend $1 on a good or service. As you can see, the total amount of spending in this situation is $8, even though the initial amount injected into the economy was only $5. Money was multiplied.There are two more multipliers (other than the money multiplier in the last chapter) that you need to know:The spending multiplier: $latex SM=\\frac{1}{MPS}&fg=007fff$The tax multiplier: $latex SM=\\frac{MPC}{MPS}&fg=007fff$MPC and MPS are respectively the marginal propensities to consume and save. As you know, the higher the MPC in a country is, the more that nation's people will spend, and vice-versa. The MPC and MPS are both numbers ranging from 0 to 1, and they both add up to 1(MPS + MPC = 1). At least one of them will be given to you on the AP exam, and you'll have to use one or both to find the tax/spending multiplier.For example, if you were given: MPC = 0.75, and wanted to know the tax multiplier, you would do as follows:

MPS + MPC = 1 => MPS = 1 - MPC = 1 - 0.75 => MPS = 0.25

MPC = 0.75 = 3/4 and MPS = 0.25 = 1/4

$latex TM=\frac{MPC}{MPS}= \frac{(3/4)}{(1/4)}=3$

The process above is a fair problem that you are expected to be able to do on the AP exam. Once you calculate either multiplier, to find the total change in aggregate demand, you multiply it by the initial spending/taxing amount.Ex: If the MPS = 0.8 and the government cuts personal income taxes by $100,000, what will be the total change in aggregate demand?Answer: MPC = 1 - MPS = 1 - 0.8 = 0.2

MPS = 0.8 = 8/10 = 4/5 and MPC = 0.2 = 2/10 = 1/5

$latex TM=\frac{MPC}{MPS}=\frac{(1/5)}{(4/5)}=\frac{1}{4}$

Total = ($100,000)(SM) = ($100,000)(1/4) = $25,000

Now, you must determine whether aggregate demand increases or decreases. Well, the government is cutting taxes, which means that people will have more expendable income, so aggregate demand will increase by $25,000

Yes, sometimes the tax multiplier will actually result in a lower amount of aggregate demand change. This is because when the marginal propensity to save is very high, people will not spend the majority of the tax cuts they receive.

Often, the AP exam will combine conflicting demand side fiscal policies in one question, one policy to increase aggregate demand and one policy to decrease it:Ex: If the MPS = 0.5, and the government increases spending by $50,000 while increasing personal income taxes by the same amount, what will be the total change in aggregate demand?Answer: MPC = 1 - MPS = 1 - 0.5 = 0.5

MPS = 0.5 = 1/2 and MPC = 0.5 = 1/2

$latex TM=\frac{MPC}{MPS}=\frac{(1/2)}{(1/2)}=1$

$latex SM=\frac{1}{MPS}=\frac{1}{(1/2)}=2$

Change due to taxing = ($50,000)(TM) = ($50,000)(1) = $50,000

Change due to spending = ($50,000)(SM) = ($50,000)(2) = $100,000

The increase in taxes leaves people with less expendable income, so aggregate demand decreases by $50,000. However, the increase in government spending increases aggregate demand by $100,000. Therefore, the total change in aggregate demand is an increase of $50,000.

Questions like these are common. Understand that government spending will always be stronger than tax changes of the same amount because government spending is a direct injection of money into the economy, while tax changes depend largely on the MPS and MPC.
fields.title: Demand Side

fields.content:
Remember that anything that changes the per unit cost of production will change aggregate supply.

Excise Taxes

Excise taxes are added taxes on the production of certain goods and services. When the government raises excise taxes on the production of goods, the per unit cost of production increases, decreasing aggregate supply. This shifts the AS curve to the left, lowering output and increasing price levels. This also means that both inflation and unemployment increase.Decreasing excise taxes work to the opposite effect.

Subsidies

The government sometimes spends on subsidies, which are payments for the production of certain goods and services (pretty much the opposite of excise taxes). Even though the government does "spend" for the subsidies, the effect to look at is on the demand side. When the government increase subsidies, the per unit cost of production decreases, increasing aggregate supply. This shifts the As curve to the right, increasing output and lowering price levels. This also means that both inflation and unemployment decrease.

Decreasing subsidies will do the opposite of above.
fields.title: Supply Side

fields.content: The Federal Reserve changes interest rates by altering the money supply. Increasing the money supply not only shifts the Sm curve to the right on the Money Market graph, but it also shifts the S'LF curve to the right on the Loanable Funds graph. Remember that the supply of loanable funds is basically the amount of money banks hold that are available to be loaned out. When the Fed increases the money supply, it does so by giving money to banks, which subsequently increases the supply of loanable funds. So make sure you understand that the two shifts to the left and to the right are synonymous.As you can see, increasing the supply of loanable funds and the money supply decreases nominal and real interest rates (shown on the graphs by shifting the Sm and S'LF curves to the right). This increases business investment due to higher profitability of loans, which in turn increases aggregate demand as well, shifting the AD curve to the right. This yields higher price levels and output. This also means that there will be higher inflation and lower unemployment. The sequence is shown on the graphs below.Decreasing the supply of loanable funds and the money supply does the opposite. The shift of the Sm and S'LF curves to the left results in higher nominal and real interest rates. This decreases business investment due to lower profitability of loans, which in turn decreases aggregate demand as well, shifting the AD curve to the left. This yields lower price levels and output. This also means that there will be lower inflation and higher unemployment.For the sake of your sanity (and mine), I'll show how each tool of the Fed will change the the money supply and supply of loanable funds. I won't continually repeat the following processes again and again for each problem. If you need to refer to this section again, then by all means, please do so. Understand the concept that decreasing the money supply and supply of loanable funds will decrease aggregate demand, while increasing the money supply and supply of loanable funds will increase aggregate demand.
fields.title: Money Supply and Loanable Funds

fields.content: The first of the Fed's three tools is open market operations, which is just buying and selling bonds.The Federal Reserve can sell bonds to commercial banks. By doing so, banks will "give the Fed money for the bonds. This means that money will go out of circulation, and thus the money supply will decrease, along with the supply of loanable funds.When the Fed buys bonds from commercial banks, it 'gives banks money for the bonds, so the money supply and the supply of loanable funds both increase.
fields.title: Open Market Operations

fields.content: As you know, banks are required to keep a certain amount of their demand deposits on reserve. These required reserves are to be held by the banks in order to have funds on demand for withdraws. Therefore, the required reserves are not technically considered part of the money supply. The Federal Reserve has control over the 'required reserve ratio (RRR), which determines the amount of required reserves.When the Federal Reserve lowers the RRR, the amount of required reserves decreases, and some of the required reserves is transferred over to the excess reserves. This transfer makes those funds part of the money supply and are now able to be loanable. Therefore, the money supply and the supply of loanable funds increase.When the Fed raises the RRR, the amount of required reserves increases, taking funds from the pool of excess reserves. This transfer takes those funds out of circulation, so the money supply and the supply of loanable funds decrease.
fields.title: Reserve Requirement

fields.content: Say a bank has one demand deposit of $100,000. If the RRR = 0.4, then the bank only has to keep $40,000 as required reserves. Say also that the bank loans all of its excess reserves. How would it be able to provide the adequate funds if the owner of that demand deposit withdrew $60,000? The bank would actually have to take a loan out from either another commercial bank or the Federal Reserve (the "lender of last resort"). The interest rate on loans from the Federal Reserve is known as the discount rate.If the Federal Reserve lowers the discount rate, then banks will be more willing to give out loans to businesses and consumers because they know that if they run out of reserves to transact withdraws, borrowing from the Fed will be cheap. It's like how business investment increases when real interest rates are lower because profitability of loans are greater. In this case, however, loans are the investment and banks are the businesses. This increase in loans will cause money multiplication, which will increase the money supply and supply of loanable funds.If the Fed raises the discount rate, banks will be less willing to loan off their excess reserves, so the process of money multiplication is restricted. This will decrease the money supply and supply of loanable funds.
fields.title: Discount Rate

fields.content:
Many prep books will try to list which specific policies are expansionary and which policies are contractionary. The only thing you need to understand is that expansionary policies try to bring the economy out of a recession (they expand the economy) and that contractionary policies try to combat high inflation (they contract the economy). If you understand what a certain policy will do it's easy to classify it as expansionary or contractionary.Ex: What type of policy would the Federal Reserve be using if it sold bonds on the open market?Answer: If the Federal Reserve sold bonds to banks, banks would give money to the Federal Reserve to buy bonds. Therefore, money would be going out of circulation, so the money supply would decrease, shifting the Sm curve to the left and raising nominal interest rates.

It's easy to generalize that increasing the supply of money will result in higher GDP, so it's implemented in expansionary monetary policies. Obviously, decreasing the supply of money would thus be implemented in contractionary monetary policy. If you want to "memorize" these, go ahead, but it's easier to just understand things.

 The AP exam will often ask about combinations of policies. For example, you should understand that lowering the discount rate and decreasing personal income taxes both increase aggregate demand. Thus, both are good expansionary policies. If this doesn't come automatically to you, you should just go through the steps:

Decreasing the discount rate will increase the amount of loans commercial banks take from the Federal Reserve. This will increase the money supply, shifting the Sm curve to the right and the SLF curve to the right (draw these out). This will decrease nominal and real interest rates, which will work to increase business investment due to higher profitability of loans. This will then increase aggregate demand. Obviously, an increase in government spending will increase aggregate demand as well. Walking through these steps should come quickly if you understand the underlying principles of each one.
fields.title: Expansionary vs. Contractionary Policies

fields.content:
Foreign exchange rates compare the relative strengths of two nation's currencies. For example, the U.S. dollar exchange rate for the euro might be $5 for \u20ac1. This means that 1 euro can get you five U.S. dollars. In this case, the euro is stronger than the dollar. If the value of \u20ac1 increased to $8, then the euro would have been said to have increased in strength, or appreciated. On the other hand, if the euro's value decreased, then it would have been said to have depreciated. For the sake of this course, we will only compare the exchange rates of two currencies with each other

Appreciation vs. Inflation

As you know, if inflation and the general price level in the United States increased, then the U.S. dollar's purchasing power would decrease because one dollar wouldn't be able to get you as much in the future when the prices of goods are higher. Many people assume that since the dollar's purchasing power would decrease, then the dollar would depreciate against other currencies, such as the euro, because the dollar's value is less. This is false; the dollar would only decrease in the United States alone, not in other countries. Inflation/deflation doesn't directly translate to depreciation/appreciation.Here's an example:The exchange rate of the dollar for the euro is $2 for \u20ac1. An apple in the United States costs $0.50. One dollar can get you two apples, and one euro can get you four apples. Inflation causes the price of an apple to rise to $1. Now, one dollar can only get you one apple, but one euro can now only get you two apples. As you can see, both the dollar "and the euro became weaker in the United States. However, relative to each other, the value of the dollar and the euro stayed the same.
fields.title: Introduction

fields.content:
Just like money, loanable funds, and overall output, there is a market for foreign currencies. The concepts of demand and supply curves are the same as with every graph we've done. When comparing two countries' currencies, we must make a graph of both countries' currencies' marketsThe horizontal axes just represent the quantity of dollars or euros in supply. The vertical axes represent the exchange rate for each currency. For example, \u20ac/$ represents the value of the dollar. Think about it like this: "euros per dollar; how many euros can I get for one dollar? On the AP exam, you can write symbols like \u20ac/$ however you want (e.x. euros/dollar or euros/$).I like to remember that the dollar market has "Dollars" on the bottom axis, so $ will be on the bottom of the fraction of the exchange rate in that market. The same goes for every other currency.

Demand

When a foreign country spends (either through its government or its people) money in another country, it must convert its foreign currency to that country's currency. Thus, it has a certain "demand for that currency. That's what the demand curve represents; the demand of a foreign country for another country's currency. In the case of the Euro Market, the demand curve represents how much U.S. citizens demand euros in order to buy European products.When foreign spending increases in another country, it must increase its conversion to that country's currency, so the demand for that currency increases. For example, if the price level of goods in the United States decreased, European people would want to buy more of American goods because they would be cheaper. In order to increase spending in America, Europeans would have to convert more euros to American dollars. Therefore, the demand curve of the dollar market would shift to the right

Supply

When a foreign country increases its spending in a country, it needs to increase its conversion to that currency (so the demand curve in that market shifts right). When that foreign country converts to that currency, it 'supplies its own currency for that country's currency. Therefore, the supply curve of the foreign country would shift to the right. This will always be true: when the demand curve in one market shifts right, the supply curve in the "other market will shift right as well.

Example

Of course, there's a 48% chance that yore confused, so I'll just give an exampleHere are the two markets for the dollar and the euro. The price level in the United States increases. Therefore, the goods and services are more expensive to everyone, including Europeans. Therefore, Europeans would decrease their spending in the United States.This means that they wouldn't need to convert to dollars to purchase goods and services as much, so the demand for the dollar would decrease. Therefore, the demand curve in the Dollar Market would shift to the left.Since Europeans would convert to dollars "less, 'they would supply 'less euros to convert. Thus, the supply curve in the Euro Market would shift to the left.The result of the shift in curves would be the same: euros/$ would decrease and $/euro would increase. You can analyze either to see which currency appreciates/depreciates.If euros/$ decreased, then one dollar would get you 'less euros than before. Thus, the dollar would be weaker, which means that it would depreciate relative to the euro.Obviously, since the dollar is weaker, the euro is stronger. Because the euro is stronger relative to the dollar, goods in the United States are now cheaper for Europeans using the euro. This means that foreign spending in the United States will increase. More specifically, the United States' "exports to Europeans will increase.The depreciation of the dollar also means that European goods will be more expensive for Americans using the dollar. Thus,the United States' imports from foreign countries will decrease. Overall, the effect of the depreciation of the dollar is that the United States' net exports (X-M) will increase.Yes, I know it seems odd... First, foreign spending in the United States decreased, and then as a result of the change in exchange rates, foreign spending in the United States increased. Take note whether a question asks how aggregate demand changes in the short-run or in the long-run.
fields.title: Foreign Exchange Market

fields.content: The example above already touched on this. When the price levels in one country are higher, goods and services are more expensive for everyone, including foreign countries. Therefore, foreign countries decrease spending in that country, which means that there is less need for foreigners to convert their currency to that country's currency. This translates to the supply of the foreign currency decreasing and the demand of the other country's currency decreasing as well.Of course, if the price levels in a country decrease, the opposite holds true: the supply of the foreign currency and the demand for that country's currency would increase due to the same logic.e.x. If the price levels in the Europe increased, then goods and services would be more expensive to everyone, including Americans. Therefore, Americans would decrease their spending in Europe, which means that there is less need to convert dollars to euros. This means that the demand of euros and the supply of dollars would both decrease.
fields.title: Price Levels

fields.content: Businesses don't like high real interest rates because they have to pay back more than they take out, known as interest. Investors, however, love high real interest rates because bonds pay "them a form of interest, known as a yield. When real interest rates increase in a country, foreign investors increase their investment in bonds because they are more "profitable" (yes, the opposite of loans, which are less profitable). In order to purchase these bonds, foreigners must convert more of their currency to that country's currency. This translates to the supply of the foreign currency increasing and the demand of the other country's currency increasing as well.If a country's real interest rates decrease, then the opposite holds true: the supply of the foreign currency and the demand for that country's currency would decrease due to the same logic.e.x. If the real interest rates in the United States increased, then bond would have higher yields (i.e. more profitable). Therefore, Europeans would increase their spending in America, which means that there would be a greater need to convert euros to dollars. This means that the demand of dollars and the supply of euros would both increase.
fields.title: Real Interest Rates

fields.content: When a country's national income/real GDP increases, its people have more expendable income. Thus, they will increase spending in not only their own country, but in other countries as well. Therefore, they will need to convert more of their currency to a foreign country's currency. As a result, the demand for the currency of the foreign country increases, and the supply of the original country's currency rises as well.If a country's national income decreases , its people will have less expendable income and will thus decrease spending in a foreign country. Therefore, there is less need to convert to the foreign country's currency. Thus the demand of the foreign country's currency and the supply of the original country's currency both decrease.e.x. If the real GDP in the United States increased, then Americans would have more expendable income. Therefore, American spending in European countries would increase, which means that there would be a greater need to convert dollars to euros. This means that the demand of euros and the supply of dollars would both increase.
fields.title: National Income

fields.content: Every country has a current account and a capital account. The current and capital accounts of a country must always sum to be zero. Therefore, when one goes up, the other must go down. The current account, which is more focused on by the AP exam, is basically net exports. For example, if the United States' exports to China increased, then America's net exports would increase as well. Assuming that the United States' current and capital accounts were both initially zero, America's current account would increase to a surplus, and its capital account would decrease to a deficit.
fields.title: Current and Capital Accounts

fields.content:
There are many ways to calculate a country's GDP, but the easiest way is by the expenditure approach

Expenditure Approach

Calculating GDP by the expenditure approach is easy: all one must do is add up the all the spending on final goods and services in a given year. The GDP has four components, and it's important that you know all of them. They are: personal consumption (C), business investment (I), government spending (G), and net exports (X-M)
Personal Consumption (C)
I refer to it as consumer spending because that's exactly what it is: the total amount households (consumers) spend on goods and services. Consumer spending accounts for the largest portion of the GDP by far. There are two types of goods that consumers spend money on:
  • Durable goods are things that last for a while, such as refrigerators and computers.
  • Non-durable goods are things that don't last for a while, such as food and tissues.
Business Investment (I)
For the sake of this course, business investment refers to investment in factors of production. Any time you see business investment, you should immediately think of factors of production. An increase in factors of production, including technology, results in economic growth. This is very important to know later in this course, as the AP exam is starting to stress this idea.Business investment can include:
  • spending on capital goods that enable it produce more
  • increases in inventory (goods not sold in the year they were produced)
Government Spending (G)
Government spending includes any projects or programs that spend money on producing a good or service, such as the construction of highways or paying an official's salary. What's important to note is that transfer payments (money granted from the government to beneficiaries, such as people with pensions or entitled to Social Security) are "not included in the calculation of GDP. The reason why is that transfer payments aren't involved in production. (Paying an official's salary is different; the government is paying for his service.)"
Net Exports (X-M)
This is as simple as it sounds: the value of exports (X) minus the value of imports (M).
GDP Equation
So all of these components are used in an equation: GDP = C + I + G + (X-M). To be honest, you'll never probably "use" this equation; it should be common sense that the increase of a component should result in the increase of GDP.

Income Approach

The income approach includes labor income (salaries and wages), rent, interest, the profits of businesses, and statistical discrepancies. Instead of using outputs to measure GDP as in the expenditures approach, the income approach uses these inputs. Both approaches will yield the same GDP. Therefore, the GDP is often referred to as the national income as well.
fields.title: Calculating Gdp

fields.content: Inflation makes the prices of goods rise, but it doesn't raise the actual "value of those goods. All inflation does is decrease the purchasing power of money; a dollar this year won't be able to buy you as much if you spend it next year. Inflation also makes a country's nominal GDP falsely represent what the country actually produces each year.Say a country's only production is apples, 5 last year and 4 this year. If the price of an apple was $1 last year and $3 this year, the country's GDP would have been $5 last year and $12 this year. This makes it look the the country produced more than it really did, even though it made less apples. What we just calculated was the country's nominal GDP, the total monetary value of goods and services produced each year. The real GDP, on the other hand, is more telling of a country's production. Real GDP accounts for inflation and measures output based on what the final goods and services "would have sold for in a "base year If we chose last year to be the base year, then the real GDP would have been $5 last year and $4 this year.
fields.title: Inflation and Real Gdp

fields.content:
The GDP deflator, or the GDP price index, is used to find the real GDP of a country. The GDP deflator is found by first making a basket of general goods, such as food, water, and other basic items that costs $100 in the base year. Then, one must calculate the price of the basket in a later year. The new price of the basket is the GDP deflator (just remove the $ sign from the number). The real GDP is calculated by the equation: 'Calculating the real GDP on free response problems is not bad. You will most likely either:
  • be given the price of certain goods in the base year and another year, along with the quantity of goods sold in each year
OR
  • be given the price of goods in a year, the quantity of goods sold in that year, and the GDP deflator
From this information, you should easily be able to calculate real GDP.
fields.title: Gdp Deflator

fields.content: Economies can fluctuate, undergoing short run growths and recession's - the peaks and valleys, respectively. However, economic growth is the increase in real GDP 'over time. It is the growth in real GDP that you see when you look at the economy in the long run. To the left is a graph of the business cycle. You won't need to use this on the AP exam, but it is helpful to understand what long run economic growth looks like.
fields.title: The Business Cycle

fields.content: Business investment increases the quantity and quality of factors of production. Therefore, this enables a country to produce more, creating economic growth. The graph on the left illustrates a country undergoing long run economic growth. It has the ability to produce more goods than is could have before, which is why the PPC shifts to the right. If you are ever asked to show economic growth on a PPC graph, this is what it should look like.
fields.title: Economic Growth and the Ppc

fields.content: Per capita GDP is a measure of a country's standard of living. It can be found by diving the real GDP of a country by that country's population. Per capita GDP is usually a better indicator of a country's productivity than real GDP is because it takes into account population. Therefore, economists would also define economic growth as the increase in per capita GDP over time as well as the definition given above.
fields.title: Per Capita Gdp

fields.content: The inflation rate a quantitative measure of how much the general price level has changed from one year to another. It is found with a price index (price of basket of goods), such as the GDP deflator. However, the base year doesn't strictly have to be 100 to work. The equation for the inflation rate is:, where CPI'1 is the first price index of the base year, CPI'2 is the price index of a different year after the base year, and inflation rate is a decimal (multiply it by 100 to get the rate in % form). Ex: if the price index is 50 in one year and 55 in the next year, what was the rate of inflation between the two years? = .1 = 10%You might get a chart with a basket of goods and each good's price listed on the AP exam. You should be able to calculate each year's price index and then calculate the inflation rate with your answers.Just to note, the equation above can be used to calculate the percent increase in anything. For example, if someone's real wages goes up from $10/hour to $14/hour, then the real wage increase rate would be 40%.
fields.title: Inflation Rate

fields.content:
The equation above is useful for any "percent increase" calculation. You might need to calculate the percent change in real or nominal GDP. Just use the same method above. Speaking of, there is another general equation to know:The AP exam asks questions involving the above equation all the time. There are usually two types:

GDP and Wage Rate

Wage rates are often increased as a result of inflationary expectations; otherwise, workers would actually be losing 'real wages, or the actual purchasing power their wages have. Yoll often be asked to calculate what workers' real wage rate increase is.Ex: If next year's wage rate will be 4% higher than this year and the inflation rate is 3%, what would be the percent increase in "real wage rates?Easy, just plug stuff into the equation above: real rate = 4% - 3% = 1%. The real wage rate would increase by 1%.Ex: If, due to inflationary expectations, next year's wage rate was increased by 5%, but the inflation rate was 7%, would workers' real wages next year be greater than, less than, or equal to their real wages today?Once again, just use the equation: real rate = 5% - 7% = -2%. The real wage would increase by -2%, or "decrease by 2% (both statements mean the same). So, their real wages next year would be less than today.

Interest Rate

Just like wages, interest rates are adjusted in order to account for inflation. If inflation rates weren't increased as a result of inflationary expectations, borrowers would be paying their lenders back with less valuable dollars. To understand this, think about someone giving you $1,000 without any expectation of you paying interest. If you pay him back two years later, wouldn't those dollars be less valuable than when you got them? The $1,000 you received could buy you 100 apples, but the $1,000 you paid back two years later could maybe only get your friend 60 apples. In this case, you were paying back negative real interest.Ex: If the inflation rate is 4%, and the nominal interest rate is 8%, what is the real interest rate?Use the same equation: real interest rate = 8% - 4% = 4%. The real interest rate is 4%.More often than not, the AP exam will use the phrase unexpected inflation. Unexpected inflation will always help out borrowers because, as aforementioned, they pay back less valuable dollars. *This doesn't mean borrowers make money off their loans; it just means that they're technically paying back less than they were supposed to.Ex: Mark received a fixed-rate loan from a bank when the inflation rate was 2%. If the inflation rate quickly rises to 4%, who benefits from the unexpected inflation: Mark, the bank, both, or neither?As I wrote before, unexpected inflation always benefits the borrower because he pays back less valuable money than what he's supposed to. Mark clearly benefits over the the bank.
fields.title: Real, Nominal, and Inflation

fields.content: Inflation is often used as an indicator of a country's standard of living. Since it decreases the purchasing power of money, if people aren't making more nominal money, they are making less real money. This is a good way to tell that a country's standard of living is dropping.Inflation can often be an inaccurate way to assess certain households' standard of living. Inflation is based on a price index calculated from the price of a basket of goods. If some households don't regularly consume goods in this basket, they "could be relatively unaffected by inflation. Be aware of this.
fields.title: Standard of Living

fields.content:
I'm going to be honest with you by saying that you don't need to fully understand these two terms, but you should at least know them

Demand-Pull Inflation

When people want a certain good, they're probably willing to pay for it. When "a lot of people 'really want a certain good in limited supply, they're probably willing to pay "more for it.' It's common sense: the more people want a limited good, the higher the price the good will go for, like in an auction. This describes demand-pull inflation. If demand for goods overall increases (called aggregate demand), so will the general price level, marking inflation. Likewise, if the aggregate demand decreases, so will the general price level.Factors that affect aggregate demand will be discussed in a later chapter

Cost-Push Inflation

As a businessman, if the prices to produce your goods goes up, would you take on the difference in profit, or would you pass this on to your customers by raising the prices of of your goods? Most would choose the latter. This describes cost-push inflation. Any time the per unit costs of production of goods rises, so will the general price level. Likewise, if the per unit cost of production of goods lower, so will the general price level.Factors that affect per unit costs of production will be discussed in a later chapter.
fields.title: Types of Inflation

fields.content: The workforce is defined as the total number of a country's citizens employed plus all those unemployed who are actively seeking work. The workforce includes all those in the armed forces, but "does not include those who are institutionalized and those who are younger than 16 (or older than 64).
fields.title: The Workforce

fields.content: The unemployment rate (in % form) equals '.The unemployment rate is used to measure an economy's health. Obviously, lower unemployment rates are generally good. High unemployment rates occur during recessions.The unemployment rate can understate the severity of a recession due to an abundance discouraged workers. Discouraged workers are those that are unemployed and have given up looking for jobs. Since they are not actively seeking work, they are not a part of the work force, and are therefore not technically considered unemployed. If a large amount of the unemployed became discouraged workers, the unemployment rate would actually drop, even though more people are "not getting jobs. The drop in unemployment rate works out mathematically with the equation above; you don't need to understand the math - just understand why discouraged workers understate the severity of recessions.
fields.title: Unemployment Rate

fields.content:
There are a few types of unemployment. The differences between them are basic, and you should know them for the AP exam.

Seasonal Unemployment

Around Christmas time, many people go out shopping. Therefore, many stores higher a few more employees to manage the sales. After this period of high traffic, stores let go of unneeded workers. This is an example of seasonal unemployment, unemployment due to changes in the season.

Frictional Unemployment

Frictional unemployment is unemployment that comes from changing jobs, careers, or location. Frictional unemployment comes voluntarily, instead of from an outside force such as a recession.
  • Someone who just graduated college yesterday is frictionally unemployed, not because he can't find a job, but because he's just started looking for one.
  • Someone who quits his job because he finds it low-paying is frictionally unemployed. He wasn't let go due to a recession; he chose to quit in order to find a better job.
Frictional unemployment is considered as natural unemployment. Yes, a couple of types of unemployment are indicators of a healthy economy. For example, an economy that has frictional unemployment is probably doing well because people are confident enough to quit their jobs in search for other ones.

Structural Unemployment

Structural unemployment comes from a change in demand of workers' skill sets. Workers for a type of job are just no longer needed anymore
  • For example, factory workers might be let go because a company bought a machine that can do the same job as them. Their "craft" is no longer needed anymore, so they are without employment.
  • The popularization of computers is another example. Typewriters are no longer needed, as people can do all their work on laptops and computers. Thus, typewriter manufacturing companies went bankrupt and left all their employees without work.
As you probably guessed, structural unemployment is usually the result of increases in technology. It is therefore considered the other type of natural unemployment. Increases in technology obviously have a profound affect on productivity, as well as economic growth (since it's a factor of production, remember?)

Cyclical Unemployment

Cyclical unemployment is the result of recessions (drops in real GDP). If real GDP decreases, that means less goods and services are being produced, and as a result, there is less need for workers. This is the type of unemployment I'll refer to in later chapters.
fields.title: Types of Unemployment

fields.content: Full employment does not refer to a time in which the unemployment rate is 0%. No, like I said above, structural and frictional types of unemployment are good for economies. Full employment refers to a period in which there is no cyclical unemployment. Full employment means that the economy is operating at its 'optimum capacity, 'not its maximum.There is a term I'll use interchangeably with full employment, NAIRU. It stands for non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment. I know it probably seems confusing, but it's not. Yoll learn later that inflation and unemployment are inversely proportional to each other; inflation happens during economic prosperity, while unemployment happens during recessions. An economy at NAIRU, or full employment, has lowest unemployment rate (0% cyclical) possible that won't cause large inflation.As you can see on the graph to the left, an economy's maximum productive capacity is on the curve. This would entail absolutely no cyclical, structural, or frictional unemployment. This is not optimal for an economy, both because structural and frictional types of unemployment are indicators of good health "and because this would cause large inflation. No, the optimal point the economy should be at is on the dashed line (don't draw this on a free response; it's just to help you understand). Once again, this means the economy is at NAIRU, full employment.If you remember in a previous section, I talked about shifting the PPC... Any shift in the PPC will also shift the NAIRU dashed line in the same direction. In case you forgot, any increase in the quantity of quality of factors of production will shift the PPC (and NAIRU) to the right because an economy will then have the ability to produce more.NAIRU is very important to understand, as there will be a bunch of graphs including the PPC that will all incorporate NAIRU. Throughout the course, I'll go through each one, and towards the end, you'll see them all link together. It'll make so much sense, you'll blow your load.
fields.title: Full Employment

fields.content:
You learned before that nominal wages are the dollars a worker makes, but real wages are the actual value of that worker's income (exactly like nominal GDP versus real GDP). In the short-run, which means immediately after an economic event, nominal wages stay the same, or are "sticky". Workers can't ask their employers to raise their pay increase right away. As a result, workers' real wages can change in the short-run based on the effect an economic event has on inflation. However, in the long-run, workers' nominal wages will adjust accordingly to the level of inflation so that they are making the same as before the economic event. Wages in the long-run are therefore called "flexibleOnce again, examples will help explain this:

Recession

Let's say that a nation that was previously at full employment experienced a drop in aggregate demand. Using the AD-AS graph, shifting the AD curve to the left would yield lower real GDP and lower price levels (if this doesn't come automatically to you, keep drawing the actual graph out). This would correlate with lower inflation and higher unemployment. Since workers' nominal wage rates stay the same and inflation is lower, real wages actually increase. Proof - Remember the rate equation: real rate = nominal rate - inflation rate. "Nominal rate" is the nominal wage increase rate, and it stays the same in the short run. Since the inflation rate decreases, the real wage increase rate goes up in the short-run. 'Anyway, this has two effects in the long-run:
  • Because workers' real wage rates increase rate went up, it is understandable for employers to drop the nominal wage increase rate.
  • Because unemployment is so high, the demand for workers is not that high. Therefore, the "price" of employing a worker becomes lower because they're now willing to work for cheap. AKA, workers will accept lower nominal wage rates.

These two result in the decrease in the nominal wage rate. If you remember, I said that wages are part of businesses' expenses. Since nominal wage rates are decreasing, businesses' expenses are decreasing as well. Thus, the per unit cost of production is decreasing also. The decrease in per unit cost of production will increase aggregate supply, shifting the AS curve to the right. This shift will decrease price levels and increase real GDP to bring the economy back to full employment. The entire process is shown in the graph. Red is the first shift, and blue is the second shift.

Inflation

Price wage flexibility works the same way with inflation. Let's say that a nation that was previously at full employment experienced an increase in aggregate demand. Using the AD-AS graph, shifting the AD curve to the right would yield higher real GDP and higher price levels. This would correlate with higher inflation and lower unemployment. Since workers' nominal wage rates stay the same and inflation is higher, real wages decrease. "This has two effects in the long-run:
  • Because workers' real wage increase rate went down, it is understandable for workers to ask for an increase in nominal wage rates.
  • Because unemployment is so low, the demand for workers is high. Therefore, the "price" of employing a worker becomes much higher because workers are scarce in quantity. AKA, employers are willing to increase nominal wages to keep/hire workers.
These two result in the increase in the nominal wage rate. Since nominal wage rates are increasing, businesses' expenses are increasing as well. Thus, the per unit cost of production is increasing also. The increase in per unit cost of production will decrease aggregate supply, shifting the AS curve to the left. This shift will increase price levels and decrease output to bring the economy back to full employment. The entire process is shown in the graph. Red is the first shift, and blue is the second shift. (As you can see, it's the complete opposite of the recessionary situation)"

Summary

Hopefully you understand that both examples of price wage flexibility worked in the same way: workers' real wage rates are affected by the increase/decrease of inflation. In the long-run, workers' nominal wage rates will adjust in an attempt to correct this change. In doing so, businesses' expenses are affected, resulting in a change in the per unit cost of production. This will change aggregate supply, bringing the nation's economy back to full employment.I must stress again that this is a possible scenario. You won't use price wage flexibility to solve every problem on the AP exam. Yoll be guided by the question into using price wage flexibility if that's what the problem calls for.Ex: Assume that France's economy is in a recession. In the absence of any changes in fiscal or monetary policies, what will happen to the price level in the long run? Here we know that the economy must be changed by a market mechanism because the question says that the government won't interfere with the economy. You could easily use the process of price-wage flexibility to determine that the aggregate supply curve would shift to the right, increasing output to full employment and decreasing the general price level.Note: Did you notice that because of price-wage flexibility, in the long-run, the price level will change, but output will not? This is the reason why the long-run Phillips curve is vertical - in the long-run, there is no trade off between the inflation and unemployment (changes in inflation won't affect the long-run unemployment rate, NAIRU ).
fields.title: Price Wage Flexibility

fields.content:
Preface

I'm just prefacing this section by saying that any time you're asked about a market mechanism (like above), you should probably use price-wage flexibility unless what I'm going to show you definitely seems like it fits the problem. The loanable funds mechanism can still "work," but it's more involved than price-wage flexibility.

Loanable Funds Market

The loanable funds graph is all about how the supply or demand of loans will change real interest rates. The supply of loans can be thought of as the amount of money banks have available to loan out. For example, if the marginal propensity to 'save in a nation increased, people would start saving more of their money. Thus, the amount of money banks hold would increase. Then, banks would have more money to loan out to businesses and people. This is the same thing as saying that the 'supply of loanable funds would increase. The demand for loanable funds is simple too: it's based on the amount of people/businesses who want to take out loans. If, for some reason, people started to take out massive amounts of loans, the demand for loanable funds would increaseThe loanable funds graph works the same way as the AD-AS graph, but instead of goods and services, the market is for loans. There is no long-run supply of loanable funds or anything, just the supply of loanable funds (S'LF) and the demand for loanable funds (D'LF). The intersection of these two points will be the equilibrium of the loanable funds market, which will determine the quantity of loanable funds and the real interest rate (real i). You won't ever have to worry about the quantity of loanable funds; the real interest rate is the only outcome of the graph that you should know.The main idea of real interest rates changing is how that impacts business investment, which you have already learned about. When real interest rates decrease, loans become more profitable for businesses to take out. Therefore, business investment increases, which increases aggregate demand as well. When real interest rates increase, loans become less profitable for businesses to take out. Therefore, business investment decreases, which decreases aggregate demand as well. Once again, don't try to memorize these rules; try to conceptualize profitability as the link between real interest rates and business investment.
Demand of Loanable Funds
The following are common triggers that shift the demand for loanable funds curve:
  • Increase/decrease in government spending will shift DLF to the right/left, respectively
    • *Will learn more about later
  • Increase/decrease in consumer demand for loans, particularly during periods of high inflation, will shift DLF to the right/left, respectively
As you can see, shifting the D'LF curve will change real interest rates, which will set off the chain reaction described above. Don't memorize which shift direction will increase/decrease real interest rates. Just know how to shift the curve, and then interpret the graph. In the instance of the graph to the left, you'll see that shifting the D"LF curve to the right increases real interest rates.
Supply of Loanable Funds
The following are common triggers that shift the supply of loanable funds curve:
  • An increase/decrease in the supply of money will shift the SLF to the right/left, respectively
    • *Will learn more about later
  • An increase/decrease in the marginal propensity to save (people start saving more money) will shift the SLF to the right/left, respectively
As you can see, shifting the S'LF curve will change real interest rates, which will set off the chain reaction described above. Don't memorize which shift direction will increase/decrease real interest rates. Just know how to shift the curve, and then interpret the graph. In the instance of the graph to the left, you'll see that shifting the S"LF curve to the left decreases real interest rates. (Yes, I copied and pasted this paragraph.)

Loanable Funds Market as a Market Mechanism

Now that you understand the loanable funds market, we'll see how the loanable funds market could theoretically self correct an economy.
Recession
Let's say that a nation that was previously at full employment experienced a drop in aggregate demand. Using the AD-AS graph, shifting the AD curve to the left would yield lower real GDP and lower price levels . This would correlate with lower inflation and higher unemployment. Because of such high unemployment, people would be fearful of losing their jobs and thus start saving more money in order to support them in case they do become unemployed. Obviously, this means that banks would hold more money, causing an increase in the supply of loanable funds, shifting the S"LF curve to the right.This shift in the S'LF curve would cause real interest rates to drop, as seen on the Market for Loanable Funds graph. Because real interest rates would be lower, the profitability of loans for businesses would increase, thus increasing business investment (don't forget the investment demand curve; you should be able to use this to prove the increase in business investment). This increase in business investment would increase aggregate demand, shifting the AD curve to the right, bringing the economy back to full employment.The entire process is shown in the graph. Red is the first shift, and blue is the second shift.
Inflation
Let's say that a nation that was previously at full employment experienced an increase in aggregate demand. Using the AD-AS graph, shifting the AD curve to the right would yield higher real GDP and price levels. This would correlate with higher inflation and lower unemployment. The high inflation would reduce the purchasing power of money. Therefore, businesses (and households) would have to take out more loans in order to continue to finance their investment/purchases. Thus, the demand for loanable funds would increase, shifting the D"LF curve to the right.This shift in the D'LF curve would cause real interest rates to increase, as seen on the Market for Loanable Funds graph. Because real interest rates would be higher, the profitability of loans for businesses would decrease, thus decreasing business investment. This decrease in business investment would decrease aggregate demand, shifting the AD curve to the left, bringing the economy back to full employment.The entire process is shown in the graph. Red is the first shift, and blue is the second shift.

Rational Expectations Theory

The good thing about this section is that yove already learned the process. Rational expectations theory is notion that households (people) make economic decisions based on their expectations of the future in the pursuit of self-interest. In doing so, however, they make economic policies ineffective. Yoll learn about monetary and fiscal policies later, but knowledge of them is not necessary to understand rational expectations theory.Really all rational expectations theory is price-wage flexibility. The AP exam will often ask how an increase in the expected amount of inflation will affect the economy. This is just like the example we did "above, except the inflation is already 'expected. This means that workers will quickly act to demand higher nominal wages. The rest of the process is the same as above, except that the shift in AD and the shift in AS happen at the same time.If the AP exam asks about expected unemployment, it's just the same concept of price wage flexibility discussed above about recessions. Once again, since it's already expected, the processes are simultaneous. However, the College Board will almost always ask about inflation instead.Just remember: rational expectations theory is exactly the same thing as price-wage flexibility. When policy makers try to influence the economy, rational expectations theory essentially makes their efforts ineffective. In the case of expected inflation, rational expectations theory results in the economy having same real GDP but higher inflation (thus higher nominal GDP as well). You shouldn't memorize this, just go through the process to figure it out. On the AP exam, you'll most likely be given an economic policy (will discuss next chapter) and will have to understand that it will create high inflation/unemployment, from which point, the rest is just price-wage flexibility.
fields.title: Loanable Funds

fields.content:
The most important parts of classical economics are understanding the processes and graphs used. You probably won't see that whole "loanable funds market mechanism," but you should understand it. However, the AP exam will definitely include questions regarding price-wage flexibility and rational expectations theory, so make sure you know them. It shouldn't be too hard, considering they're the same thing, eh?

Keynesian Economics

Keynesian economics is all about the government aiding the economy. Yove already seen Keynesian economics at work.For example, if the economy is in a recession, the government might increase its expenditures. This increase in government spending would increase aggregate demand, shifting the AD curve to the right to bring the economy back to full employment.Another example: if the economy is facing high inflation, the government might increase personal income taxes. This would leave people with less money to spend, and as a result, consumer spending/consumption would decrease. Therefore, aggregate demand would decrease as well, shifting the AD curve to the left to bring the economy back to full employment.Keynesian economics is just basic aggregate demand change due to government actions".
fields.title: Summary

fields.content: Keynesian economists believe that more often than not, economies are in recessions, and the government must aid them in order to push them towards full employment. This is why many questions regarding Keynesian economics have to do with recessions. Traditionally, Keynesian economists think that economies are so far in recession that they lie along the flat part of the AS curve (far to the left), known as the Keynesian range. This results in their belief that increases in aggregate demand due to government involvement in the economy will raise real GDP while only increasing the general price level by a slim amount.The graph to the left is a good illustration of the Keynesian economists' belief. As you can see, shifting the AD curve to the right raises price levels by a negligible amount when the economy lies on the Keynesian range of the AS curve.There is a classical range of the AS curve as well, but it's not in the scope of this course.
fields.title: Range of as Curve

fields.content: Let's say that a nation that is in a recession. In order to combat this, Keynesian economists would advocate that the government increase its expenditures.. This increase in government spending would increase aggregate demand as well, shifting the AD curve to the right and bringing the economy back to full employment.But wait, how would the government pay for the increase in expenditures? If the government received no extra revenue but increased its expenses, it would have a budget deficit - more money going out that coming in. In order to finance its budget deficit, the government would actually have to borrow from the private sector (banks). This increase in borrowing would result in an increase in the demand for loanable funds as well, shifting the D"<sub>LF</sub> curve to the right. This would result in the increase of real interest rates.If real interest rates became higher, the profitability of loans that businesses take out would decrease, which means that business investment would decrease as well. The decrease in business investment would also decrease aggregate demand, shifting the AD curve the left, pulling the economy back into a recession. Furthermore, this decrease in business investment will decrease the production of factors of production, which will slow down the long-run economic growth rate of the nation.As you can see, the crowding out effect makes government interaction with the economy ineffective. More important, however, is how crowding out specifically decreases business investment and therefore long-run economic growth rates.The crowding out effect happens as a result of Keynesian economics. Classical economists use the crowding out effect as an argument for why Keynesian economics hurt the economy. Please don't think that crowding out is something that Keynesian economists "came up with It is just a possible side effect of Keynesian economics on the economy.
fields.title: Walk Through

fields.content: Classical economists believe that real interest rates have a profound impact on business investment. Their concept of the investment demand curve is that business investment is elastic, or very dependent on real interest rates. A change in real interest rates results in a large change in business investment. This is consistent with the classical ideology discussed above.
fields.title: Classical Investment Demand

fields.content: Keynesian economists believe that real interest rates don't have a large effect on business investment. Their concept of the investment demand curve is that business investment is inelastic, or largely independent of real interest rates. The same change in real interest rates used in the graph above yields a very small change in business investment. This is consistent with the Keynesian ideology discussed above.
fields.title: Keynesian Investment Demand

fields.content: Bond prices are inversely related to interest rates. When interest rates go up, bond prices fall, and vice-versa. Don't worry about the explanation... but I'll add it on anyway. Let's say I bought a bond that gave me a 5% yield/interest rate. If the real interest rate goes up, new bonds will offer yields higher than 5%, maybe 7% or something. These new bonds are obviously more attractive to people because they give them larger payouts. Now, my 5% bond will still only give me a 5% yield. Which bond is someone going to want to buy, the 5% bond or the 7% bond? Clearly the 7% bond! This means that I'll have to lower the price of my 5% bond in order to get someone to want to buy it over the 7% bond. As you see, as the real interest rate increases, the prices of existing bonds decrease because they're less valuable.
fields.title: Bond Prices

fields.content: The AP exam might refer to the term "stagflation This is a phenomenon marked by the simultaneous increase of both inflation and unemployment (the economy is "stagnating" and suffering "inflation"). Stagflation occurs when short-run aggregate supply decreases (the AS curve shifts to the left). Try it out, and you'll see that real GDP will decrease, while price levels will increase. This is synonymous with the increase of both inflation and unemployment.
fields.title: Stagflation

fields.content: The federal funds rate is the interest rate that commercial banks charge for loans that they take out from each other. The Federal Reserve can target a federal funds rate through open market operations. The federal funds rate changes in the same way as real interest rates. When the Fed sells bonds to banks, banks 'give money to the Fed for the bonds. Thus, their excess reserves decrease, which increases the federal funds rates because loanable funds will be in limited supply. When the Fed buys bonds from banks, banks 'get money from the Fed for the bonds. Thus, their excess reserves increase, which increases the federal funds rates because there will be an abundance of loanable funds. The Fed doesn't use its other tools to target the federal funds rate; it only uses open market operations. When the federal funds rate is lower, loans are cheaper for banks to take out from other banks. This enables banks to lower the real interest rate that they charge normal people for loans as well. This, of course, has a chain effect that will ultimately end up in the increase in aggregate demand. On the other hand, when the federal funds rate is higher, real interest rates increase, which decreases aggregate demand.
fields.title: Federal Funds Rate

fields.content:
The equation of exchange is: $latex MV=QP&fg=007fff$

where M is the total amount of money in circulation in a country (the money supply), V is the velocity of money, P is the price level, and Q is real GDP.

Technically, real GDP times the price level equals nominal GDP, so the right side of the equation is just equivalent to the nominal GDP in a nation. Yoll probably only really see this on a multiple choice question. A good example of a question might be:
