If the velocity of money is stable, an increase in the money supply will result in which of the following?

    1. a decrease in the inflation rate
    2. a decrease in the unemployment rate
    3. a decrease in real GDP
    4. an increase in government spending
    5. an increase in nominal output
Well, if V is constant, and M increases, then the quantity QP must increase as well. QP = nominal GDP, so (e) is the correct answer.
fields.title: Equation of Exchange

fields.content:
The circular flow model just describes how money "flows" through the economy. Businesses, or firms, provide households (consumers) with goods and services in return for their money. Households provide businesses with factors of production, such as land and labor. In return, businesses compensate households with wages, rent, etc.

Leakages/Injections

Money can be injected into the circular flow of the economy, or it can be leaked from it. Things like government transfer payments, export revenues, and increases in loans are examples of injections into the circular flow of a nation's economy because they help create more production and spending. Things like imports, personal income taxes, and increased savings of money in banks are examples of leakages from the circular flow because they reduce production and spending.
fields.title: Circular Flow

fields.content: Some people get confused between the debt and the deficit. Every year, the federal government has a budget, which determines the government's projected revenues and expenses. When the government spends more money than it receives in a year, then the government is facing a budget deficit. When the government spends less money than it receives in a year, the government has a surplus. The national debt is the accumulation of past and current budget deficits and surpluses. So while deficits and surpluses are annual figures, the debt is the total difference between expenses and revenues in the United States' history.
fields.title: Debt

fields.content: The College Board won't always use the United States in its questions. In case you didn't know, the Federal Reserve is America's national bank. Other countries' national banks operate in the same way that the Fed does.
fields.title: National Bank

fields.content: Hyperinflation is just really high and out of control inflation. It most often takes place as a result of continuous expansion of the money supply in order to finance budget deficits.
fields.title: Hyperinflation

fields.content:
The rest of this chapter will just be examples that will incorporate ideas from many different chapters.

  1. Assume that France's economy is currently in a recession.
    1. Draw a correctly labeled graph of aggregate supply, aggregate demand, and long-run aggregate supply.
    2. Draw a correctly labeled graph of the short-run and long-run Phillips curves.
    3. Identify a supply-side fiscal policy that the federal government should implement.
      1. Show the effect of this policy on the the graphs drawn in part (a) and part (b)
    4. Suppose that instead of a fiscal policy, the government implements a monetary policy to solve the recession.
      1. Which open market policy should the Federal Reserve pursue?
      2. Using a correctly labeled graph of the market for loanable funds, show how the policy in part (d)(i) affects real interest rates.
      3. Show the effect of the monetary policy chosen on the graphs drawn in part (a) and part (b)
    5. How could the monetary policy chosen in part (d) effect the growth rate of France's economy?
      1. Show this effect on the graphs drawn in part (a) and part (b)
    6. Now suppose that the government chose to take neither a fiscal policy nor a monetary policy in response to the recession.
      1. What will happen to short-run aggregate supply in the long-run? Explain.
      2. What will happen to the price level as a result of this?
    7. Assume that the United States openly trades with France.
      1. Using a correctly labeled graph of the foreign exchange market for the euro (France's currency), show how the change in price levels in part (f) affects the exchange rate of the U.S. dollar and the euro.
      2. If the United States' current account balance with France was initially zero, how will the price level change in part (f) affect the American current account in the short-run?
Let me preface the answer by saying that you'll in all likelihood never see a problem as long as this one. Also, I will give more in-depth explanation than needed to score points on the AP exam. The text in blue is just to help your comprehension of the answer; you wouldn't have to write it on the AP exam to score full points.(a) An economy in a recession is producing less than it would at full employment, so the equilibrium point should be to the left of the long-run aggregate supply curve.(b) If an economy is producing less than it would at full employment, than it actually has less <em>than</em> full employment. Thus, the unemployment rate should be higher than NAIRU, the natural rate of unemployment (once again, this is just full employment).(c) In order to get the economy back to full employment, we'd have to increase aggregate supply. If the government increased subsidies for businesses, the per unit cost of production would decrease, and thus aggregate supply would increase, shifting the AS curve to the right and getting the economy back to full employment.

(i) Increasing aggregate supply shifts the AS curve to the right, which increases real GDP and lowers the price level. This is synonymous with lowering both unemployment and inflation. The only way this can be achieved on the Phillips curve graph is by shifting the PC to the left. Now, both graphs show that France's economy is at full employment.

  (d)(i) France's national bank should buy bonds. If France's national bank buys bonds, it will <em>give</em> money to commercial banks. This will increase the money supply and the supply of loanable funds, which, as you'll see below, will reduce real interest rates. The reduction in real interest rates will increase business investment due to greater profitability on loans. The increase in business investment will then increase aggregate demand, bringing France's economy back to full employment.

(ii) No explanation is needed. The logic behind this step is explained above. The real interest rate would fall.

.

.

.

(iii) As said before, the reduction in real interest rates would increase business investment, which would increase aggregate demand, shifting the AD curve to the right. This would results in higher output and price levels, which would mean higher inflation and lower unemployment. This is illustrated on the Phillips curve graph by moving along the curve to the left.

 (e) Remember that business investment is always in factors of production. The increase in business investment due to interest rate changes will increase factors of production, which will stimulate long-run economic growth.

(i) Long-run economic growth is synonymous with the increase in long-run aggregate supply, so the LRAS curve will shift to the right. Likewise, the natural rate of unemployment will decrease as a result of this, so the LRPC will shift to the left.

(f)(i) In a recession, price levels are normally lower, which means that workers with fixed wages have high real wages. Therefore, it is acceptable for businesses to lower the nominal wages of workers in the long-run to get their real wages back to their original level. This decrease in nominal wages will lower businesses' expenses, and thus decrease the per unit cost of production. This will increase aggregate supply, which will bring the economy back to full employment.

(ii) An increase in aggregate supply, illustrated by shifting the AS curve to the right, would decrease the price level in France.

(g)(i) A decrease in the price level in France would increase American spending in France because goods and services would be cheaper. In order to pay for the goods, Americans would have to convert their dollars to euros, so the demand for euros would increase, shifting the D curve in the Euro Market to the right. As you can see, $/euro (dollars <em>per</em> euro) would increase, so one euro would be able to get you more dollars. This means that the euro would have gotten stronger. Therefore, the euro would have appreciated relative to the dollar.

(ii) Since Americans would initially increase spending in France, America's imports would increase. This would decrease net exports for the United States. Therefore, America's current account balance would decrease in the short-run. Likewise, France's exports would increase, so France's net exports would increase as well. Therefore, France's current account balance with the United States would increase. Hopefully this makes sense; if one country's net exports go up, then the other country's net exports should go down. Pay attention to the which country's perspective you should take.

Just to add to part (g), yes, the initial effect would increase American spending in France. However, after the change in exchange rates, the euro would be more powerful against the dollar, so goods in France would become more expensive to Americans in the <em>long-run.</em> Therefore, in the long-run, American spending in France would decrease. Yes, it's like another market mechanism that tries to restore equilibrium in economics.

Ground State: The lowest energy state (1)Excited State: Higher energy stateIonization Energy: The amount of energy needed to remove an electron from an atomEnergy Level Diagram: Series of lines that depict different energy levelsElectrons can move between different energy levels.

  • When an electron moves to a higher energy level, energy is absorbed because a photon is absorbed
  • When an electron moves to a lower energy level, energy is released because a photon is released
These leaps in energy levels are called quantum leapsThe energy of the released photon, is equal to the difference of the energy levels the electron leaped from. This can be solved with the equation

where E is the change in energy of the electron, E<sub>i</sub> is the amount of energy in the initial energy level, and E<sub>f</sub> is the amount of energy in the final energy level

Since , this equation can also be written as

where f is the frequency of the photon and h is Planck's Constant

Lyman Series (ultraviolet): Occurs when electrons drop to level 1

Balmer Series (visible): Occurs when electrons drop to level 2

Paschen Series (infrared): Occurs when electrons drop to level 3

As we have seen, light behaves like waves with interference and diffraction, but also behaves like particles with the photoelectric effect. Since a wave can act like a particle, a particle can also behave like a wave. This particle can have a wavelength known as its de Boglie wavelength while also having momentum at the same time. These are all related by the equation

where h is Planck's Constant, p is the momentum, m is the mass, v is the velocity, and λ is the de Broglie wavelength of the particle

fields.content:
When we dealt with acceleration before, it was when something is speeding up or slowing down. In this chapter, we will deal with another form of acceration, centripetal acceleration.Centripetal Acceleration: Acceleration caused by changing direction around a curved path

  • Unit => Meters per Second Squared <img align="absmiddle" alt="\left (\frac{m}{s^{2}} \right )" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?\left&space;(\frac{m}{s^{2}}&space;\right&space;)"/>; Symbol => a<sub>c</sub>
Centripetal Force: Force directed towards the center of a curved path that causes the centripetal acceleration
  • Unit => Newton ; Symbol => Fc
  • The centripetal force vector points in the same direction as the direction of the centripetal accleration vector (towards the center of the curved path)
  • The velocity vector is tangent to the curved path
fields.title: Centripetal Acceleration

fields.content:
Fulcrum: Point of the axis of rotation (on a seesaw the fulcrum is at the center)Torque: Vector quantity that is the product of the distance from the fulcrum and the component of the force perpendicular to the distance

  • Unit => ; Symbol => Τ

where θ is the angle between the distance d and the force F

when a system is in equilibrium

ex.) When one block weighing 10kg is 1 meter from the fulcrum and another block weighing 1kg is 10 meters from the fulcrum, the net torque is 0 as seen below.

fields.content:
Magnetic Flux: The product of an area times the magnetic field perpendicular to that area

  • Unit => Weber ; Symbol => Φ

where B is the magnitude of the magnetic field, A is the amount of area the field is passing through, and θ is the angle between the area vectors and magnetic field vectors
fields.title: Magnetic Flux

fields.content:
Lenz's Law is really displaying conservation of energy. By using your right hand, you can easily use this knowledge to find the direction of the induced current
  • If the flux is decreasing, flux in the same direction needs to be induced to keep the flux constant to conserve energy. Stick your thumb in the direction of the decreasing flux and curl your right hand fingers. They curl in the direction of the induced current.
  • If the flux is increasing, flux in the opposite direction needs to be induced to keep the flux constant to conserve energy. Stick your thumb in the direction opposite the increasing flux and curl your right hand fingers. They curl in the direction of the induced current.
fields.title: Finding the Direction of the Induced Current

fields.content:
Work: Way in which energy is exchanged; scalar quantity that is the product of a force on an object over a distance

  • ex.) Pushing a box does work on the box because you apply a force on the box to move it a distance

  • When the direction of a force is parallel to the distance it is causing it to move, the amount of work done is equal to

where F is the net force in the direction of motion and d is the distance in which this force acts

  • When the direction of a force <em>is not</em> completely parallel to the distance it is causing it to move, the amount of work done is equal to

where F is the net force, d is the distance in which this force acts, and Θ is the angle between the force and distance vectors

  • When the direction of a force is perpendicular to the distance it is trying to make it move, the amount of work done is equal to 0 as Θ = 90° and cos 90° = 0

fields.title: Pascal's Principle

fields.content:
This theorem provides an equation for the speed of a fluid coming out of a hole from the bottom of a container, as seen in the situation below. From Bernoulli's Equation, we know that . With this, we can find the velocity of the fluid moving out of the container at Point 2.

  • Since A<sub>1 </sub>is much greater than A<sub>2</sub>, we can assume that V<sub>1</sub> is much less than V<sub>2</sub>. This allows us to make the assumption that V<sub>1</sub>≈0 from the flow rate equation. Plugging this into our equation we are left with <img align="absmiddle" alt="\,{\color{Blue} P_{1}+\rho gh_{1}=P_{2}+\rho gh_{2}+\frac{1}{2}\rho v_{2}^{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?\,{\color{Blue}&space;P_{1}+\rho&space;gh_{1}=P_{2}+\rho&space;gh_{2}+\frac{1}{2}\rho&space;v_{2}^{2}}"/>.
  • P1 and P2 are both atmospheric pressure, so since its on both sides of the equation, they cancel out so we get .
  • h1 equals 0 since we set this point as the bottom of our container and h2 equals x1 - x2. Plugging both these into our equation, we get .
  • Since ρ is on both sides of this equation, they both cancel which gives us .
  • Through algebraic manipulation, we are left with our final fluid velocity at point 2.

where g is gravity and h<sub>1</sub> is the height of the fluid

fields.title: Relationships

fields.content:
Kinematics: The study of how something moves in terms of its velocity and accelerationDisplacement: Vector quantity that defines an object's change in position

  • Unit => Meter <img align="absmiddle" alt="(m)" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?(m)"/>; Symbol => Δx
Distance: Scalar quantity that defines how far an object has traveled
  • Unit => Meter <img align="absmiddle" alt="(m)" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?(m)"/>; Symbol => d
Average Velocity: Vector quantity that is equal to the change in displacement over a time
  • Unit => Meters per Second <img align="absmiddle" alt="\left ( \frac{m}{s}\right )" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?\left&space;(&space;\frac{m}{s}\right&space;)"/>; Symbol => v

Average Speed: Scalar quantity that is equal to the total distance traveled over a time (cannot be negative)
  • Unit => Meters per Second <img align="absmiddle" alt="\left (\frac{m}{s} \right )" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?\left&space;(\frac{m}{s}&space;\right&space;)"/>; Symbol => s

Average Acceleration: Vector quantity that is equal to the change in velocity over a time
  • Unit => Meters per Second Squared <img align="absmiddle" alt="\left (\frac{m}{s^{2}} \right )" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?\left&space;(\frac{m}{s^{2}}&space;\right&space;)"/>; Symbol => a
Gravity: Creates acceleration due to Earth's mass and is equal to about 9.8 m/s2
  • Symbol => g
fields.title: Motion Definitions

fields.content: As the ball is thrown, its displacement increases until it reaches its highest point. At this point the ball is neither gaining or losing altitude, which is why the velocity is equal to 0. It then begins to lose altitude until it falls back to its original position so there is no net change of displacement.
fields.title: Displacement Graph

fields.content: When the ball is first thrown, the velocity is the greatest because as it climbs, acceleration due to gravity resists its motion upwards. It eventually causes it to stop climbing and then begins to pull it back down to the ground. The initial and final velocities both have the same magnitude.
fields.title: Velocity Graph

fields.content: The acceleration remains constant at -9.8 m/s^2 (gravity).
fields.title: Acceleration Graph

fields.content:
• The velocity graph plots the slope of the displacement graph at every single point
  • The acceleration graph plots the slope of the velocity graph at every single point
fields.title: Slope Relationships

fields.content:
• The area bounded by the curve above the x axis for the velocity graph equals the total distance traveled in the positive direction
  • The area bounded by the curve below the x axis for the velocity graph equals the total distance traveled in the negative direction
fields.title: Area for Velocity Graphs Relationships

fields.content:
• The area bounded by the curve above the x axis for the acceleration graph equals the amount of positive change in velocity
  • The area bounded by the curve below the x axis for the acceleration graph equals the amount of negative change in velocity
fields.title: Area for Acceleration Graphs Relationships

When we are dealing with many kinematic problems, three equations become of much use. These equations are seen below. REMEMBER THESE!

where v is the final velocity, v<sub>o</sub> is the initial velocity, and a is the acceleration over a time t

where v<sub>o</sub> is the initial velocity, a is the acceleration over a time period t, x is the final position, and x<sub>o</sub> is the initial position

ex.) A car accelerates from 8.0 m/s to 12.0 m/s in 5.4 seconds. Determine the acceleration of the car and the distance traveled.

  • Givens
  • so <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} a= \frac{12.0\, m/s\, \, - \, \, 4.0\, m/s}{5.4\, s}=1.48 \, m/s^{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;a=&space;\frac{12.0\,&space;m/s\,&space;\,&space;-&space;\,&space;\,&space;4.0\,&space;m/s}{5.4\,&space;s}=1.48&space;\,&space;m/s^{2}}"/>
  • so

ex.) A ball is thrown straight up and has a hang time of 3.2 seconds. How high does the ball climb before it finally falls back down?

  • Givens
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} v_{f}=0\, \, m/s}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;v_{f}=0\,&space;\,&space;m/s}"/> because at its highest point, it is neither ascending or descending
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} total\, time=3.2\, \, s}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;total\,&space;time=3.2\,&space;\,&space;s}"/> but the time we use is <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} t=1.6\, \, s}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;t=1.6\,&space;\,&space;s}"/> since the time it takes to reach the peak is one half of the total hang time
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} a=g=-9.8\, \, m/s^{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;a=g=-9.8\,&space;\,&space;m/s^{2}}"/>
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x_{o}=0\, \, m}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x_{o}=0\,&space;\,&space;m}" style="line-height: 22px;"/>
  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} v = v_{o} + at\, }" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;v&space;=&space;v_{o}&space;+&space;at\,&space;}"/> so <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} 0\, m/s = v_{o} + (-9.8\, m/s^{2})(1.6\, s)\, }" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;0\,&space;m/s&space;=&space;v_{o}&space;+&space;(-9.8\,&space;m/s^{2})(1.6\,&space;s)\,&space;}"/> which means <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} v_{o}=15.7\, m/s\, }" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;v_{o}=15.7\,&space;m/s\,&space;}"/>
  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} v^{2} = v_{o}^{2} + 2a(x-x_{o})}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;v^{2}&space;=&space;v_{o}^{2}&space;+&space;2a(x-x_{o})}"/> so <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} (0\, m/s)^{2} = (15.7\, m/s)^{2} + 2(-9.8\, m/s^{2})(x-0\, m)}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;(0\,&space;m/s)^{2}&space;=&space;(15.7\,&space;m/s)^{2}&space;+&space;2(-9.8\,&space;m/s^{2})(x-0\,&space;m)}"/>
  • With algebra, we solve for peak height as <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} x=12.6\, m}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;x=12.6\,&space;m}"/>
fields.title: Kinematic Equations

fields.content:
So far everything we have learned in this lesson only referred to one dimensional motion. What if an object now has motion properties in the x and y directions? To solve for these properties we can use the chart below. 

  • There is always acceleration in the y-direction due to gravity
  • The only way an object can accelerate in the x-direction is with a device such as a rocket
  • If no device acts upon an object, the speed in the x-direction will remain constant

ex.) A baseball is thrown at an initial speed of 32 m/s at an angle of 35 degrees from the horizontal. Determine the time of flight, the horizontal displacement, and the peak height of the baseball.

  • Givens
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} v_{o}=32.0\, \, m/s}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;v_{o}=32.0\,&space;\,&space;m/s}"/>
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red}\Theta =35^{o}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}\Theta&space;=35^{o}}"/>
  • x-direction
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} v_{ox}=(32.0\, \, m/s)\cos 35^{o}=26.2\, \, m/s}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;v_{ox}=(32.0\,&space;\,&space;m/s)\cos&space;35^{o}=26.2\,&space;\,&space;m/s}"/>
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} v_{ox}=v_{fx}=26.2\, \, m/s}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;v_{ox}=v_{fx}=26.2\,&space;\,&space;m/s}"/>
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} a_{x}=0\, \, m/s^{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;a_{x}=0\,&space;\,&space;m/s^{2}}" style="line-height: 22px;"/>
  • y-direction
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} v_{oy}=(32.0\, \, m/s)\sin 35^{o}=18.4\, \, m/s}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;v_{oy}=(32.0\,&space;\,&space;m/s)\sin&space;35^{o}=18.4\,&space;\,&space;m/s}"/>
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} v_{oy}=-v_{fy}=-18.4\, \, m/s}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;v_{oy}=-v_{fy}=-18.4\,&space;\,&space;m/s}"/>
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} a_{y}=g=-9.8\, \, m/s^{2}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;a_{y}=g=-9.8\,&space;\,&space;m/s^{2}}" style="line-height: 22px;"/>
  • Time of flight
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} v _{fy}= v_{oy} + a_{y}t}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;v&space;_{fy}=&space;v_{oy}&space;+&space;a_{y}t}"/> so <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} -18.4\, \, m/s= 18.4\, \, m/s + (-9.8\, \, m/s^{2})t}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;-18.4\,&space;\,&space;m/s=&space;18.4\,&space;\,&space;m/s&space;+&space;(-9.8\,&space;\,&space;m/s^{2})t}"/>
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red}t=3.8\, \, s}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}t=3.8\,&space;\,&space;s}"/>
  • Horizontal Displacement
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \Delta x=v_{ox}t}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\Delta&space;x=v_{ox}t}"/> so <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \Delta x= (26.2\, \, m/s)(3.8\, \, s) }" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\Delta&space;x=&space;(26.2\,&space;\,&space;m/s)(3.8\,&space;\,&space;s)&space;}"/>
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \Delta x=99.6\, \, m }" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\Delta&space;x=99.6\,&space;\,&space;m&space;}"/>
  • Peak Height
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} v_{y}^{2}=v_{oy}^{2}+2a_{y}\Delta y}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;v_{y}^{2}=v_{oy}^{2}+2a_{y}\Delta&space;y}"/>
    • At the ball's peak height, <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} v_{y}=0\, \, m/s}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;v_{y}=0\,&space;\,&space;m/s}"/> so <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} (0\, \, m/s)^{2}=(18.4\, \, m/s)^{2}+2(-9.8\, \, m/s^{2})\Delta y}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;(0\,&space;\,&space;m/s)^{2}=(18.4\,&space;\,&space;m/s)^{2}+2(-9.8\,&space;\,&space;m/s^{2})\Delta&space;y}"/>
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} \Delta y=17.3\, \, m }" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;\Delta&space;y=17.3\,&space;\,&space;m&space;}"/>

fields.content:
Just like in the waves and sound chapter, the velocity of waves can found with the equation

where f is the frequency of the wave and λ is the wavelength

  • All electromagnetic waves in a vacuum travel at a speed of 3.00 x 10<sup>8 </sup>m/s, which is also known as just "c"
  • We can only see visible light, which occurs between 450 nm and 700 nm
fields.title: Basic Ideas

fields.content:
Snell's Law: Depicts the relationship between the index of refractions and the incident and refracted angles "

where n<sub>1</sub> and n<sub>2</sub> are the two different index of refractions and θ<sub>1</sub> and θ<sub>2</sub> are the two angles

Critical Angle: Where the angle of refraction becomes 90\xb0
  • Since the sin 90° = 1, the critical angle can be found by the equation

where n<sub>1</sub> and n<sub>2</sub> are the two different index of refractions and θ<sub>crit</sub> is the critical angle
fields.title: Snell's Law

fields.content:
When light hits a barrier with two slits in it, we see a phenomenon called diffraction.Diffraction: The bending of waves when they come into contact with an obstacleMany problems in this chapter have to deal with light hitting two slits and observing the result on a screen.This situation is seen below.Path Difference: The difference of the lengths of two waves (how much longer one wave had to travel than the other)
  • Unit => Meter ; Symbol => δ

where L1 and L2 are the lengths of waves 1 and 2, d is the distance between the slits, and Θ is the angle between the horizontal and first bright spot on the screen

Central Maximum: The bright spot directly across from the center of the slits

Constructive Interference: When waves combine crest to crest (in phase)
  • Cause bright spots when they hit a screen
  • The path difference for destructive waves can be found with the equation

where m is the wave integer and λ is the wavelength

Destructive Interference: When waves combine crest to trough (out of phase)
  • Cause dark spots when they hit a screen
  • The path difference for constructive waves can be found with the equation

where m is the wave integer and λ is the wavelength
fields.title: Double Slit Interference

fields.content:
Because of the nature of waves, there does not exist just one bright spot on the screen. There are multiple spots each of decreasing intensity from the central maximum.To find \u0394y from the previous diagram above, we can derive it from a couple basic steps
  • Δy = L tan Θ as we can derive from the previous diagram
  • When Θ is relatively small, tan Θ approximately equals sin Θ so then Δy = L sin Θ
  • Through algebraic manipulation from the path difference equation above, sin Θ = mλ / d
  • Plugging sin Θ = mλ / d into Δy = L sin Θ, we get the equation

where m is the wave integer, λ is the wavelength, L is the distance between the barrier and the screen, and d is the distance between the slits
fields.title: Distance  Between Spots

fields.content:
Some equations help explain some relationships for images. These equations are seen below.

where f is the focal length, d<sub>o</sub> is the distance from the object to the mirror, and d<sub>i</sub> is the distance from the image to the mirror

where M is the magnification, d<sub>o</sub> is the distance from the object to the mirror, d<sub>i</sub> is the distance from the image to the mirror, h<sub>o</sub> is the height of the object, and h<sub>i</sub> is the height of the image

*The negative is there to signify that it can be negative.*

*If M is positive, the image is upright. If M is negative, the image is inverted.*
fields.title: Equations

fields.content:
1. Draw a line parallel to the axis from the top of the object to the mirror that is then reflected through the focal point
  2. Draw a line from the top of the object that passes through the focal point to the mirror that is then reflected parallel to the axis
  3. Draw a line from the top of the object that hits the vertex then reflects back at the same angle
The point where all these lines intersect is the top of the image.
fields.title: Diagram Drawing Steps
Concave Mirror Example

fields.content:
1. Draw a line parallel to the axis from the top of the object to the lens that is then reflected through the far focal point
  2. Draw a line from the top of the object that passes through the <strong>near</strong> focal point to the lens that is then reflected parallel to the axis
  3. Draw a line from the top of the object through the center of the lens
The point where all these lines intersect is the top of the image
fields.title: Diagram Drawing Steps - Convex Lens

fields.content:
1. Draw a line parallel to the axis from the top of the object to the lens that is then reflected through the <strong>near</strong> focal point
  2. Draw a line from the top of the object that passes through the <strong>far</strong> focal point to the lens that is then reflected parallel to the axis
  3. Draw a line from the top of the object through the center of the lens
The point where all these lines intersect is the top of the image
fields.title: Diagram Drawing Steps - Concave Lens

fields.content:
Magnetic Field (B-Field): Field that is caused from moving charges

  • Unit => tesla (T); Symbol => B
  • When the field is directed into the page, the schematic for this is an x (think of an arrows' fins when looking from behind)
  • When the field is directed out of the page, the schematic for this is a dot (think of an arrow's tip when looking from the front)
fields.title: Magnetic Fields

fields.content:
Magnetic Force on a Moving Charge: Force felt on a moving charge when it comes into contact with a magnetic field
  • Unit => (N) Symbol => FB

where v is the velocity of the particle, q is the magnitude of the charge, Θ is the angle between v and B, and B is the magnitude of the B-Field

  • The direction of the force is found using the right hand rule, which is seen below
fields.title: Magnetic Force on a Moving Charge

fields.content:
To find the direction of the magnetic force,
  • Stick your right thumb in the direction of the velocity of the charge
  • Stick your other fingers in the direction of the magnetic force
  • And the direction of the force is the direction your palm points
NOTE: This is only when the charges are POSITIVE, so when the charge is negative, use your left hand instead and use the same concept
fields.title: Right-Hand Rule for Moving Charges

fields.content:
Since current-carrying wires contain moving charges, they create a magnetic fields around them.
  • The magnetic field lines are concentric circles about the center of the wire
  • The magnitude of this field can be found from the equation below

where μ<sub>o</sub> is a permability of free space constant, I is the amount of current in the wire, and r is the distance from the wire

μ0 = 4∏ x 10-7 Tm/A2
fields.title: Magnetic Field From a Current-Carrying Wire

fields.content:
Magnetic Force on a Current-Carrying Wire: Since current-carrying wires contain moving charges (current) it also feels a force when it comes into contact with a magnetic field
  • Unit => (N) Symbol => FB

where I is the amount of current, L is the length of the wire, Θ is the angle between L and B, and B is the magnitude of the B-Field

  • The direction of the magnetic force is found using the same right hand rule for moving charges, this time pointing your thumb in the direction of the current
  • The direction of the magnetic field is found using the right hand rule for current-carrying wires, which is seen below
fields.title: Magnetic Force on a Current-Carrying Wire

fields.content:
To find the direction of the magnetic field around a wire,
  • Stick your right thumb in the direction of the current
  • Curl your other fingers and your fingers point to the direction of the magnetic field
To find the direction of the current in a wire,
  • Curl your fingers to where they line up with the swirl of the magnetic field
  • Your thumb points in the direction of current flow

To find the direction of the magnetic field from a loop of wire,
  • Curl your fingers in the direction of the current
  • Your thumb points to the direction of the magnetic field
To find the direction of the current in a loop of wire,
  • Stick your right thumb in the direction of the the magnetic field
  • Curl your other fingers and your fingers curl in the direction of the current flow
fields.title: Right-Hand Rule for Current-Carrying Wires

fields.content:
Take two wires next to each other that have the same directions for current flow...

As we can see, the B-Field

  • out of the page to the left of wire 1 is made greater from both wires adding same direction B-Fields
  • between the wires is made smaller from the wires as they subtract from each other
  • into the page to the right of wire 2 is made greater from both wires adding same direction B-Fields
fields.title: Same Direction Current Flows

fields.content:
Now take two wires next to each other that have the opposite directions for current flow...

As we can see, the B-Field
  • out of the page to the left of wire 1 is made smaller from the wires as they subtract from each other
  • between the wires is made greater from both wires adding same direction B-Field
  • out of the page to the right of wire 2 is made smaller from the wires as they subtract from each other
fields.title: Opposite Direction Current Flows

fields.content:
Linear Momentum: Vector Quantity that is the product of an object's mass and its velocity

  • Unit => ; Symbol => p

where m is the mass and v is the velocity of the object

Conservation of Momentum: Momentum is always conserved; initial momentum is equal to final momentum as seen in the equation below

where p<sub>i</sub> and p<sub>f</sub> are the initial and final momentums, m is the mass of the object, and v<sub>i</sub> and v<sub>f</sub> are the initial and final velocities of the object
fields.title: Momentum

fields.content: Elastic Collision: Kinetic energy 'is conserved.
fields.title: Elastic Collisions

fields.content: Inelastic Collision: Kinetic energy 'is not conserved.
fields.title: Inelastic Collisions

fields.content:
Impulse: Vector quantity that is the product of force and the time for which the force acts; It is equal to the change in momentum of an object

  • Unit => ; Symbol => J
fields.title: Impulse

fields.content:
Force: A push or pull exerted from an interaction between two objects

  • Unit => Newton ; Symbol => F
Forces account for the movement of objects, such as when you push a box, you are exerting a force on it to make it move forward.Mass: Measurement of inertia that remains constant no matter what the location isex.) A ball on Mars has the same mass as a ball on Earth
  • Unit => Kilograms
fields.title: Force

fields.content:
1. An object in motion will stay in motion unless it is acted upon by a force

ex.) A cart driving without friction or air resistance will keep going forever at the same speed

2. The sum of forces on the object is proportional to the mass of the object times the acceleration

where m is the mass and a is the acceleration of the system

  • This is true for components in both the x and y directions so by branching off of this,

where m is the mass, a<sub>x</sub> is the acceleration in the x-direction, and a<sub>y</sub> is the acceleration in the y-direction of the system

3. For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction

ex.) When a hammer hits a nail, the nail also hits the hammer
fields.title: Newton's Laws

fields.content:
Most people commonly mistake that weight and mass are the same thing. This is not true.Weight: Measurement of gravitational force one body exists on another (the stronger the gravity, the more an object weighs)

ex.) A ball on the Earth has much more weight than a ball on the Moon because Earth's gravity is much larger

  • Unit => Newton ; Symbol => W or Fg
  • The force due to gravity (weight) can be written as

where m is the mass of the object and g is gravity
fields.title: The Force of Gravity (Weight)

fields.content:
So if an object that has weight, say a book, is resting on a table, shouldn't it accelerate downward because of the force due to gravity? Since the weight pulls the book down, there has to be a force pushing it up to be in equilibrium. This is the normal force. Normal Force: The force component that is perpendicular to the surface that is being acted upon"
  • Unit => Newton ; Symbol => N or Fn
  • So in our above situation, the force due to gravity pulls the object down, but the table exerts a normal force on the book which pushes it up. Since these forces point in opposite directions, they cancel each other out and the book remains in place which means the acceleration is equal to 0.

where F<sub>g</sub> is the force of gravity and F<sub>n </sub>is the normal force
fields.title: The Normal Force

fields.content:
Ever wondered why your car slows down when you aren't pushing on the gas? Well this mainly due to the force of friction.Friction: Force that slows down moving objects on rough surfacesStatic Friction: Friction that keeps an object from rest"
  • Unit => Newton ; Symbol => Fsf
Kinetic Friction: Friction that acts when an object is moving
  • Unit => Newton ; Symbol => Fkf
The strength of it depends on two things

1. The Coefficient of Friction: Constant that depicts how rough a surface is

    • Symbol => μ<sub>s</sub> for static friction and μ<sub>k</sub> for kinetic friction

ex.) The coefficient of friction is much greater for sand paper than that of ice

2. The Magnitude of the Normal Force

ex.) A heavier block will have a greater force of friction acting on it because the weight and therefore normal force is greater

As a result of these two factors, the two friction formulas are

where μ<sub>s</sub> is the coefficient of static friction, and N is the normal force

where μ<sub>k</sub> is the coefficient of kinetic friction, and N is the normal force
fields.title: The Frictional Force

fields.content:
Tension: Force that occurs when pulling ropes taught
  • Unit => Newton ; Symbol => T or F<sub>t</sub>

ex.) Whenever you reel in a fishing line or use a pulley, you are seeing the force of tension at work.
fields.title: The Force of Tension

fields.content:
Equilibrium: When an object or system has no acceleration in either the x-direction or y-direction

  • Sum of forces in both directions equals 0 as the forces all cancel out with each other with a opposing forces

  • ex.) If two people are pulling on a box from the opposite sides with a 10 N force, they cancel out and it does not accelerate
fields.title: Equilibrium

fields.content:
What about when the forces do not cancel out? Well, this makes the sum of forces not equal to 0 which means there is now acceleration in the system.

  • ex.) When someone accelerates a box by pushing it, the normal force the person exerts on the box is greater than the force of friction in the opposite direction
fields.title: Acceleration

fields.content:
When dealing with many problems in this class, it is essential to draw free-body diagrams to visualize what is happening. Free-body diagrams have arrows that depict the forces that are acting on an object or system. The steps for drawing a free-body diagram are shown below.

  1. Draw a dot to represent the object
  2. Draw all arrows with their tails at the dot extending outward
  3. Draw arrows to scale unless the problem says otherwise (for larger forces, draw longer arrows and for smaller forces, draw shorter arrows)
  4. Unless the problem states otherwise, draw dashed lines for force components in the x and y directions (see example 2 below)
  5. If two forces are equal, draw a marker on them to show the arrows are congruent
  6. Label the forces with their symbols (Fg, Fn, Ff, and Ft)
The best way to learn how to do this is through examples1.) Draw a free-body diagram for the book that is at rest on a table (no acceleration)2.) Draw a free-body diagram for a block being pulled up a rough surface (has friction) with a rope at a constant speed (no acceleration)3.) Draw a free-body diagram for a mass being acclereated upwards with a string tied around it
fields.title: Free-Body Diagrams

When the temperature of a substance changes, the amount of heat that corresponds with this change is given by the equation

where Q is the heat added or removed, m is the mass of the substance, c is the specific heat, and ΔT is the temperature change in degrees Celsius

*When ΔT is negative, heat is removed. When ΔT is positive, heat is added.*
fields.title: Temperature Change

fields.content:
Phase Change: When a substance goes from a solid to a liquid or from a liquid to a gas or vice versaLatent Heat of Transformation: Number that tells how much heat per unit mass is required to cause a phase change within a substance
  • Unit => ; Symbol => L
Heat of Fusion: The L quantity we use when changing from a solid to a liquid or vice versaHeat of Vaporization: The L quantity we use when changing from a liquid to a gas or vice versaThe amount of heat needed for a substance to go though a phase change can be given by the equation

where m is the mass of the substance and L is either the latent heat of fusion or latent heat of vaporization depending on the phase shift

*When Q is negative, the substance is either being changed from a gas to a liquid or from a liquid to a solid. When Q is positive, the substance is either being changed from a liquid to a gas or from a solid to a liquid.*

This all can be depicted by the diagram below
fields.title: Phase Change

fields.content:
Avogrado's Number: Constant equal to 6.02 x 1023 molecules

  • Symbol => N<sub>A</sub>

Universal Gas Constant: Constant equal to 8.31 J/mol·K

  • Symbol => R

Boltzmann's Constant: Constant equal to 1.38 x 10-23 J/K

  • Symbol => kB

The number of moles, n, of a substance can be found with the equation

where N is the number of molecules, and N<sub>A</sub> is Avogrado's Number
fields.title: Basic Info

fields.content:
Pressure, Volume, and Temperature for gases all are related. This relationship can be given by the Ideal Gas Law Equation equation

where P is the pressure, V is the volume, n is number of moles, R is the Universal Gas Constant, and T is the temperature in Kelvin

  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="\,{\color{Blue} k_{B}=\frac{R}{N_{A}}=\frac{R}{N/n}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?\,{\color{Blue}&space;k_{B}=\frac{R}{N_{A}}=\frac{R}{N/n}}"/> which can be manipulated to <img align="absmiddle" alt="\,{\color{Blue} n=\frac{k_{B}N}{R}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?\,{\color{Blue}&space;n=\frac{k_{B}N}{R}}"/>. Plugging this into <img align="absmiddle" alt="\,{\color{Blue} PV=nRT}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?\,{\color{Blue}&space;PV=nRT}"/>, we are left with a different form of the Ideal Gas Law Equation equal to

where P is the pressure, V is the volume, N is number of molecules, k<sub>B</sub> is Boltzmann's Constant, and T is the temperature in Kelvin

where is k<sub>B</sub> is Boltzmann's Constant, M is the mass of one of the molecules, m molecular mass, R is the Universal Gas Constant, and T is the temperature in Kelvin

  • When ΔV is negative, the work is done on the gas (volume decreases) and the work is positive due to the negative sign in the equation

fields.content:
Vector: Quantity that has magnitude and direction

  • ex.) 30 miles per hour to the west
Scalar: Quantity that has magnitude, but not direction
  • ex.) 30 miles per hour
fields.title: Vector Definitions

fields.content:
If A is a vector, it has a component in the x-direction and in the y-direction

  • i and j are symbols to show which component we are dealing with
Magnitude of a Vector: Can be found if the individual components are known through the equation<img alt="{\color{Blue} A=\sqrt{(Ax)^{2}+(Ay)^{2}}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Blue}&space;A=\sqrt{(Ax)^{2}+(Ay)^{2}}}" style="margin: 5px auto; display: block; text-align: center;" width="167"/>
fields.title: Properties of a Vector

fields.content:
Say we have a vector, vector A....

  • If we multiply A by a positive constant, k, we are left with a new vector with the same direction as A, but with a new magnitude (kA)
  • If we multiply A by a negative constant, -k, we are left with a new vector with the opposite direction as A, and with a new magnitude (kA)

Say we have another vector, vector B...
  • If we add A to B, we are left with a new vector, vector A + B
  • If A = Ax + Ay and B = Bx + By, A + B = (Ax + Bx)i + (Ay + By)j
  • If we subtract B from A, we are left with a new vector, vector A + (-B)
  • If A = Ax + Ay and B = Bx + By, A - B = (Ax - Bx)i + (Ay - By)j
fields.title: Vector Manipulation

fields.content:
Terminal Velocity: Velocity at which a falling object feels no net force (therefore acceleration) because the force of gravity cancels out with the air resistance force
  • Unit => Meters per Second <img align="absmiddle" alt="\left ( \frac{m}{s}\right )" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?\left&space;(&space;\frac{m}{s}\right&space;)"/>; Symbol => v<sub>t</sub>
  • This is depicted below

Since we know that the force of gravity and air resistance are equal at terminal velocity, we can find the equation for the terminal velocity of an object

  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="F_{air}=F_{g}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?F_{air}=F_{g}"/> at terminal velocity
  • This means
  • Through algebraic manipulation, this leads us to the equation

where k is a constant of proportionality, m is the mass of the object, and g is gravity

ex.) A falling object has a mass of 3.0 kg and a terminal velocity of 34 m/s. What is the value of its constant or proportionality?

  • Givens
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} m=3.0\, kg}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;m=3.0\,&space;kg}"/>
    • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} v_{T}=34\, m/s}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;v_{T}=34\,&space;m/s}"/>
  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} F_{air}=F_{g}}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;F_{air}=F_{g}}"/> at terminal velocity so <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} kv_{T}=mg}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;kv_{T}=mg}"/>
  • This means <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} k(34\, m/s)=(3.0\, kg)(9.8\, m/s^{2})}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;k(34\,&space;m/s)=(3.0\,&space;kg)(9.8\,&space;m/s^{2})}"/>
  • <img align="absmiddle" alt="{\color{Red} k=0.86\, kg/s}" src="http://latex.codecogs.com/gif.latex?{\color{Red}&space;k=0.86\,&space;kg/s}"/>

fields.content:
Neurons are the individual nerve cells that make up the entire nervous system. Glial cells are a main function in your body because they help and maintain the growth of your neurons. A neurons job is to receive, decode and process, and send information to the rest of the body. Every neuron is made up of many different parts.
  1. Cell body (soma) contains the nucleus and other substances that are vital to the life of a neuron.
  2. Dendrites are branch-like structures that grow out of the neuron so the neuron and connect with other neurons. This allows information to be passed from neuron to neuron.
  3. Axon comes out of the cell body and ends in terminal buttons.
  4. Terminal buttons are the figures that branch out from the axon that contain neurotransmitters.
  5. Neurotransmitter are chemical structures that lie at the ends of dendrites and terminal buttons and are what is needed for the neurons to communicate. Different neurotransmitters have different chemical makeups and so they will perform different tasks.
  6. Myelin sheath is the fatty covering around the axon which speeds up process. It is usually made up of Schwann's cells.
  7. Synapse is the space between terminal buttons of a neuron and the dendrites of another.
  8. Nodes of Ranvier are the gaps in the myelin sheath.
fields.title: Makeup of the Neuron

fields.content: Sensory neurons or afferent neurons are neurons that relay information to the brain from specific receptors in the body. Motor neurons or efferent neurons are the messages sent from the brain to the rest of the body. For example, when the brain signal the muscles to relax or contract. Interneurons are the neurons that communicate from one neuron to the next.
fields.title: Types of Neurons

fields.content: When a the brain or special organs want to send a message to somewhere else in the body, they will fire a neurotransmitters that contain the message. This happens very quickly. Before the neurotransmitter can be fired between cells, there is a process within the neuron itself. The neuron must receive a sufficient amount of stimulation for an action potential to occur but if it does not have enough, there will be no action potential. This is called the all or none principal. It will either fully fire or wont fire at all. There are no inbetweens. In the polarized stage (resting potential), the neuron is prepared and ready to activate and communicate with other neurons. This is where the action potential is created and then the depolarization stage (action potential) is when the neuron fired and the action potential occurs. After the neuron is depolarized, it must be repolarized (refractory period). This is when the neuron can't fire and the neuron is trying to build up the action potential again.
fields.title: How the Neuron Communicates Within Itself

fields.content:
The pre-synaptic neuron is the neuron sending the message which sends the message through the synapse. The synapse is the point of communication between the two neurons. The post-synaptic neuron is the neuron that is receiving the message. When the message doesnt send send correctly, there is reuptake and that is when a pre-synaptic neuron absorbs the neurotransmitter from a post-synpatic neuron so the neurotransmitter can be used again. The two types of messages from neuron to neuron. There is an excitatory message and an inhibitory message.
  • Excitatory message increases the chance that the post-synaptic neuron will fully receive the message and create an action potential
  • Inhibitory message decreases the chance the post-synaptic neuron will activate.
fields.title: How the Neurons Communicate With Eachother

fields.content:
1. Acetylcholine which causes muscle contraction and involved in memory function. Too much can cause seizures while too little can cause Alzheimer's and paralysis.
  2. Serotonin regulates sleep, emotions, aggression, impulsivity, and appetite. If there is too much, OCD occurs. If there is too little, depression can occur.
  3. Norepinephrine is a hormone produced by the adrenal glands and controls learning and memory and survival instincts. Too much can cause neurotic behavior while too little can cause depression and stress.
  4. Dopamine regulates body movement, thought porcesses, and sensations. Schizophrenia and hallucinations can be produced if there is too much dopamine but too will can cause Parkinson's diease or drug addiction.
  5. Endorphins control pain perceptions and positive emotions. It is a natural opiate released when experiencing pain. Having too many endorphins can cause a person to physically harm themselves to feel pain while too little will cause a person to become addicted to opiate and have cronic pain.
fields.title: Types of Neurotransmitters

fields.content: The central nervous system is broken down into the brain and the spinal chord. The brain controls us and relays messages to the rest of the body. The spinal chord connects the brain and the peripheral nervous system.
fields.title: The Central Nervous System

fields.content:
The peripheral nervous system carries messages to and from the central nervous system. This system is broken down agin into the somatic nervous system and the autonomic nervous system.
  • The somactic nervous system controls voluntary muscles and transmits snesory information to the central nervous system
  • The autonomic nervous system controls involuntary body function. This system is broken down into the sympathetic nervous system and the parasympathetic nervous system. The sympathetic system arouses the body to use energy while the parasympathetic system calms the body and trys to maintain energy.
fields.title: The Peripheral Nervous System
The Glands of the Endocrine System

fields.content: This gland regulates the production of other hormones released in the endocrine system. It also produces the growth hormone in the body. It is located just under the brain.
fields.title: Pituitary Gland

fields.content: The pineal gland communicates with the pituitary gland. This gland produces melatonin which regulates the sleep cycle of a person. It controls sleep and wakefulness. This is located in the center of the brain.
fields.title: Pineal Gland

fields.content: The thyroid controls metabolism and is located in the throat. The pancreas regulates bloos sugar leavels and controls how hungry a person is. This is near the stomach.
fields.title: Thyroid and Pancreas

fields.content: The adrenal glands produce hormones that respond to stress and also produce epinephrine, norpinephrine, and adrenaline which control the flight or fight of a person. This is located behind the kidneys.
fields.title: Adrenal Glands

fields.content: The gonads are the sex organs so they are found in the ovaries and testes. These control the testesterone and the estrogen in a male and female.
fields.title: Gonads

fields.content:
This is the largest part of the brain. It is made up of several structures but mostly the cerebral cortex. The cerebral cortex is divided into hemipsheres and is responsible for higher thought level and sensory and motor processing. The cerebral cortex is connected by the corpus callosum. The two hemispheres of the frontal lobe have completely different functions.The left brain functions are of the math and science focused and like concrete answers.
  • uses logic, facts and rules, math and science, knowing, sequntial list maker
  • speech words and good speller
  • practical and safe
  • reality based and forms strategies
The right brain functions are more art, english and more creative.
  • uses feelings, symbols and images, good at visualizing an outcome, fantasy based
  • art, music, acting, architecture
  • risk taking
  • spatial perception, appreciates, philosophy and religion
fields.title: The Forebrain

fields.content:
The hindbrain is the region at the base of the brain that contains structures that contain basic life functions.
  • Medulla controls vital life functions like breathing, blood pressure, heart beat, and circulation.
  • Cerebellum is located at the back of the brain and is responsible for muscle coordination,maintaining posture, and balance and coordination.
  • Pons connects the medulla to the cerebellum and also helps coordinate the movement of each side of the body. It helps make sure the body is doing the same thing.
  • Recticular Activating System (RAS) is a network of neurons that filters incoming informations and regulates mood.
fields.title: Hindbrain

fields.content: The mid brain is the smallest brain region and is involved in processing hearing and seeing. The substantia nigra is apart of motor control and contains large amounts of dopamine while the locus coeruleus involved in stress/panic and releases norepinephrine.
fields.title: Mid Brain

fields.content:
Frontal lobe is the largest lobe and it processes voluntary muscle movements and it controls strategies, plans, good decision making, thinking, planning,and emotional control.
  • Broca's area produces speech so if damaged a person can no longer speak.
  • Motor strip controls voluntary movements.
  • The pre-frontal cortex regulates personality and the recreating of things in the mind.
Parietal lobe is located on both hemishperes and processes body snesations like touch and pressure. The somato-sensory strip receives informations from touch receptors in the body.The temporal lobe is located on both hemispheres and by the temples of a person head and it the primary place to receive auditory information. Located only in the left temporal lobe is the Wernicke's area and that's main purpose is to comphrend what a persons heaard so if that's damaged, a person will not be able to understand a person talking.Occipital lobe is located at the back of the cerebral cortex and its main purpose is to receive and process visual information. The lobe sees images before the person even knows the have seen it.
fields.title: The Lobes

fields.content:
The limbic system are structures that form around the brain stem that control learning, emotion, motivation, and memory.
  • The hippocampus is involved in long term memory, new memories, and learning.
  • The thalamus receives sensory information, processes it, and then sends the sensory message to the correct part of the cerebral cortex.
  • The amygdala is involved in emotion, memory, fear and rage, and helps make humans decisions until theyre 25.
  • The hypothalamus regulates survival, fight or flight, feelings, mating, passes genes to next generation, eating, and drinking. The suprachiasmatic nucleus controls the sleep cycle of a person and other psyiological rhythms of the body.
fields.title: The Limbic System

fields.content:
There are many different ways that people study the brian and many of those are used through technology. The different methods used measure and learn different things about the brain.

  • EEG measure the brains waves and activities
  • PET scan measure radioactivity tagged substance that will show up while a person does a stimulating activity.
  • MRI produces highly detailed images of the brain and the bodys structures.
  • FMRI shows moment by moment changes of the brain's activity. This is the most advanced way to look at the brain.
fields.title: How to Study the Brain

fields.content: Early philosophers like Plato and Democritis thought about the relationship between the brain and behavior but not until 1879 had there been any physical progression. In 1879, Wilhelm Wundt created the first physcological lab that allowed him to train people in introspection which is seeing how people respond cognitively to stimuli. He focused on the makeup of the mind and the identification of feelings, perception, and images. Through his lab work, Wundt came up with his theory of structuralism. Structuralism is the thought that the mind functions through the emotions and sensations. From wundt came many other strucutral psychologists like G. Stanley hall, Edward Titchener, and Margaret Floy Washburn. G. Stanley Hall created his own lab like Wundt but his was at John Hopkins University. Along with starting his own lab, hall helped found the American Psychological association and became its first president. Titchener brought the idea of introspection into his own lab where he looked at how the basic elements of the brain were related. Washburn was the first woman to received her ph.D in psychology. These psychologists were all from the School of Stucturalism.
fields.title: Introspection-Structuralism:

fields.content: William James believed that structuralists werent looking at the brain correctly. He wanted to figure out the purpose or the function that brain had in the behavior of humans. He thought that humans were more likely to be involved subjectively in understanding their actions and feeling than objectively. Other functional psychologists, James Cattell and John Dewey, focused on the mental functions of the brain and how that influenced behavior. James Cattell is known for mental testing which John Dewey is know for child development and education. Along with Mary Whiton Calkins, who became the first woman president of the American Psychological Association, these psychologists make up the School of Functionalism.
fields.title: Introspection- Functionalism:

fields.content: Behaviorists believe that behavior results from learning and conditionaing. They focus on measuring observable behavior that happens because of the enviornment they are in. Ivan Pavlov was one of the first behaviorists and he trained dogs to salivate when a tone was heard. He learned about conditioning and stimulus-response learning. Behaviorists analyze the enviornment around the subject before the behavior occurs, the actual behavior itself, and the repercussions after the behavior or also know as stimuli and response. John B. Watson believed that to make psychology a science they would have to study observable traits like behavior and not just unobservable traits like the unconscious responses. B.F. Skinner expanded on the idea of behaviorism and showed that behavior can be encouraged by positive reinforcements or discouraged by negative reinforcements. He used birds and treats to show how positive and negative reinforcement work. Behavioral psychology was the main psychological perspective from the 1920s to the 1960s.
fields.title: Behavioral Approach:

fields.content: Abraham Maslow and Carl Rogers believed in free will and the ability to solve their own problems. Humanists believed that behavior and choices are dependent on physiological, emotional, or spiritual needs. Although humanisitc theories arent easily tested by scientific method, many psychologists use these ideas to help patients out in solving problems in their everyday life.
fields.title: Humanistic Approach:

fields.content: Sigmund Freud treated patients for mental diseases by talking to them over long periods of time to uncover the unconscious mind which included conflicts, motives, and defenses which strengthened the patient's self knowledge. Freud believed that repression was a main cause of mental disorders because anger and tension have been built up for many years which cause the body harm. Through word association, dream analysis, and other psychological therapies, a psychoanalytic psychologist would further understand the human thought and behavior of a patient.
fields.title: Psychoanalytic Approach:

fields.content: Biological psychologists think that what the mind does and how a person acts is through the biological makeup of the person. A person may act or think based on their genes, hormones, and neurotransmitters. The behavior or organisms may be caused by the chemical and biological processes that occur in the body.
fields.title: Biological Approach:

fields.content: Bases on Charles Darwin's idea of natural selection is a main theory in evolutionary psychology because psychologists believe that behavior is caused by the adaptations of organisms to survive in the enviornment around them. The traits that are more advantageous to the a person have a higher rate of survival and will be the traits passed down from generation to generation.
fields.title: Evolutionary Approach:

fields.content: Cognitive psychologists emphasize how people handle, remember, and store social situations. This is because the different ways people look at situations and how they view the world will impact how they behave and think in different enviornments.Jean Piaget is a cognitive psychologist that studied cognitive development of children.
fields.title: Cognitive Approach:

fields.content: People from different cultures have different social norms and experiene situations differently. Psychologists analyzie the differences between people from different cultures by studying gestures, spoken language and body language. This approach attempts to understand the differences ion cultures and try tp predict how a person would act in different enviornments.'.
fields.title: Sociocultural Approach:

fields.content:
Experimenter bias happens during an experiment when a researcher is treating either the control or experimental group differently to enhance their chances of confirming their hypothesis. Another way that can affect the outcome of the experiment is through demand characteristics. Demand characteristics are when subjects use cues to learn how they should respond to the treatments which can skew the data. To control the effects of experimenter bias and demand characteristics, researchers can run a single or double blind experiment.
  • Single-blind experiment is when the subjects do not know if they are in the control or experimental group but the researcher does know what group they are in.
  • Double-blind experiment is an experiment where neither the researcher or the subject know which group the subjects are in. There is an outside source that placed the subjects into each group and they will handle giving the treatments to the participants so that the researcher nor subjects know what group is what.
One way to control bias and demand characteristics is through a placebo. A placebo is a fake treatment (i.e pill, food, drug) that will have no affect on the subject. When the subject thinks that they have a better well-being or believe a change has occurred to them because of the placebo that is called the placebo effect. Some researchers use a design that allows the participants to be their own control. That is they take two different types of treatment and the effects are looked analyzed but the order in which they are taken can cause a problem so researchers use counterbalancing. Counterbalancing is when half the participants take one treatment first and the other half take the second treatment first. This eliminates the chance that the order in which the treatments are taken can cause a bias.
fields.title: Eliminating Bias in an Experiment

fields.content: Naturalistic observation is when a researchers does not interfere with the subjects and just observes them in their natural habitats. This allows the researcher to see the true behavior of subjects without manipulating anything.
fields.title: Naturalistic Observation

fields.content: Correlational method is used to determine if the presence of one variable willl have the presence or absence of another variable. Survey method is when researchers hand out questionnaires to ask a large number of people questions about thoughts, behaviors, interests, etc. This is an easy was to gain a knowledge about a large number of people but in order to have an accurate conclusion the researcher must use a random sample which is difficult to do because the survey method has a low response rate. From a survey, researchers can look at the relationship between two variables but they can not imply a cause and effect relationship because their is no dependent and independent variable. Ex post facto study which look at the effect ad try to figure out the cause of the effect. Case studies is a method that uses a small amount of participants and looks how they evolve over time or to understand a specific problem with them. Because of the small number of participants, scientists can not generalize their findings to a larger population.
fields.title: Survey Method, Ex Post Facto, and Case Studies

fields.content:
Descriptive statistics describe a data set. Psychologists will summarize this data into a frequency distribution that will arrange the data to show the frequency of each answer. This can be represented as a histogram (bar graph) or a frequency polygon (line graph).The most common form of statistical measure is known as central tendency. This is comprised of mean, median, and mode.
  • Mean is the average of all the score in the data set.
  • Median is the middle score.
  • Mode is the score that is most frequent in the data set.
A normal distribution is when a bell shaped curve represents the data. That is that the mean is the center point of the data. A group of data may become skewed by outlier and the distribution no longer is bell shaped. An outlier is an extreme value that is far away from the rest of the data (i.e data set= 1,1,1,1,3,2,,5,3,2,5,3,1,4,4,4,10... 10 is the outlier). If the skew is caused by a high score, then the distribution is positively skewed (skewed right) and if the skew is caused by a low score, the distribution is negatively skewed (skewed left).
fields.title: Descriptive Statistics

fields.content:
There are different ways to see the variability in a distribution. The three main ways is through range, variance, and stadnard deviation.
  • Range is the difference between the highest and lowst scores in a data set
  • Variance is the standard deviation squared. It measures the average distance of a score from the mean.
  • Standard deviation also measures the average distance of a score from the mean.
All of these aspects can be accomodated using a z-score. A z-score is the distance left or right from the mean of the data set in terms of standard deviations. A negative z score is below the mean and a positive one is above the mean. In a normal distribution, there are percentiles which show how the proportions of scores are divided in terms of standard deviations. One standard deviation away from the mean in both positive and negative direction 68% of scores occur. Two standard deviations away is 95% and three standrd deviations is 99% of scores occur.
fields.title: Measures of Variability

fields.content:
For animal research the guidelines are:

  1. There must be a clear scientific purpose.
  2. The research must be done so the least amount of harm occurs.
  3. The animals must be taken care of in a humane way.
  4. The acquirement of the subjects must be done legally.
For human research the guidelines are:
  1. Participation must be voluntary.
  2. Subjects must know they are in a experiment and must provide consent.
  3. All subjects name and information from the experiment must be kept confidential.
  4. Participants cant be in danger of having any mental or physical health risk during the experiment.
  5. After the study, subjects must be debriefed and told the purpose of the study and the scientifical significance.
fields.title: Ethical Guidelines for Research

fields.content: As you learned in the chapter covering the Constitution, the Bill of Rights was set in place to prevent a tyrannical government. More specifically, the Bill of Rights safeguards citizens from unfair acts of the federal government. However, it does nothing to protect civil liberties from the state governments.
fields.title: The Constitution

fields.content: The 14'th Amendment was used by the Supreme Court to apply the Bill of Rights to the states in a process called selective incorporation. The 14th Amendment has two main components that were crucial to the process of selective incorporation: the Equal Protection Clause and the Due Process Clause.Civil liberties were gradually applied to the states through court cases using these two clauses instead of all at once. This is why the process is referred to as selective incorporation. Most of the Bills of Rights applies to the states, but some amendments have yet to be incorporated, such as the second (the right to bear arms) and the eight (the protection against excessive fines).
fields.title: Selective Incorporation Through the 14<Sup>Th</Sup> Amendment

fields.content:
THE FIRST INCORPORATION

The state of New York arrested newsman Gitlow when he wrote a piece that advocated the eradication of the government through a revolution of workers. While Gitlow's conviction was upheld, the Supreme Court ruled - in "Gitlow v. New York - that freedom of speech and the press (part of the First Amendment) are protected from the states by the Due Process Clause of the 14'th Amendment. This court case was the first in a long line of cases that would incorporate the Bill of Rights.

Symbolic Speech

The Supreme Court has ruled that certain forms of nonviolent and nonthreatening protest qualify for protection as symbolic speech. Some of these are: burning flags ('Texas v. Johnson) and wearing armbands (Tinker v. Des Moines - the armbands were protests against the Vietnam War). However, some acts such as burning draft cards ('United States v. O'Brien) are not considered protected forms of symbolic speech.
fields.title: Freedom of Speech Protections

fields.content:
Freedom of speech is a basic right that all Americans should have. Clearly from the cases above, freedom of speech is necessary to protect the powerless. However, there are many times when Americans aren't allowed to say whatever they want. The best example is shown in the court case Schneck v. United States

Schneck v. United States

Schneck was indicted for violating the Espionage Act after he sent thousands of letters advocating opposition to a military draft. Schneck appealed to the Supreme Court, which found his conviction to be constitutional despite restricting his First Amendment rights of free speech. The chief justice ruled that the First Amendment applies in most situations, unless use of free speech causes a "clear and present danger The rationale was that if one were to yell "fire!" in a theater, it would cause panic and ultimately danger (people can die from being trampled).

Other Speech Restrictions

The Supreme Court has also limited free speech in other ways. Libel and slander are written and spoken, respectively, forms of false, insulting speech. The Supreme Court has ruled that statements are only libel or slander if one can prove that "the statements in questions are made with actual malice There is also no constitutional provision to protect all forms of obscenity. Usually the communities are the bodies responsible for enforcing governmental guidelines for obscenity.
fields.title: Freedom of Speech Restrictions

fields.content: The government has tried to control and restrict freedoms of the press. This usually happens in times of war, when the government would like the media not to report on certain happenings for the interests of national security or in order to not compromise its position in a war. One of the most important cases was New York Times Co. v. United States, which involved a leakage of American entanglement in Vietnam known as the Pentagon Papers. When the government tried to stop the New York Times from printing any more related material, the Supreme Court ruled that the act of preventing material from being printed before it is actually released - known as prior restraint - is unconstitutional.
fields.title: Freedom of the Press

fields.content: The Free Exercise Clause guarantees that the government cannot obstruct a person from practicing his or her religion, unless the practice involves illegal activity. For example, a Mormon cannot be prevent by the government from attending his church, but the government can stop him from practicing polygamy (Reynolds v. United States), even though it is practiced in Mormonism, because polygamy is illegal in the United States. Some Native Americans ingest peyote (an illegal drug) as a part of their religious ceremonies, but the Supreme Court ruled that such an act is still illegal, regardless of its religious use (Oregon v. Smith).
fields.title: The Free Exercise Clause

fields.content:
The Establishment Clause prevents the authorization of a national, state, or local religion. The AP regularly uses "A wall of separation between Church and State" as a reference to the Establishment Clause. This clause has prevented the institution of school prayer in public schools (Engel v. Vitale); although, it is not unlawful for student clubs to hold prayers before or after school. Government funding for religious purposes is not black and white - parochial schools are allowed some subsidies for lunches and textbooks. In order to help insure that the government does not violate the Establishment Clause, guidelines were made in the court case Lemon v. Kurtzman. The guidelines were promptly named the Lemon Test:
  1. The activity must have a secular (nonreligious) purpose.
  2. The activity can neither advance nor inhibit religion.
  3. The activity cannot involve "excessive entanglement" between the government and religion.
fields.title: The Establishment Clause

fields.content:
The Fourth Amendment pertains to unlawful searches and seizures. Despite the fact that it was in the Constitution, the Fourth Amendment was ignored often, and information found in such illegal searches and seizures were used to as evidence to convict people of crimes.

Weeks v. United States

The Supreme Court ruled that any evidence obtained from illegal searches and seizures protected by the Fourth Amendment is inadmissible in a court of law. This is known as the exclusionary rule.

Mapp v. Ohio

The Supreme Court applied the exclusionary rule to the states (selective incorporation).
fields.title: The 4<Sup>Th</Sup> Amendment and the Exclusionary Rule

fields.content:
The Sixth Amendment pertains to every citizen's right to counsel (an lawyer) in court

Betts v. Brady

The Supreme Court ruled that state governments were not required to provide defendants counsel even if they could not afford a lawyer.

Gideon v. Wainwright
