The Supreme Court overruled the decision in Betts v. Brady by deciding that state governments must provide lawyers to those that cannot afford one.
fields.title: The 6th Amendment

fields.content: In the court case Miranda v. Arizona, the Supreme Court ruled any evidence revealed during interrogation of criminal suspects who are not informed of their "Miranda rights" will be inadmissible in a court of law. You hear these Miranda rights every time an arrest is made on 'Law and Order
fields.title: Miranda Rights

fields.content:
Griswold v. Connecticut

The state of Connecticut had a law that banned any forms of contraception (for all you young ins, contraception is a method to prevent pregnancy). In Griswold v. Connecticut, the Supreme Court stuck down the law, ruling that the Constitution implied the right to privacy.
fields.title: Contraception

fields.content:
Roe v. Wade

Using the rationale of the right to privacy established in the previous case, the Supreme Court stuck down a Texas law that banned most abortions. Roe v. Wade legalized abortion in the states.

Planned Parenthood v. Casey

In this court case, the Supreme Court ruled that states can regulate abortions, as long as they don't impose an "undue burden" on the patients. For example, a state cannot require the consent of a woman's partner in order to have an abortion.'.
fields.title: Abortion

fields.content: The Thirteenth Amendment abolished slavery.
fields.title: The 13th Amendment

fields.content: The Fourteenth Amendment, as you know, was crucial for incorporating civil liberties. However, its Equal Protection Clause also gave citizenship to former slaves, repealing the Dred Scott decision, which said that blacks were not citizens of the United States.
fields.title: The 14th Amendment

fields.content: The Fifteenth Amendment enfranchised black males (gave them the right to vote).
fields.title: The 15th Amendment

fields.content: The Supreme Court overruled the decision in Plessy v. Ferguson (allowing "separate but equal" public accommodations) by saying that the provision of "separate but equal" is intrinsically unequal.
fields.title: Brown v. Board of Education

fields.content: This law made it illegal to base a worker's pay based on race, religion, or gender.
fields.title: Equal Pay Act of 1963

fields.content: Despite the federal government's attempts to stop racial segregation, many state and local governments, mainly in the South, continued to separate blacks from whites. This forced Congress to pass the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which made any sort of discrimination based on race, religion, or gender, illegal. This included the end to all Jim Crow Laws (basically more racial segregation laws).
fields.title: The Civil Rights Act of 1964

fields.content: The Twenty-fourth Amendment outlawed poll taxes.
fields.title: The 24th Amendment

fields.content:
Congress also passed the Voting Rights Act of 1965, which protected blacks' right to vote by stopping practices used largely in the South to disenfranchise them. The outlawed tactics were:
  • Poll taxes - many blacks were poor and could not afford the fee to vote
  • Literacy tests - many blacks were uneducated and therefore could not pass these tests to vote
  • Grandfather clauses - bascially allowed poor and uneducated white men to vote by saying that anyone who had a grandfather that voted before 1867 was also allowed to vote
  • White primaries - blacks were not allowed to vote in primary elections
The Voting Rights Act of 1965 also let the federal government regulate elections in states that had less than half their populations registered to vote.
fields.title: The Voting Rights Act of 1965

fields.content: This kind of ties in with civil rights, but whatever. The Supreme Court has ruled that any categorization based on race or gender must have a compelling or moderate, respectively, reason. Affirmative action is allowed as a "plus factor" in admissions decisions in the interests of promoting diversity. Therefore, promoting diversity is a good reason (in the Supreme Court's eyes) for colleges' use of affirmative action.
fields.title: Reason

fields.content: Colleges are not allowed to use quotas as a part of their affirmative action process. For example, colleges may not require that their incoming freshmen classes must have a composition of at least 30% blacks.
fields.title: Quotas

fields.content:
I don't believe you'll be tested on specific cases, but I'll list them anyway:

University of California v. Bakke

The Supreme Court ruled that quota systems are unconstitutional, but affirmative action can be used as a "plus" factor.

Grutter v. Bollinger

The Supreme Court upheld the ruling in the previous case.

Gratz v. Bollinger

The Supreme Court once again upheld Bakke by ruling that a college's admissions process placed too much emphasis on race.
fields.title: Cases

fields.content: Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Lucretia Mott, Susan B. Anthony, and Betty Friedan.
fields.title: Leaders of Women's Rights

fields.content: The Nineteenth Amendment enfranchised all women.
fields.title: The 19th Amendment

fields.content: This was an attempt at an amendment to basically guarantee everyone equal rights, but it was not ratified by Congress.
fields.title: The Equal Rights Amendment

fields.content: This was just a convention that tried to stop discrimination against women.
fields.title: The Seneca Falls Convention

fields.content: Women gained rights in order ways, such as contraceptive rights, abortion rights, and gained fights from the Civil Rights Act of 1964. These all have already been mentioned.'.
fields.title: Other Stuff

fields.content:
The Senate has 100 members (2 from each state). Senators must be at least 30 years old, a resident of the state he represents, and an American citizen for at least 9 years. Senators serve 6 year terms. Senators were originally elected by the state legislatures, so they essentially represented the states rather than their peoples. The 17th Amendment changed the election of Senators to be by the direct vote of the people.The Senate holds three exclusive powers:
  • Try (judge) impeachment trials
  • Confirm presidential appointments (including federal judges, Supreme Court judges, and cabinet heads)
    • There is an unwritten custom when confirming appointments called senatorial courtesy. The Senate will only approve an appointment if the majority party senator(s) from the state the appointee is to serve is/are not opposed to the action.
  • Ratify treaties made by the president

Leaders of the Senate

The Constitution names the vice president as the leader of the Senate. Nevertheless, the president pro tempore, the Senator with the longest service in the majority party (the party that has the majority of the chairs), conducts meetings in the Senate most of the time because the vice president usually does not take this duty. However, the leader of the majority of the party (most often not the president pro tempore) is the real leader of the Senate. The majority party reaps the following benefits:
  • Holds the chairs and the majority of every committee
  • Assigns bills to committees
  • Sets the agenda
Both the majority and minority party leaders have Whips, who are people in each party who attempt to maintain party agreement on votes.
fields.title: The Senate

fields.content:
The House of Representatives has 435 members. Members of the House must be at least 25 years old, a resident of the state he represents, and an American citizen for at least 7 years. Members of the House serve 2 year terms. Members of the House have always been directly elected by the people, which is why the House was known to represent the public's interest.The House of Representatives also holds three exclusive powers:
  • Impeach any United States office holder (including the president)
  • Generate revenue tax bills
  • Choose the president when no candidate has a majority of electoral college votes

Leaders of the House of Representatives

The Speaker of the House of Representatives conducts meetings in the House and is second to the vice president to take over the presidency should the president be unfit to do so. However, the majority leader is the true leader of the House. The majority party shares the same benefits as the majority party in the Senate, as well as choosing the Speaker of the House. Both the majority and minority party leaders have Whips, who are people in each party who attempt to maintain party agreement on votes.

Reapportionment

Each state has representatives proportional to their populations, with a census taken every 10 years to apportion seats in the House. Congressional district lines in each state are drawn by state legislatures. Often during reapportionment, state legislatures use gerrymandering, which is an attempt to redraw congressional district lines in order to benefit the majority party in control of the state legislature. Often, the lines are drawn like a puzzle, like the famous image to the left. Many rules have been made about the process, but the Supreme Court has not called gerrymandering for partisan political reasons unconstitutional.
fields.title: The House of Representatives

fields.content:
Congress has many checks over the judicial and executive branch

Checks over the Judicial Branch

The most important power Congress has over the judicial branch is its power to amend the Constitution. Once an amendment has been ratified, it is the "supreme law over the land" and must be obeyed by the Supreme Court.

Checks over the Executive Branch

Congress has gained much power of the executive branch, including:
  • The power to override a veto with a two-thirds vote in both houses
  • The requirement of Senate confirmation of presidential appointments
  • The passage of the War Powers Resolution Act of 1973, which required the president to inform Congress within two days of the deployment of troops. This also requires the president to bring troops back within 90 days if Congress does not give him an extension. Remember that Congress has the power to declare war, but the president can still deploy troops without Congress' authority.
  • Congressional oversight, which allows Congress to budget, evaluate, and set guidelines for executive agencies
fields.title: Checks and Balances

fields.content: This is possibly the most important committee, as it has the ability to generate tax revenue bills. It's important to note that this committee is in the House of Representatives, which we know has the sole power to generate taxing bills.
fields.title: The House Committee on Ways and Means

fields.content: The Speaker of the House controls the House Committee on Rules, which sets schedules for voting and rules for floor debate. It is important to note that the House of Representatives has a much more controlled floor than the Senate due to its larger population.
fields.title: The House Committee on Rules

fields.content: Senators often use a filibuster to impede the passage of a bill they do not support. A filibuster is basically a speech with no time limit that halts all legislative processes in the Senate. Filibusters are regularly successful in stopping a bill. A vote of 60 senators must be taken to end a filibuster. The filibuster has essentially made it a requirement to have 60 senators support a major bill to ensure its passing in the Senate.
fields.title: Filibuster

fields.content: If the bill does survive both the committee and the floor of a house, it will be sent to the other house of Congress to endure the same process. If it happens to make it out of the other house as well, the bill will be sent to a conference committee to resolve any differences between the two houses on the bill. Finally, the bill will be sent back two both houses to have a final decision.'.
fields.title: Final Passage of a Bill

fields.content:
This bill put limits on individual contributions to presidential candidates, but in return offers public funding to candidates for both the primaries and general elections.

Self Contributions

In the case Buckley v. Valeo, the Supreme Court ruled that while limits should still exist for individual contributions to presidential candidates, the contributions that the candidates themselves make cannot be refined, as that is considered as a form of protected speech.
fields.title: The Federal Election Reform Act

fields.content: 527s are tax-exempt organizations that can engage in activities such as running advertisements or mobilizing citizens to vote.
fields.title: 527 Organizations

fields.content: Political contributions that are fully disclosed are referred to as hard money. Hard money are limited in amounts.
fields.title: Hard Money

fields.content:
Soft money are undisclosed funds raised in unlimited amounts for the purposes of party building (such as advertising for the Democratic of Republican Party).

Ban on Soft Money

Soft money contributions were banned by the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act.
fields.title: Soft Money

fields.content:
Primary elections and caucuses determine the candidates for the major political parties. Most states hold primaries, but a few hold caucuses, which require voters to attend open meetings of party members in order to designate their choice of candidates. There are two types of primaries:
  • An open primary allows anyone to vote in its election, even members of another party
  • A closed primary requires voters to be registered voters of that party
There are also two ways a candidate can get electors:
  • Winner-take-all - if a candidate wins the popular vote in the state, he will receive all of that state's electors
  • Proportional - candidates receive a state's electors based on the proportion of votes they acquire. If a candidate gets 25% of a state's votes, he'll receive one-fourth of that state's electors
The first primary and caucus are held in New Hampshire and Iowa, respectively. Many people criticize this tradition because the two states receive too much attention for being first. This has resulted in other states pushing forward the dates of their primary elections, known as front-loading. A very small percentage of citizens actually vote in primaries and caucuses, which is why the systems are criticized for being unrepresentative of the people.

National Party Conventions

These used to be the actual places where presidential candidates were nominated; however, due to the rise of primaries and caucuses, they are just formalities. The candidates usually even know if they were nominated or not before the conventions.
fields.title: Primaries and Caucuses

fields.content:
Most American citizens only bother to cast their ballots in the general election. Originally, state legislatures chose their own state's electors. Today, each state's electors are chosen by the political party that gets the most votes in each state. By voting for Barrack Obama in Illinois, one is technically voting for the Democratic Party to have the ability to select all 20 electors in the state of Illinois. It goes without saying that the electoral college system is winner-take-all in each state. A state's electoral votes will only be given to the candidate who receives the most votes in that state. Because of this, it is very difficult for third party candidates to win the general election. As aforementioned, a third party candidate could hypothetically receive 20% of votes in every state and still receive zero electoral votes. Another result of the winner-take all system is that candidates will spend much more time in swing states, where the votes could go either way, instead of in states where the candidate is a sure winner or loser

Reforming the Electoral College

Many people dislike the electoral college because, mathematically, a candidate could win the general election without winning the popular vote. However, it is difficult to reform the electoral college for the following reasons:
  • It benefits several powerful interest groups
  • It requires an amendment to be reformed
  • It gives small states with smaller populations a disproportional influence, so it will be hard to garner their support in any reform
fields.title: General Election

fields.content: Since incumbents are office holders during their time of reelection, they're inherently more well known than their challengers are.
fields.title: Reputation

fields.content:
Incumbents have three special privileges that contribute to their advantage over incumbents.

Franking

Incumbents are allowed to send mail to their constituents free of charge.

Pork-Barrel

Incumbents try to put pork-barrel in legislation, which brings projects to their districts (and thus jobs their constituents), primarily in the hopes of gaining their constituents' support

Casework

Incumbents sometimes help individual citizens out by "cutting through bureaucratic red tape" to help solve their problems. This gives incumbents a good image, helping gain the support of people they don't even directly help.
fields.title: Privileges

fields.content: Incumbents receive more contributions (especially from interest groups) to their campaigns than do their challengers.'.
fields.title: Campaign Financing

fields.content: The Constitution granted specific powers to the Constitution (there are 27, but it is not necessary to know all of them). As aforementioned in the previous chapter, the most important powers given to Congress are the ability to levy revenue taxes and the ability to regulate interstate commerce.
fields.title: Enumerated Powers

fields.content: The last clause of the enumerated powers is the the necessary and proper (or elastic) clause. As you might imagine, this is used by the federal government to address issues that were not relevant at the time, such as the creation of the national bank.
fields.title: Implied Powers

fields.content: The 10<sup>th</sup> Amendment states that any powers not given to the federal government nor prohibited by the Constitution are reserved to the states. These are mostly local tasks, such as establishing public schools, hospitals, and local governments.
fields.title: Reserved Powers

fields.content: These are powers held by both the federal and state governments. This is a great example of federalism: shared power between national and state level.
fields.title: Concurrent Powers

fields.content: One of the most important attributes of federalism is that it increases political participation because of the lower levels of government (state and local). Even if someone is not running for office, there are most opportunities to get involved, such as helping someone else campaign for a local office position. Federalism also separates powers onto different levels, preventing any body of government from getting too big. Lastly, many federal policies are the result of prior implementation at the state and local levels. Federalism allows different levels of governments to experiment to possibly find a solution to a national issue much faster than just having one large body of government trying to solve the problem on its own.
fields.title: Advantages to Federalism

fields.content: This is a system of government in which the federal and state governments work cohesively on an issue or program. Concurrent powers is a good way to think of this; both levels of government share powers and work together. The most famous example of cooperative federalism is the interstate highway program.
fields.title: Cooperative Federalism

fields.content: This is a system of government in which the the federal and state government do not directly interact with each other about issues or programs. They have their own separate "spheres of influence.
fields.title: Dual Federalism

fields.content:
This is a political philosophy of devolution, which is just a general transfer of powers from the federal government to states. The types of grants offered to the states is a way in which power can vacillate back and forth between state and local levels.
  • Block grants are given to states with an extensive range of uses. The states can almost do anything (within reason) with block grants. Therefore, block grants support devolution by giving states more power and discretion.
  • Categorical grants are given to states for explicit intentions. States must follow specific guidelines for the purposes of the categorical grants. Thus, categorical grants hinder the process of devolution.
  • Mandates are requirements the federal government imposes on states usually as a condition of receiving grants. Mandates are usually to do with civil rights, environmental policy, or handicap protection (eg. building ramps).
fields.title: New Federalism

fields.content:
The state of Maryland had attempted to impose a tax on all notes of banks not chartered in Maryland, and in doing so, attempted to levy a tax on the Second National Bank of the United States. Chief Justice John Marshall made two rulings:
  • Congress has the constitutional authority to charter a national bank through its implied powers.
  • The Maryland tax on the national bank was unconstitutional.
The implication of Marshall's rulings is that the national government is supreme to the states.
fields.title: McCulloch v. Maryland

fields.content:
This clause of the Constitution has added to national supremacy in two ways:

Gibbons v. Ogden

The Court of Chancery of New York ruled that the defendant, Gibbons, could not operate a ferry service between New Jersey and New York because the plaintiff, Ogden, had been granted absolute rights to do so by the state of New York. However, Gibbons had received the license to operate the ferry from the 'federal government. Therefore, the Supreme Court ruled that Gibbons' ferry service was lawful because Congress has the sole right to regulate all interstate commerce

Civil Rights Act of 1964

The Supreme Court ruled that the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which banned discrimination in public accommodations (including restaurants and movie theaters), was constitutional because Congress has the ability to regulate interstate commerce, which these places were partaking in all the time.'.
fields.title: Interstate Commerce Clause

fields.content: Interest groups often form what are known as political action committees (PACs), which help candidates by raising money for their campaigns. Incumbent members of the House of Representatives specifically enjoy the benefits of PACs for their campaigns. However, laws have been put in place that sets a maximum of $5,000 total in contributions from one PAC to a certain candidate for an election.
fields.title: Financing Campaigns

fields.content: Interest groups try to help finance candidates' campaigns in order to influence them on public policy. This process is known as lobbying. In addition to offering congressional candidates with financial resources, an important function of interest groups is to provide them with key information regarding specific issues (clearly related to the members of the interest groups). Many people confuse interest groups' intentions with those of political parties. Interest groups are only concerned with certain issues pertaining to them; and they are very helpful to congressional candidates when offering them information about these issues.
fields.title: Lobbying

fields.content: Interest groups have ways of influencing the judicial and executive branch as well. Interest groups can file amicus curiae briefs in court cases or even use litigation to directly sponsor a case. Interest groups are also very involved in the activities of regulatory agencies.
fields.title: Influencing Other Branches of Government

fields.content: The more money, the more interest groups can aid PACs, sponsor court cases (litigation), and influence public policy in general.
fields.title: Financial Resources

fields.content: Interest groups that have members who truly care about the issues the groups are about and work diligently towards achieving their goals will obviously be more successful than interest groups with indifferent members.
fields.title: Intensity

fields.content: Interest groups that have a lot of people will have more reach than smaller interest groups. However, according to Olson's law of large groups, the larger the interest group, the more serious the free-rider problem. Free-riders are people not a part of an interest group yet still receive benefits from the work that interest group does.
fields.title: Size

fields.content:
There are several types of interest groups, but knowing them is not particularly stressed by the AP exam. Nevertheless, I'll list some:

  • Business interest groups
  • Labor interest groups
  • Environmental interest groups
  • Equality interest groups
    • National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP)
    • National Organization for Women (NOW)
If you ever are asked about a specific interest group on the AP exam, the answer should be easy to pick out. What you should know, however, is that in the past couple decades, the amount of business interest groups has risen greatly.
fields.title: Types of Interest Groups

fields.content: Iron triangles are mutually beneficial collaborations (often called subgovernment) between an interest group, a bureaucratic agency, and a congressional committee.
fields.title: Iron Triangles

fields.content: AN issue network is a collection of individuals - including interest groups, think tanks, and congressional staffs - who regularly discuss public policies.There is usually confusion between iron triangles and issue networks. Iron triangles are formed to politically benefit those involved, which issue networks are more about discussions more than anything.
fields.title: Issue Networks

fields.content: Public policies are the result of many interest groups competing to influence government. This is results in a healthy democratic compromise.
fields.title: Pluralist Theory

fields.content: There are so many interest groups influencing politicians that public policies often conflict with each other, weakening government. Basically, an extreme, cynical form of pluralism.
fields.title: Hyperpluralist Theory

fields.content: The majority of public policy is influenced by a small number of powerful interest groups comprised of wealthy elites.'.
fields.title: Elite Theory

fields.content:
This is not that stressed by the AP exam, but I think that it is essential information to know anyway. The United States has a mixed capitalist, free market economy. This means that instead of the government controlling everything that is produced in the country, citizens control the vast majority of businesses (in what is known as the private sector). However, the government is still able to regulate the economy by overlooking businesses' practices

Classical Theory

Classical economists believe in pure laissez faire economic systems. These types of economies feature absolutely no government intervention at all. They believe that the economy is self-regulating and does not need help from the government to stabilize itself.

Keynesian Theory

Keynesian economists believe that government intervention in the economy is essential for healthy growth. They still support the privatization of the economy, but think that in recessionary or inflationary periods of time, the government must guide the economy in the right direction. The United States is keynesian; any time taxes are altered or the government spends money, the economy is being affected.
fields.title: America's Economic System

fields.content: The federal budget is the annual statement of projected revenues (mainly through taxes) and expenditures of the country in a given year. The budget reflects what how the government believes its finances will play out; however, they don't always happen that way. People use the terms balanced budgets, budget deficits, and budget surpluses to describe the three possible ways a budget can be made. A balanced budget is one in which the government spends the same amount of money as it consumes, hence the word "balanced A budget deficit is a scenario in which the government will spend more money than it gains. A budget surplus is the opposite of a budget deficit, but it rarely occurs.
fields.title: The Budget

fields.content:
There are two types of financial policies in the United States: monetary and fiscal.

Monetary Policy

Monetary policy deals with the changing of interest rates in an attempt to influence the economy. They are changed through the Federal Reserve Board's alteration of the amount of money in circulation, or the money supply

Fiscal Policy

Fiscal policy deals with actions taken by elected government officials, such as lowering taxes or increasing government spending through new programs.
fields.title: Financial Policies

fields.content:
Entitlement programs are mandated by federal law. The government does not have a choice whether or not to pay into them (unless action against the programs are taken, of course). Anyone who meets the requirements of a certain program is entitled to its benefits. Entitlement programs are not the only forms of spending the government cannot control; however, it's important to note that they make up the majority of it

Social Security

Social Security is one of the most discussed entitlement programs today. It gives payments to senior citizens. Unfortunately, Social Security as it is now will burden the future taxpayers of America. One main reason why is that the average life span has been steadily rising, which means beneficiaries will receive more overall payments than those before them. This is why government officials are pushing to increase the Social Security eligibility age. Another reason why is that the work force is depleting, while the number of retirees is increasing. This means that a small group of people are going to have to support Social Security for a large group of beneficiaries.

Health Care

Two of the other most expensive entitlement programs are:
  • Medicare - provides health insurance for the elderly
  • Medicaid - provides health insurance for those that have financial need
fields.title: Entitlement Programs

fields.content:
I call the following potential advantages because they can easily be seen as drawbacks; to each his own:

Moderate Policy

When neither major party controls all of government, policy is less likely to be ideologically one-sided. For most Americans, this hinderance of radical change in the country is good.

Weakening of Political Parties

Due mainly to irritation with government during times of divided government (more on that below), the public has experienced party dealignment, which is the shift away from major political parties towards moderate viewpoints. More people are starting to label themselves as independent rather than Democrat or Republican. This takes power away from political parties. Parties try to combat this by attempting to reduce split-ticket voting (when people vote for candidates of different parties in a single election; see closed primaries in Elections).
fields.title: Potential Advantages of Divided Government

fields.content:
GridLock

Instead of making compromises during divided government like we'd expect, the two major political parties have are stuck in gridlock. Neither party is willing to give in, which slows down the legislative process (filibusters are a major tool for minority party members to stop the passage of a bill)

Decline of Trust

People become irritated with the lack of progress the government makes during divided government. This leads to drops of the public's trust in the government's ability to carry out its responsibilities. You learned about the decline of public trust in Political Beliefs.
fields.title: Disadvantages of Divided Government

fields.content: Americans believe, with some exceptions, that the government should not interfere with people's activities, as long as they do not hurt other people. These fundamentally include free speech and religion.
fields.title: Liberty

fields.content: Americans collectively believe that everyone should have an equal vote, be treated equally under the law, and have an equal chance to succeed. It is important to note that while Americans believe in equality of opportunity, they do not believe in economic equality. Economic equality is more of a socialist idea than a liberal one.
fields.title: Equality

fields.content: Americans believe that citizens have a duty to support their communities, but government officials also must be accountable to the people.
fields.title: Democracy

fields.content: Americans believe that people are responsible for their own actions and decision; this is unlike a collectivist culture in which people identify more as groups.
fields.title: Individual Responsibility

fields.content: As aforementioned, there has been a general decline of American trust in government. This decline started since the 1950s and has not seemed to halt. Part of the reason for the decline of trust is the corresponding deterioration of American political efficacy, the amount impact citizens think they have on the government.
fields.title: Mistrust of Government

fields.content:
Conservatives generally support:
  • Increased military funding
  • Less government regulation of the economy
  • Religion in schools
while generally being against:
  • Abortions
  • Social programs such as:
    • Welfare
    • Social Security
    • Universal healthcare
fields.title: Conservatives

fields.content:
Liberals generally support:
  • Social programs such as the ones above
  • Free choice in getting abortions
  • Increased government regulation of the economy
  • Gay rights
while generally being against:
  • Religion in schools
  • Increases in military funding
fields.title: Liberals

fields.content: The process by which children and adolescents acquire political attitudes and opinions is called political socialization. The media through which political socialization happens includes school and social media, but the most important by far is family at home. Children are likely to identify with their parents' political beliefs and values if those beliefs and values are strong.
fields.title: Sources of Political Culture

fields.content: While there are leaders of political parties (such as Democrats and Republicans) at every level of government, organizations of these parties at each level are independent of each other. For example, the National Democratic Party has no real bearings on, say, the Democratic Party of Illinois. Even though they both stand for the same ideas, they are not directly linked to one another.
fields.title: National, State, and Local Levels of Parties

fields.content: Single-member district elections feature a plurality, winner-take-all system. This means that the candidate that acquires the most votes is elected into office. This is different from a majority election, in which the winning candidate must receive at least half of all votes cast. Winner-take-all means that the overall winner of the election wins the office or all of the seats offered on the ballot. The electoral college uses the winner-take-all system. When President Obama won 57.6% of the vote in Illinois in the 2012 presidential election, he gained all 20 of Illinois' electors. Almost all of the elections that take place in the United States are in single-member districts.
fields.title: Single-Member Districts

fields.content:
Single-member district elections makes it hard for third party candidates to win. One of the main reasons why is that the Democratic and Republican Parties are household names that garner a lot of attention. Third party candidates have to petition to be placed on the ballot, while that is automatically done for candidates of the two major parties. The winner-take-all featured electoral college system makes it almost impossible for a third party candidate to win a presidential election. Even if a candidate received a modest percentage of votes in every state, he could still end up with zero electors. In addition, third party candidates are not even allowed to speak in presidential debates. The greatest impact third parties have is taking away support from another candidates. Support for Ralph Nader's Green Party took away from Al Gore's vote in the 2000 election.There are several types of third parties:

Ideological Parties

These tend to be of extremist political viewpoints. Good examples are the Socialist Party, the Communist Party, and the Libertarian Party.

One-Issue Parties

These often discuss a single issue, such as banning alcohol (the Prohibition Party) or banning abortions (the Right to Life Party).

Factional Parties

These often split off from major parties. Theodore Roosevelt's "Bull Moose" Progressive Party split the Republican Party in 1912.
fields.title: Third Parties
The Rise and Fall of Political Parties

fields.content: The Federalists supported a strong central government, as well as a national bank (which was not explicitly granted by the Constitution). However, the Democratic-Republican Party, which advocated smaller central government and no central bank, defeated the Federalists in the 1800 presidential election. The importance is that this was the first time power was peacefully given up following an election.
fields.title: The Federalists and Democratic-Republicans

fields.content: Andrew Jackson led the Democrats, who advocated for universal male suffrage for whites, used the spoils system (mentioned in The Bureaucracy), and was against the National Bank.
fields.title: Jacksonian Democracy

fields.content: Abraham Lincoln led the Republican Party to become the only third party in American history to win a presidential election. This was largely due to the party split of the Democrats over the issue of slavery.
fields.title: Slavery and the Republicans

fields.content: Democrat Franklin Delano Roosevelt pushed his economic reform plan, called the New Deal. This time period was characterized by a party realignment, as many blacks (who previously mainly voted for the Republicans) voted for the Democratic Party. This major shift of party loyalty happened in what is called as a critical election.
fields.title: Reform and the New Deal

fields.content: Just as blacks swayed towards the Democrats, Richard Nixon's "Southern strategy" worked in acquiring the votes of white conservatives in the South. However, Nixon's era was also branded as the inception of divided government (more on this later), which slowed down the legislative process of the federal government. This frustrated voters, and led to the decline in trust they had in government. The most important consequence of this is that an increasing number of people started to identify themselves as moderate independents, instead of Democrats or Republicans. This resulted in the decline of power political parties had in a process known as party dealignment.'.
fields.title: The Fall of Political Parties in the Nixon Era

fields.content: There are 15 executive cabinet departments, with a secretary leading each, except for the Department of Justice, which is led by the attorney general. As aforementioned, many cabinet members (including their leaders) do not have strong loyalty to the president. One reason for this is that often cabinet heads stay for several administrations, so the president in command is usually not the one who appointed them.
fields.title: The Cabinet

fields.content:
Independent agencies are appointed by the president and confirmed by the Senate just like other agencies, but the president may not remove them.

INDEPENDENT REGULATORY AGENCIES

These agencies monitor certain regions of the economy. There are a few to know:

  • Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) protects investors in the securities market (basically stocks).
  • Federal Reserve Board sets monetary policy by controlling the money supply. This affects real interest interest rates, which have an effect on inflation and economic growth. The Federal Reserve Board is also insulated from the public as well as politics in general because it does not receive funding through the congressional budgetary process.

Independent Executive Agencies

These agencies that oversee specific functions. It's not important to know much about them or any specific examples of them (like NASA).
fields.title: Independent Agencies

fields.content: These are exactly what they sound like: businesses partially or fully owned by the government. They don't deal with the everyday sense of "government tasks Anything government corporations do could be done by a private company. A good example of a government corporation is the United States Postal Service. The deliverance of mail is also done by private companies, such as FedEx and UPS.
fields.title: Government Corporations

fields.content: Bureaucratic agencies have some discretionary authority when making decisions, but the vast majority of their employees have specific jobs to and rules to follow. Many of the regulatory agencies' responsibilities are monitoring private businesses, their operating procedures, and what their effects are (such as on the environment). Often, the implementation of a policies of several bureaucratic agencies can overlap, causing a waste of financial resources.
fields.title: Bureaucratic Authorities

fields.content: Since bureaucrats are appointed officials, they are subject to bias during the process of selecting them. The Pendleton Act created the civil service, which hires workers on the base of merit instead of any other reason such as loyalty. The spoils system is a good example of a system that selected employees based on their party loyalty.
fields.title: Appointing Officials

fields.content:
Congress can use its committees to monitor and regulate agencies by doing the following:
  • Investigating agencies
  • Allocating responsibilities as a separation of power
  • Establishing rules and guideilnes for agencies to follow
fields.title: Congressional Oversight

fields.content: Both the president and Congress have economic authority over the bureaucracy. The president can control an agency's budget through the Office of Management and Budget. Congress, however, is the body of government that appropriates (authorizes or sets aside) funds for bureaucratic agencies.
fields.title: Economic Authority

fields.content: The weaknesses of the Articles of Confederation were evident during Shays' Rebellion, a six month period in which thousands of armed Massachusetts farmers protested the foreclosure of their estates. Shays' Rebellion helped demonstrate why a stronger federal government was necessary to keep peace and prosperity in America.
fields.title: Shays' Rebellion

fields.content: Even with the Great Compromise, other issues had to be addressed, such as the representation of a state based on its population of slaves. In what is known as the Three-Fifths Compromise, the Framers declared that a slave would be counted as three-fifths of a free man towards a state's population in determining its representation in Congress.
fields.title: Three-Fifths Compromise

fields.content: Article I of the Constitution established the legislative branch, which was meant to be the most powerful of the three. This new Congress had much more economic power than the central government of the Articles of Confederation. Most importantly, Congress was granted the power to levy revenue taxes and regulate interstate commerce.
fields.title: The Legislative Branch

fields.content: Article II established the executive branch, which consisted of a president chosen by an electoral college.
fields.title: The Executive Branch

fields.content: Article III established the judicial branch, which included the Supreme Court. It is important to note that the Constitution itself did not establish any other court system, nor did the Supreme Court have the ability to do so. Congress was given the power to establish other federal courts.
fields.title: The Judicial Branch

fields.content:
As aforementioned, the Constitution set up a system of check and balances. While this may slow legislation, it prevents one body of government from gaining too much power over the others. Examples of checks and balances are:
  • The President can veto (deny) a bill passed by Congress. However, Congress can override this veto with a two-thirds vote in both the Senate and the House of Representatives.
  • The Supreme Court can declare congressional and presidential acts as unconstitutional in a process that is known as judicial review. However, if Congress passes a constitutional amendment, the Supreme Court must abide by it.
  • The Senate must ratify treaties made by the President. Additionally, the Senate must confirm presidential nominations to the Supreme Court.
fields.title: Checks and Balances

fields.content:
The Constitution protected individual rights with the following:
  • Prohibition of bills of attainder, which are acts that allow punishment before a fair trial
  • Prohibition of ex post facto laws, which are laws that allow the punishment of a man for an act that became illegal after he committed it
  • Guarantee of writ of habeas corpus, which is a legal action that requires a person under arrest to be brought before a judge in a legal court
  • Prohibition of religious requirements to hold office
fields.title: Individual Freedoms

fields.content:
The Framers believed that the best interest of the people is not always what the majority supports. Therefore, they set up the Constitution in a way to safeguard from such "excessive democracy" in the following ways:
  • Federal judges are appointed by the President and serve life terms. Therefore, they need not be supported by the majority to get and stay in power.
  • The President himself was not elected by the popular vote. The President was originally chosen by electors sent by state legislatures. However, now electors are chosen by the popular vote in each state.
  • The Senate was originally chosen by state legislatures, not the people. However, once again, this was later changed.
  • The longer term than in the House of Representatives, along with the staggered term of office (not every Senator is up for election in the same year), allowed the Senate to not radically change composition if some popular movement garnered a lot of support.
fields.title: Insulation From Popular Passions

fields.content: In order to garner support for the Constitution, a group of Federalists wrote a series of 85 essays and articles. Among them was James Madison, who argued in the 'Federalist Number 10 that political factions were obviously unwanted but virtually inevitable. He said that a strong and large national government would divide political power and authority and thus lessen the hazard of political factions.
fields.title: The Federalist Papers

fields.content: All the states eventually ratified the Constitution, and, as the Federalists promised the Anti-Federalists, the Bill of Rights was introduced in the first session of Congress.
fields.title: Historical Ratification

fields.content:
An amendment of the Constitution can be proposed by two methods:

  • A two-thirds vote in both the Senate and the House of Representatives
  • A national convention assembled at the request of two-thirds of the state legislatures
An amendment of the Constitution can be <em>ratified</em> by two methods:
  • Ratifying conventions in three-fourths of the states
  • Three-fourths of the state legislatures
fields.title: Amending the Constitution

fields.content: There are 94 district courts, all of which collectively hear almost 90% of all federal cases.
fields.title: The District Courts

fields.content: These are (13) appellate courts given the responsibility of reviewing certain district court decisions. It is important to note that the courts of appeals only review cases and their decision; they do not hold separate trials.
fields.title: The Circuit Courts of Appeals

fields.content:
The Supreme Court reviews cases from both the state supreme courts and the federal circuit courts of appeals. The decisions made by the Supreme Court are effective throughout the country, not just in that certain case.

Judicial Review

The Supreme Court enabled itself the capability of judicial review, which is the power to proclaim a piece of federal legislation as unconstitutional. This was established in the landmark case Marbury v. Madison.

Solicitor General

The Solicitor General takes care of appeals to the Supreme Court, possibly compelling the Court to hear certain cases.
fields.title: The Supreme Court

fields.content:
Presidents have very obvious reasons for nominating a justice to the Supreme Court. They most often are some of the following:
  • Political ideology - Presidents will usually pick people who they think will support themselves and their policies.
  • Race or gender - Presidents may pick a person of a certain minority group in order to gain the vote of that group.
  • Political aquecacy - Presidents also clearly must consider how well of a job an appointee will do. It will look bad on the president if an appointed justice shows incompetency.
fields.title: Nominations

fields.content:
Justices usually practice one of two philosophies: judicial restraint or judicial activism.

Judicial Restraint

Justices who practice judicial restraint believe that they should use precedent (guidelines set by previous Court cases) and the Framers' original intentions when deciding a case. Stare decisis (let the decision stand) is a popular phrase used when using precedent. Justices of this philosophy also believe in deferring to elected bodies of government when in doubt of a case

Judicial Activism

Justices who practice judicial activism believe in voting based on political considerations, such as ideology. Often justices of this philosophy feel that they need to correct wrongdoings, regardless of the Framers' original intent or the widely accepted interpretation of the Constitution.
fields.title: Philosophy on Making Court Decisions

fields.content: Since justices are appointed by the president and serve life terms, they are generally unswayed by the popular opinion of the public. However, they cannot go too out of favor from governing bodies elected by the public, as federal judges are still subject to impeachment.
fields.title: The Public
The Process of Hearing a Supreme Court Case

fields.content:
There are two main types federal jurisdictions:

Original Jurisdiction

Original jurisdiction is the ability to hear and try a case for the first time. The Supreme Court has original jurisdiction mainly when the case involves:
  • Multiple states
  • The governments of the United States and a state

Appellate Jurisdiction

Appellate jurisdiction is the ability to review a case and possibly change its decisions from a lower court. Most of the Supreme Court's cases are under appellate jurisdiction, coming to the Court in the form of a writ of certiorari. A writ of certiorari is an order issued by the Supreme Court to lower courts to send up the record of a case in question for review. The rule of four is a practice of the Supreme Court in which four of the nine Supreme Court justices must vote to hear the case in order to grant writ of certiorari.
fields.title: Jurisdiction

fields.content: Each side of the case files a brief, citing facts and arguments that supports their side. Also, third parties (such as interest groups) to the case may file amicus curiae (friend of the court) briefs, which also provide relevant information to the case.
fields.title: Briefs

fields.content: After oral arguments are heard, the attorneys are given half and hour to speak on behalf of their clients.
fields.title: Arguments

fields.content:
After discussion between the justices, they take a vote on the matter. A majority of at least 5 votes decides the case. Finally, the justices offer their opinions:
  • The majority opinion explains the rationale for the Court's majority's decision on the case.
  • The minority opinion explains the rationale of those dissenting from the majority.
  • The concurrent opinion explains an alternative reason for why one sided with the majority.
fields.title: Voting and Opinions

fields.content: The media provide government officials a way to inform the public of their programs and agenda. Presidents regularly use the media for these tasks.
fields.title: Government Officials

fields.content:
The media also provide the public with their own reports of news, mainly concentrated on campaigns. However, the real coverage is on the candidates more so than their platforms. The media focus on providing coverage of following:
  • Day-to-day activities around the campaigns like rallies and protests
  • Poll numbers - this is referred to as horse-race journalism
  • Sound bites of debates and discussions rather than what they are about
The important thing to know is that the media does not actually provide the viewers with much coverage of the candidates' policies (the important stuff) - they mainly focus on the candidates themselves.
fields.title: The Public

fields.content:
The president can exercise a veto in two ways:
  • A straight up veto to a bill. This can be overridden by a two-thirds vote in both houses of Congress (although, this is very rare).
  • Not signing a bill. If Congress is not in session after 10 days and the bill is still unsigned, it will be rejected in what is known as a "pocket veto
Many have tried to allow the president to use a line-item veto in order to speed up the legislative process. A line-item veto is a partial veto of a bill. A government official would sign off on parts of the bill, and only those parts would become law. State governors often have this authority, but the Supreme Court ruled it unconstitutional for the president to have it as well.
fields.title: Veto

fields.content:
The president can make the following appointments:
  • Federal judges, including Supreme Court justices
  • Cabinet members and heads of independent agencies
  • Diplomats/ambassadors
The president must abide by the custom of senatorial courtesy, or risk having the Senate deny his confirmation.

Removal of Appointments

The president may also remove any appointees under his administration other than heads of independent agencies and federal judges.
fields.title: Appointments

fields.content: As aforementioned, even though Congress has the constitutional power to declare war, the president is the commander-in-chief of the armed forces of the United States. Many American presidents have deployed troops without the approval of Congress.
fields.title: Commander-In-Chief

fields.content: The president has the exclusive power to negotiate treaties with other nations. These treaties are subject to Senate approval. In order to avoid these, presidents often use executive agreements, which work like treaties, but are only guaranteed for the president's administration. The next president may choose to ignore any previously existing executive agreements.
fields.title: Chief Diplomat

fields.content: The president and others in the executive branch cannot be forced to disclose information to the public or Congress if that information's disclosure may impede the actions of the executive branch. Basically, the president is able to withhold information from the public.
fields.title: Executive Privilege

fields.content: The president is able to grant a presidential pardon, which is the forgiveness for a crime and the cancellation of its punishment.
fields.title: Pardons
Other Parts of the Executive Branch

fields.content: The White House Staff are the most loyal members of the executive branch to the president. They mainly manage the Oval Office and help advise the president about policies.
fields.title: The White House Staff

fields.content: This office is largely responsible for overlooking the federal budget.
fields.title: The Office of Management and Budget

fields.content: There are 15 executive departments, all of which have heads appointed by the president. It is important to note that often cabinet members are more loyal to their own departments than to the president.'.
fields.title: The Cabinet

fields.content: People with higher incomes are more likely to vote. Additionally, people with higher incomes are generally more likely to vote for a Republican candidate.
fields.title: Income

fields.content: People with more education are more likely to vote. Additionally, people with more education are likely to vote for a Republican candidate. Although, education seemed to be less of a factor in the 2008 and 2012 elections.
fields.title: Education

fields.content: Whites have higher turnout rates than do blacks and other minorities such as Hispanics. However, blacks with the same education and income level as whites vote in higher percentages. Blacks largely vote for Democratic candidates.
fields.title: Ethnicity

fields.content: Men vote at a lower rate than do women. Men prefer Republican candidates, while women tend to support Democrats.
fields.title: Gender

fields.content: Young people vote at lower percentages than older people. Young people tend to prefer Democrats, while older people tend to support Republicans.
fields.title: Age

fields.content: Protestants are known for supporting Republicans candidates. In fact, people use a term for these devout conservatives: WASPs - White Anglo-Saxon Protestants.
fields.title: Religion

fields.content: Because of the United States' federal system (rather than a unitary of confederate system), there are many elected government positions, ranging from local to state to national levels. Thus, America has many more elections than other democratic countries have. There are so many elections that it is difficult for most to participate in each one they are eligible for. In fact, the majority of Americans only vote in the presidential elections and completely ignore all the other ones like the primaries and state and local elections.
fields.title: Voter Fatigue

fields.content: As we already learned, Americans think that they have little impact on the government and the decision it makes, which is why many choose not to even bother voting.
fields.title: Decline of Political Efficacy

fields.content: The process of registering to vote in the United States is not easy due to many registration laws set in place to stop voting fraud. Many citizens do not want to go through the pain of registering, which leaves them unable to cast a vote in any election. The simple fact that many democratic countries automatically register citizens to vote leaves people wondering why the process in America is so difficult. The Motor Voter Act has made registration easier by enabling people to register to vote while renewing their drivers' license. Nevertheless, many people do not drive cars, leaving them out of the benefits of the bill. Furthermore, the bill actually created a disproportion in the increase of voter registration, as much of the people who do not drive cars are living in poverty.
fields.title: Difficult Voter Registration

fields.content: Every four years, the presidential election is held on a Tuesday, so many people feel inconvenienced by having to vote on the same day they have work.
fields.title: Weekday Presidential Election

fields.content: Voters who belong to conflicting groups that determine their voting behavior are said to have cross-pressures. For example, a young white male has cross-pressure because young people tend to vote for Democrats, but whites and men tend to vote for Republicans. People facing cross-pressures are less likely to vote.'.
fields.title: Cross-Pressures

fields.content: Kennedy a Democrat, defeated the Republican Nixon in the election of 1960, launching the beginning of the Kennedy administration that became known as The New Frontier.
fields.title: The Election of 1960

fields.content:
THE BAY OF PIGS CRISIS

Kennedy and the CIA provided over one thousand Cuban exiles that were opposed to the rule of Castro with guns and supplies in order to invade the nation and take Castro out of power. The United States did provide the exiles with weapons and supplies, although it did not give direct military support, and the whole plan turned out to be a failure, with nearly all of the Cuban exiles being slaughtered and giving a bad reputation to the Kennedy Administration.

THE CUBAN MISSILE CRISIS

The Soviets set up nuclear launch sites in Cuba, although the U.S., under Kennedy's command, was able to surround the island and not let any Soviet ships deliver the missiles to arm the launch sites in Cuba. Kennedy negoigated by promising that the U.S. would refrain from invading Cuba. Kennedy's decision and the way he handled the situation that could have easily turned into a disaster is considered one of his successes in foreign policy.

DOMESTIC POLICY AND THE KENNEDY ASSASSINATION

Kennedy made attempts to end the current economic recession at the time through cutting taxes and other methods, although his efforts did not avail. Kennedy was assassinated in 1963, and was replaced by his Vice President, Lyndon B. Johnson.
fields.title: Foreign Policy

fields.content:
Johnson was known for being effective at getting legislation passed, and he was able to pass a large tax cut that would hopefully stimulate great increases in spending in order to help lift the economy out of the recession.

JOHNSON's GREAT SOCIETY

Johnson's domestic policy entailed a plan known as The Great Society; he was able to pass the followings policies and pursue the following plans for his Great Society:

•War on poverty

•Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965

•Medicare

•Medicaid

SUPREME COURT CASES AFFECTING CIVIL RIGHTS

•Gideon v. Wainwright: Ensures that accused or arrested persons are able to be represented in court.

•Miranda v. Arizona: Requires police or legal authority to read the arrested person their rights that were given in the 5th amendment.

THE PROGRESS IN CIVIL RIGHTS LEGISLATION

Johnson enforced affirmative action in construction projects in order to make sure the provisions set by the Civil Rights Act of 1964 were followed. The following policies were passed to advance civil rights and liberties.

•Civil Rights Act of 1964: Enforced the rules against segregation in public.

•24th Amendment: Outlawed poll taxes, which were being used to keep African Americans from voting.

•Voting Rights Act of 1965: The federal government registered some voters in areas that commonly used literacy tests.

CIVIL RIGHTS ACTIVITIES AND MOVEMENTS

Martin Luther King Jr. became a powerful figure in the advancement of black civil rights, while he believed in peaceful protest and nonviolence, in opposition to Stokey Carmichael, who led a movement where blacks believed themselves to be superior, which was an idea known as black power.

•Desegregation of Little Rock High School in Arkansas: Eisenhower ordered the involvement of the national guard in order to bring black students into the high school with using force and blocking out the furious protestors of the community.

•Montgomery Bus Boycott: People boycotted the use of the public busing services in montgomery in order to demonstrate defiance of the segregation in busing systems.

•Greensboro, North Carolina Sit-In: A group of black college students sit at a diner counter and refuse to move until they are served.

•Freedom Summer: An effort to get a bunch of black voters registered in the south, although the effort resulted in violence.

•Freedom Rides: A group of students rode an interstate around in order to protest the segregation that occurred on buses and interstate transit throughout southern states. President Kennedy ordered law enforcement to help protect the demonstrators.

•March on Washington: About a quarter million people, both white and African American, participated in a large march to express their opposition of persecution and the discrimination of blacks. This march is where Martin Luther King delivered his "I Have a Dream" speech.

There was also a significant advancement in the civil rights of Mexican Americans in the 1960s with strong leaders such as César Chávez.

WOMEN's RIGHTS

Women's Rights also became a popular and widely supported demand in the 1960s, with women specifically wanting to be paid the same as men for the work that they did. The Equal Rights Amendment, which would have guaranteed equal rights for women, was passed by Congress although it was not approved by the state legislatures, thus denying its passage of becoming law. The National Organization for Women, known as NOW, also worked for promoting and supporting women's rights during this time period.
fields.title: Domestic Policy

fields.content:
THE VIETNAM WAR

Vietnam split into North and South Vietnam after World War II, with North Vietnam being under the control of the communist party and the Vietnamese leader Ngo Dinh Diem. The North began to attack the south, with its communist militants known as the Viet Cong. Because of the domino theory, which was the belief that once one nation fell to communism then many others would follow, the U.S. sent military support to Vietnam in hopes of establishing a democratic government there. After the start of the Vietnam War, although war was not officially declared, the nations had to substitute its economic focus on food and other consumer products for producing war goods, and this substitution became commonly known as the tradeoff of "guns or butter". Johnson also had to cut the social programs and pull back some of the aid that he was giving in his Great Society.

THE WAR POWERS RESOLUTION

Passed in 1973 by Congress while overriding a presidential veto in order for it to be put into effect, was Congress' way of putting the president in check with regard to his power of mobilizing the military in another country. It required the president to notify Congress within at leaf 48 hours before sending troops, and it also required their approval of mobilizing such a force. The Resolution was commonly ignored by most presidents.

THE GULF OF TONKIN RESOLUTION

Johnson's way around the War Power Resolution was by asking Congress to allow the passage of the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution which basically gave Johnson the authority to mobilize American troops in southeast Asia upon his command and without the approval of anybody else.

FURTHER WAR EVENTS

Johnson tried to force a quick surrender out of the Vietnamese communists by bombing North Vietnam, in Operation Rolling Thunder, although the North Vietnamese had a different plan in mind, for they intended to drag on the war and win by outlasting the Americans. The amount of troops started out relatively small, around 10,00 in 1963, although by 1969, the amount of U.S. troops in Vietnam had climbed up to over 500,00 men. With these large increases in the amount of men being sent to fight in Vietnam, the disapproval rate for the war rose with certain people back at home. People were also angered and against the war because of the way Johnson dealt with it and refused to tell Americans the truth about the war directly. Supporters of the war were known as hawks, while people who were against the war or participated in antiwar protests were known as doves. Due to the war and some of the decisions Johnson was forced to make, he eventually lost his Great Society that he worked had to get legislation passed for and also the presidency due to disapproval among Americans and the competition he faced in Eugene McCarthy and Robert McCarthy. There were some previous oaths that were broken by the United States throughout the course of the Vietnam War. Johnson stopped sending more American men to fight in Vietnam, he ended bombing on North Vietnam, and also withdrew from running in the 1968 presidential election.
fields.title: Foreign Policy

fields.content: Richard Nixon was the Republican candidate for the 1968 presidential election, while the democratic candidate was Hubert Humphrey.  There was also a third party candidate, George Wallace, which added great uncertainty to the predicted outcome of the election. Nixon won the election in a very close race.
fields.title: The Election of 1968

fields.content:
Nixon's National Security Advisor, Henry Kissinger, helped Nixon make his mark on foreign policy. Their foreign policy placed a greater significance of using the power of the United States in dealing with other countries, and they also wanted the U.S. to regain the position of power it had in the world after losing some of its influence in dealing with the Soviets and amid their actions

Vietnam

Nixon adopted the idea of Vietnamization, where the U.S. armed and trained the Vietnamese in order to for them to shift some of the military burden toward South Vietnam, so that the U.S. could start bringing some of its troops back home. The U.S. discussed peace with the North while troops were being drawn out by the U.S., when the U.S. bombed North Vietnam in order to seal the deal of negotiating peace. There was an agreement to end the fighting in 1973. By April of 1973, all U.S. troops had left Vietnam for home.

China

Nixon came to better relations with communist China by agreeing to interact and cooperate in a manner known as peaceful coexistence. Chinese-American trade was resumed, the U.S. pulled its troops out of Taiwan, and China agreed to recognize Taiwan as part of China.

The Soviet Union

After easing political tensions with their visit to the Chinese, Nixon and Kissinger used this to their advantage, for such action would force the Soviets to also ease tension with the U.S. in fear of falling behind China. This allowed the U.S. to come to better relations with the Soviets as well; this policy was known as d\xe9tente. The United States and the Soviets signed the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty (SALT I), which agreed to limit the amount of nuclear missiles that both the U.S. and the Soviets produced. The United States also cooperated with Russia with regard to trade and cooperating in research and development.
fields.title: Foreign Policy

fields.content:
New Federalism

Nixon tried to undo the great shifts of power that went in favor of the central government during Johnson's' administration, and instead he tried to limit big government and give more power back to the states. He did this by revenue sharing, which was basically a method that gave some of the tax money that normally went tot he federal government to the states

The Judiciary and Supreme Court

Earl Warren, the Chief Justice of the court who had led a period of judicial activism in the Supreme Court, was replaced by Warren Burger, according to Nixon's wishes, after Warren retired. Burger was a strict constructionist, which was a sharp contrast to the philosophy that led the Court in to the decisions under Warren.
fields.title: Domestic Policy

fields.content: In order to find out what the Democrats were up to, the Nixon Administration sent men to break in and plant bugs in the Democratic National Headquarters, which was located in the Watergate hotel. The men were caught, and while interrogating and finding out more on these "burglars", it seemed like some of the information lead back to the Nixon Administration and the Committee to Re-Elect the President (CREEP). Although there was no concrete evidence that undoubtedly proved that Nixon took part in or conducted the scandal, it seemed fairly certain that he was involved. As the case was pursued, it was also found out that Nixon had taped other meeting in the Oval Office, and there was a court hearing. Accusing Nixon of obstructing justice and abusing the power of the presidential office, Nixon was impeached by the House. Nixon admitted that he knew about the coverup, and resigned from office before he was able to be removed. The investigation of the Watergate Scandal led to the discovery of all sorts of Corruption that was taken place during Nixon's Administration. The whole occurrence caused a great amount of unrest and distrust among people toward the American government.'.
fields.title: The Watergate Scandal

fields.content: Gerald Ford occupied the office of presidency by replacing Spiro Agnew as vice president upon his resignation, and then replacing Nixon upon his resignation. His vice president was Nelson Rockefeller. Ford granted Nixon an unconditional pardon on the crimes and corruption that he may have been involved with. Ford's action spared trials although people criticized him for sympathizing for an unjust cause, and thus he lost popularity. Ford and Congress clashed over their ideas on how to battle the recession, for Ford thought the issues were rooted in foreign oil dependency and the low purchasing power of the dollar. Ford attempted to continue Nixon's approach on foreign policy, although lack of cooperation from Congress allowed more Asian countries to fall to communism.
fields.title: Gerald Ford's Presidency

fields.content: Jimmy Carter entered enter in 1977, and he used a strategy to appear as a Georgian farmer and a Washington outsider in order to help him with the election. With the countries that sold oil and that made up the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, OPEC, raising the prices of oil, the U.S. entered an energy crisis and caused a high rate of inflation. This crisis resulted in a recession with further inflation and unemployment. The nation tried to reduce its consumption of oil, although its efforts were not to any avail.
fields.title: Domestic Troubles

fields.content:
The Camp David Accords

Regarded as Carter's greatest success in foreign policy, the Camp David Accords were a peace agreement between ISrael and Egypt, which was brought on by Jimmy Carter

Iranian Hostage Crisis

The United States was in support of the Shah of Iran, and the two had become allies. The influence of the U.S. on the Shah made him more open westernizing Iran, which many Iranian nationalists thought was a dig race to the tradition of their country and culture. Once the U.S. took in the Shah to help give him medical aid amid his illness, these Iranian nationalists became furious, and in their rage, captured 63 Americans from the U.S. embassy in Iran and held them hostage, which became the event known as the Iranian hostage crisis. Negotiations on behalf of the U.S. were mainly unsuccessful, even military operations were attempted and failed, although the Iranians finally let the hostages go to an agreement shortly after Carter left office.

More Foreign Policy

Jimmy Carter also signed a second Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty, (SALT II), although it was not approved by Congress. Upon the Soviets invading Afghanistan, Carter punished the Soviets by boycotting the summer olympics in Moscow and cutting off grain shipments to Russia. Carter also finally officially recognized communist China, the People's Republic of China, and turned over the control of the area surrounding the Panama Canal to the native Panamanians.
fields.title: Foreign Policy

fields.content:
Reagan was a Republican who was elected to office in 1980 as an ex-actor and another Washington outsider who used this in his campaign like Carter. He was a true conservative and his presidency marked the first conservative presidency since the 1920s. Reagan was able to champion the average American worker and reduce the size of government due to the Republican control in Congress.

Reagan utilized the idea of supply side economics, where he combated the recession by lowering taxes that businesses would normally have to pay during the production of their products. his method worked, and his economic policy, also known as Reaganomics, caused unemployment to drop in the U.S and mark the recovery that was taking place in the economy. Reagan also lowered personal income taxes so that consumers so that consumers had more money to spend and stimulate the economy. He also implemented food stamps and supported Medicare.During the Reagan administration, business and industry became more deregulated in order to increase competition, lower the amount that businesses would have to spend by regulating their practices, which would lead to businesses being allowed to sell their goods for cheaper prices.Reagan was also a strong advocate of increasing military defense spending, although he normally tried to shrink government size and its spending in most other forms. He came up with an idea for a missile defense system that was popular because of its absurdity, and was called the Strategic Defense Initiative, or SDI, but more commonly referred to as "Star Wars" for the way the design included high tech-lasers and futuristic technology. Reagan attempted to cut spending on social programs, although Democrats refused to let that happen, so the budget defect actually increased due to the increase in defense spending while social spending wasn't reduced, even some programs, such as Medicare, grew.
fields.title: Domestic Policy

fields.content:
The Soviet Union

Reagan was determined to regain military power in the U.S. and deal with the Soviets in a very frank way, which would increase Cold War tension, while referring to the Soviet Union as an "evil empire". However, the United States and the Soviet Union signed the INF treaty, which removed and destroyed nuclear bombs of each nation, although a nuclear freeze was not reached.

Iran Contra Affair

At first, the U.S. provided aid to the Nicaraguan government, known as the Contras, who were over thrown by the communist rebus known as the Sandanistas. However, the Democrats passed a law that prohibited the Reagan administration from continuing to provide the Contras with aid in Nicaragua. In a secret scheme that was carefully kept from the public, the Reagan Administration continued to aid the Contras with the money they received from selling weapons to the Iranians who were fighting Iraq, and these deals were also kept a secret. The whole scheme, known as the Iran-Contra Affair, was discovered by the American public, and was viewed as a disgraceful scandal that left a bad mark on the Reagan administration.

Grenada

One of Reagan's successes in foreign policy was the way he dealt with the rise of communism in Grenada. A group of Pro-Cuban people from grenada were about to form a military base on the island, although Reagan sent the military to intervene and foil their plans before the communist military base was established.
fields.title: Foreign Policy

fields.content: Sadam Hussein had risen to power in Iraq, and he ordered the invasion of Kuwait, which was an exporter of oil to the U.S. Feeling that its source of oil was threatened, the U.S. responded by attacking the forces from Iraq in the Persian Gulf War and attempting to get them them out of Kuwait in an attack known as Desert Storm, where over half a million troops were sent from the U.S. and other countries form the United Nations. The force attack forced Iraq to surrender in just about 4 days, although Hussein remained in power, but the credit for brilliant foreign policy was given to Bush.
fields.title: Foreign Policy

fields.content: Social issues of the 1980s and 1990s included racial discrimination, affirmative action, and the amount of minorities that were occupying government offices, which was only on the rise at state levels rather than national levels at the time. Many Hispanics came into the U.S. within the 1980s and 1990s as well. The 1986 Immigration Reform Act made all illegal aliens citizens, and the 1990 Immigration Act loosened the amount of restrictions on people who had special employment skills.'.
fields.title: Domestic Policy
