fields.content: The members of Congress were elected in 1788 before the Constitution was ratified.
fields.title: Congress

fields.content: George Washington was unanimously elected president during the drafting of the Constitution
fields.title: The President

fields.content: The Supreme Court was established in 1789 when Congress passed the Judiciary Act of 1789.
fields.title: The Judiciary

fields.content:
After the war, the nation was in a bit of a financial crisis due to the debt that it agreed to pay back to Britain in the Treaty of Paris, and also because American industry was still in its early years. Alexander Hamilton proposed a plan to get the nation on solid financial footing. His plan had three main parts

•Establish a National Bank

•Pay off all debts at face value

•Set high protective tariffs
fields.title: Early Problems
American Involvements and Decisions Under Washington

fields.content: Washington declared the new nation of America to remain neutral in the French Revolution, even though it agreed to help out the French government in any future wars they had. Washington justified his decision with the French government by saying that because France was in the middle of a Revolution, it was no longer in the same state as it was when he made the agreement. One French diplomat broke the rules of formal diplomacy by personally convincing U.S. citizens in America to support the French government in the rebellion at his home country. Outraged by the gesture, Washington demanded that the French recall the diplomat to France, although the diplomat, Genet, refused and instead chose to live in America. Thus, the whole affair was referred to as "Citizen Genet".
fields.title: Neutrality

fields.content: George Washington sent John Jay to negotiate with Britain to form a treaty that would arrange the British to leave some forts that they had still occupied along the western frontier.
fields.title: Jay's Treaty

fields.content: Thomas Pinckney formed a treaty with Britain that allowed U.S. use of the Mississippi River's waterways for trade purposes.
fields.title: The Pinckney Treaty

fields.content: The constitution and the ability of the new nation to quell domestic uprisings under its authority came to the test when a group of Pennsylvanian farmers refused to pay the federal excise tax on whiskey. Determined to smash the uprising in order to set an example for other potential rebellion; George Washington sent Alexander Hamilton and an army of over 10,000 Americans militiamen to deal with the rebellious farmers, which immediately ended the conflict in a peaceful manner.
fields.title: the Whiskey Rebellion

fields.content: America defeated the native americans and gained new land for which to settle at the Battle of Fallen Timbers.
fields.title: Native Americans

fields.content: Washington's presidency may not have included multiple complex implementations of policy, although he established a precedent by which many presidents after him followed for many years. He set this precedent through his words and actions as well as in his Farewell Address. Washington also set the example of leaving office after his two four-year terms, which was not required at the time.
fields.title: Washington's Leadership and Legacy

fields.content:
•Stay neutral in European Affairs

•Avoid political parties

•Avoid national division and sectionalism
fields.title: The Main Concerns in Washington's Farewell Address

fields.content: Washington also was against political parties from the start as soon as they emerged within the Federalists and Anti-Federalists over the idea of ratifying the Constitution. Even after the document's ratification, the two political parties remained organized with similar views and ideas, although the Anti-Federalists evolved into a new political party: The democratic-republicans. They were led by Thomas Jefferson and James Madison, who had switched from his earlier reposition on being a supporter of a strong central government to becoming a champion of states rights like Jefferson. The Federalists mostly merchants and bankers, still supported a strong central government, and interpreted the Constitution loosely, while the Democratic-Republicans, mostly farmers, favored states rights and advocated a strict interpretation of the constitution, and were also more sympathetic to the French.
fields.title: The Formation of Political Parties

fields.content: After frustration with French warships seizing and attacking U.S. cargo ships, John Adams sent American diplomats to negotiate with the french. The American diplomats were met with three French Diplomats, nicknamed X, Y, and Z, who refused to deal with the American diplomats with the respect that they wished, and instead asked the Americans for bribes. The diplomats made the nation swell with pride by refusing bribery. The nation was on the brink of war with potential land to settle on the line, although Adams cut the conflict short in a peaceful manner. The whole incident was referred to as the XYZ affair.
fields.title: French Diplomacy

fields.content: Winning a majority in both the Senate and the House, the federalists planned to diminish their opponent party, the Democratic-Republicans, by passing policy known as the Alien and Sedition Acts. The policy made it necessary for immigrants to live in America for 14 years before being naturalized, for immigrants tended to support the Democratic Republicans, as well as making it illegal for the media to criticize the government. It also made it legal for the government to deport any suspicious foreign aliens with the potential of being spies.
fields.title: The Federalists Dominate

fields.content: James Madison and Thomas Jefferson thought that the Alien and Sedition Acts violated the Bill of Rights and the Constitution, so in the Virginia and Kentucky Resolutions of 1799, they declared that the states could nullify the law. The Resolutions did not directly repeal the Sedition Acts, but they rather instead due to a loss of a Federalist majority in Congress as well as John Marshall's later establishment of Judicial Review.
fields.title: The Democratic-Republicans Respond

fields.content: By the election of 1800, John Adams had lost popularity because of the Alien and Sedition Acts as well as imposing high taxes. The two main candidates in the elections were the two democratic republicans, Aaron Burr and Thomas Jefferson, who tied after the first election of the presidential electors. According to the Constitution, the election was to be decided by going to the House where each state would be given one vote. The House election decided Jefferson as the winner. With John Adams and the defeat of the Federalists, there was the first example of a peaceful transition of power between two political parties. This transition of power is known as the revolution of 1800.
fields.title: John Adams Leaving of Office

fields.content: Mercantilism in the mid 1700s spurred an increase in competition between European nations, although England had troubling regulating the colonial coast and discovering smuggling activity under the Navigation Acts. This lead to a period of Salutary Neglect, where the mother country left the colonies alone and didn't interfere with their activity until 1764.
fields.title: Salutary Neglect and Mercantilism
The French and Indian War and the Aftermath

fields.content: The British were being defeated in the early stages of the war, although eventually they won and signed the Treaty of Paris in 1763. In the aftermath of the war, hostility was developed between the colonists and Britain because they believed that their war efforts were under appreciated, and they were proud of their personal attempts to defend the colonies. They were not impressed with the British militia and thought that their battle tactics were poorly suited for fighting in the woodland of the Americas. The Seven Years War gave the colonies a newfound confidence in their abilities to defend themselves in a period of war.
fields.title: British Success

fields.content: The series of four wars took a toll on Britain and required a large sum of revenue to pay for the vast costs of war. This tax pressure was at first laid on the wealthy British, although it was shifted to the shoulders of the Colonists after the war. The British recognized the importance of defending their American frontier, and responded by sending large amounts of troops to the colonies. British favor of making the colonists pay more for the cost of the British Empire as well as the increase in British troops in the colonies marked the end of Salutary neglect and the beginning of colonial and British tension.
fields.title: British Action After the War

fields.content: In response to the encroachment of settlers in Native American lands and frustration with poor treatment, native Americans under the leadership of Chief Pontiac attacked and destroyed English settlement on the American frontier. The English relied on British rather than colonial troops to handle the rebellion. The rebellion ended with the English putting the Proclamation of 1763 into effect, which didn't allow colonists to settle west of the Appalachian Mountains . The legislation had the intention of protecting the colonies, although it was met with colonial protest on the basis that their liberty and representation in British government was being violated.
fields.title: Pontiac's War

fields.content: Placed an import tax on glass, tea, and paper and was enacted in 1767. This tax placed the burden indirectly on the colonists because the merchants had to directly pay the tax while it influenced the prices of the goods that the colonists payed for. John Dickinson wrote "Letters from a Pennsylvania Farmer" in an effort to unite the colonies in their protest of British taxation without representation that was evident in the Townshend Acts. The Townshend Acts were repealed in 1770 due to a decrease in revenue because of colonial boycotts and protest on the basis of taxation without representation that was initiated by John Dickinson. However, Parliament left the tax on tea to remain as a way of insisting on their right to tax the colonies.
fields.title: Townshend Acts

fields.content: Mandated that colonists allowed British troops in their homes and provided adequate hospitality.
fields.title: Quartering Act

fields.content: Placed a tax on molasses and other luxuries. It differed from other duties because it directly raised revenue for the crown.
fields.title: Sugar Act (Revenue Act of 1764)

fields.content: A tax enacted in 1765 that required colonists to buy a specific stamp that had to be placed on almost all kinds of official legal documents. It was faced with severe protest from the colonists because it was the first direct tax on the colonists rather than the indirect duties that merchants that imported British goods had to pay. Patrick Henry raised the popular cry of "taxation without representation" to unite colonists in protest of the Stamp Act. The colonial gang that was devoted to defying British control over the colonists in an unfair manner, known as the Sons of Liberty, attacked merchants willing to pay the Stamp tax as well as tax collectors.
fields.title: Stamp Act

fields.content: Upon Parliament's repeal of the Stamp Act in 1766, Parliament also put the Declaratory Act into effect which stated theat the crown had the ability to levy taxes on the colonies in all cases whatsoever. The Act replaced the brief rejoicing in the colonies with renewed protest and conflict between Britain and the colonies.
fields.title: Declaratory Act

fields.content: In 1773, Parliament made the price of the British East India Company's tea cheaper than that of other nations' tea, even with tax remaining from the Townshend Acts included. This Act led to the Boston Tea Party.
fields.title: Tea Act
Further Causes of Colonial-British Conflict and Tension

fields.content: British soldiers stationed in the Boston to defend British officials from the colonial gang "The Sons of Liberty" were harassed by a group of colonists in 1770. The soldiers shot at the mob, killing five colonists. John Adams defended the soldiers and court and led to them being acquitted.
fields.title: The Boston Massacre

fields.content: The Tea Act led to colonists further boycotting British tea, regardless of the price because buying it would recognize the crown's ability to tax the colonies without their representation in levying such a tax. A ship full of British tea arrived in Boston Harbor in 1773, and at night a group of colonists dressed up as native americans dumped all the tea into the harbor to express their defiance of British taxes on the colonies.
fields.title: The Boston Tea Party

fields.content: The colonial expression of defiance present from the Boston tea party angered the king and brought on a series of punishing acts in 1774 known as the coercive acts, or intolerable acts.. These acts prohibited trade activity in the harbor until the damage of the tea was payed for, as well as an increase in British power in colonial government and extensions to the Quartering act.
fields.title: The Coercive Acts

fields.content: The Quebec Act of 1774 was also passed to punish the colonies for the Boston Tea Party along with the Coercive Acts, which mandated that the extended province of Quebec would be directly controlled by Britain. The Act angered colonists because it negated new colonial claims to the land in the province and it also allowed the practice of Roman Catholicism.'.
fields.title: The Quebec Act

fields.content: In the early 19th century, the more relaxed and less serious view of religion that was common during the Enlightenment period was removed by Calvinist religious revivals in a movement known as The Second Great Awakening, renewed Americans' concern for religion. Religious leaders such as Charles G Finney preached sermons that gave hope to Americans, promising them salvation and quelling their fears of damnation by saying they would be saved if they continued to work hard and have strong faith. The area in New York that commonly held sermons was known as the Burnt Over District. Peter Cartwright preached Baptist and Methodist views in the south where he attracted thousands of people to hear his lectures on religion.
fields.title: The Second Great Awakening

fields.content: The idea of transcendentalism became common in the early 1800s. Transcendentalism was a lifestyle and way of thinking that placed a small amount of importance on organized religion and conformity, it instead placed superiority on individualism and being at peace with the world and one's self. Ralph Waldo Emerson was a transcendentalist leader who gave seminars that attracted many people, and he was an opponent of slavery. Henry Thoreau was another well-known transcendentalist who lived by Walden's teachings. he lived in the woods for an experiment, where he reflected on life and attempted to discover truths about the world. Thoreau was an advocate of peaceful protest and only obeying society and laws that agreed with his own morals.
fields.title: Philosophy and Transcendentalism
Social and Cultural Movements and Reform

fields.content: Brook Farm was a social experiment that attracted many philosophers and idealists. The experiment led a lot of free creativity and artistic thinking, however it was all ended due to a high amount of debt and a bad fire that made the Brook Farm project impossible to continue.
fields.title: Brook Farm

fields.content: Other social utopias and experiment were established by the religious Shakers, as well as in the one Community in New York were all property and people were shared and equal. The Four Phalanxes was another similar project that arranged for people to live together in similar quarters in a community as a way to beat out the fierce competition of society. Robert Owen also formed the secular experiment known as New Harmony which tried close the class and financial gap between people although a financial crisis ended the project.
fields.title: Other Communities and Social Projects

fields.content: The painter William Mount and Frederick Church captured the scenic American landscapes in their paintings. Greek architecture also gave a large influence to new buildings that were being built in the early 1800s. Famous novels during the time were the Scarlet Letter by Nathaniel Hawthorne, The Last of the Mohicans by Jane Fenimore Cooper as well as Moby Dick by Herman Melville.
fields.title: Changes in Art and Literature

fields.content: Temperance, or the refrain from using alcohol, become a widely respected movement in the 1840s. The Temperance movement made it clear that refraining from alcohol consumption was overall good for society with more effective work on the job, and less crime. Taxes on alcoholic substances were early actions made by states to side with reformers, although as the movement continued and its success became more clear, Maine became the first state to ban the sale of alcohol in 1851.
fields.title: Abstaining From Alcohol

fields.content: There was a large amount of reform in hospitals, prisons, and schools for the needy in the early 1800s and mid-1800s in an attempt to fix the poor conditions that were evident beforehand. Dorthea Dix was a leading figure in the movement for reforming mental hospitals where conditions for mentally ill people were initially poor and unsanitary. She convinced states to build new mental hospitals that were more constructive and that had more of a positive environment. Samuel Gridley Howe also contributed to the lives of the physically disabled by founding a school for blind people. Pennsylvania formed new prisons in the state that experimented with locking up convicts in a cell alone to give them space to reflect on their life and actions, although it proved to be a failure because of the high amount of suicides that the confinement caused.
fields.title: Reform in Prisons and Mental Institutions

fields.content: One of the largest leaders for public school reform was Horace Mann who worked to improve school conditions by making attendance mandatory, making the school year longer, and by increasing advocating an increase in the skill of teachers. Tax-supported schools became common among states. Horace Mann and other teacher made textbooks the main resource for education as well a guide for the way to act and the formation for one's work ethic in order to obtain success in one's career. The Second Great Awakening also encouraged the establishment of new colleges.
fields.title: A Brighter Future for Public Education

fields.content: After the industrial revolution, the typical American family was being redefined and so were the roles of men and women. As the years rolled on toward the mid 1800s, the average size of an American family decreased to about five or six members. Most women that were wives in middle class families tended to take care of the home while the husband went to work. The Cult of Domesticity, which many such women abided, basically stated the idea that women and men were leaders in their own spheres, were the woman's sphere was at the home and man's sphere was at work or in other worldly matters.
fields.title: Differences in the Family and Genders

fields.content: The Grimke sisters were leaders in the women's movement and were advocates for the complete equality between men and women.Lucretia Mott and Elizabeth Candy Stanton also started campaigning for women's rights reform. The leaders of the women's rights movement held a convention known as the Seneca Falls Convention in 1848 where they discussed the necessity of equality between genders and the discrimination that currently existed.
fields.title: the Advancement Toward Women's Rights

fields.content: Especially after the Antislavery movement, people began to more openly express their opposition to slavery. William Lloyd Garrison, a radical abolitionist, demanded the immediate freedom of all slaves, and even held contempt for the Constitution in the way that it was a "pro-slavery" document. He started an abolitionist newspaper that was known as The Liberator. Garrison's extreme wishes and beliefs caused the abolitionist movement to split, with one section forming a political party known as the liberty party, who ran James Birney as their candidate in 1840. Escaped and free blacks were also outspoken abolitionists, such as Frederick Douglass. Other blacks that opposed slavery included Harriet Tubman and Sojourner Truth, and they helped slaves reach freedom through a system known as the underground railroad. In the south, a slave named Nat Turner led a violent revolt among slaves where over 50 whites were killed, and in punishment the revolt was crushed and many blacks were killed. The violent incident put and end to antislavery murmurs that were taking place in the south earlier.
fields.title: Abolitionism and Antislavery

fields.content: Since so many stocks were bought on margin, the stocks were way overvalued, and some insiders that knew this began to sell, and eventually everybody began selling which caused the ultimate crash which occurred on a date known as Black Tuesday. After the crash, many people who had money invested in stocks lost a lot of money, their jobs, and homes. Since people could not pay back their loans to banks, banks were forced to foreclose and go under.
fields.title: The Stock Market Crash of 1929

fields.content: The Home Loan Bank Act and Reconstruction Finance Corporation were passed in order to help businesses regain footing. Hoover thought the depression would be short, although he did not believe that it was the responsibility or that it was the best idea for the government to directly help the unemployed and Americans through and the depression, but rather that it was the role of the community to help each other and rise up as one. He believed that this attitude would eventually get America out of the depression. Hoover did order the Farm Board to help out farmers and keep the prices of their crops up by buying their surpluses, however the surpluses kept adding up so the board eventually stopped buying their crop surpluses.
fields.title: Hoover's Method on Dealing With the Depression

fields.content: The bonus army was a group of about 20,00 military veterans who demanded their compensation bonuses that were initially scheduled to be payed to them later marched on Washington D.C. The marchers set up a shanty camp, known as a "Hooverville" by D.C., and after the bill was rejected by Congress many of the veterans left, while some other stayed until they were violently and aggressively dispatched by the military force that Hoover ordered.
fields.title: The Bonus Army

fields.content: In one of the most intense times of the Great Depression, the disapproval for the Republican Hoover ran high, which allowed Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the democratic candidate, to win the election.
fields.title: The 1932 Election

fields.content:
Roosevelt promised three parts of change that would ultimately lead to the improvement of economic conditions which were simplified down to relief, recovery, and reform. After taking office in 1933, the following hundred days were a period that entailed Congress passing every single law or policy that Roosevelt wished to put into effect, giving that time period the name "The One-Hundred Days".

•Fireside Chats: Roosevelt spoke directly to the American people in a series of these talks to advise and help them through the depression by letting them know what must be done.

•Bank Holiday: Roosevelt closed the banks on March 6 to allow a day for them to be reorganized

Financial Recovery Programs

•Home Owners Loan Corporation: This corporation helped fund home mortgages.

•The Farm Credit Administration: Provided loans to prevent foreclosures of land that was owned by farmers that were in a lot of debt. The loans also had a rather low interest rate in order to further help the farmers.

•Emergency Banking Relief Act: Banks were inspected to ensure stability and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was established to buy the stocks of banks when they are in trouble.

•Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation: Established by the Glass-Steagall Banking Act to insure bank deposits.

Unemployment Relief Programs

•Public Works Administration (PWA): Provided money for construction

•Federal Emergency Relief Administration: The Federal Emergency Relief Administration (FERA) was established in order to work on construction projects for the public such as parks, bridges, roads, and schools.

•Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC): Hired young men to work on federal projects and lands and compensated them by giving money to their families.

•The Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA): It hired poor people in the Tennessee Valley area to build dams, manufacture fertilizer, and control flooding and erosion.

Regulation of Agricultural Output

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration (AAA) payed farmers subsidies to reduce the amount of land they plowed to encourage growing less crops and raise prices.

FUrther Recovery in the Industry and economy

•NRA: The National Recovery Administration helped businesses become profitable again by setting up a plan that would outline the functions of the businesses such as the amount of labor, labor hours, and level of production.

•CWA: The Civil Works Administration also hired people to work on temporary construction projects.

•SEC: The Securities Exchange Commission was made to keep watch over the stock market in order to ensure that certain occurrences that led to the stock market crash did not happen again.

•FHA: Gave bank loans to people who would buy new houses as well as renovate or fix old houses.

•WPA: The WPA, or Works Progress Administration, also spent a lot of money in order to help people get jobs. These people also worked on construction projects as a source of work.

•RA: The Resettlement Administration gave loans to farmer and helped migrant workers find an adequate place to live.

•Wagner Act: The Wagner Act, also known as the National Labor Relations Act, supported workers and unions by backing their rights to collective bargaining and also banned certain acts of business that were not fair to the workers.

•REA: The Rural Electrification Administration (REA) would give loans to electrical companies to extend their services and power to rural areas.

The Second New Deal

Roosevelt enacted a program known as the Second New Deal in 1935 which targeted the aid of a more specific group, such as farmers, workers of factories, as well as blacks.

Critics of FDR and the New Deal

•Father Charles E. Coughlin: Believed that Roosevelt was not strong enough of an advocate of an equal distribution of wealth.

•Huey Long: A senator from Louisiana who was a champion of the poor and was well known for the way that he opposed FDR.

•Dr. Francis Townshend: A champion of the elderly who wanted there to be a pension for older people.

•American Liberty League: A group formed by Roosevelt's critics, primarily the ones that were advocates of business, that tried working against New Deal policies that they believed would lead the nation to socialism and a less desirable state.
fields.title: Roosevelt's Plan and the New Deal

fields.content: The Committee of Industrial Organization (CIO) : A union group that was created upon the disagreement of leadership in the AFL because of the prospect of admitting industrial workers to the union that primarily allowed skilled workers. John Lewis founded the CIO and the group included non-skilled workers and blacks. They were known for these protesting tactics of sit-down strikes.
fields.title: Unions and Labor

fields.content: Although Congress was usually on FDR's side when it came to passing New Deal legislation, the Supreme Court tended to more of an opponent of such legislation and would sometimes declare them unconstitutional. This greatly frustrated FDR, so in a scheme known as The Court Packing Plan, he asked Congress to increase the number of justices on the Supreme Court by six members while carefully making sure that these justices would support New Deal legislation. This would give New Deal supporters a majority in the Supreme Court, which would in turn give FDR control of all three branches of government. The idea of adding justices was rejected by Congress, although the situation ceased to be a problem to Roosevelt as the old justices that had opposed his New Deal programs retired.
fields.title: Clashes With the Judiciary

fields.content: There was another recession in 1938 that almost undid all of the economic progress that had taken place since the stock market crash. A new spending program was adopted by FDR in 1938 which ended the recession. FDR had a harder time passing legislation once Congress was controlled by the conservatives in 1938.
fields.title: Additional Economic Downturns

fields.content:
The Wheeler-Howard Indian Reorganization Act ended the division of indian reservations in order to give away land to individuals. It also increased the amount of rights that indians on their reservations.

'.
fields.title: Native Americans
The Nation After World War Ii and in the Beginning of the Cold War

fields.content:
Demobilization

Coming back from the war, the industry and factories had to convert back to being able to produce consumer goods instead of war goods. The soldiers coming back from the war did replace women who were working in the industry to an extent, although women had been considerably more involved in working in the industry ever since World War II.

Unions and Labor

The United Mine Workers and the railway workers threatened a strike due to their demand for higher wages. Truman responded by seizing both the mines and the railway although at the end of the matter, the unions got most of what they wanted.

Truman also show his lack of sympathy for unions and labor when he vetoed the Taft-Hartley Act, which was a policy that would put a lot more restrictions and limitations on unions regarding their power and frequency of action or striking. the Act also gave more power to the employers rather than the employees or laborers.

Civil Rights

Truman proposed for Congress to:

•Establish the Fair Employment Practices Commission (FEPC)

•Create a vivil rights commission that would be permanent

•End segregation in public accommodations and schools.

•Outlaw lynching

--His requests were rejected by a conservative Congress--
fields.title: Domestic Policy

fields.content:
Truman and Communism

Truman thought that they best way to deal with the Soviets and communism was by just leaving it alone to deal with its own problems, while ensuring that it didn't expand, for the hope was that it would eventually fail due to the lack of a proper and effective system. This idea was known as containment.

The Truman Doctrine

The Truman Doctrine was Truman's decision to provide a large amount of aid to Greece and Turkey in order to prevent it from falling to the communists, since Britain was no longer able to provide aid there itself. The doctrine was successful in preventing these nations from almost surely falling into the hands of communism.

The Marshall Plan

A plan that was more radical and had plenty of opposition, for it would entail the additional involvement of the U.S. in Europe in order to subside the existence and growth of communism. The plan was approved by Congress.

The Berlin Crisis and the Airlift

Western Germany was experiencing a change for the better since after the war under control of the U.S., Britain, and France. In a situation known as the Berlin Crisis, the Soviets blocked the path to Western Germany in order to force the Western Powers to come to some of compromise to appease them, although the we tern powers refused and instead continued to support and ship goods to western Germany by the use of an airlift. The more had frustrated and outmaneuvered the Soviets while evading war, which frustrated the Soviets. Recognizing their defeat, the Soviets stopped blocking the path to Western Germany in 1949.

Revolution in China

After a civil war in China, the communist party known as the People's Republic of China took over China and was led by Mao Zedong. The U.S. refused to continue foreign and diplomatic relations with the communists and instead supported the Chinese nationalists that were defeated and that had fled to Taiwan.

Korea

After the war, Korea was divided into the North and South, with the North being overseen by the Soviets and the Soviets being overseen by the U.S. until the nations had gained footing and structure in their government. The North Koreans then invaded South Korean territory, upon which action the U.N. sent troops to support South Korea with the vast majority of these troops being U.S. troops led by General Douglas MacArthur. Douglas MacArthur was finally able to push the north Korean communist forces north pas the 38th parallel, and then finally, against the wishes of Truman, continued his offense and attacked China. MacArthur was removed from command and also lost support from Congress. Peace negotiations had made no progress once Truman left office and was replaced by Eisenhower, but once Stalin died the fighting ended with an armed truce between North and South Korea.
fields.title: Foreign Policy

fields.content: The Republican Dwight D. Eisenhower won the election and took office in 1952.
fields.title: The Election of 1952

fields.content:
The McCarthy Hearings

In the midst of the red scare and the nation's fear of communism, McCarthy took advantage of the situation to gain popularity by claiming that he could identify communist spies in the American government, although he rarely had much solid evidence. McCarthy continued to gain popularity as he accused more Americans, politicians, and officials, although he got carried away and finally became disapproved by the nation went he attempted to accuse a well respected American General for sympathizing with the communists. Support for McCarthy and his wild accusations, known as McCarthyism, ended after the hearings of the general and practically going up against the military.

Civil Rights

Eisenhower made attempts at furthering the progress of civil rights by proposing the desegregation of military schools, which was at first rejected then accepted with the help of Senator Lyndon B. Johnson in Congress. The Civil Rights Act of 1957 was also passed, as well as the Civil Rights Act of 1960 which was made to help protect the voting rights of African Americans, although both of the laws did not amount to much progress or change in the civil rights situation.

The Board v. Board of Education decision in the Supreme declared that separate was inherently unequal, and thus undoing the decision was established by the Supreme Court in the past in the Plessy v. Ferguson case.

Change in American Society and Life

The expansion and further development of the highway system in the U.S. as well as the creation of the suburban housing area known as Levittown were the causes of a great amount of growth in the suburbs of America in the 1950s. There was also success in the economy with a higher amount of research, development, and productivity. Such productivity improvement that came about because of technological advances came at the expense of workers and the amount of jobs available in the economy.
fields.title: Domestic Policy, Events, and Advancements

fields.content:
Handling the Cold War

The concept of massive retaliation was put into effect by Eisenhower's sceretary of state, who supported the idea of threatening the Soviets with an incredibly large force in order to respond to literally any form of Soviet agression, no matter how small. His tactic was a sharp contrast to the previous idea of containment and was a lot more bold and aggressive in its way of keeping the soviets and communism in check. During Eisenhower's presidency, the military buildup along with the supply of nuclear weapons significantly increased.

The Middle East

The Eisenhower Doctrine assured that the United States would become personally involved and would intervene in the affairs of the Middle East, with military force if necessary,if the Soviets were to attempt spreading the influence of communism there.
fields.title: Foreign Policy

fields.content: Fidel Castro came to power in Cuba in 1959. His rise in power began the hostility of Cuba toward the U.S., negogiations and agreements with the communists and soviets, as well as the national ownership of business in Cuba, giving Castro and the government a large amount of control over the nation, in contrary to the democratic changes that the U.S. had hoped for the nation.
fields.title: Cuba

fields.content: Tensions between the U.S. and the Soviets peaked once again when Khrushchev proposed an idea for a change in the situation of Berlin, Germany, although the United States refused to compromise. War was the expected outcome of the matter, which was known as the second Berlin Crisis, although once the deadline for the offer passed, both nations continued to go about their business despite high hostility and tension without going to war.
fields.title: More on the Cold War

fields.content: Hawaii requested annexation from a separate government that American planters established in their defiance to the control of the Hawaiian Queen, Liliuokawani.
fields.title: Hawaii

fields.content:
Citizens who were strong advocates of the nation aggressively expanding its power and settlement abroad wanted the nation to obtain Cuba from Spain, with by means of violence if necessary. Cuban nationalists had already initiated a revolt of their own by destroying Spanish plantation in Cuba, and yellow journalists in the United States did every thing to make headlines as dramatic as possible in an attempt to rally and unite the nation in a war effort in order to expand and support the movement of imperialism.

Motivation to Begin War

The De Lome Letter was another factor that spurred people to support the war effort, which involved the U.S. intercepting a Spanish letter that was highly critical of the American president and the government. It created a large amount of hype among the indignant Americans. The incident that practically sealed the deal of America going to war with Spain was an incident referred to as "Remember the Maine". The event entailed an American ship called the Maine that was docked in a Cuba harbor, when it spontaneously exploded killing almost three hundred Americans that were on the ship. The causes of the explosion were unknown, although patriotic and imperialism-supporting Americans didn't hesitate to blame the Spanish and have the rest of the nation join them in their cries of rage and war against Spain.

The U.S. Becomes Involved In Cuba

McKinley decided to intervene in Cuba, but only for the good of the Cubans so they could establish their own government, which he explained in a document known as the Teller Amendment which was sent to Spain. Upon the declaration of war, the assistant secretary of the navy, Theodore Roosevelt, ordered the naval commodore Dewey to seize the lands of the Philippines that were under Spanish rule at the time. The Americans then captured Manila later in the year of 1898. Americans and Cubans fought in Cuba, with many troops dying of disease. A memorable moment in the war was when the rough riders under Theodore Roosevelt were victorious on San Juan Hill. U.S. battleships practically destroyed the Spanish naval fleet in July at Santiago Bay which practically was the cause of the United States winning the war and forcing Spain to come to them with wishes for peace which was established in the Treaty of Paris.

Cuba After the War

After the U.S. victory in Cuba, it passed the Platt Amendment which prohibited foreign intervention from any other nation in cuba, and it also established America's ability to restore order and control in Cuba. In 1934, Cuba became its own nation, repealing the amendment to the nation's constitution.
fields.title: The Spanish-American War

fields.content:
Trade Interests

John Hay implemented the Open Door Policy that ensured that the United States would pursue its interest in China among the other foreign countries that had interest in trade with China.

The Boxer Rebellion

A group of Chinese Nationalists who were against foreign influence gave rise to a rebellion and attacks on foreign settlers. The U.S. sent troops in order to ensure the protection of its people and its property that was in China.
fields.title: China

fields.content: The "Big stick policy" was a term used to describe Theodore Roosevelt's foreign policy because of its aggressiveness. Roosevelt became president in 1901 after the death of President McKinley, for Roosevelt was vice president at the time.
fields.title: Big Stick Policy

fields.content: Roosevelt helped the people of Panama in their revolution in return for an amount of land that would be used to build the Panama canal, which would allow for the passage of boats through Panama, eliminating the necessity of traveling all around the Continent of South America.
fields.title: The Panama Canal

fields.content: Roosevelt's Roosevelt Corollary made the U.S. responsible for policing South American countries and ensuring that other nations didn't use violence to collect their debts from them, while taking a certain amount of control of the South American country in order to ensure its ability to restore itself so it would be able to pay off such debts. Since it declared that the U.S. would have total authority and would readily use force in a certain territory, the Roosevelt Corollary was often compared with the Monroe Doctrine.
fields.title: The Roosevelt Corollary

fields.content: Under the Taft Administration, Taft being Roosevelt's successor, the United States pursued a foreign policy in Latin America and China known as "Dollar Diplomacy". The policy basically included the U.S. having more influence and investment in China at the expense of blocking out Japan and European countries from doing so.
fields.title: Dollar Diplomacy

fields.content: Under the Wilson Administration, Wilson being Taft's successor, the United States acted more in favor of what was morally right than what was in the best interest of American businesses. The policy was put to the test during the Mexican revolution, while American businesses supporting the current government under the dictator Huerta. Wilson refused to support Huerta because of his brutality, so when the Mexicans failed to overthrow Huerta, Wilson tried to aid by sending in U.S. troops. The act ended in the failure, and ended with the Mexican people rioting.
fields.title: Moral Diplomacy

fields.content: The industrial revolution was made possible in the late 1800s due to the abundance of natural resources, the large amount of transportation that was made possible through waterways and railroads, the large amount of labor, and new technology in engines.
fields.title: The Industrial Revolution

fields.content: Another trait of the industrial revolution was the progress in the construction of railroads, where almost all of the railroads in the south were consolidated into the Pennsylvania railroad which bought out almost all of its competitors. All railroads were standardized and compatible which allowed for further expansion of railroad tracks.
fields.title: Railroads

fields.content: The demand for natural resources and energy ran high, with coal frequently being an answer.
fields.title: Energy

fields.content: The idea of "social darwinism" became popular during the period, which applied principles of survival of the fittest that was commonly associated with nature to the world of business and industry. The idea that only the most competitive and intense businesses would be able to grow and succeed in the world defined the mentalities of companies at the time. The principle of social Darwinism also advocated a laissez-faire atmosphere among businesses, since leaving businesses to their intense and sometimes ruthless competition would lead to collateral improvements in methods and efficiency as each company is trying to outdo the other. This could only prove effective if the government did not interfere and try to play the role of a regulator or equalizer.
fields.title: Competition in Business

fields.content: Andrew Carnegie was a very successful and powerful businessman who practically controlled the steel industry. He utilized the concept of vertical integration, where a company would control all the processes of manufacturing including the early stages of production of structures such as railroads. The idea would include the railroad company also taking control of the process for gathering the raw materials and making the steel; so in effect it would be able to completely control the industry. Andrew Carnegie rose from humble beginnings, being a poor Scottish immigrant before he became a powerful businessman. He believed in fierce competition among businesses and social darwinism, however in "The Gospel of Wealth" he also proclaimed that it was a successful man's duty to give back to society in the form of philanthropy, which he held to by the way he gave millions of dollars to build public structures for the good of society.
fields.title: Andrew Carnegie

fields.content:
The Knights of Labor

Formed in 1869 by Terrence Powderly, it was a labor union that was at first secret then later went public. It extended membership to virtually all workers, regardless of gender, race, or skill, for it would take in both skilled and unskilled workers. THe union usually resorted to negotiations rather than the other commonly used tactic among other unions, striking, in order to obtain reform and improve conditions in the workplace. The union was destroyed by the Haymarket Riots in 1886 where there was a very large peaceful collaboration of Knights who were striking for a standard 8-hour work day, when a bomb was thrown by an anarchists, killing Knights and police officers.

The American Federation of Labor

Founded by Samuel Gompers in 1886, the AFL pursued higher wages and better conditions for its workers. The AFL only extended membership to skilled workers and became the United States' biggest Union by the very first years of the 1900s.

Strikes

The Homestead Strike

Upon the decision of one of Carnegie's managers in the steel industry to cut wages for workers, a strike was initiated. Guards were involved with the matter to break up the strike, they were attacked, and then the strike was broken. The Homestead Strike marked the end of union influence in the steel industry for quite some time.

Pullman Strike

The Pullman Strike of 1894 was initiated once George Pullman, who was in charge of a railroad sleeping car manufacturing company, cut wages for workers. He fired all unions workers that attempted to bargain with him. The strike stopped up railway transportation throughout the whole country. The strike also proved to be violent at times, with multiple workers being killed. Federals courts implemented an injunction that made it forbidden for the operations of the mail cars to be interfered with, which union leaders violated, which caused them to be jailed and also caused the Pullman Strike to come to an end.
fields.title: Labor and Conditions

fields.content: Monroe's presidency marked the time known as the era of good feelings. During this time, the nation was growing and the political atmosphere was relatively friendly due to the nearly complete disappearance of the Federalist party.
fields.title: Era of Good Feelings

fields.content: The ability of ht eUnited States to contend with a major such as Britain in the war of 1812 as well the nations settlement expansion and industrial growth established a sense of unity and pride in Americans under the presidency of Monroe. The era was dominated by a strong feeling of Patriotism.
fields.title: Nationalism

fields.content: Tarriff of 1816A protective tarriff that would promote American manufacturing with most New England States in favor of the tarriff along with the south mostly in favor. John C Calhoun and Thomas Jefferson favored the tarriff, while Daniel Webster opposed the tariff.the american systemHenry Clay's American system included a three part plan to advance America's economic ProsperityNational BankProtective Tariffsinternational improvementsmore john marshallJohn marshall ruled on several more cases after Marbury Madison, where he established the judicial branch's power to enact judicial review under Thomas Jefferson, however in Monroe and Madison's Presidency he also ruled on cases in a way that granted more power to the central government.panic of 1819Due to the failure of the Second Bank of the United States to control inflation, many banks closed, money became less valuable, and the nation was in poor economic standing altogether in an economic crissi known as the Panic of 1819. Large amounts of western farmland were foreclosed, and westerners began opposing the national bank.Missouri Compromise and Henry Clay and tallmadge amendmentThere was initially a balance betwen slave and non slave states in the Union, when suddenly missouri from the louisiana purcahsed applied for statehood. There was slavery in the territory, so northerners were afraid to led Missouri enter the union as a aslave state and tip the sectionalism balacen. To help quell the issue, Henry Clay proposed a compromise known and the Missouri compromise which had a three part planMissouri would enter the union as a slave stateMaine would be admitted as a free stateAll new states north of the latitudinal line 36' 30'' would have slavery prohibited.General progress under madison and monroeAfter the war of 1812, westward settlement had increased rapidly. Native Americans were being cleared from their lands, farmers and plantations needed more space and land, immigrants increased the size of the American population, and roads and canals allowed for easier movement westward.rush bagot agreement of 1817Britain and America establihed an agreement to limit military fortifications along the American-Canadian border, marking the beginning of the the largest unfortified border history in the world.Adams Onis TreatyLatin American TradeRussian Claims of AlaksaMonroe DoctrineFeeling threatened by renewed interests that European nations had in colonizing in America, Monroe's powerful words in the Monroe doctrine made it clear that any attempt to colonize or settle in the Western HEmisphere by any European nation would result in aggression by the United States. Britain initially wanted to support America in its attempt to dissuade other European nations from actively settling and increasing trade in the Western Hemisphere because it believed it had a common interest, but in the end Monroe's words made it clear that the doctrine applied to Britain as well and the U.S. stood alone and certain in the matter.Fall of the FederalistsIt fell after its crushing defeat in 1816 and did not elect a presidential candidate in 1820Election of 1824/ corrupt bargaintransportationThe construction of interstate roads,and canals, specifically the Erie canal, stimulated trade and westward settlement. The Erie canal was built in new York and its success spurred the building of new canals that connected the east and west, helping the economy and also helped with settlement. Railroads also became a more safe, prevalent, and reliable source of transportation as well as a method to carry cargo.industrial revolutionIn the early 1800s, America became a world leader in manufacturing and the field soon surpassed agriculture in value in America. The growth was attributed to numerous mechanical and technological advances tht came about, marking the era known as the industrial revolution.Samuel Slater invented and expanded cotton mill factories in the U.S., making New England a leader in manufacturing.Eli Whitney invented the cotton gin, making harvesting cotton more efficient, and he also developed a method to make rifles out of interchangeable parts which allowed for more efficient production in a process known as mass prodcution. Robert Fulton created the first steam engine, making boat travel more efficient.labor conditionsThe Lowell system started a movement of attracting laborers by housing them in dormitories while they work as a way of convincing to work in a factory rather than try their luck with settling in cheap land out west. It became more common for worker to become factory workers, and in general the amount of control that women had over their own loives was growing. THey had a choice between staying at the home or becoming a facotry worker at a company like Lowell Systems, whichc was common. Child labor was common, and other poor conditions in the workplace led to frustration among factories workers and eventually led to the estalishment of unions which tried to make work hours and conditions more reasonable. Success was limited due to overly willing immigrant workers, state laws, and economic depression.  sectionalism south cotton and slaveryThe south was mainly known for its agriculture, with there being very little manufacturing and industry because farmers and plantation owners though cash crops were more profitable. The crop that was most commonly harvested in the south was the cash crop, cotton, giving the South the nickname of King Cotton. Cotton was needed by American and british textile mills in high demand. There were large plantations in the south with very large amounts of land and many slaves, but there were much more smaller farms and subsistence farmers that made up the compromised the majority of the white people in the south.stono rebellionThere was unruliness among the slaves in the south, and in an incident known as the stono rebellion, about twenty slaves tried to escape to Spanish Florida for freedom.tobacco sugar rice and cotton plantationAlong with cotton plantations, there was also other crops such as sugar, rice, and tobacco grown in the south, with the majority of the farmers being having smaller farms or being subsistence farmers.reasons for increase in slaveryThe demand ffor slaves in the south was increased by the high need for cotton, as well as the intensive manual labor that was required for harvesting cotton, and also Eli Ehitney's inventiob, the cotton gin, made cotton more efficient and profitable.southerners beliefsSlavery was part of southern culture, and in a way, southerners justified keeping slaves. They stated that they gave slaves a means of living, a place to sleep, food, a roof over their heads, and technically work that served as a sense of purpose in life. Beliefs such as this was a large part of southern culture and they stood by them firmly with the idea that they were helping the slaves with their lives.northimmigrantsFrom about 1830 to the end of of the 1850s, a large amount of immigrants from Ireland and Germany arrived in the United States. Irish immigrant's main motivation for coming to the United States was the failure of their potato crop back at home, as well as the numerous amount of jobs that were availbable in the U.S. with its large amount of new industry.American response to immigrantsNot all Americans welcomed immigrants into their nation, they felt threatened about them taking their potential jobs, and they also felt they infiltrated their culture by setting up their new communities as well as their Roman Catholicism.SettlementThe American western frontier was moving and expanding westward, and in the 1830s the mountain men blazed the Oregon Trail.New StatesThe lands between the Ohio and Mississippi river were becoming settled, and the land was divided up in five new states: Missouri, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, and Ohio Battle of Fallen TimbersAs Americans expanded and settled westward, there were additional encounters with Native Americans. Native Americans were fought by Americans in a battle known as the Battle of Fallen Timbers. In the Treaty of Greenville, it was agreed that Native Americans would open up more of their land to American settlementIn The Black Hawk War, America victories caused the Sauk and Fox tribes to move across the Mississippi River.
fields.title: Economic Plans

fields.content: The empires of Europe began to base their national power off of their prosperity and wealth as well as the prosperity and wealth that their colonies contributed from trade. To increase the amount of wealth that the colonies contributed to the mother country, England implementing stricter trade policy that was known as the Navigation Acts in 1650.
fields.title: Mercantilism

fields.content: •Certain products could only be exported to England, such as tobacco.•All goods that were imported to England had to first pass through ports in England.•Colonial trade had to be operated by English Ships.The Navigation Acts helped protect the colonies from other countries with the naval protection of England, although the colonies were payed low prices for goods sold to England while they had to high prices for goods imported from England. The Massachusetts Bay Colony had its charter removed due to a chronic violation of the Acts.
fields.title: The Navigation Acts

fields.content: From the Early years of the colonies, the amount of black slaves in the colonies grew at a rapid rate. Virginia had over 100,000 black slaves by 1750. The supply of African slaves seemed limitless, the labor was cheap, and there was less of a chance of revolt with black slaves than there was with immigrant farmers. Slaves had pretty much no rights. Slaves marriages weren't recognized, they couldn't be taught to read or write, they could have no property, and they could be split apart from their families. About 20% of the colonial population of about 2.5 million consisted of slaves in 1775.German, Scotch-Irish, and Other European immigrants comprised roughly 20% of the colonial population by 1775. They settled in most colonies excluding the new England colonies because they wished to avoid the Puritan authorities there. English immigrants made up the vast majority of the colonial population, bringing along with them a dominating English culture.
fields.title: Slavery

fields.content: The steady food supply in the colonies drew many settlers and their families and raised new families. Families were typical large with 8 kids being a typical amount of children for a family. Men were the primary landowners and workers, and they were given extensive limits of power in the home with regard to the treatment of their wives. Women mainly kept to the home, with their primary duties including keeping up the house, cleaning the house, and tending to as well as educating the children.
fields.title: Family Units

fields.content: •New England Colonies: Primarily merchants and shipbuilders.•Middle Colonies: Small farms and some industry•Southern colonies: Subsistence farmers and large plantations•Transportation: Bodies of water and rivers provided the main method of transporting of goods
fields.title: Economy

fields.content: In the colonies, there was a religious movements in the 1730s known as the Great Awakening, lead mainly by two ministers, Jonathan Edwards and George Whitefield. Their sermons focused on the idea of people living on the verge of damnation due to their chronic sins, and they must make a change in the way they address their religion in order to be saved. Such sermons were given in any area, such as barns and fields, and one of the more popular ones was known as "Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God", which was given by Jonathan Edwards. The movement increased the amount of people following the teachings of evangelical sects.
fields.title: The Great Awakening

fields.content: Education began to develop in the colonies, with the implementation of multiple grammar schools, high school, and colleges. The New England colonies had the most advanced education system, while the southern colonies primarily relied on the homeschooling of children in order to get educated. Colleges in the colonies included Harvard, the first colonial college, as well as Yale, and William and Mary. All these colleges were sectarian and promoted the teachings of a specific religious sect. The Great Awakening also spurred the establishment of other sectarian colleges such as Princeton, Dartmouth, Brown, and Rutgers.
fields.title: Education

fields.content: The increase in colleges also increased the amount of people practicing more advanced professions such as becoming a physician or lawyer. The first medical college started in 1765. The need for lawyers became apparent as legal complications in court became prevalent, famous lawyers at the time included Patrick Henry and John Adams who would later use legal standing to justify the cause of an American Revolution.
fields.title: Professions

fields.content: Colonial Intellectuals such as Benjamin franklin and Thomas Jefferson were affected by the Enlightenment in the mid 1700s, where logic, reason, and science gained new strength and importance. John Locke and Isaac Newton were both leaders in the movement, and Benjamin Franklin also made progress with studies and inventions during this time. Followers of the movements typically believed in God although they believed that all occurrences in life were able to be explained by science.
fields.title: The Age of Reason
The North and South Become Hostile Over the Issue of Slavery

fields.content: Under the strict enforcement of the Fugitive Slave Law, marshals could hunt escaped slaves and return them to their masters, there were heavy fines against anyone who helped a slave escape. The law was made to diminish the expanse of the underground Railroad which was a well planned out system made to help slaves escape. The North reacted by given caught slaves trials before they were returned, which angered the South.
fields.title: Fugitive Slave Law

fields.content: A book by Harriet Beecher Stowe called Uncle Tom's Cabinet added fuel to the fire because the book described the in-depth horrors that were part of a slave's life. The upsetting description caused more people to sympathize with slaves.
fields.title: Anti-Slavery in Literature

fields.content: Dred Scott was a former slave who reached Wisconsin, a free state. He sued for his freedom on the ground that his time on free soil made him a free man. Dred Scott lost the case under the ruling that he couldn't sue in court because he was and African American and that the framers didn't intend for African Americans to be citizens of the UNited States. Also, the court argued it couldn't take away any personal property, including slaves. The Dred Scott decision pleased Southerners while leaving Northerners in shock and adding additional sectional tension to current matters.
fields.title: The Dred Scott Decision

fields.content: Stephen A. Douglas introduced a bill to Congress that called for the building of a railroad that would stretch from Chicago to the western states. The Kansas Nebraska Act would provide that the land that the railroad would pass through would be divided into two states: Kansas and Nebraska. The land's slavery status was to be decided by popular sovereignty, and then ban slavery north of the lateral 36' 30''. The Act caused numerous Southerners and Northerners to rush to the new states to add their slavery or anti-slavery influence to the vote of popular sovereignty. Fighting and violence broke out between the groups, making the term "Bleeding Kansas" stick.
fields.title: Violence in Kansas

fields.content: The writing of constitution of the Kansas was rigged by people who supported slavery. They rigged the election of people who were to draw up the constitution so that there were more proslavery than antislavery members. The outcome was the Lecompton Constitution.
fields.title: The New Constitution of Kansas

fields.content: John Brown led a raid in Harper's Ferry, Virginia in 1959 by trying to arm and rally slaves in a revolt. Federal troops captured Brown and ended the violent uprising. The matter shocked and angered southerners, and made more moderate Northerners frown upon Brown's use of violence, however he was firmly supported and hailed by abolitionists.
fields.title: Raid in Harper's Ferry

fields.content: The Kansas Nebraska Act destroyed party unity during the vote for the act and the Whig party altogether because it had hardly any sectional unity, it was more of a compilation of ideas and personalities. With the Whigs gone, for they did not run another presidential candidate in 1852, new sectional parties emerged, such as the Free-Soil Party, and the Republican Party.
fields.title: Political Parties

fields.content: In the election of 1856, most of the votes had an obvious sectional influence. The Democratic candidate, Buchanan, was a Northner who supported the South on most issues. The Republicans elected John C. Fremont and ran an anti-slavery campaign, although they were not technically running an abolitionist campaign. Buchanan and the Democrats won the election, however, the Republicans made an incredibly strong showing for a new party.
fields.title: The Election of 1856

fields.content: Abraham Lincoln, a Republican, ran against Stephen A. Douglas for senator where they both took place in numerous debates. In one of the debates, Lincoln frankly asked Douglas if he supported the Dred Scott decision or popular sovereignty. Attempting to make a non sectional response, Douglas attempted to be diplomatic and not directly take the South's side on the matter in his official response that was known as the Freeport Doctrine. The doctrine caused him to lose the support of Southern Democrats during the election for the presidency in 1860.
fields.title: Douglas Loses Support in the South

fields.content: In the election of 1860, the Democrats split into North and South sections when electing a presidential candidate. The Northern Democrats nominated Douglas while the Southern Democrats nominated John Breckenridge of Kentucky. The Constitutional Union Party was a non sectional party who chose John Bell of Tennessee as its candidate. Lincoln and the Republicans ended up winning ht election, mainly because of the division of the Democratic party.
fields.title: The Election of 1860

fields.content: South Carolina was the first state to secede from the Union after the election of Lincoln. After South Carolina, Georgia, Mississippi, Florida, Texas, and Alabama, and Louisiana also seceded from the Union. The seceded states formed the Confederate States of America and picked Jefferson Davis to be their president. Lincoln declared a state could not decide on its own to leave the Union, and asked the southern states' reconsideration. Instead, the Confederates attacked a ship that was bringing supplies to Fort Sumter. The attack was the official beginning of the Civil War.
fields.title: Secession From the Union and the Formation of the Confederacy

fields.content: The term "manifest destiny", became commonly used to describe the mission that America had to expand as a nation westward into the rest of the landmass that was adjacent with America, including territory as far west as the Pacific.
fields.title: The Manifest Destiny

fields.content: Americans were pushing the frontiers of America past the Mississippi and looking to prospectively even settle beyond that, while commercial agriculture thrived in the midwest and industry and manufacturing dominated the Northeast. By 1853, the united States consisted of 48 states, while Hawaii and Alaska were added later to make 50.
fields.title: The Layout of the Land

fields.content: In 1821, Mexico won independence from Spain, and it settled in Texas. Many American settlers were granted entrance to Texas by the Mexican government as long as all settlers were Roman Catholic and slavery would be banned. American immigrants outnumbered Mexicans greatly in Texas, making immigration closed to any more Americans, causing protest by Moses Austin, the leader of white immigration to Texas, causing him to be jailed.
fields.title: Independence

fields.content: Santa Anna became the dictator of Mexico, making the Americans in Texas rebel with violence and causing the battle of the Alamo. Santa Anna couldn't suppress the rebellion, making him sign a treaty that recognized Texas' independence and recognizing it as the Lone Star State, a nation independent from Mexico, Texas, or any other nation at the time. When Texas requested being a state of the U.S. in 1836, the matter was prolonged until 1845 when James K. Polk, a big advocate of territorial expansion, accepted Texas' request for annexation in 1845.
fields.title: Dictatorship and Revolt

fields.content: Once accepted as state in the Union, Mexico attacked Texas due to being unsatisfied with the current ownership of disputed lands, making the United States declare war and thus beginning the Mexican War. The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo ended the fighting of the Mexican War under the conditions that the United States would recognize the Rio grande as the border between Mexico. Also, the United States had to give Mexico 15 million dollars for the land.
fields.title: The Mexican American War

fields.content: With the new land made available by the Mexican Cession, David Wilmot proposed the Wilmot Proviso would would prohibit slavery in any new states that were formed from land gained by the cession. John C. Calhoun was an outspoken opponent of the bill, and it was rejected by the Senate under the grounds that it was Congress' duty to protect the land of new settlers, including the slaves of plantation owners.
fields.title: Slavery in Lands Won From Mexico

fields.content: Before the Mexican War began, Mexico attempted to attract settlers by giving away land in California. Many whites settled in the territory and became absorbed by Spanish culture, but James K. Polk wished for the state to be annexed. He told his request to Mexico and was refused at first, although during the Mexican War, whites started up the Bear Flag Revolt, declaring California and independent territory from mexico, however after the war, the treaty gave California to the U.S as part of the mexican session.In 1849, many settlers flooded to California in hopes of making money by finding large amounts of gold and other precious metals, and also in 1849, California requested statehood upon the condition of having slavery banned in California.
fields.title: The Desire for the Annexation of California

fields.content: Admitting California as a free state in 1849 would destroy the current balance between free and slave states that was current in 1849. To help relieve the political crisis, Henry Clay proposed the Compromise of 1850, which would admit California to the American Union as a free state, have popular sovereignty decide the freedom of the rest of the states formed from the Mexican Cession, enforce a Fugitive Slave Law, as well as have Texas give disputed land to the Union to make free states in return for ten million dollars. The Compromise of 1850 was passed by Congress.
fields.title: Attempting to Preserve Sectional Balance

fields.content: The land that was given to America in the Mexican Cession, particularly New Mexico, contained many Mexicans, making there 75,000 new Mexican immigrants to the United States. Mexicans were discriminated by whites and tension continued between the to groups.
fields.title: Mexican-Americans

fields.content: Spain gave up its claim in the Oregon Territory in the Adams-Onis Treaty, and Russia withdrew its claims from the territory. Britain eventually set agreed with James K. Polk to set the boundary with the United States at the 49th parallel, due to fear of war with the Americans and their popular cry "Fifty-Four Forty or Fight!" The agreement divided the territory into the Oregon Territory and the Washington Territory.
fields.title: Claims in the Northwest

fields.content: President Polk first offered to buy Cuba from Spain, but was refused. Franklin Pierce later secretly sent diplomats to negotiate the purchase of Cuba from Spain. The agreement was known as the Ostend Manifesto, and was eventually leaked to the press, forcing Pierce to drop the plan.
fields.title: Cuba

fields.content: America also bought additional land from Mexico in the Gadsden Purchase in return for 10 million dollars.
fields.title: The Gadsden Purchase

fields.content: The U.S. also bought land from Russia that was called also, mainly due to the wishes of Secretary of State William Seward. At first chastised for the decision, Alaska was called Seward's Folly, or Seward"s icebox, until oil and other precious metals were found in the land.
fields.title: Alaska

fields.content:
•A larger army and population

•Had better skilled officers

•A superior railroad system

•Had much more industry and factories for manufacturing war goods

•An established and powerful central government
fields.title: Northern War Advantages

fields.content:
•Was fighting a defensive war

•Received finances from overseas cotton purchases
fields.title: Southern War Advantages

fields.content: Both the North and South resorted to draft laws in order to get soldiers. The draft applied to all men as old a 17, and there were certain exemption laws and substitues were allowed, and in the North, a draftee could be exmepted by paying a fine. Such policies caused poorer families to become upset and begin Draft Riots. When the amount of battle ready men started to dwindle, the North allowed blacks to serve in 1862.
fields.title: Organizing Troops for War

fields.content: There was discrimination in the military; blacks were rarely soldiers and were more often cooks, drivers, and medics. The Confiscation Act of 1861 stated that any slaves who escaped to the Union would gain their freedom. Slaves did not fight in the south, but they did take on war construction related projects and indirectly help with the war effort.
fields.title: African Americans Fighting in the War

fields.content:
The North

•Selling government bonds

•Higher Tariffs

•Issuing and using paper money

The South

•Land taxes

•Taxes on specific goods

•Issuing more paper money
fields.title: Financing the War

fields.content:
The Confederate Constitution

The Following Provisions were established under the Confederate Constitution

•Protective tariffs were banned

•All property including slaves were protected

•States rights were superior to the central government

Retaliation From States Within the Confederacy

North Carolina did not obey the draft law, and South Carolina and Georgia even talked of secession from the Confederacy.

The Support of Western Europe

France and Britain sympathized with the Confederacy and they believed being allies with them would provide them with a steady source of cotton for their textile mills.
fields.title: A New Confederate Nation

fields.content: Women on both sides adapted to help with the war effort in their own way. They took the place of the the men in the manufacturing and factory jobs, however there wages were less than what men were paid. Women raised money for the war as well as sewed and did medic type jobs. Women were also spies, and some fought as soldiers while disguised as men.
fields.title: Women and the War Effort

fields.content:
•Capture the capitol of the Confederate States of America (C.S.A.), Richmond

•Block southern ports and trade

•Control the Mississippi River

•The main goal was to split the south and block their port so they couldn't trade their cotton with foreign nations in exchange for supplies; without imports the South would be nearly entirely starved of its much needed manufactured goods.
fields.title: The Northern Battle Plan

fields.content: In what was the first actual battle of the Civil War, 30,00 Union troops went down to Bull Run Creek, Virginia in 1861. The Union was winning the battle at first, but then were counterattacked by General Thomas "Stonewall" Jackson and were forced to retreat. The battle ended any kind of hopes for their to be a quick war.
fields.title: The First Battle of Bull Run

fields.content: Lee continued with his force after winning in the clash at the Second Battle of Bull Run in northern Virginia and planned to attack at Maryland where he hoped to win a key victory in order to officially win the support of Britain. General McClellan of the Union army knew Lee's battle plan because it had been dropped by a Confederate officer, although the battle of Antietam ensued in 1861 and proved to be the bloodiest day of the war with over 20,000 men being either killed or wounded. Lee's forces were pushed back and forced to retreat to Virginia.
fields.title: Antietam

fields.content: The North lost a key battle at Chancellorsville, and after the battle southern general Robert E. Lee was able to take his troops northward. He hoped to end the war quickly by going on the offensive, but he was defeated and forced to retreat at Gettysburg. General Ulysses S Grant secured the Mississippi by raiding Vicksburg in 1863, which was on the Mississippi. The Northern victories at Gettysburg and Vicksburg proved to be the beginning of the North having the upper hand in the war, with the South entering more and more of a state of economic depression and overall desperation. Next year, Grant was in control of the entire Union army.
fields.title: Chancellorsville, Gettysburg, and Vicksburg

fields.content: At the end of the war, the Northern strategy of cutting off the south's ports and trade proved to be very effective. It was an important reason as to why the South became incredibly desperate for war goods and supplies in the final years of the war.
fields.title: The Union Blockade

fields.content: Grant and Lee engaged their armies in a series of battles, when finally Grant surrounded Lee at Richmond. General William Sherman led his army in a "march from the sea" from Atlanta, which he burned, to Savannah. Sherman's forces brutally destroyed all in their path, demonstrating total war in order to completely obliterate any of the Confederates' hopes in the war and crush their will of fighting on. His march lasted from 1864-1865.
fields.title: General Sherman's "March From the Sea"

fields.content: Grant continued to attack and contain Lee at Petersburg. Shortly after, Richmond fell, and Lee surrendered, marking the end of the War in 1865.
fields.title: The Fall of Richmond and the End of the War

fields.content: Despite Lincoln's hesitance to abolish slavery altogether due to political reasons and fear of prejudice, Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation in 1862, which freed all slaves in rebelling states. The document did not grant freedom to slaves in border states, although Lincoln did encourage those states to develop a plan that would emanciapte their slaves with compensation to the slaves' owners. The Emancipation Proclamation did not technically grant freedom, because it only applied to slaves in Confederate states that were not under Union control; although the document gave a new meaning to the entire war. Lincoln was mainly attmpting to end the war through pressurring the Confederates states to come to peace as early as possible.
fields.title: The Emancipation Proclamation

fields.content:
Democrats and republicans joined to form the Union party in the North for the election of 1864, and they nominated Lincoln as their candidate and Andrew Johnson as Vice President.
