With the war being won with the nation staying organized and under control, with banking being stronger than ever, it seemed clear that Lincoln would be reelected when running agins the Democratic candidate and war-hero General George McClellan. Lincoln won reelection in 1864 by a landslide without surprise.

'.
fields.title: The Election of 1864

fields.content:
•Royal Colonies: Colonies directly controlled by the crown.

•Proprietary Colonies: Ruled by individuals who were given a charter by the King. The King gave such charters to friends to use as a tool for nearly total control.

•Corporate Colonies: Colonies that were formed by a group of colonists' funds, such as a joint stock company.
fields.title: The Three Types of Colonies
The Formation of the New Colonies

fields.content: The royal colony of Virginia, one of the Chesapeake colonies, the first colony of England, was mainly established for economic purposes, although it faced many hardships throughout the duration of its early years as a colony. Tobacco was overproduced and low-priced, and poor leadership gave rise to rebellion and disorder. Virginia also faced labor shortages with just using indentured servitude, Indian slaves, and the Headright system, so the colony turned to enslaving African blacks. The headright system was a way of Virgina attracting English settlers by promising 50 acres of land to any settler that payed for their voyage to America. Virginia's royal governor, Sir William Berkeley, would largely ignore the needs of the farmers that were subject to Indian attacks on the frontier of the colony and instead focus on implementing policy that would help the more wealthy portion of the colony's population. Such acts on Berkeley's behalf angered the low-class farmer of Virgina, and in 1676, Nathaniel Bacon rounded up an army of farmers to raid Indian villages near the Virginia border in what was the event known as Bacon's Rebellion. Governor Berkeley tried suppressing the army with his own forces, although they were defeated by Bacon's farmers. Within a short period of time, Nathaniel Bacon died, causing his army to disintegrate.
fields.title: Virginia

fields.content: Maryland was a proprietary colony of the Chesapeake Colonies. It was formed by Lord Baltimore, also known as George Calvert once he was given a charter from King Charles I in 1632 in return for dutiful service. Lord Baltimore passed the charter on to his son Cecil Calvert. The colony was mainly made as a haven for Catholics, although under the Act of Toleration it also gave religious freedom to all Christians.
fields.title: Maryland

fields.content: Reverend Thomas Hooker led a group Puritans that left the Massachusetts colony to colonize Hartford. The Fundamental Orders of Connecticut, was the first American constitution created and was written by the colonists of Hartford. John Davenport led the colonization of New Haven, in land near Hartford. In 1665, New Haven and Hartford merged to form Connecticut under a royal charter.
fields.title: Connecticut

fields.content: New Hampshire was founded under a royal charter granted by King Charles II. The authorities of New Hampshire came up with the Halfway Covenant in order to solve the lack of engagement of young and teenage Puritans in the Puritan church. The Halfway Covenant stated that individuals could still participate in church involvements without publicly declaring their total belief in Christ.
fields.title: New Hampshire

fields.content: The Rhode Island colony mainly consisted of misfits and individuals that were not accepted by the Puritan church because of their personal beliefs. The colony had complete toleration of all religions, and was founded by Roger Williams in 1644. Roger Williams was a Puritan minister who was banished from the Massachusetts Bay Colony because of his preaching about individual conscience being beyond the control of church authority. Anne Hutchinson was also banished by Puritan authorities because of her belief in antinomianism, the belief that the deeds one executed is less religiously important than the personal faith one has. She founded the colony of Portsmouth, which joined with Williams' former colony of Providence to form Rhode Island.
fields.title: Rhode Island

fields.content: North Carolina's land held multiple smaller tobacco farms, but not many large crop plantations because of its lack of easy access to harbors.
fields.title: North Carolina

fields.content: Created mainly as a supplier of food that was home to many rice-growing plantations that operated under slavery.
fields.title: South Carolina

fields.content: The Duke of York, who would in the future become James II, took lands between New Hampshire and Virginia by force from the former Dutch colonists. With his powerful naval force, the Duke of York took the land easily and ordered his men to treat the former Dutch colonists well. At first closed-minded to assembly for the colony, he raised taxes which angered the colonists under the basis of taxation without representation. Noticing how his decisions angered the colonists, he eventually allowed them a representative assembly in 1683.
fields.title: New York

fields.content: Two colonies of East and West New Jersey were formed by proprietary charters under friends of the Duke of York, although the merged to make New Jersey in 1702 as to avoid the previous confusion of land and property lines. The colony allowed religious freedom as well as an assembly.
fields.title: New Jersey

fields.content: In 1681, William Penn was the granted the land of Pennsylvania by the King as a way of repaying his dead father for his services to his country. Penn was a Quaker, so he wanted to make his new colony a haven for other persecuted Quakers and people of other religious denominations. Quakers, or the Society of Friends, were a religious group that believed one's own conscience is the most important element in determining one's own salvation. He wanted to grant the colony a representative assembly and religious freedom, and use his colony as an experiment for other liberal governmental theories, thus came the term: "Penn's Holy Experiment".
fields.title: Pennsylvania

fields.content: Delaware was created in 1702 from a southern portion of land that was at first Pennsylvania.
fields.title: Delaware

fields.content: Georgia was created with the purpose of taking prisoners from England to fill the colony to make it serve as a buffer zone for the other colonies. Formed as a royal colony in 1732, making it the last colony to be formed, Georgia restricted the consumption of alcohol as well as the use of slavery. Such bans were lifted in 1752, and Georgia started to have more plantations grown on the its land.
fields.title: Georgia

fields.content: The courts at the time narrowly interpreted the constitution, which made it difficult for any reforming or regulatory legislation to be passed and in effect made it very easy for limited government intervention and laissez-faire to continue. In elections, both Democrats and Republicans refrained from taking strong stances on issues, and also the Republicans continued on the post-Civil war of "waving the bloody shirt" to rally voters against the Democrats who caused the war and so much loss for the dear Union. Since not much happened politically in government, a game of patronage became a big part of politics, which was basically a competition between and within parties to assign and hold government positions and offices. Republicans who didn't involve themselves in this game of patronage were known as "mugwumps". Presidential administration during the Gilded Age included those of Rutherford B. Hayes who won the election of 1876, James Garfield who won the election of 18880, and Chester A. Arthur who was placed into the presidential office in 1881. Upon taking the office, Garfield was swarmed by people requesting government positions. When he was about to leave on vacation, a distressed person who was desperate for an office position, but had not gotten one yet shot president Garfield in the back, making vice president Chester A. Arthur the next president of the United States in 1881.
fields.title: Politics

fields.content: The democratic candidate, Grover Cleveland, won the election of 1884, marking a small comeback for the Democratic party.
fields.title: The Election of 1884

fields.content: The end of the overwhelming amount of patronage that was taking place in politics was facilitated by the enactment of the Pendleton Act of 1881 by the Civil Service Commission. The act made it mandatory for people to take a specific test in order to hold certain government positions or jobs.
fields.title: Reform in Politics

fields.content: One large issue in the gilded age, especially during 1880, was the subject of tariffs. Tariffs were very high, which was eliminating foreign competition and thus allowing American companies to charge even more for their own goods. Farmers also complained about high tariffs because European countries would often respond to high U.S tariffs by putting their own taxes on farming imports from the U.S., causing American farmers to loss some of their businesses.
fields.title: Tariffs

fields.content: Farmers waned more money in circulation so that they could invest in new land at a lower interest rate, also, an increase in the amount of money in circulation would allow them to pay off their debts more easily since the currency would be inflated later on. Their way of setting this situation into effect was by supporting the minting of a large amount of soft money, or silver coins. The bankers wanted the opposite to happen, and instead were strong advocated of a limited hard currency that would be backed by the gold in order to preserve its value.
fields.title: The Debate Over Currency

fields.content: Other people supported the minting of paper money that wouldn't be backed by gold or silver, and such people formed the Greenback Party. Once the economic crisis during the 1870s ended, the Greenback Party dissolved although there were still many people in favor of increasing the amount of money in circulation for their own possible benefit.
fields.title: The Greenback Party

fields.content:
Harrison president marked the first that Congress surpassed over a billion dollars on its budget. With the large budget, the Harrison's Congress accomplished the following:

•The high tariff known as the McKinley Tariff of 1890

•Additional pension payments to war veterans.

•The Sherman Antitrust Act which banned the formation of trust or another sort of conspiracy amongst companies in order to interfere with the natural competition of trade
fields.title: Harrison's Billion Dollar Congress

fields.content: There was a dispute over the regulation of railroads, for certain railroads were charging more or less for certain passengers, and the railroads argued they were in the right under the "due process clause" In the supreme court, it was declared that the people had the ability to regulate the railroads in such a way and thus the railroads were defeated in the matter. Congress passed the Interstate Commerce Clause which established the Interstate Commerce Commission which regulated railroads and transportation.
fields.title: Railroads

fields.content: John Rockefeller and his large Standard Oil Company had trusts with other oil companies in order to eliminate competition with other companies. Ultimately trusts, would become monopolies that dominated the industry, and the idea of owning all the other companies in a single industry was also known as horizontal integration.
fields.title: Big Business

fields.content: The rise of the people's party or the Populist Party, was mainly made successful due to the widespread amount of support it received from farmers. The party wanted to shift the concentration of power away from the rich merchants and bankers. The Populist Party drafted the Omaha Platform which called for government regulation of railroads, the minting of silver, immigration reform, and shorter workdays. Basically the Populist party wanted to end the laissez-faire style capitalism that had been ruling the economy at that time.
fields.title: Populist Party

fields.content: During the panic of 1893, President Cleveland attempted to deal with the crisis by championed the gold standard. A decrease in silver prices made a lot of people convert over to the gold currency, and Cleveland responded by repealing the Sherman Silver Purchase Act which mandated the purchase of a specific amount of silver every month.
fields.title: The Sherman Silver Purchase Act

fields.content: In the election of 1896, the Populist Party supported William Jennings Bryan as their candidate after his inspiring "Cross of Gold" speech that effectively conveyed the concerns and goals of the Populist Party. The Republican Party nominated William McKinley as their candidate who supported the gold standard as well as a high tariff in order to protect American industry and manufacturing. Bryan received the majority of his support from the western and southern regions of America, although the manufacturing centers of the nation gave McKinley their solid support, causing him to win the election. After losing the election of 1896, the Populist Party pretty much disappeared.
fields.title: The Election of 1896
The Age of the Common Man and Democracy

fields.content: The sense of social equality was also elevated by changes in the structure of elections and politics. Universal male suffrage was granted in a movement that started at first in new western states, which spread to all U.S. states until all men were allowed to vote, regardless of the property they owned. Also, elections became more democratic by the reduction in primary caucuses that were used to nominate candidates, which were only open to party leaders. They were widely replaced with nominating conventions that instead allowed all people to participate in the nomination of candidates. Also, presidential electors were now elected by the population rather than state legislatures, making presidential elections more democratic and making it more necessary for the campaigns to appeal to the masses.
fields.title: The Change in Elections and Voting Requirements

fields.content: The supporters of Andrew Jackson called themselves Democrats while his opponents formed a party known as the Whigs who nominated henry Clay as their presidential candidate.
fields.title: Party Evolution

fields.content: Jackson generally supported states rights, and his position was reaffirmed by his action of vetoing a bill, which was known as the Maysville Road Veto. Congress wanted to build the Cumberland Road in Kentucky, however Jackson vetoed the bill on the ground that it wasn't constitutional.
fields.title: States Rights

fields.content: The protective tariff of 1828, also known as the Tariff of Abominations, was a raised version of the Tariff of 1824. John C. Calhoun and the state of South Carolina deemed that the tariff was unconstitutional, and because of that, it was susceptible to nullification. The idea of nullification primarily stated that a state had the ability to decide wether or not to obey a federal law, and therefore declare it void, which was basically an idea derived from the Virginia and Kentucky resolutions many years earlier. Calhoun declared the nullification of another tariff in 1832. Angered, Andrew Jackson boldly got Congress to pass the Force Bill which allowed military action in South Carolina, while declaring that nullification was treason. Instead of engaging troops, Jackson instead compromised by lowering the tariff. However, his bold and powerful actions in the face of the crisis made militant southern rebels retreat.
fields.title: Tariffs and the Nullification Crisis

fields.content: Andrew Jackson love for democracy did not extend to native Americans; that was made clear by the Indian Removal Act of 1830. It forced many native americans to leave their land and move west of the Mississippi while leaving their land open to American settlement. Other states also forced tribes to migrate, and the Cherokee tribe tried suing Georgia. In a case known as Cherokee nation v Georgia, the court declared that the Cherokee tribe was not a nation and could not sue in court. Widespread movement of many native americans resulted in a very difficult time for the tribes in a period known as the Trail of Tears, where traveling conditions were incredibly stressing and tolling. The conditions killed thousands of native americans during the trek.
fields.title: Indian Removal Act

fields.content: During Andrew Jackson's presidency, the wife of the secretary of state was a target of gossip amongst the other wives of the cabinet members because she was committed of adultery, making her a social outcast. Jackson felt for Eaton and tried persuading the wives of the cabinet members to accept Mrs. Eaton socially. The affair sparked controversy among Jackson and the politicians and their wives, and the heated conflict is what caused vice president John C Calhoun to leave office and have his place taken by Martin Van Buren.
fields.title: Peggy Eaton Affair

fields.content: Andrew Jackson believed that the bank of the united states was unconstitutional, and so he vetoed the Bank re-charter bill in 1832, thus killing the bank of the united states. Jackson withdrew all federal funds and instead distributed the funds among states banks which were referred to as pet banks.
fields.title: Jackson and the Bank of the United States

fields.content: Due to poor economic and financial policy, the price of western land badly inflated. Andrew Jackson attempted to resolve the crisis by mandating that all purchases of federal land were to be made with gold and silver rather than bank notes. The attempt made matters worse, making banknotes worthless and making land lose almost of its value, starting the economic depression known as the panic of 1837.
fields.title: Specie Circular and the Panic of 1837

fields.content: In the Upcoming election, where Martin Van Buren was the democratic candidate and William Henry Harrison was the Whig candidate, Martin Van Buren and the Deomcrats were blamed for the poor economy, although it mostly was due to the national bank being killed by Jackson. The whigs launched a campaign for Harrison that was known as "Log Cabin and hard Cider" that emphasized the humble beginnings of Harrison and his very self accomplished track record in battle. The denounced "Martin Van Ruin", and in 1840, William Henry Harrison was elected to office, thus making the whigs officially a national party. Harrison died very soon after taking office due to an illness, making his Vice President, John Tyler, take the office of the president. John Tyler was not a true whig, and his presidency upset whigs, and they referred to Tyler as "His Accidency"
fields.title: The Election of 1840

fields.content: The original natives of the Americas entered the Americas around 40,000 B.C. by crossing over the Bering Strait from what is now Serbia. By the time Columbus arrived in America, there were about 50 million natives spread across the land. The Native Americans at that time had a wide range of cultures, although different groups had their own established settlements and skill in hunting and fishing as a method to obtain food. The natives practiced their distinctive crafts and some had domesticated animals.
fields.title: The Origins of the First Settlers of America

fields.content: Columbus, a native Italian explorer, tried finding such a route for trading with the Chinese under an agreement with the Spaniards. On his expedition, he believed he reached China, although it turns out that he instead reached the shores of the Americas. Long past Columbus' death when he still believed he discovered a new path to China in 1506, European transportation to the Americas had permanently been established. The Europeans and the Native Americans made trades and exchanges upon their interactions, however Europeans brought numerous diseases to the Americas that wiped out a significant number of the Native American population.
fields.title: Columbus

fields.content: The Spanish mainly settled in southern and central America, and they shipped large amounts of gold and silver back to Spain, making them one of the powerful countries in continent. The Spanish sought to conquer all lands they discovered and also used the natives in these lands as labor slaves for Spaniards who settled in the "New World", making them work their land in return for minimal care. As the number of Native Americans available for conversion to slaves dwindled, the Spanish began importing slaves from Africa.
fields.title: Spanish Settlement in the Americas

fields.content: The French settled and exploration areas that were mainly concentrated in northeastern Canada in what is now known as Quebec, as well as other eastern land such as Louisiana and areas along the Mississippi River. French Catholic preachers were sent to the new land with the goal of converting the natives' religious loyalties, although their efforts normally resulted in violence. Many French settlers were fur traders due to their lack of encounters with precious metals. The French were also known to have more peaceful and friendly relations with the natives, treating them as allies, with some even taking Native Americans as spouses.
fields.title: French Settlement in the Americas

fields.content: In the 1500s, the English began attempts of settling the eastern coast of the Americas as well. As the met the Native of America, they at first engaged in friendly exchange of goods and and teachings from the natives. As time elapsed, the english became close minded to the Native American culture, viewing them as inferior and savage, which gave way to violence and the natives feeling that their way of life was threatened by further settlements of the English. As the English migrated to America, their ships clashed with the Spanish navy in the Atlantic ocean, and their victories made them known as a significant naval power. Sir Walter Raleigh lead the first significant attempt of an English settlement at Roanoke Island in 1587, although the venture ended in a failure. The English once again tried settling in the early 1600s, although their poor economy was proving to be an obstacle for such efforts. In order to overcome this setback, the creation of joint-stock companies became popular where multiple middle class English individuals could pool their finances into a larger venture for a settlement in the Americas that had promises for profit.
fields.title: English Settlement in the Americas

fields.content: In 1607, King James 1 of England gave a charter to a joint-stock company, known as the Virginia Company, for purposes of settling in the Atlantic coast of America. The early years of the settlement were hardly prosperous, with Indian attacks, sickness, and lack of food posing as a threat to the settlement in becoming a failure. John Smith's powerful leadership whipped the men of the company back into shape, making them more efficient and hard working, which enabled the survival of the settlement.  John Rolfe introduced growing and selling tobacco as means for making profit in the colonies through its sales in England. The introduction of large tobacco plantations demanded a large workforce, which brought about the prospect of indentured servitude, where individuals would be brought to the colony to work with promises of land after the worked for the amount of time specified in a contract. Politically, the colony was significant because of its establishment of the House of Burgesses; a form of representative government between the colonists and the government of England. Due to financial problems, the Virginia Company lost its charter and Jamestown fell under the direct control of King James I, making Jamestown the first royal colony.
fields.title: Jamestown

fields.content: The Puritans were a religious group that wanted to "purify" the English Anglican Church from any Roman Catholic influence which they considered "unclean". The Massachusetts Bay Company, consisting of a group of Puritans , was given a charter by King Charles I to form the Massachusetts Bay Colony in America under the leadership of John Winthrop. Their motive was to gain religious freedom in the new land and to further cleanse the Anglican church in their new colony. In the 1630s, a civil war in England drew thousands of English settlers to the colony. This movement of settlers to the Massachusetts Bay Colony is called The Great Migration.
fields.title: The Puritans and the Massachusetts Bay Colony

fields.content: The Pilgrims were another religious group interested in colonizing in the new world for religious freedom, although unlike the Puritans, they wanted to separate from the church of England completely, giving them their name, the Separatists. The Pilgrims received a charter from the London Company for settling south of the Hudson River. Before arriving in their designated land, the Pilgrims signed a document known as the Mayflower Compact which established their own form of self-government. On their voyage aboard the Mayflower they were blown off course to Cape Cod. Their survival mainly depended on the aid of the Native Americans.
fields.title: The Pilgrims and the Plymouth Colony

fields.content: Jefferson sent diplomats to France to arrange a deal with Napoleon to purchase new Orleans and Florida for 10 million dollars, although Napoleon offered all of Louisiana for 15 million. The purchase violated the constitution if interpreted in the narrow way that Jefferson normally did, although it could be justified by a much broader interpretation. Meriwether Lewis and William Clark were sent on an expedition o discover the territory, where they were accompanied by the native american Sacagawea. They discovered many things about the new land and even developed trade routes and maps.
fields.title: Louisiana Purchase

fields.content: Before Adams left office, he made a series of "midnight appointments" for court justices in order for it to be controlled by Federalists. Jefferson then tried removing some of these appointees, although one of the appointees, Marbury, sued Jefferson for the right to his commission under the Judicial Act of 1794. In the Case Marbury vs. Madison, Chief Justice John Marshall ruled that Marbury did not technically have a legal right to his commission because the Judicial Act of 1794 was a piece of legislation that violated the constitutional, and therefore Marshall declared it unconstitutional. Thus, Jefferson won the case, although more importantly, Marshall's ruling gave the power of judicial review to the judiciary, a power never used before although it would leave a great mark on the power of the judiciary for many years to come.
fields.title: Marshall and the Supreme Court

fields.content: Angry over his loss in the race to become the governor of New York due to Hamilton's opposition in his campaign, he challenged Alexander Hamilton to a duel in which he shot and killed him. Burr fled west where he attempted to become the emperor of Western territories, when Jefferson ordered his arrest. Aaron Burr was acquitted and sent into exile.
fields.title: The Escapades of Aaron Burr

fields.content: A native American chief, Tecumseh, united a large number of native americans and rallied the cry of stopping white settler's intrusion on their territory. The village of Tippecanoe was built to consolidate the native americans who promoted the cause. General William Henry Harrison of the U.S. led an army and attacked and burned down the village. Killing Tecumseh.
fields.title: Tecumseh and Tippecanoe

fields.content: Jefferson was frustrated by the British seizure of neutral American cargo ships and the impression of American soldiers during Britain's war with France. In 1807, a British warship, Leopard, fired at the American warship Chesapeake, killing a few Americans. America was on the brink of war although Jefferson handled the situation with diplomacy and peace, and by getting Congress to put the Embargo Act into effect as a way of punishing the British. The Embargo Act of 1807 prohibited American trade with any other country in order to cripple Britain by shortening its import needs, however Britain easily substituted the imports it once received from the U.S. with goods from other countries, while the Embargo Act devastated the American economy. Since it proved to be such a large failure, the Embargo Act was repealed by Thomas Jefferson in 1809, allowing trade with all nations except for Britain and France.
fields.title: British Tension and the Embargo Act

fields.content: A bill was passed in Congress that would allow trade with either Britain or France, whichever nation recognized The United States' rights as a neutral nation and agreed to stop attacks on American ships. Napoleon of France agreed, so the U.S. resumed trade with France while it kept trade with Britain suspended, only to find out that Napoleon continued to seize American ships.
fields.title: MacOn Bill No. 2

fields.content: In 1808, James Madison was elected to office as a Democratic-Republican and was backed by Thomas Jefferson during the election. However, Federalists did gain considerable control in Congress due to the widespread anger over the Embargo Act.
fields.title: Madison's Election

fields.content: On June 16th of 1812, Britain finally stopped seizing American ships because it needed certain U.S. supplies, although not knowing this at the time, the U.S. declared war on Britain in 1812. Supporters of the war were known as War Hawks, while people opposed to the war were typical New England merchants who called the War of 1812 "Mr. Madison's War". At first, Britain mainly attacked from the Canadian border, where AMerican troops were able to hold them off for the most part. The Americans won minor naval battles such as in Lake Erie and also off rh Coast off Nova Scotia with the U.S. warship known as the Constitution and nicknamed Old Ironsides. General William Henry Harrison also led America to victory at the Battle of Thames. In 1814, Britain defeated France, and then shifted it military focus toward America. Britain went to invade New York, but were driven back by U.S. troops. britain also invaded Washington D.C and burnt the capital, although it was stopped at Baltimore and Fort McHenry, after which battle Francis Scott Key wrote the Star Spangled Banner. The British also attacked new Orleans, but were defeated by Andrew Jackson, although his victory was won nearly two weeks after the U.S. and Britain signed the Treaty of Ghent.
fields.title: Fighting the War

fields.content: A group of New England Federalists who were opposed to the war of 1812 met in Hartford Connecticut in 1814 to discuss what could be done about their dislike about the war, more moderate members present at the convention wanted a higher majority in both houses in order to declare war in the future, while more radical New Englanders discussed secession from the Union. These talks were quelled once the U.S. reached a treaty with Britain later that year.
fields.title: Hartford Convention

fields.content: The Treaty of Ghent, signed in 1814, left both nations off the way they were beforehand, by only stopping fighting, and restoring prewar territory lines.
fields.title: Treaty of Ghent

fields.content: Although the U.S. suffered significant losses during the War of 1812, its ability to contend with a large world military and naval superpower ignited a spirit of nationalism in Americans, while the New England Federalists' anti-war attitude was seen as unpatriotic.
fields.title: Nationalism

fields.content: The Party's accomplishments entail reform in the Voting Process including a more democratic process, with more direct primaries, and the direct election of senators instead of having state legislatures vote for the senators. Prohibition of alcohol, which was established in the 18th amendment, was initiated by the progressives, as well as an increase in women's rights and eventually women's suffrage, or women earning the right to vote, which was gained in the 19th amendment. Other achievements made by the progressive party included a graduated income tax, which gave higher tax rates to those with a higher income, safer and more sanitary conditions in the workplace, regulation of big business and industry, and an increase in the amount of conservation project to help protect the environment.
fields.title: Accomplishments of the Progressive Party

fields.content:
The Industrial Workers of the World, known as the Wobblies, were labor union lead by Eugene V. Debs who was arrested for his involvement in the Pullman Strike, and they believed in talking and negotiating through the system for better conditions.

African Americans
fields.title: Labor Unions

fields.content: The Great Migration was the movement of blacks going North and leaving the South for better employment opportunities and less fear of segregation and violence which began around 1910. During this time, organizations such as the NAACP, or the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and the National Urban League, and the Nation of Islam were developed in order to help accommodate the new blacks in the north.
fields.title: Demographic Changes

fields.content: •Booker T Washington: Born a slave, and he encouraged blacks to work hard in order to obtain eventual economic equality, although he did not expect or believe blacks would have equal social standing to whites.•Du Bois: He was not born a slave. but rather free born, and he founded the NAACP and thought blacks shoo;d strive to attain total equality.•Marcus Garvey : He was from America and his leadership was widely supported ordinary African Americans.
fields.title: Major African American Leaders

fields.content:
Theodore Roosevelt gained the title of "Trustbuster", for the way he strictly enforced the Sherman Antitrust Act and brought over forty lawsuits to collaboration of businesses that were along the lines of violating the act. Under his administration, Congress also passed the Pure Food and Drug Act, as well as th Elkins and HepBurn Act which fortified the Interstate Commerce Commission. Roosevelt was also a powerful leader in the conservation movement, especially when he canceled the sale of 200 million acres of public land and established the Inland Waterways Commission.

The Taft Administration and Domestic Economics

The Dingley Tariff of 1897 was still under effect during Taft's presidency, and Republicans normally supported high tariffs, although more and more high tariffs were being blamed for the increase in prices. Taft said he would reduce tariffs, so he signed the Payne-Aldrich Tariff because it lowered certain rates, althought it raised many others. He signed it mainly to get other legislation passed that he wanted to be passed.
fields.title: Roosevelt's Regulation of Business of and Land

fields.content:
The split in the Republican Party and the formation of the progressive party was linked to Richard Ballinger, an official under Taft who reopnened the sales for certain land that Roosevelt previously closed. He was muckraked by a forester for certain corrupt activity, although Ballinger was found to be innocent of these. The forester, Pinchot, was then fired by Taft, angering progresives and causing the split of the Republican party in the Porgressive Party.

The Election of 1912

The Progressive Party, also known ad the Bull-Moose Party, elected Theodore Roosevelt, who ran against the Republican candidate Taft and the Democratic candidate, Woodrow Wilson. Due to the split of the Republican Party, Wilson won the election of 1912 and became the next president of the United States.

The Wilson Administration
fields.title: The Republican Party Splits

fields.content: Under Wilson, a new lower tariff known as the Underwood-Simmons tariff of 1913 was passed despite a locked debate in the Senate.
fields.title: Tariffs

fields.content: Also during the Woodrow Wilson Administration, Congress established the Aldrich Commission to keep an eye on the flow and amount of money because of the Panic of 1907 that foreclosed banks. The Commission stated that there were numerous reasons for reform in the banking system, and in response, Wilson enacted the Federal Reserve Act that would enable banks to be more flexible with their money and be able to receive temporary money during a crisis. The Act also set up the Federal Reserve Bank that would be run by a "Board of Governors".
fields.title: The Regulation of Banks

fields.content: Wilson also made efforts to regulate big business through passing the Clayton Antitrust Act as well as his creation of the Federal Trade Commission. This allowed for the investigation of business for illegal practices as well as the ability for the government to dissolve businesses that were convicted of poor and unmoral marketing practices.
fields.title: The Regulation of Business
Readmitting the Confederate States to the Union

fields.content: Lincoln had to think of a way to readmit Confederate states that were previously in rebellion back to the union.  He came up with the following plan. The Union would readmit any states that had at least 10% of the voters in that state take the oath of allegiance to the Union and accept the freedom of slaves. Due to the way the requirement for readmission to the union mandating an oath of allegiance from 10% of voters in the state, this idea of Lincoln's was known as the ten percent plan.
fields.title: Ten Percent Plan

fields.content:
Congress though that Lincoln's Ten Percent Plan was being too lax on state readmission and that the plan would make it easy for a state that got readmitted to be completely controlled by ex-Confederates and sectionalists. They proposed another bill that they thought would make for a stricter, loyal, and not sectionalist reconstructed state. The bill was called the Wade-Davis bill and would plan to readmit states that had at least half of the citizens of their states to have taken an oath of allegiance to the Union as well as to only permit non Confederate affiliated officials to draw up the new state constitution. Lincoln pocket vetoed the bill

The Presidency of Johnson
fields.title: Wade-Davis Bill

fields.content: Lincoln was assassinated in 1865, and afterward Vice President Johnson was appointed to the office of the presidency.
fields.title: Lincoln's Assassination

fields.content: Johnson was originally from the South, and was a white supremacist who though the war was necessary to preserve the Union. Because of this, Johnson often clashed with the propositions and ideas of the radical republican Congress. Jackson lost even more support from Congress when he vetoed a bill that would allow the Black Codes in the south.
fields.title: Johnson's Origins and Beliefs

fields.content: By 1865, all of the 11 states that had seceded from the Union had rejoined the Union while ratifying the freedom of slaves under the Thirteenth Amendment. There were also some old Confederate leaders that held government positions such as in Congress. Southern states allowed adopted black codes that would limit the rights and abilities of the newly freed slaves in the south. Some examples of the black codes were the way blacks were prohibited to purchase land or even sue a white in court.
fields.title: Reconstruction Progression

fields.content: Jackson gave a series of speeches where he gave explanations as to why it would be a bad idea to give completely equal rights to blacks and what kind of society that would make. Republicans in Congress were angered and retaliated by accusing Jackson of being an unintelligible traitor and they raised a rally with an action known as "waving the bloody shirt" to gain support among Northerners to remind them of all the blood that was shed to win the war.
fields.title: Further Opposition to Jackson in Congress

fields.content:
Freedman's Bureau

The Freedmen's Bureau was set up by the federal government in order to help blacks that were jobless. The Bureau. It tried to give blacks southern lands that were taken by the Union during the war. It also helped build schools for these southern blacks and taught them to read.
fields.title: The Protection of Blacks Through Legislation

fields.content: Congress attempted to protect free blacks from the oppression and discrimination they were faced with under the Black codes in the South. They tried doing this by passing Civil Rights Act of 1866 which made all blacks in the United States U.S. citizens. The legislation was only a temporary protection because it could be repealed if a southern majority ever existed in Congress. Congress obtained its permanent solution by passing the fourteenth amendment which made all people that were born or naturalized in the U.S. citizens of the nation. The amendment also extended all rights and protections of U.S. citizens to those persons. The fourteenth amendment also limited the political influence of the south by not allowing ex-Confederates to hold state or federal government official positions.
fields.title: The Civil Rights Act of 1866

fields.content: Congress also passed the fifteenth amendment amendment which ultimately extended voting rights to all blacks and denied the states' ability to withheld any citizen that right for any reason.
fields.title: The 15th Amendment
Congress Puts Pressure on the South and Jackson

fields.content: Congress also passed the Tenure of Office Act over Johnson's veto which made it illegal for the president to remove any government official without the consent of Congress. Johnson disobeyed the Act by firing a radical republican official, the Secretary of War Edwin Stanton. Upon this act, the House impeached Johnson, and the Senate tried him, but the vote was just one vote short of removing Johnson from office.
fields.title: Johnson's Impeachment

fields.content: The Republican candidate and war hero, Ulysses S. Grant, won the presidential election in 1868.
fields.title: The Election of 1868

fields.content: This Act promoted and granted social equality in public places for all people including African Americans, although policy was poorly enforced and made hardly any impact. Eight years later, the Act was declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court.
fields.title: The Civil Rights Act of 1875

fields.content: Republicans also took control of southern states while they were under military control to ensure that they met the requirements for reconstruction. Eventually, the Republicans were withdrawn from the states. These southern Republicans were detested by native southerners and were called scalawags, while southerners called people who moved North "carpetbaggers".
fields.title: Republicans in the South

fields.content: The newly emancipated slaves often lived in communities together with their family, or they moved to frontier states or northern cities where they would be less serrated by the rest of the population. Blacks also made an effort to educate themselves and their future generations. Blacks established many churches, most commonly Baptist or Methodist after leaving the white dominated ones. Freed blacks also commonly became sharecroppers where they would work a farmer's land in return for a piece of their own land to harvest.
fields.title: Freed Blacks in the South

fields.content: Grants administration was known for the political corruption that was common under his presidency. There were multiple large and well-known scandalous incidents that occurred during the time.
fields.title: Corruption

fields.content: Stock experts gave advice to members of Congress in order to cover up they way they were taking advantage of their own insider knowledge to make market decisions.
fields.title: Credit-Mobilier Affair

fields.content: A scandalous conspiracy that included the diversion of tax money from liquor companies to federal revenue agents.
fields.title: Whiskey Ring

fields.content: In local governments, there were political machines that brought corruption to cities, with William Tweed, known as Boss Tweed, being the most notorious political boss in New York City. He stole large amounts of money with his political machine known as the "Tweed Ring" from taxpayers.
fields.title: Boss Tweed

fields.content: The Republican party nominated Grant again, while the Democrats and the liberal Republicans nominated Horace Greeley, who died, granting Grant the reelection.
fields.title: The Election of 1872

fields.content: Overbuilding and too much growth in industry led to an economic depression in 1873 known as the Panic of 1873. Grant later gave in to the advice of banker and attempted to resolve the crisis by printing additional greenbacks.
fields.title: The Panic of 1873

fields.content: White Supremacy was widespread in the 1870s, when the Ku Klux Klan was at a high level of power. The KKK was an organization founded by an ex-Confederate general who promoted the use of terror tactic to frighten freed blacks in the south from exercising and using their own rights. The tactics often included violence, and the government stepped in to help prevent the violence in 1870 with the Force Acts.
fields.title: The Persecution of Blacks in the South

fields.content: In the election of 1876, the republicans elected Rutherford B. Hayes while the Democrats nominated Samuel j. Tilden. The electoral votes were very close, with Tilden only needing one more electoral vote from three last contested states in order to win the election. A special counting committee was organized to decide which candidate would receive the final electoral votes from the states. The committee gave all the votes to the Republican, Hayes, which angered the Democrats and caused the necessary implementation of the Compromise of 1877. The Compromise arranged that Hayes would be president, the building of a transcontinental railroad in the south would be supported, and the support of Republicans in the south would cease.
fields.title: The Election of 1876

fields.content:
In the South, freed slaves were granted the right to vote by the 15th amendment, although the South use other methods that didn't go against the 15th amendment directly in order to prevent blacks from voting. Common examples of such tactics included:

•The Grandfather Clause

•Literacy tests

\u2022Property Qualifications.
fields.title: Barriers Between Blacks and Voting

fields.content: Jim Crow Laws were also in effect in the south that caused segregation between blacks and whites in public facilities. The Ruling in Plessy v. Ferguson, declared that "separate but equal" public accommodations were constitutional, thus ending any hopes for a quick fix to segregation in the near future. The NAACP helped blacks hold onto their rights in the midst of the discrimination that they were facing. African Americans responded by living in their own established communities among each other that placed a high amount of significance on church.
fields.title: Segregation

fields.content:
The South by the 1890s had improved its economic state greatly since its state of ruin after the civil war. Cotton production increased, and also the increase in the amount of railroad tracks in the land promoted the rapid growth of business and industry in the South that had not existed before.

'.
fields.title: Economic Advancement in the South

fields.content: The cut in loans to Allies as well as higher tariffs made farmers suffer an economic blow in the 1920s, although earlier on in the decade they also benefited and prospered. Surpluses also had an impact on farmers, although Congress established the Farm Board in order to buy such surpluses from the farmers.
fields.title: Trouble for Farmers

fields.content: There was a significant amount of corruption in the economy and politics during the 1920s. One of the most significant scandals, known as the Teapot Dome Scandal, occurred when the officials under the Harding administration bribed people to a company to drill for oil on a land that was reserved and it was illegal to drill on at the time.
fields.title: Corruption in Business and Government

fields.content: African Americans began to express their culture through many ways, including music, especially jazz which combined elements of music from American, African, and European music, making the 1920s also known as the jazz age. After the great migration, there were some areas in cities that were almost entirely populated by blacks, such as Harlem, which was the main site of the black cultural and artistic movement known as the Harlem Renaissance.
fields.title: African-American Culture

fields.content: The 18th amendment which enacted prohibited was a difficult law to enforce because many Americans disagreed with the law and found ways to get around it through smuggling systems such as bootlegging, which was a term used to describe the underground trafficking of alcohol during the time that it was . Congress the Volstead Act, which would have enforced the 18th amendment. The amendment and Prohibition was repealed by the 21st amendment in 1933.
fields.title: Prohibition and Its End

fields.content: After world war 1, legislation was passed to restrict immigration starting with the Immigration Restriction Act in 1921 and the National Origins Act in 1924. The laws were passed with the purpose of lowering the amount of immigrants from Asia and southern Europe.
fields.title: Immigration

fields.content: The Ku Klux Klan was once again on the rise, while this time they persecuted more groups of people, mainly religious sects were added to their list, including Catholics and Jews.
fields.title: The Second Rise of the Ku Klux Klan

fields.content: In this race, the Democratic candidate, Al Smith, was a catholic, and he ran against the Republican Herbert Hoover. For reasons such as not being from a rural background and also being Catholic, Al Smith lost the widespread of southern Democrats, costing him the election and making Herbert Hoover the next president of the United States.
fields.title: The Election of 1928
Addressing Weaknesses of the Articles of Confederation

fields.content: At the Annapolis Convention in 1785, it was agreed to revise the Articles in an attempt to fix some of the problems it posed for the new nation and its overly weak government at another convention. That convention was held in Philadelphia with over fifty delegates present, and it was decided that a new document was needed to frame the government properly.
fields.title: The Annapolis Convention

fields.content: Although the initial intention for the Philadelphia Convention was just to revise the Articles of Confederation in Philadelphia, the delegates soon realized a new document was necessary. The meetings to create this new constitution were held secretly and secluded from the public in Philadelphia with George Washington as chairperson.
fields.title: The Philadelphia Convention
Critical Topics During the Drafting of the Constitution

fields.content: The delegates from different states disagreed on the method to decide the amount of representation each state would receive in Congress. The debate mainly circled two main ideas: the New Jersey Plan and the Virginia Plan.
fields.title: Representation

fields.content: Favored by smaller states, it proposed the idea of giving all states an equal amount of state representatives in Congress.
fields.title: The New Jersey Plan

fields.content: Favored by larger states, it proposed the idea of giving states an a number of state representatives in Congress that would be proportional to the population of the state with a higher state population assigning a higher number of representatives.
fields.title: The Virginia Plan

fields.content: This idea for representation was a combination of the two previously mentioned plans for representation. It would establish a bicameral legislature, with one house of Congress granted equal represenation with the other house granting state representation based on population.
fields.title: The Great Compromise

fields.content: It was decided that when determining a state's population in order to grant a state the appropriate number of representatives, all slaves would only count as 3/5 of a person.
fields.title: Three Fifths Compromise
the Ratification and Acceptance of the Constitution

fields.content: James Madison, George Washington, Alexander Hamilton,  and others supporters of the Constitution, most typically merchants,  were known as the Federalists: they wanted the constitution to grant the central more power than it was previously given by the Articles of Confederation.
fields.title: Federalists

fields.content: James Madison, who was also referred to as the "Father of the Constitution" lead the writing of 85 persuasive essays to convince the necessity of ratifying the new constitution.
fields.title: The Federalist Papers

fields.content: Patrick Henry, John Hancock, and other people that opposed the constitution were the Anti-Federalists. They feared that power the Constitution granted the central government would allow a reutrn of the tyranny that the colonists experienced under the rule of Britain. They were concerned with the states rights, and they felt a Bill of Rights in the Constitution would be necessary. Anti-federalists mainly consisted of farmers rather than merchants.
fields.title: Anti-Federalists

fields.content: After the raitification of the Constitution, the heated debate regarding whether or not to add a Bill of Rights in order to protect the rights of individuals continued, with Anti-Federalists strongly in favor. There were reasons that made it seem like a Bill of Rights wasn't even necessary, for all state constitutions had a Bill of Rights included, and there were also certain rights listed in the Articles of the actual constitution. A bill of Rights was finally added in 1791 and were the first ten amendments.
fields.title: Bill of Rights

fields.content: The opening statement at the beginning of the Constitution was called the Preamble.
fields.title: Preamble

fields.content: The Constitution consisted of seven articles that listed the powers designated to the legislative, executive, and judicial branch of government. The articles also included statement about the document being the supreme law of the land as well as the processes for ratifying and amending the document.
fields.title: Seven Articles

fields.content: The amendment are listed at the end of the Consitution, with the Bill of Rights comprising the first ten amendments.
fields.title: Amendments
Key Concepts of Government Implemented the Constitution

fields.content: The legislative, executive, and judicial branches of government were established in an effort to spread out the power of government, so that one official or branch of government wouldn't become too powerful, and since each branch's power was kept in check by the power of the others, there was less of a chance for corruption to occur.
fields.title: Three Branches of Government and Checks and Balances

fields.content: In a similar fashion that the three ranches of government checked each other's powers, there was also a balance of power between the central government and the states. The idea of there being such a distribution in power is known as federalism and is a key principle that the United States Constitution was founded on.
fields.title: Federalism and Limited Government
The Growth and Culture of Cities

fields.content: Many American were moving toward the urban areas that were concentrated in the Northeast and away from their farms. Americans usually moved from rural to urban societies if their farms were not doing well, or they were unable to compete with the commercial level of production that was becoming common on cars due to additional technology and machinery.
fields.title: Changing Demographics

fields.content: Poor immigrants in the city tended to live in the slums and cramped apartments downtown that became to known as tenements. The majority of immigrants that came to United states in the late 1800s were from Eastern and Southern Europe. This was unlike the old immigrants that mainly consisted of british, Irish, and German immigrants. the newer immigrants were from countries such as Italy, Poland, Russia, Slovakia, Greece, and Croatia. The majority of the immigrants who came from these countries during this time went to the city because of economic crises, market declinations, political reasons, or religious persecution. Political bosses or ward leaders of a city were often of the first people who an immigrant family would meet; and he would generally help them with finding a job or do them other favors in return for their promise to vote for him in the next election. This was one of the main factors that made it possible for political bosses to retain their power despite the corruption that ensued under them. As stated in a previous chapter, political bosses would completely dominated local politics and would also decide who would run for their party in certain office elections. Political Bosses would conduct schemes such as stealing money from taxpayers, and the most notorious was Boss Tweed of New York who was finally exposed by the artist Thomas Nast. The technology of cable cars as well as the use of horse driven carriages also made it possible to commute across the city.
fields.title: Immigrants

fields.content:
•Pollution

•Lack of light - Solved emerging technology in illuminations as wells Thomas Edison's lightbulbs

•Communication - Solved by emerging technology of the telegraph and also the telephone.
fields.title: Problems With Urbanization

fields.content: Young educated individuals attempted to learn about the problems of poor working immigrants families and attempting to improve their conditions through experimental housing projects. Jane Addams started the Hull House in Chicago in 1889. The Hull House helped educate immigrants and provide them adequate living conditions. About twenty years later after the construction and success of the Hull House, there were hundreds of settlement houses distributed across American cities.
fields.title: Settlement Houses

fields.content: The majority of European immigrants that came to cities in the late 1800 were Roman Catholic, causing the Roman Catholic Churches in America to gain significant followers and support.
fields.title: Religion
The Buildup to Entering World War I

fields.content:
In the early years of World War 1, Wilson declared America's neutrality in the war. Although the United States was officially declared neutral, most Americans sympathized with the Allies, including Britain and France, rather than Germany. The United States had and economic interest in the war and traded goods with Britain and France with their neutral merchant ships. The United States' neutrality was not completely respected, and both the British and Germans harassed American merchant ships. The German submarines, known U-boats, were infamous for the way they sunk enemy merchant ships on sight, and because the British sometimes flew the American flag on their ships to the fool the Germans, the Germans were forced into acting aggressively toward American merchant ships in most cases.

The Sinking of the Lusitania

The German U-boat harassment of American merchant ships made Americans frustrated with the Germans as it was, although their opposition for the Germans in the war was further elevated after German U-boats sunk a British passenger ships called The Lusitania in 1916, killing over 120 American passengers on board. After the incident, the Germans agreed to ensure the safety of he passengers on the ship that was sunk. The Germans also made other actions to restrict the tactics used in aggression to foreign ships, although such restriction were raised once the war situation was far against the favor of the Germans in 1917. The previous German change of action further pushed the prospect of the United States joining the war, which the Germans knew although they hoped to end the war before that could happen. Wilson won reelection on the slogan "He Kept Us Out of War", although he even allowed for the beginning of a mild military preparedness program to facilitate the United States joining the war if necessary in 1915.
fields.title: America and Neutrality

fields.content: The final straw that ultimately made the U.S. join the war was an intercepted message sent by Germany that was intended for Mexico to read, stating that they wanted their support in the war effort against Britain and France and that if they comied, Germany would help Mexico take back some of the territory it lost to the United States. Unrestricted submarine warfare was also at its peak at the time, giving all the more reason for the U.S. to join the war out of its extreme frustration. In 1917, Wilson officially declared war on Germany, and the United States began to mobilize in the war effort. The War Industries Board was established to handle the trade of war goods for the Allies, and a draft was issued in order to collect the necessary amount of troops.
fields.title: The Zimmerman Note
World War I and Post-War Events

fields.content:
After the Russians had to withdraw their effort in the war against Germany with the Allies after the Bolshevik Revolution and rise of the Communist Party, the Germans were then able to solely focus on fighting on the west side with Britain, France, and the U.S. The Germans unrestricted submarine warfare was having the intended effect on the Allies, and in response the U.S. began a vast project of ship construction. The American troops which numbered in the hundreds of thousands later in the war, were under the command of General John Pershing, and were able to withstand the final German offensive in the late years of the war and practically ensure a victory for the Allies. The peace conference at the end of the war made Wilson anxious to bring up his fourteen point plan, which included the following concepts:

•Freedom of the seas

•Minimization of tariffs and similar trade barriers.

•An end to secret diplomacy

•A reduction in military buildups in order to secure and ensure domestic safety

•An adjustment of colonial claims

•Evacuation of foreign troops in other countries from the war

•Certain government adjustments in foreign European nations

•An establishment of a collaborative world organization that would promote peace and reduce the risk of another future world war. That organization was to be called the League of Nations.
fields.title: War With Germany and Victory

fields.content: Wilson went to the peace conference in Paris to propose and win approval for his fourteen point plan, although the rest of ht nations from the Allies were primarily concerned with revenge and dividing up territory from the lands they had defeated, while Wilson's focus was peace and the prevention of another such war in the future. Wilson's fourteen points were ignored for the most part, although he did win approval for the League of Nations. The Allies also agreed to make Germany pay a large sum in reparations, that would lead to their future economic depression and crisis which would put them in a desperate state for new leadership that would be granted by Adolf Hitler who would start World War 2.
fields.title: Peace Conference in Paris

fields.content: Wilson returned the United States with the Treaty of Versailles, which was widely criticized by Americans and politicians, especially Wilson's political Republican nemesis, Henry Cabot Lodge for its unjust conditions placed on Germany as well as the other Central Powers. Wilson's League of Nations was also criticized and viewed as a tool used by Wilson for reelection to a third term in 1918 while the League's actions wouldn't remotely serve the interests of the United States. Wilson strongly fought off all criticisms, and in his tour of speeches around the nation in order to rally support for his League of Nations, he was forced to retire his effort because of a stroke and health conditions. The Senate did not ratify the Treaty of Versailles twice and instead negotiated a separate treaty with the defeated Central Powers.
fields.title: Wilson's Opposition in the U.S.

fields.content:
After the war, there was a widespread fear in America of the rise of the radical communists in Russia after the Bolshevik Revolution. Americans feared that there were similar radicals in the United States that would overtake the government. During the scare, Attorney General Mitchell Palmer accused multiple Americans and government officiasl of having affiliation with the communists party, and many of the suspected were jailed despite a large lack of evidence. Since their was such a lack of evidence for these individuals convictions, they were eventually released. The size and magnitude of the Red Scare was further expanded by the rise of labor unions after the war. The labor unions at the time were effectively using tactics known as collective bargaining, which entailed a group of employees negotiating with their employees about conditions or other requests. However, as time went on, the relationship between businesses and workers became worse due to the elevation of prices in goods while worker's wages stayed the same. This triggered many strikes that spread across the nation, giving labor unions a bad reputation, and also making Americans to see them in a more unpatriotic or un-American light.

'.
fields.title: The Red Scare

fields.content: Roosevelt's Good Neighbor Policy was a way of him trying to gain support of nations that would be allies should war come. In the process the United States' role as the interferer of Latin American affairs and the Roosevelt corollary was no longer in effect.
fields.title: Good Neighbor Policy

fields.content: The United States passed a series of Neutrality Acts in 1935 which did not allow the United States to export weapons to nations that declared themselves in aggression. An embargo on certain nations could also be allowed, making that nation have to come to American ports to get their goods, although these policies did not differentiate between hostile and friendly nations.
fields.title: The U.S. And Neutrality

fields.content:
Europe and France tried to avert going to war with German by giving Hitler what he wanted in granting Germany the part of Czechoslovakia that was populated by many Germans. Instead, Hitler took advantage of their proposal and took that part of the nation and eventually had all of Czechoslovakia under his control.

Germany was taking aggressive action on not only Czechoslovakia, but other nations along with help Italy and Japan. These three nations became known as the Axis Powers.
fields.title: Further German Aggression

fields.content: Roosevelt made deals with Great Britain known as the destroyer deal and the Lend-Lease, where he gave 50 world war 1 destroyers to Britain in order to be able to build military equipment and weapons for the Britain and France on British land. This deal was made after France and Britain declared war on the axis powers.
fields.title: U.S. Cooperation With the Allies

fields.content: Roosevelt and Winston Churchill of England signed the Atlantic Charter which clarified what the nations wanted out of the war, the charter included the destruction of the Nazi Party and territorial conditions. The charter also clarified that then nations wanted what what known as the Four Freedoms: freedom from war, freedom from fear, freedom from the want of seas and the freedom of the seas.
fields.title: The Atlantic Charter

fields.content: Further Japanese aggresion prompted Roosevelt to cut off oil shipments to Japan, which greatly frustrated and crippled Japan. Japan then prepared to attack the United States, and the U.S. anticipated such an attack from intercepting messages and cracking the Japanese code, but warnings were not heeded in time.The Japanese then attacked and bombed the United States at Peal Harbor on December 7, 1941.
fields.title: Pearl Harbor

fields.content:
The Contribution of Women

The United States then mobilized its forces and began a draft. African Americans were still segregated while they set served in the military, and women played an increasingly key role in the economy as they substituted in for many of the jobs that men previously occupied while they were drafted overseas. The amount of women in the workforce increased by about 33% during the war, although their wages were still lowered compared to those received by men.

Internment

Shortly after the mobilization of the United States, about one hundred thousand Japanese Americans, most of which were born in the U.S., were moved to Japanese internment due to the fear of the Japanese in America helping with the Japanese war effort.

Demographic Shifts

During the war, the birthrate rose due to many men marrying before they were drafted overseas to fight in the war. Also, the demographics changed as people moved to find work in areas that were bustling in the type of industry that built war goods. The state that gained the most people during this shift was California, being home to many large shipyards and factories for war materials.

Minorities

During the war, African Americans, Hispanics, and Native Americans also became more involved in the workforce. They moved to cities to find work in the industry, although lower wages for these workers created reason for argument, and discrimination also peaked in violence, notably the Zoot Suit Riots that involved Hispanic workers.

Segregation and Reform in the Industry

African Americans began to get fed up with discrimination in the defense industry, and threatened a march on Washington if nothing was done. In response, Roosevelt issued Executive Order 8802 which demanded fairer treatment to all workers in the defense industry. The FEPC was also established at this time. His order did not aid African Americans that were serving in the military, or really do much to help with the improvement of treatment these workers received from their co-workers, although it did greatly affect the amount of jobs they were offered.
fields.title: Adjustments Back at Home

fields.content: The War Production Board oversaw the use of the of the nation's resources during the war, and it was also responsible for the conversion of assembly lines and factors to being able to produce war materials. The United States was able to pay for the war by the sale of war bonds as well as tax increases, although the war still greatly increased the national debt.
fields.title: Funding the War

fields.content:
Defeating the Germans

The United States first planned on fighting the Germans in Europe and defeating them there before shifting their attention to the Japanese in the Pacific. By 1944, The Allies had won in the North African Front, the Soviets, also part of the Allies, had driven Germany's offensive backward and became the offensive themselves, Italy had been invaded, and the large invasion of Europe on the Allies behalf, in a procedure known as Operation Overlord, took place in the summer of 1944. The invasion was a very bloody battles on the beach known as D-Day, with many lives lost to the intense machine gun fire. After the invasion, the Allies continued their offensive into Germany, Hitler committed suicide in May of 1945, and the Allies won the war.

Defeating the Japanese

With the Germans defeated and the war won in Germany, the United States then formed a strategy to defeat the Japanese in the Pacific. General Douglas MacArthur was in charge of leading the United States through their battle plan in the Pacific islands. The war in the islands was expected to drag on for a considerable amount of time. After failing to negotiate peace with Japanese militants, not so much the Emperor of Japan, the United States then attacked Japan with an atomic bomb on first the city of Hiroshima and then Nagasaki. The attack then forced the surrender of the Japanese. The surrender then brought the need for new policies and treaties to the table.
fields.title: U.S. War Strategy and Fighting the War

fields.content: The idea and plans for a new world wide alliance known as the United Nations to be formed was adopted by the U.S., Britain, USSR, and China at the Dumbarton-Oaks Conference in 1944.The Yalta Conference in 1945 agreed to divided up the militarized zones of Germany into four parts, and the eventual democracy of Poland with the Soviet government overseeing its development until the nation was on its feet. It also planned for a future conference to discuss the formal formation of the United Nations. Stalin also received authority and control of other territories that were involved in the war during the conference. At the Potsdam Conference in 1945, the occupation situation of Germany was figured out in depth. Most of Eastern Europe had been turned over to communism at the end of the conferences, and it was point used to criticize Roosevelt and his decisions and agreements made at those conferences. After the war, the United States had firmly established its role as a world superpower with the responsibility of keeping check on the world and promoting peace.
fields.title: Negotiations, Conferences, and Post-War Treaties

fields.content: The British Colonies in North America united against the British. The American colonies developed feelings of patriotism, became fed up with high British taxes and struggled to accept their lack of control over their own laws. The Enlightenment inspired Americans. A Declaration of Independence was written. America started winning battles against a highly trained army due to knowing the land better and British forces being too far away from supplies. After winning several battles, the French helped the Colonies to weaken Britain. The British decided the war was too costly and surrendered. The Americans disputed about how they should be governed. After much debate the Constitution was signed. A democratic-republic was created. The Constitution inspired many revolutions over the coming years.The United States stated they would not allow any country to take a colony in North America when they had power. It expanded from coast to coast. It took some land but bought most of it from France in the Louisiana Purchase. The Cotton Economy of the south kept the Atlantic Slave Trade running. A civil war was fought to get rid of slavery in the south. The United States was one of the few countries open to immigrants. The United States industrialized extremely fast. It overtook European nations. US innovation spread overseas.
fields.title: American Revolution

fields.content: Canada was still loyal to Britain. Some small revolts took place. The British did not want to deal with another revolutionary war so the gave Canada its own constitution and parliament. Britain still controlled foreign affairs.
fields.title: Canada

fields.content: Haiti was inspired by the successful American and French Revolutions. French Haiti was confused during the French Revolution. As the French poor gained better conditions the slaves thought they too were entitled to freedom. The French did not want this for Haiti. The French fought the Rebels, but lost due to yellow fever. Frustrated the French sold the Louisiana purchase to the US. Haiti suffered due to it having no friendly countries. The US didn't want to associate because the southern states feared it would inspire their slaves to rebel.
fields.title: Haiti

fields.content: Simon Bolivar was educated in enlightenment ideals. Bolivar Swept across Venezuela, Bolivia Ecuador and Colombia. Imperial powers were cleared out of South America. The Reagent of Brazil made it a constitutional monarchy with him in charge.Mexico wanted its independence. However, it had competing classes. It quickly escalated into a three way war between the lower class, the upper class and Spain. A dictatorship was established but quickly removed from power. A republic was put in place.Bolivar wanted to unite the nations into one union like the US. This was never achieved. Dictators quickly took control of the continent. Representative government disappeared.The economy of these nations was greatly slowed by only having one main good. Only a select few profited. Many were extremely poor. Other countries mainly the United States exerted dominance through investing. The United States built the Panama Canal to profit.Mexico had another revolution led by Pancho Villa. Many were killed. A populist government was almost put in place. Mexico ended up being a mild dictatorship.
fields.title: Latin America

fields.content: The earliest forms of worship tended to be asking and thanking spirits. Shamans aided the worship by healing of the sick, fortune telling, predicting weather trends, assisting in prayer or keeping taboo items out of the society. Spirit worship was still practiced in some advanced societies like Shintoism in Japan. Many spirit worshipping cultures believed in honoring their ancestors spirit. Proper burial was important in honoring ancestors. Syncretism, the blending of new and old religions, tended to leave imprints in modern Religions like Christianity and Hinduism.
fields.title: Spirit Worship

fields.content: Judaism was the first monotheistic religion. The Hebrew people believed they were descended from a man, Abraham, who made a covenant or promise with God. The Jewish people were conquered by many different early empires. Hebrews were torn from their land and their temples were torn down. The Jews were one of the few groups to keep their cultural identity after having been conquered. Rather than being assumed by the empire's culture they rejected paganism. After being oppressed for so long Jews came to hope for a savior for that would one day free them. This idea was somewhat ironicRabbis acted as leaders of the religious community. Judaism was the first religion to have a set scripture in the Torah. This religion had set rules in the Ten Commandments, which is thought to have been influenced by the Code of Hammurabi. Dietary restrictions were in place. Like most early religions, Judaism led to a patriarchal societies.
fields.title: Judaism

fields.content: The religion dominating South Asia up until 700 BCE was Vedism, which required people to follow brahmins' (priests') orders unquestioningly and receive sacraments that only brahmins could perform. The spread of written language led to a belief that the people themselves had a say over their religious experience. Vedism was not ever rejected but gradually change into a larger belief system, Hinduism.Hinduism has three main gods: Brahma (the world), Vishnu (the preserver) and Shiva (the destroyer). Due to syncretism, Hinduism came to include many gods and goddesses. Local villages would only accept Hinduism if their deity was accepted into Hinduism.There is a belief in reincarnation. By observing all rules one would be born into a higher status life and eventually escape the cycle of reincarnation. The idea of Karma (one would be rewarded for doing good in life and punished for doing bad in the next life) was derived from Vedism. The concept of Karma led to a strict Caste system, including a class that were forced to complete tasks that made them unclean.
fields.title: The Transition Into Hinduism
