fields.content: Liberal leaders wanted much more change and traditional communists very upset about the changes Gorbachev made. The Eastern European freedom encouraged anti-Soviet thought in the USSR itself. Hard-line communists staged a revolt. Common people prevented this. The Union broke up and Gorbachev resigned.
fields.title: Breakup of the Soviet Union

fields.content: The Ottoman Empire new that is was not innovating at the rate of other countries. Some sultans would try to reform, but many powerful groups were opposed to any change. One of these groups were the janissary warriors. They refused to learn new tactics or incorporate new technology. They had enough influence to prevent any change from occurring. The janissaries even assassinated a sultan who was trying to reform the empire. Some modernization took place: scientific knowledge was encouraged, religion played less of a role in government and a European style military was formed.The Tanzimat Reforms brought about more change. Women were given opportunities to be educated, the empire began to practice religious tolerance, schools began teaching western science. A telegraph service and postal service were established.The empire deteriorated further due to rebellions and the power of other European nations. The Greek waged a war of independence. Because of their Christian faith the other nations of Europe came to their aid. The Ottomans lost and gave up Greece. Muhammed Ali led rebellions in north Africa. Ali Modernized Egypt by giving it a military and encouraged the growing of cotton.The Young Turks led a coup. They seized control and put a representative government in control. They allied themselves with the Germans. The Italians began seizing Ottoman territory.
fields.title: Decay of the Ottoman Empire

fields.content: European nations did not want to see any nation gain more power due to the fall of the Ottoman Empire. The nations wanted its collapse to be slow and not allow for any new formidable enemy to take its place. European nations aided the Ottoman Empire against Muhammad Ali. Britain and France aided the Ottoman Empire against the Russians in the Crimean War. Balkan states revolted and almost destroyed the empire. At the Congress of Berlin the states were granted independence.England and France disputed over the Suez Canal. Britain had most of the shares in the company that owned the canal. Eventually Britain militarily intervened to keep control. A rebellion was led to take the territory back and the British easily overcame it.
fields.title: European Balance of Power

fields.content: Britain extended influence over Persia after finding it had oil reserves. Russia took parts of Persia. It was divided into spheres of influence. Central Asia was mostly taken by Russia in trying to get a warm water port.
fields.title: Persia and Central Asia

fields.content: The Papacy granted all of the new world, bar Brazil, to Spain. The Spanish had unprecedented in taking control of the new world. European diseases killed between one-fourth and one-half of the native population. Europeans had horse that the Native populations had no idea how to fight against. Spanish swords were much better crafted and it showed in battle. Guns aided the Spanish as well. Some civilizations thought that the Spanish were the god Quetzalcoatl and were afraid to fight them. The Spanish made deals pitting some civilizations against each other. Cortes conquered the Aztec Empire. Pizarro destroyed the Incan Empire. The House of Trade in Spain ran all colonial economic activity. Silver and Sugar were exported in bulk. This new wealth allowed Spain to become the most powerful nation at the time. The Spanish started the encomienda system of forcing natives to be citizens and to work. This was replaced with the slave trade as natives were dying to easily and Catholic Clergy (like Bartolome de Las Casas) protested using natives as labor. There was a rigid social structure. Those born in Spain were known as Peninsulares and at the top. Creoles (Spanish decent but born in the new world) were next, followed by mixed race. Native Ancestry was at the bottom of the social structure.
fields.title: Spanish Colonization

fields.content: Brazil was given to Portugal. Natives were at the mercy of the Portuguese. Many were forced to convert to Catholicism. Sugarcane was grown in plantations.
fields.title: Brazil

fields.content: The Dutch seized several islands and a portion of Brazil. The Dutch made a deal with a local tribe to get the island of Manhattan. A trading post known as New Amsterdam was built. The English took the colony and named it New York.
fields.title: Dutch Influence

fields.content: The English had a colony, Jamestown. Religious minorities settled to avoid persecution. Raw Materials were taken from the colonies and sent to England. English Colonies were the only ones encouraged to be permanent settlements. The Colonies each had separate local governments. To get to America colonists would agree to work as slaves for a set number of years to pay for their voyage.
fields.title: English Colonization

fields.content: The French made some settlements across Canada and along the Mississippi. The French were interested in trading for fur. After the loss in the French and Indian War, the English took Canada and Spain got the territory in Louisiana.
fields.title: French Colonization

fields.content: In the Columbian Exchange the world was transformed. The New World was introduced to horses, cows, sheep, and pigs. Coffee was found to flourish in South America. Cotton, Tobacco and Sugarcane were also give to the Americas. Corn and Potatoes had significant influence of AfroEurasia. Diseases from the old world devastated Native American Populations.
fields.title: Exchange

fields.content: Rival ambitions in creating empires created tension between European nations. Fights would frequently break out. Countries allied together in attempt to avoid conflict as countries would not want to fight two. Italy, Germany and Austria-Hungary Allied together. Britain, France and Russia allied together. Countries also had nationalism and believed they were the best. This led to further competition. Nations built up militaries to deter war although it had the exact opposite impact.Nations in the Balkans kept trying to achieve independence. Austria-Hungary would not allow this. In Bosnia, the nephew of the Archduke of Austria was assassinated. Austria said the only way they would not invade was if they submitted to ridiculous demands. Bosnia begged Russia for help. Russia felt compared as they shared common slavic culture. Russia declared war on Austria-Hungary. In turn that Led to Germany Declaring war on Russia, France and Britain. Italy realigned itself with Russia, France and Britain.
fields.title: The Cause

fields.content: Germany dreaded the idea of fighting a two front war. To avoid this they created the Schlieffen Plan. They would focus almost all their force on France immediately, hoping to take all of France within 6 weeks. To avoid the militarized French border the German Army went through the neutral Belgium. Belgium had some resistance and the Germans were unable to take France after suffering defeat at the Marne River.The Germans were then stuck fighting a two-front war. The Germans also gave the allied nations propaganda, as it had attacked a neutral nation. A stalemate quickly broke out on the western front as the defensive machine gun made it difficult to take ground. Trenches were dug to provide cover for soldiers. Virtually no territory changed hands for several years due to the trench warfare. Life in the trenches was scarring for soldiers. On the Eastern front Russia lost tons of land and many lives. By 1917, Russia was essentially defeated.Great Britain had an extremely powerful navy. It had many warships. It imposed a blockade upon Germany and its allies. Germany resorted to its submarines. Germany had no idea which ships were bringing weapons to the Allies, so it began a policy of unrestricted submarine warfare. Germany accidentally sunk a US passenger ship, the Lusitania. This gave the United States motivation to join the Allies.
fields.title: Shaping of the War

fields.content: Due to colonies around the world the war spread much further than Europe. France and Britain had troops stationed in Africa attempt to seize German colonies. The French brought Africans to fight in Europe. Canada, Australia, New Zealand and South Africa joined the Allies on behalf of Britain. Japan joined the allies and took German possessions in the pacific. In the Middle East, Australian and New Zealander troops tried to destroy the Ottoman empire in Gallipoli although it was mostly unsuccessful. Arab Princes were convinced to rise up against the Ottoman Empire and Essentially destroyed it.
fields.title: Global Developments

fields.content: To get the best army a nation could have nations had to get the civilian populations to contribute to the war effort. Nations had to ration food and metals. Drafts were put in place to increase military size. Civil liberties were put on hold; publications were censored to keep anti-war sentiment. Women took up jobs in factories, achieving more pay.
fields.title: Total War

fields.content: Due to the Russian Revolution, Russia surrendered seeding much of its land to Germany. Germany appeared as it would win the war as Britain was becoming resource deprived. The United States then joined the war. The Germans launched an offensive against Paris, reaching the Marne again. They were stopped by a multinational force. They went into retreat. The Axis Powers surrendered.
fields.title: End of the War

fields.content: The nations declared peace at the Paris Peace Conference. President Woodrow wilson had a list of fourteen points to ensure future peace. He campaigned for end of secret treaties, arms reduction, the end of imperialism, demilitarization, self-determination of all nations and the freedom of the seas. His biggest stress was a League of Nations, an organization to peacefully resolve conflict. The leaders of France and Britain simply wanted to punish Germany and they did by putting heavy reparations on Germany. Austria-Hungary was split into Austria and Hungary. Other territory became independent states. Italy received some of the territory it was promised, but not all which frustrated many. Britain and France were placed in charge of the middle east and were supposed to be preparing them for independence. A state for the Jewish was not created to avoid tension with the Muslim Population.Germany had to assume all blame for the war. Germany lost territory, such as Alsace and Lorraine. Germany was to remain demilitarized. German colonies were placed under allied ownership.
fields.title: Treaty

fields.content: Hitler's agression, nationalism, tension over the unfair Treaty of Versailles, alliances all led to the second world war. Hitler withdrew from the league of nation and started rebuilding the military. The Soviet Union and France feared German aggression and agreed to protect Poland and Czechoslovakia.Italy invaded Ethiopia, yet the League of Nations did nothing. Hitler took the Rhineland and nothing was done. Spain fell under the control of Fascists. Stalin tried to help the legitimate Spanish Government and became infuriated that France and Britain did not do the same.Japan aligned with Italy and Germany. Japan invaded China ruthlessly. Germany united with Austria, again violating the Treaty of Versailles. Hitler wanted to take the Sudetenland. Britain and France met with Hitler. They agreed to let Germany have the land in return for Hitler promising he wouldn't take any more territory. The Soviet Union became angry that it was left out of this decision. Germany then took the rest of Czechoslovakia, then Lithuania. Italy took Albania. Japan started fighting the Soviet Union on the borders. Stalin gave Hitler Poland and a non-aggression pact was formed.
fields.title: Causes of the War

fields.content: Airplanes and tanks changed the nature of war. No longer was defense superior. New artillery and bombers also made offensive strikes easier. As countries were more industrialized more arms were made. Radar and Sonar also change warfare.Germany realizing the advantage of new technology and dreading a two front war again decided to go on the offensive. The German Blitzkrieg allowed for Poland to be taken in weeks. Germany then moved to France. France had prepared it's border with the Maginot line. Germany went through Belgium and avoided it altogether. France and the rest of Western Europe surrendered early.
fields.title: New Warfare

fields.content: Germany was essentially only left with one immediate enemy. They focused all their military might on Britain. The Royal Navy blocked German attempts of an amphibious landing. Hitler sent waves of bombers to destroy Britain. Britain held out, due to radar and that citizens could hide in the subway beneath hundreds of feet of limestone. The United States gave aid to Britain, through the Lend-lease program. Hitler Became frustrated and temporarily gave up.
fields.title: Britain's Defense

fields.content: Hitler had to invade Greece and Yugoslavia as Mussolini had failed. Germany launched Operation Barbarossa, the invasion of the Soviet Union. Germany almost made it to Moscow but got stopped by a last ditch effort (which was celebrated with intense vodka drinking from the Ruskies).
fields.title: The Eastern Front

fields.content: Japan started attacking Western Colonial possessions. Japan took most of the Chinese coast and Indochina. The US stopped trading with Japan, which stunted its war effort. Japan bombed the US pearl harbor, bringing the US into the war.
fields.title: Japan

fields.content: Due to America and Russia's combined economies the longer the war lasted the more likely an allied victory became. Germany and Japan would have to severely cripple there remaining enemies to keep an advantage. Japan waged a large naval battle at Midway. The US won, destroying much of Japan's fleet, crippling the Axis powers. The British dealt a setback to Germany when tanks were stopped before they reached the Suez Canal. Russia was able to turn back the German advance at Stalingrad.German submarine fleets became less of a threat as sonar allowed for easy detection. British and American bombers could destroy much of Europe with minimal loss of troops. Britain and America used the North African territory they had taken to stage an invasion on mainland Europe. They knocked Italy out of the war and deposed Mussolini. An invasion of western Europe was planned. This invasion was known as D-day. Germany was now fighting a three front war. Hitler eventually committed suicide and Germany Surrendered.Japan had no way to win, but engrained in the culture was to not give up. Japan began tactics like Kamikaze pilots who would crash planes to destroy naval craft. To avoid loss of American lives, the United States deployed two nuclear bombs. Japan finally surrendered.
fields.title: Allied Strength

fields.content: Japanese soldiers had raped thousands of women and butchered civilians in their conquest of Asia. Japan had killed many prisoners of war. People were used for biological and chemical war subjects.Nazi war crimes were far worse. They used secret police and concentration camps to keep civilians obeying. They Euthanized those with disabilities or injuries.The Nazi's considered certain people to be undesirable. It was decided that certain groups were ethnically unacceptable. Jews and other groups were constantly harassed. The Holocaust soon ensued.Jews were forced to wear yellow stars, to show they were different. Many were taken and but in small cramped areas, known as ghettos. Some Jews were sent to concentration camps. Squads were sent to find and kill Jews after the army went through.Extermination camps became a reality. Jews from everywhere in Europe were caught and sent to camps. Approximately 6 million jews were killed.
fields.title: Crimes Against Humanity

fields.content: 'The Articles of Confederation formed a weak national government that had no powers to levy taxes, regulate interstate commerce, or defend itself.'
'A rebellion of farmers that proved to the Framers that a stronger central government was needed.'

'Created a bicameral legislature that provided a Senate with equal representation and a House of Representatives with representative proportional to population. This essentially solved the issue of representation during the Constitutional Convention.'
'A slave counted as three-fifths of a free person towards a state's population (used to determine representation in Congress).'
'The Constitution granted Congress the power to levy revenue taxes and regulate interstate commerce.'
'Understand the powers of the presidential veto, judicial review, and Senatorial confirmation of presidential appointments.'

'The Constitution has prohibited:
-Ex post facto laws
-Bills of attainder
-Religious qualifications to hold office
Additionally, it guarantees a writ of habeas corpus. '

'In order to protect the national government from a possibly fickle majority, the Constitution safeguarded the country with the following:

-Federal judges are appointed by the president and serve life terms.
-The president was not originally elected directly by the people.
-Senators were not originally elected by the people.
-Senators have staggered terms.'
'Papers written in support of the Constitution. James Madison wrote that political factions were inevitable.'

'An amendment of the Constitution can be proposed by two methods:
-A two-thirds vote in both the Senate and the House of Representatives
-A national convention assembled at the request of two-thirds of the state legislatures

An amendment of the Constitution can be ratified by two methods:
-Ratifying conventions in three-fourths of the states
-Three-fourths of the state legislatures'

'Quantity that has magnitude and direction'
'Quantity that has magnitude, but not direction'
'When you know the x and y components of a vector, the magnitude of this vector can be found through this equation (pythagorean theorem)

'With a vector, vector A and a constant k
  • A * k = kA which has the same direction as A, but different magnitude
With a vector, vector A and a negative constant -k
  • A * k = -kA which has the opposite direction as A and different magnitude
'

'With two vectors, A and B,
  • A + B = (Ax + Bx)i + (Ay + By)j
  • The tail of B goes on the tip of A
'

'With two vectors, A and B,
  • A - B = (Ax - Bx)i + (Ay - By)j
  • The tail of -B goes on the tip of A
'

'A system of government in which both the national and state levels have political authority.'

'Powers granted to the national government by the Constitution
eg:
-Levy taxes
-Regulate interstate commerce'
'Powers given to the national government by the elastic clause'
'Powers given to the states by the Tenth Amendment'
'Powers held by both the federal and state governments'

'-Increases political participation
-Prevents one body of government from getting too big
-Allows 'experimentation''

'National and state levels of government work together
-eg. interstate highway program'
'National and state levels of government have their own 'spheres of influence.''
'A system of federalism that favors devolution'

fields.title: 'Types of Grants from the National to the State Level'

fields.content:
'-Block grants have little restrictions, which supports devolution
-Categorical grants are for specific programs, which supports national supremacy
-Mandates are conditional requirements that the states must adhere to, which supports national supremacy '
'The Chief Justice ruled that the states cannot tax the national government because the national government is supreme to them.'
'The Supreme Court ruled that the federal government has the sole right to regulate interstate commerce.'
'The Supreme Court upheld this act because places of public accommodation inherently partake in interstate commerce, which is exclusively regulated by Congress.'

'-30+ years old
-Resident of state he represents
-American citizen for 9+ years'

'-Try impeachments
-Confirm presidential appointments
--Senators will follow the custom of senatorial courtesy, which means they won't confirm an appointment if any majority party senator from the state the appointee is to serve is opposed to the action.
-Ratify Treaties'

'-25+ years old
-Resident of state he represents
-American citizen for 7+ years'

'-Impeach U.S. officers
-Generate tax revenue bills
-Choose the president if no one receives a majority of electoral college votes'
'State legislatures use gerrymandering when redrawing congressional district lines in order to benefit the party in control.'

fields.title: 'Benefits of the Majority Party in both Houses'

fields.content:
'-Holds the chair and majority in each committee
-Assigns bills to committees
-Sets the agenda'

'Congress can:
-Amend the Constitution to make a law supreme over the land
-Override a veto
-War Powers Resolution Act forced the president to notify Congress within 2 days of deployment of troops
-Congressional oversight over executive agencies'

'-Select committees are temporary and created for a particular reason
-Standing committees are permanent
-Conference committees resolve differences between the houses about a bill
-Joint committees have members from both houses of Congress'
'Has the ability to generate tax revenue bills'
'Sets the rules for floor debate. The House floor is much stricter than the Senate floor.'
'Tool used in the Senate to stop the passage of a bill with an 'endless' speech. Requires 60 votes to be ended.'

'The president can veto by:
-Straight up vetoing a bill
-Not signing a bill for 10 days, and if Congress is adjourned by then, it's a pocket veto
Remember, line-item vetos for presidents are unconstitutional.'

'The president can appoint:
-Federal judges
-Cabinet members & heads of independent agencies
-Diplomats
He may remove all but federal judges and heads of independent agencies.'
'The president can deploy troops without approval of Congress.'
'The president can negotiate treaties, but often he just makes executive agreements.'
'The president may withhold information from Congress and the public.'
'The president may grant pardons to citizens.'

'-The most loyal members to the president
-Mainly manage the Oval Office'
'Overlooks the federal budget'

'-15 executive departments
-Members are often more loyal to their department than to the president.'

'Established the three level federal court system:
-District Courts
-Circuit Courts of Appeals
-The Supreme Court'

'-The Supreme Court can determine the constitutionality of federal laws.
-Was put in place by the ruling in Marbury v. Madison'

'Justices practicing judicial restraint believe they should use:
-Precedent (stare decisis)
-The Framers' original intentions
-Defer to elected bodies of government'
'Reviewing a case is possible with a writ of certiorari from the Supreme Court, which is possible when four justices vote in favor of doing so (rule of four).'

'-15 departments, all with secretaries except for the Department of Justice, which has the attorney general
-Members do not have strong loyalties to the president'

'-Cannot be dismissed by the president
--The Federal Reserve Board is an independent regulatory agency that sets monetary policy and is insulated from the public and politics.'

'Businesses owned by the government
-USPS is a good example'

'-Implementation of several agency's policies may overlap, causing waste
-Agencies have some discretionary authority but still have specific guidelines set in place'
'The Pendleton Act created the civil service, which hires employees base on merit.'

'Congress uses committees to:
-Investigate
-Allocate responsibilities
-Set up guidelines'

'-The president can control an agency's budget through the Office of Management and Budget.
-Congress appropriates an agency's funds.'

'-Elect candidates to office
-Determine public policy and agenda
-Connect citizens to government'
'Political parties exist at the national, state, and local levels, but the organizations at each level are independent of the those at different levels.'
'These feature a plurality (most votes win) and the winner-take-all system'

'It's hard for third parties to win elections because:
-Third party candidates must petition to have their names on the ballot
-Third party candidates aren't backed by name brand political parties
-Third party candidates aren't allowed to speak in presidential debates
-The winner-take-all system of the electoral college makes it difficult for third party candidates to acquire any electoral votes

Third parties can take away support from a major candidate.'

'-Ideological parties are based on extreme political viewpoints
-One-Issue parties are focused on a single controversial issue
-Factional parties split off from major partes'
'Their success in the 1800 election marked the first time power was peacefully given up following an election.'

'Advocated for:
-Universal male suffrage
-Spoils system
-No national bank'
'Because of Lincoln, the Republican Party became the first third party to win a presidential election.'

'-FDR's election was a critical election
-Blacks changed party loyalty from the Republican Party to the Democratic Party'

'-Nixon's 'Southern strategy' brought votes from the conservative South
-Divided government resulted in:
--The decline of trust in the government
--The increase in identification as independent
--The decline of power of political parties'

'Americans believe in the following:
-Liberty
-Equality of:
--Treatment under the law
--Opportunity
--NOT economic equality
-Democracy
-Individual responsibility'
'The decline of trust in government can partially be attributed to the decline of political efficacy, the belief that one has an effect on the government.'

'Conservatives support:
-Increased military funding
-Less government regulation on the economy
-Religion in schools

Conservatives are against:
-Abortions
-Social programs'

'Liberals support:
-Social programs
-Abortion rights
-Increased government regulation on the economy
-Gay rights

Liberals are against:
-Religion in schools
-Increased military funding'

'Political socialization is the process by which children and adolescents acquire political attitude and opinions.
Methods of political socialization include:
-School
-Social media
Family at home (most important by far)'

'-People with higher incomes are more likely to vote
-People with higher incomes are more likely to vote Republican'

'-People with more education are more likely to vote
-People with more education are more likely to vote Republican'

'-Whites have higher turnout rates than do minorities
-However, blacks of the same education and income levels as whites are more likely to vote
-Blacks tend to vote Democrat'

'-Women are more likely to vote than men
-Women are more likely to vote Democrat
-Men are more likely to vote Republican'

'-Old people are more likely to vote than younger people
-Old people are more likely to vote Republican
-Young people are more likely to vote Republican'
'Protestants are more likely to vote Republican'

'-Most people only vote in the presidential elections
-Because of America's federal system, it has many more elections than other democracies
-Many people do not bother to vote in these elections, lowering America's voter turnout'
'Many citizens do not feel that they impact the government, so they do not vote.'

'-America's registration process is lengthy in order to reduce voter fraud
-As a result, many people do not want the hassle of registering, making them unable to vote in elections
-The Motor Voter Act makes registration easier by allowing people to register when they renew their licenses
--This increases the registered voters by a disproportionate amount because many impoverished people do not drive cars (and therefore don't have licenses) '
'Many people feel inconvenienced by having to vote in the presidential elections on a Tuesday, and they decide not to cast their vote.'
'People who belong to conflicting groups that determine their voting behavior are less likely to vote.'
'The sale of these as tools to deliver the news has fallen, and the Internet, radio, and television have become replacements.'

'-The media lets government officials inform the public of their policies
-The president has quick access to the media'

'-The media give the public news coverage, but they are mostly concerned with the candidates more than their platforms.
-The media focus on:
--Day-to-day activities
--Horse-race journalism (poll numbers)
--Sound bites of debates and discussions'

'Structuralism: mind operates by using emotions and sensations
Wilhelm Wundt: first psychological lab in introspection
G. Stanley Hall: founded and first president of American Psychological Association
Edward Titchener: investigated how small elements of introspection are related
Margaret Floy Washburn: first woman to get Ph. D in psychology'

'Functionalism: applying finding to situations and understanding how they adapt to the enviornment
William James: published The Principles of Pyschology and created functionalism pyschology
James Cattell: mental tests
John Dewey: child development and education
Mary Whiton Calkins: first woman president of American Psychological Association'

'Behavioraism: behvior is a result of learning and can be a response from a stimuli
Ivan Pavlov: salivating dogs
John B. Watson: create psychology a sciene
B.F. Skinner: positive and negative reinforcement'

'Based on the needs of people
Abraham Maslow and Carl Rogers: free will'
'Sigmund Freud: used the unconscious mind and the idea of repression to help patients'
'This is based on the idea that the biological makeup of a person affects their behavior and thoughts'

'Traits that are sustainable will be passed down from generation to generation
Charles Darwin: natural selection
'

'This approach has to do with how people perceive situations will create how they act
Jean Piaget: children'
'The different cultures will affect how people think and act'

'-Limits individual contributions to presidential elections
--In Buckley v. Valeo, the Supreme Court ruled that self contribution is a form of protected free speech and therefore cannot have a limit
-Offers public funding for the primaries and the general elections'

'-Tax-exempt organizations
-Engage in activities such as:
--Mobilizing citizens to vote
--Running advertisements'

'-Hard money is limited and must be fully disclosed
-Soft money is unlimited and undisclosed
--The Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act banned soft money'

'Most states hold primaries, but some hold caucuses, which are gatherings of party members.

Types of primaries:
-Open primaries let anyone vote
-Closed primaries only let registered party members vote

Ways to get electors:
-Winner-take-all - The candidate with the most votes in a state gets all that state's electoral votes
-Proportional - Candidates receive a state's electoral votes based on the proportion of popular votes they acquire'

'-The first primary and caucus are held in New Hampshire and Iowa, respectively
-They're criticized for getting too much attention, causing other states to move up their primary dates as well (front-loading)
-Mostly dedicated party members vote in primaries and caucuses, so people feel that they're unrepresentative'

'Incumbency is the most important factor for reelection. Incumbents enjoy the following perks:
-Reputation - more people know who they are
-Privelages:
--Franking - incumbents can send mail to constituents for free
--Pork-Barrel - incumbents bring home projects that give money to their constituents
--Casework - incumbents often help solve individual constituents' problems, which gives them a good public image
-Campaign Financing - incumbents receive much more contributions (especially from interest groups) to their campaigns than do their challengers.'

'-Civil liberties protect all citizens as individuals from the government
-Civil rights protect groups - such as gays and blacks - from discrimination'
'The Bill of Rights protects people from the federal government but not from state governments'

'-The process by which civil liberties from the Bill of Rights were gradually applied the states - one by one
-The 14th Amendment was used by the Supreme Court for selective incorporation. It contains two components:
--The Equal Protection Clause
--The Due Process Clause'

'-The first of several selective incorporations
-Ruled that freedom of speech and the press are protected from the states by the 14th Amendment '

'-Some forms of nonviolent protest are protected as symbolic speech:
--Burning flags (Texas v. Johnson)
--Wearing Armbands [for Vietnam War] (Tinker v. Des Moines)
-Some protests are not protected as symbolic speech:
--Burning draft cards (United States v. O'Brien)'
'Ruled that speech isn't protected if it creates a 'clear and present danger''

'-Speech is only libel or slander (written or spoken forms of false defamation) if they can be proven to be made with 'actual malice.'
-Communities are in charge of implementing governmental guidelines against obscenity'
'In New York Times Co. v. United States, it was ruled that prior restraint, preventing material from being printed before it is released, is unconstitutional.'

'-Government cannot prevent someone from practicing his faith unless he is breaking laws by doing so.
--Reynolds v. United States - Mormons may not practice polygamy, even if it is a part of their faith
--Oregon v. Smith - Ingesting illegal drugs is not allowed, even if it is a part of a religious ceremony'

'-Government cannot establish a national, state, or local religion ('separation of Church and State'):
--Engel v. Vitale - prayer in public schools is unlawful
---However, student clubs hold prayers before or after school
--Lemon v. Kurtzman - government can provide some aid to parochial schools.
---In order to not violate the Establishment Clause, government uses the Lemon Test:
----The activity must be for a secular (nonreligious) purpose
----The activity can neither advance nor inhibit religion
----The activity cannot involve 'excessive entanglement' between the government and religion'

'-The 4th Amendment protects from unlawful searches and seizures
-Weeks v. United States - the Supreme Court ruled that evidence obtained from illegal searches and seizures is inadmissible in court. This is the exclusionary rule.
-Mapp v. Ohio - the Supreme Court applied the exclusionary rule to the states (selective incorporation)'

'-The 6th Amendment gives the accused the right to counsel (lawyer) in court
-Betts v. Brady - ruled that state governments did not have to provide defendants counsel
-Gideon v. Wainwright - the Supreme Court overruled the decision in Betts v. Brady, deciding that state governments must provide counsel to those that cannot afford it'
'In Miranda v. Arizona, the Supreme Court ruled the evidence revealed during interrogation of criminal suspects who are not informed of their 'Miranda rights' will be inadmissible in court.'
'In Griswold v. Connecticut, the Supreme Court abolished a state law that banned abortions by ruling that the Constitution implied the right to privacy.'

'-Roe v. Wade - the Supreme Court used the right to privacy to legalize abortion in the states
-Planned Parenthood v. Casey - the Supreme Court ruled that states can only regulate abortions if doing so does not impose an 'undue burdon' on the patients.'
'Abolished Slavery'
'Repealed the Dred Scott decision that said blacks were not American citizens'
'Gave blacks the right to vote'

'Ice is less dense than water, thus when bodies of water freeze, only the surface does. This allows the bottom of the bodies to remain habitable.'

'By nature of its bonds, water can dissociate ionic, polar covalent, and some nonpolar molecules. This is done by water molecules interacting and attracting other molecules through dipole attractive forces. This versatility makes water an important solvent.'

'A buffer has the ability to prevent drastic changes in pH of a system. This is important in biological processes that depend on a stable/specific pH to function properly. A buffer increases hydroxide ion concentrations when a solution becomes more acidic, and increases hydrogen ion concentrations when a solution becomes more basic. '

'The Articles of Confederation formed a weak national government that had no powers to levy taxes, regulate interstate commerce, or defend itself.'
'A rebellion of farmers that proved to the Framers that a stronger central government was needed.'

'Created a bicameral legislature that provided a Senate with equal representation and a House of Representatives with representative proportional to population. This essentially solved the issue of representation during the Constitutional Convention.'
'A slave counted as three-fifths of a free person towards a state's population (used to determine representation in Congress).'
'The Constitution granted Congress the power to levy revenue taxes and regulate interstate commerce.'
'Understand the powers of the presidential veto, judicial review, and Senatorial confirmation of presidential appointments.'

'The Constitution has prohibited:
-Ex post facto laws
-Bills of attainder
-Religious qualifications to hold office
Additionally, it guarantees a writ of habeas corpus. '

'In order to protect the national government from a possibly fickle majority, the Constitution safeguarded the country with the following:

-Federal judges are appointed by the president and serve life terms.
-The president was not originally elected directly by the people.
-Senators were not originally elected by the people.
-Senators have staggered terms.'
'Papers written in support of the Constitution. James Madison wrote that political factions were inevitable.'

'An amendment of the Constitution can be proposed by two methods:
-A two-thirds vote in both the Senate and the House of Representatives
-A national convention assembled at the request of two-thirds of the state legislatures

An amendment of the Constitution can be ratified by two methods:
-Ratifying conventions in three-fourths of the states
-Three-fourths of the state legislatures'

'Quantity that has magnitude, but not direction'

  • A * k = kA which has the same direction as A, but different magnitude

'

  • The tail of -B goes on the tip of A

'A system of government in which both the national and state levels have political authority.'

'Powers granted to the national government by the Constitution
eg:
-Levy taxes
-Regulate interstate commerce'
'Powers given to the national government by the elastic clause'
'Powers given to the states by the Tenth Amendment'
'Powers held by both the federal and state governments'

'-Increases political participation
-Prevents one body of government from getting too big
-Allows 'experimentation''

'National and state levels of government work together
-eg. interstate highway program'
'National and state levels of government have their own 'spheres of influence.''
'A system of federalism that favors devolution'

fields.title: 'Types of Grants from the National to the State Level'

fields.content:
'-Block grants have little restrictions, which supports devolution
-Categorical grants are for specific programs, which supports national supremacy
-Mandates are conditional requirements that the states must adhere to, which supports national supremacy '
'The Chief Justice ruled that the states cannot tax the national government because the national government is supreme to them.'
'The Supreme Court ruled that the federal government has the sole right to regulate interstate commerce.'
'The Supreme Court upheld this act because places of public accommodation inherently partake in interstate commerce, which is exclusively regulated by Congress.'

'-30+ years old
-Resident of state he represents
-American citizen for 9+ years'

'-Try impeachments
-Confirm presidential appointments
--Senators will follow the custom of senatorial courtesy, which means they won't confirm an appointment if any majority party senator from the state the appointee is to serve is opposed to the action.
-Ratify Treaties'

'-25+ years old
-Resident of state he represents
-American citizen for 7+ years'

'-Impeach U.S. officers
-Generate tax revenue bills
-Choose the president if no one receives a majority of electoral college votes'
'State legislatures use gerrymandering when redrawing congressional district lines in order to benefit the party in control.'

fields.title: 'Benefits of the Majority Party in both Houses'

fields.content:
'-Holds the chair and majority in each committee
-Assigns bills to committees
-Sets the agenda'

'Congress can:
-Amend the Constitution to make a law supreme over the land
-Override a veto
-War Powers Resolution Act forced the president to notify Congress within 2 days of deployment of troops
-Congressional oversight over executive agencies'

'-Select committees are temporary and created for a particular reason
-Standing committees are permanent
-Conference committees resolve differences between the houses about a bill
-Joint committees have members from both houses of Congress'
'Has the ability to generate tax revenue bills'
'Sets the rules for floor debate. The House floor is much stricter than the Senate floor.'
'Tool used in the Senate to stop the passage of a bill with an 'endless' speech. Requires 60 votes to be ended.'

'The president can veto by:
-Straight up vetoing a bill
-Not signing a bill for 10 days, and if Congress is adjourned by then, it's a pocket veto
Remember, line-item vetos for presidents are unconstitutional.'

'The president can appoint:
-Federal judges
-Cabinet members & heads of independent agencies
-Diplomats
He may remove all but federal judges and heads of independent agencies.'
'The president can deploy troops without approval of Congress.'
'The president can negotiate treaties, but often he just makes executive agreements.'
'The president may withhold information from Congress and the public.'
'The president may grant pardons to citizens.'

'-The most loyal members to the president
-Mainly manage the Oval Office'
'Overlooks the federal budget'

'-15 executive departments
-Members are often more loyal to their department than to the president.'

'Established the three level federal court system:
-District Courts
-Circuit Courts of Appeals
-The Supreme Court'

'-The Supreme Court can determine the constitutionality of federal laws.
-Was put in place by the ruling in Marbury v. Madison'

'Justices practicing judicial restraint believe they should use:
-Precedent (stare decisis)
-The Framers' original intentions
-Defer to elected bodies of government'
'Reviewing a case is possible with a writ of certiorari from the Supreme Court, which is possible when four justices vote in favor of doing so (rule of four).'

'-15 departments, all with secretaries except for the Department of Justice, which has the attorney general
-Members do not have strong loyalties to the president'

'-Cannot be dismissed by the president
--The Federal Reserve Board is an independent regulatory agency that sets monetary policy and is insulated from the public and politics.'

'Businesses owned by the government
-USPS is a good example'

'-Implementation of several agency's policies may overlap, causing waste
-Agencies have some discretionary authority but still have specific guidelines set in place'
'The Pendleton Act created the civil service, which hires employees base on merit.'

'Congress uses committees to:
-Investigate
-Allocate responsibilities
-Set up guidelines'

'-The president can control an agency's budget through the Office of Management and Budget.
-Congress appropriates an agency's funds.'

'-Elect candidates to office
-Determine public policy and agenda
-Connect citizens to government'
'Political parties exist at the national, state, and local levels, but the organizations at each level are independent of the those at different levels.'
'These feature a plurality (most votes win) and the winner-take-all system'

'It's hard for third parties to win elections because:
-Third party candidates must petition to have their names on the ballot
-Third party candidates aren't backed by name brand political parties
-Third party candidates aren't allowed to speak in presidential debates
-The winner-take-all system of the electoral college makes it difficult for third party candidates to acquire any electoral votes

Third parties can take away support from a major candidate.'

'-Ideological parties are based on extreme political viewpoints
-One-Issue parties are focused on a single controversial issue
-Factional parties split off from major partes'
'Their success in the 1800 election marked the first time power was peacefully given up following an election.'

'Advocated for:
-Universal male suffrage
-Spoils system
-No national bank'
'Because of Lincoln, the Republican Party became the first third party to win a presidential election.'

'-FDR's election was a critical election
-Blacks changed party loyalty from the Republican Party to the Democratic Party'

'-Nixon's 'Southern strategy' brought votes from the conservative South
-Divided government resulted in:
--The decline of trust in the government
--The increase in identification as independent
--The decline of power of political parties'

'Americans believe in the following:
-Liberty
-Equality of:
--Treatment under the law
--Opportunity
--NOT economic equality
-Democracy
-Individual responsibility'
'The decline of trust in government can partially be attributed to the decline of political efficacy, the belief that one has an effect on the government.'

'Conservatives support:
-Increased military funding
-Less government regulation on the economy
-Religion in schools

Conservatives are against:
-Abortions
-Social programs'

'Liberals support:
-Social programs
-Abortion rights
-Increased government regulation on the economy
-Gay rights

Liberals are against:
-Religion in schools
-Increased military funding'

'Political socialization is the process by which children and adolescents acquire political attitude and opinions.
Methods of political socialization include:
-School
-Social media
Family at home (most important by far)'

'-People with higher incomes are more likely to vote
-People with higher incomes are more likely to vote Republican'

'-People with more education are more likely to vote
-People with more education are more likely to vote Republican'

'-Whites have higher turnout rates than do minorities
-However, blacks of the same education and income levels as whites are more likely to vote
-Blacks tend to vote Democrat'

'-Women are more likely to vote than men
-Women are more likely to vote Democrat
-Men are more likely to vote Republican'

'-Old people are more likely to vote than younger people
-Old people are more likely to vote Republican
-Young people are more likely to vote Republican'
'Protestants are more likely to vote Republican'

'-Most people only vote in the presidential elections
-Because of America's federal system, it has many more elections than other democracies
-Many people do not bother to vote in these elections, lowering America's voter turnout'
'Many citizens do not feel that they impact the government, so they do not vote.'

'-America's registration process is lengthy in order to reduce voter fraud
-As a result, many people do not want the hassle of registering, making them unable to vote in elections
-The Motor Voter Act makes registration easier by allowing people to register when they renew their licenses
--This increases the registered voters by a disproportionate amount because many impoverished people do not drive cars (and therefore don't have licenses) '
'Many people feel inconvenienced by having to vote in the presidential elections on a Tuesday, and they decide not to cast their vote.'
'People who belong to conflicting groups that determine their voting behavior are less likely to vote.'
'The sale of these as tools to deliver the news has fallen, and the Internet, radio, and television have become replacements.'

'-The media lets government officials inform the public of their policies
-The president has quick access to the media'

'-The media give the public news coverage, but they are mostly concerned with the candidates more than their platforms.
-The media focus on:
--Day-to-day activities
--Horse-race journalism (poll numbers)
--Sound bites of debates and discussions'

'Structuralism: mind operates by using emotions and sensations
Wilhelm Wundt: first psychological lab in introspection
G. Stanley Hall: founded and first president of American Psychological Association
Edward Titchener: investigated how small elements of introspection are related
Margaret Floy Washburn: first woman to get Ph. D in psychology'

'Functionalism: applying finding to situations and understanding how they adapt to the enviornment
William James: published The Principles of Pyschology and created functionalism pyschology
James Cattell: mental tests
John Dewey: child development and education
Mary Whiton Calkins: first woman president of American Psychological Association'

'Behavioraism: behvior is a result of learning and can be a response from a stimuli
Ivan Pavlov: salivating dogs
John B. Watson: create psychology a sciene
B.F. Skinner: positive and negative reinforcement'

'Based on the needs of people
Abraham Maslow and Carl Rogers: free will'
'Sigmund Freud: used the unconscious mind and the idea of repression to help patients'
'This is based on the idea that the biological makeup of a person affects their behavior and thoughts'

'Traits that are sustainable will be passed down from generation to generation
Charles Darwin: natural selection
'

'This approach has to do with how people perceive situations will create how they act
Jean Piaget: children'
'The different cultures will affect how people think and act'

'-Limits individual contributions to presidential elections
--In Buckley v. Valeo, the Supreme Court ruled that self contribution is a form of protected free speech and therefore cannot have a limit
-Offers public funding for the primaries and the general elections'

'-Tax-exempt organizations
-Engage in activities such as:
--Mobilizing citizens to vote
--Running advertisements'

'-Hard money is limited and must be fully disclosed
-Soft money is unlimited and undisclosed
--The Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act banned soft money'

'Most states hold primaries, but some hold caucuses, which are gatherings of party members.

Types of primaries:
-Open primaries let anyone vote
-Closed primaries only let registered party members vote

Ways to get electors:
-Winner-take-all - The candidate with the most votes in a state gets all that state's electoral votes
-Proportional - Candidates receive a state's electoral votes based on the proportion of popular votes they acquire'

'-The first primary and caucus are held in New Hampshire and Iowa, respectively
-They're criticized for getting too much attention, causing other states to move up their primary dates as well (front-loading)
-Mostly dedicated party members vote in primaries and caucuses, so people feel that they're unrepresentative'

'Incumbency is the most important factor for reelection. Incumbents enjoy the following perks:
-Reputation - more people know who they are
-Privelages:
--Franking - incumbents can send mail to constituents for free
--Pork-Barrel - incumbents bring home projects that give money to their constituents
--Casework - incumbents often help solve individual constituents' problems, which gives them a good public image
-Campaign Financing - incumbents receive much more contributions (especially from interest groups) to their campaigns than do their challengers.'

'-Civil liberties protect all citizens as individuals from the government
-Civil rights protect groups - such as gays and blacks - from discrimination'
'The Bill of Rights protects people from the federal government but not from state governments'

'-The process by which civil liberties from the Bill of Rights were gradually applied the states - one by one
-The 14th Amendment was used by the Supreme Court for selective incorporation. It contains two components:
--The Equal Protection Clause
--The Due Process Clause'

'-The first of several selective incorporations
-Ruled that freedom of speech and the press are protected from the states by the 14th Amendment '

'-Some forms of nonviolent protest are protected as symbolic speech:
--Burning flags (Texas v. Johnson)
--Wearing Armbands [for Vietnam War] (Tinker v. Des Moines)
-Some protests are not protected as symbolic speech:
--Burning draft cards (United States v. O'Brien)'
'Ruled that speech isn't protected if it creates a 'clear and present danger''

'-Speech is only libel or slander (written or spoken forms of false defamation) if they can be proven to be made with 'actual malice.'
-Communities are in charge of implementing governmental guidelines against obscenity'
'In New York Times Co. v. United States, it was ruled that prior restraint, preventing material from being printed before it is released, is unconstitutional.'

'-Government cannot prevent someone from practicing his faith unless he is breaking laws by doing so.
--Reynolds v. United States - Mormons may not practice polygamy, even if it is a part of their faith
--Oregon v. Smith - Ingesting illegal drugs is not allowed, even if it is a part of a religious ceremony'

'-Government cannot establish a national, state, or local religion ('separation of Church and State'):
--Engel v. Vitale - prayer in public schools is unlawful
---However, student clubs hold prayers before or after school
--Lemon v. Kurtzman - government can provide some aid to parochial schools.
---In order to not violate the Establishment Clause, government uses the Lemon Test:
----The activity must be for a secular (nonreligious) purpose
----The activity can neither advance nor inhibit religion
----The activity cannot involve 'excessive entanglement' between the government and religion'

'-The 4th Amendment protects from unlawful searches and seizures
-Weeks v. United States - the Supreme Court ruled that evidence obtained from illegal searches and seizures is inadmissible in court. This is the exclusionary rule.
-Mapp v. Ohio - the Supreme Court applied the exclusionary rule to the states (selective incorporation)'

'-The 6th Amendment gives the accused the right to counsel (lawyer) in court
-Betts v. Brady - ruled that state governments did not have to provide defendants counsel
-Gideon v. Wainwright - the Supreme Court overruled the decision in Betts v. Brady, deciding that state governments must provide counsel to those that cannot afford it'
'In Miranda v. Arizona, the Supreme Court ruled the evidence revealed during interrogation of criminal suspects who are not informed of their 'Miranda rights' will be inadmissible in court.'
'In Griswold v. Connecticut, the Supreme Court abolished a state law that banned abortions by ruling that the Constitution implied the right to privacy.'

'-Roe v. Wade - the Supreme Court used the right to privacy to legalize abortion in the states
-Planned Parenthood v. Casey - the Supreme Court ruled that states can only regulate abortions if doing so does not impose an 'undue burdon' on the patients.'

fields.content: 'The Chief Justice ruled that the states cannot tax the national government because the national government is supreme to them.'

fields.content:

He may remove all but federal judges and heads of independent agencies.'

fields.content:
'It's hard for third parties to win elections because:
-Third party candidates must petition to have their names on the ballot
-Third party candidates aren't backed by name brand political parties
-Third party candidates aren't allowed to speak in presidential debates
-The winner-take-all system of the electoral college makes it difficult for third party candidates to acquire any electoral votes

Third parties can take away support from a major candidate.'

fields.content:
'-Ideological parties are based on extreme political viewpoints
-One-Issue parties are focused on a single controversial issue

fields.content: 'Their success in the 1800 election marked the first time power was peacefully given up following an election.'

'Advocated for:
-Universal male suffrage

fields.content: 'Because of Lincoln, the Republican Party became the first third party to win a presidential election.'

-Blacks changed party loyalty from the Republican Party to the Democratic Party'

fields.content:
'-Nixon's 'Southern strategy' brought votes from the conservative South
-Divided government resulted in:
--The decline of trust in the government
--The increase in identification as independent
--The decline of power of political parties'
fields.title: 'Fall of Political Parties'

fields.content:

-Liberty
-Equality of:

--Opportunity
--NOT economic equality
-Democracy
-Individual responsibility'

Conservatives are against:

Family at home (most important by far)'

--This increases the registered voters by a disproportionate amount because many impoverished people do not drive cars (and therefore don't have licenses) '

'-Limits individual contributions to presidential elections

fields.content:
'Most states hold primaries, but some hold caucuses, which are gatherings of party members.

Types of primaries:
-Open primaries let anyone vote
-Closed primaries only let registered party members vote

Ways to get electors:
-Winner-take-all - The candidate with the most votes in a state gets all that state's electoral votes
-Proportional - Candidates receive a state's electoral votes based on the proportion of popular votes they acquire'
fields.title: 'Primaries and Caucuses'

fields.content:
'-The first primary and caucus are held in New Hampshire and Iowa, respectively
-They're criticized for getting too much attention, causing other states to move up their primary dates as well (front-loading)
-Mostly dedicated party members vote in primaries and caucuses, so people feel that they're unrepresentative'
fields.title: 'Primaries and Caucuses (more)'

fields.content:
'Incumbency is the most important factor for reelection. Incumbents enjoy the following perks:
-Reputation - more people know who they are
-Privelages:
--Franking - incumbents can send mail to constituents for free
--Pork-Barrel - incumbents bring home projects that give money to their constituents
--Casework - incumbents often help solve individual constituents' problems, which gives them a good public image
-Campaign Financing - incumbents receive much more contributions (especially from interest groups) to their campaigns than do their challengers.'
fields.title: 'Congressional Elections'

fields.content:
'-Civil liberties protect all citizens as individuals from the government
-Civil rights protect groups - such as gays and blacks - from discrimination'
fields.title: 'Civil Liberties vs. Civil Rights'

fields.content: 'The Bill of Rights protects people from the federal government but not from state governments'
fields.title: 'The Constitution'

fields.content:
'-The process by which civil liberties from the Bill of Rights were gradually applied the states - one by one
-The 14th Amendment was used by the Supreme Court for selective incorporation. It contains two components:
--The Equal Protection Clause
--The Due Process Clause'
fields.title: 'Selective Incorporation'

fields.content:
'-The first of several selective incorporations
-Ruled that freedom of speech and the press are protected from the states by the 14th Amendment '
fields.title: 'Gitlow v. New York'

fields.content:
'-Some forms of nonviolent protest are protected as symbolic speech:
--Burning flags (Texas v. Johnson)
--Wearing Armbands [for Vietnam War] (Tinker v. Des Moines)
-Some protests are not protected as symbolic speech:
--Burning draft cards (United States v. O'Brien)'
fields.title: 'Symbolic Speech'

fields.content: 'Ruled that speech isn't protected if it creates a 'clear and present danger''
fields.title: 'Schneck v. United States'

fields.content:
'-Speech is only libel or slander (written or spoken forms of false defamation) if they can be proven to be made with 'actual malice.'
-Communities are in charge of implementing governmental guidelines against obscenity'
fields.title: 'Other Speech Restrictions'

fields.content: 'In New York Times Co. v. United States, it was ruled that prior restraint, preventing material from being printed before it is released, is unconstitutional.'
fields.title: 'Freedom of the Press'

fields.content:
'-Government cannot prevent someone from practicing his faith unless he is breaking laws by doing so.
--Reynolds v. United States - Mormons may not practice polygamy, even if it is a part of their faith
--Oregon v. Smith - Ingesting illegal drugs is not allowed, even if it is a part of a religious ceremony'
fields.title: 'The Free Exercise Clause'

fields.content:
'-Government cannot establish a national, state, or local religion ('separation of Church and State'):
--Engel v. Vitale - prayer in public schools is unlawful
---However, student clubs hold prayers before or after school
--Lemon v. Kurtzman - government can provide some aid to parochial schools.
---In order to not violate the Establishment Clause, government uses the Lemon Test:
----The activity must be for a secular (nonreligious) purpose
----The activity can neither advance nor inhibit religion
----The activity cannot involve 'excessive entanglement' between the government and religion'
fields.title: 'The Establishment Clause'

fields.content:
'-The 4th Amendment protects from unlawful searches and seizures
-Weeks v. United States - the Supreme Court ruled that evidence obtained from illegal searches and seizures is inadmissible in court. This is the exclusionary rule.
-Mapp v. Ohio - the Supreme Court applied the exclusionary rule to the states (selective incorporation)'
fields.title: 'The 4th Amendment and the Exclusionary Rule'

fields.content:
'-The 6th Amendment gives the accused the right to counsel (lawyer) in court
-Betts v. Brady - ruled that state governments did not have to provide defendants counsel
-Gideon v. Wainwright - the Supreme Court overruled the decision in Betts v. Brady, deciding that state governments must provide counsel to those that cannot afford it'
fields.title: 'The 6th Amendment'

fields.content: 'In Miranda v. Arizona, the Supreme Court ruled the evidence revealed during interrogation of criminal suspects who are not informed of their 'Miranda rights' will be inadmissible in court.'
fields.title: 'Miranda Rights'

fields.content: 'In Griswold v. Connecticut, the Supreme Court abolished a state law that banned abortions by ruling that the Constitution implied the right to privacy.'
fields.title: 'Contraception'

fields.content:
'-Roe v. Wade - the Supreme Court used the right to privacy to legalize abortion in the states
-Planned Parenthood v. Casey - the Supreme Court ruled that states can only regulate abortions if doing so does not impose an 'undue burdon' on the patients.'

fields.content: 'The Articles of Confederation formed a weak national government that had no powers to levy taxes, regulate interstate commerce, or defend itself.'
fields.title: 'The Articles of Confederation'

fields.content: 'A rebellion of farmers that proved to the Framers that a stronger central government was needed.'
fields.title: 'Shays' Rebellion'

fields.content: 'Created a bicameral legislature that provided a Senate with equal representation and a House of Representatives with representative proportional to population. This essentially solved the issue of representation during the Constitutional Convention.'
fields.title: 'The Great Compromise'

fields.content: 'A slave counted as three-fifths of a free person towards a state's population (used to determine representation in Congress).'
fields.title: 'Three-Fifths Compromise'

fields.content: 'The Constitution granted Congress the power to levy revenue taxes and regulate interstate commerce.'
fields.title: 'Economic Powers Gained by Congress'

fields.content: 'Understand the powers of the presidential veto, judicial review, and Senatorial confirmation of presidential appointments.'
fields.title: 'Checks and Balances'

fields.content:
'The Constitution has prohibited:
-Ex post facto laws
-Bills of attainder
-Religious qualifications to hold office
Additionally, it guarantees a writ of habeas corpus. '
fields.title: 'Individual Freedoms'

fields.content:
'In order to protect the national government from a possibly fickle majority, the Constitution safeguarded the country with the following:

-Federal judges are appointed by the president and serve life terms.
-The president was not originally elected directly by the people.
-Senators were not originally elected by the people.
-Senators have staggered terms.'
fields.title: 'Insulation from Popular Passions'

fields.content: 'Papers written in support of the Constitution. James Madison wrote that political factions were inevitable.'

fields.content:
'An amendment of the Constitution can be proposed by two methods:
-A two-thirds vote in both the Senate and the House of Representatives
-A national convention assembled at the request of two-thirds of the state legislatures

An amendment of the Constitution can be ratified by two methods:
-Ratifying conventions in three-fourths of the states
-Three-fourths of the state legislatures'
fields.title: 'Amending the Constitution'

fields.content:
'With a vector, vector A and a constant k
  • A * k = kA which has the same direction as A, but different magnitude
With a vector, vector A and a negative constant -k
  • A * k = -kA which has the opposite direction as A and different magnitude
'
